This is an attempt to break through that filter.

Your self-image dictates your actions.

Everything you do,everything you think about, and everything you stress over, all point back to the person you believe you are when you look in the mirror.

I’ve noticed I’ve been second-guessing myself lately.

Living in Miami, there’s no getting away from the noise.

I have friends that are crushing it and mentors I can turn to.

My personal brand (although not huge) has given me this warped idea of the way people perceive me, so I’ve felt a need to stick within the lines of that perception.

But when I started my agency in 2021, I was a stupid little idiot – alone.

I didn’t have people in my ear telling me what to do.

And I wasn’t competing with friends or others on social media.

It was just me, my pea-sized brain, and an urge to build a better life.

Objectively, I’m way smarter, more experienced, and have more leverage than the 20-year-old beginner version of myself.

But that kid had something I’ve lost to an extent – he was dumb enough to trust himself.

This leads me to the question,

Where does certainty come from?

There are two types of certainty.

Type 1 is evidence-based.

When you’ve done something a million times, previous data leads you to a conclusion.

Simple right?

But the second type of certainty is the one that’s needed to maintain a healthy balance.

Type 2 is delusional confidence.

It’s guided by intuition.

And it knows it could very well be making a poor decision, but it’s okay with any outcome that comes its way.

The thing about this type of certainty is if you don’t use it, you start to lose it.

The ideas you used to have and your naive intuition start to get quieter.

You become a robot confiding within the lines of whoever you believe yourself to be.

And if that identity isn’t malleable, you find yourself in a box.

Within that box, you create your own limitations, and you lose the confidence in yourself to trust outside of them…

Maybe?

Idk. I’ve been blindly typing away on my computer for the last few minutes, so I’m gonna reread this email to see if it makes any sense.

Ok, I’m back.

My intuition told me to stop being a bitch and send this email, so I’m just gonna click the button and go watch a movie.

Gn (or gm if you’re reading this in the morning, which is honestly kind of offensive because I expect you to drop everything you’re doing and read my email no matter where you are at any time of day).

Efkbnehjwkfbnjlknfi,

Ben

subject: i drove a car through the white picket fence
content:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

It’s been about a week since we chatted, and I’m starting to miss you.

I wrote half of an email the other day and didn’t send it.

It was about “striking while the iron is hot.”

In short, the initial excitement you get about a new project will carry you through the grunt work.

But if you wait to take action for too long - that excitement fades, and you usually never start.

About halfway through, I got distracted and stopped writing.

Ironic right?

Anyway, I would've graduated this past week if I didn’t drop out of college to scam boomers and little kids on the internet.

It’s interesting seeing people I went to school with “fall in love” and get married.

Are they really in love?

Or are they just settling because they think they won’t be able to do any better?

I don’t know.

It just seems so early.

What I can tell you is that if they are settling, it won’t last.

Over the next few years, the white picket fence will begin to decay.

Those little cracks will get bigger.

And eventually, someone will probably cheat with the maid or pool boy.

I don’t mean to be so doom and gloom.

But life gets dull when you’re not working on something new.

You start to wonder what else is out there.

Most cope with this by obsessing over things that don’t matter, starting drama, and worshiping celebrities.

It’s an attempt to make their lives feel like they aren’t pointless.

But what makes life worth living?

Am I doing it the right way?

I’m building businesses, cultivating lasting relationships with amazing people, and working towards going through a pack of zyns daily.

I’ve found a different outlet to occupy my time on this spinning rock.

It feels right, but what’s the end game?

It’s only when I’m able to take a step back and zoom out that I feel like I truly appreciate it.

18-year-old me would’ve given away his last pack of mango Juul pods to be where I am now.

Still, most days still feel relatively monotonous.

That feeling is what I wanted to escape by taking this route.

Sure, it’s better than sitting in a cubicle with a bunch of they/thems, taking orders from some schmuck who thinks they’re the shit because they make $186,000 per year.

My average client will make more than your annual salary this month, jackass.

But I don’t know if the feeling of monotony ever goes away.

Not matter how exciting things are,

No matter who you know,

No matter who you are,

You still have to get up every day, put your pants on the same way you’ve done since you were 4, and get shit done.

Great things take time, and the work isn’t always fun…

But when you learn to enjoy the work, that’s when life begins to matter.

Take the Lakers - 3.5 tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. In order to reach my peak schizophrenic state that I love so much, I'm fasting until 7pm tomorrow. You should join. Reply if you're in <3

subject: your $902923834 payout is on the way!
content:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}, how was your day?

Mine was good.

The Jews that are controlling the weather must be happy because it was a beautiful day in Miami.

Ok, I have a confession.

Yesterday I told you that I was gonna fast until 7 pm today.

I might've had a slice of banana bread at 4 pm.

Sorry.

A lot of you replied to yesterday's email, so it gave me enough of an ego boost to write again today.

But I don’t really know what to talk about.

Sometimes these emails come to me easily.

I start typing, my fingers seem to get taken over by my monkey brain, and a few minutes later, I have a semi-coherent email.

Other times, I’ll write a sentence, think about how it’ll make you perceive me, and talk myself out of it.

Am I oversharing?

Will this make me look weak?

Do I sound too homophobic or fatphobic? (I am genuinely scared of fats).

But then I remember that you, too, are just some grown little kid trying to figure things out.

Even if you’re making $300k a month.

It’s starting to become embarrassing that I’m not netting $100k a month yet.

I almost deleted that sentence.

Ok, I’m out of thoughts – let's try something new.

Reply to this email with a question, and I’ll base my next email around the best questions I get.

I don’t know why you would want any advice from some 22-year-old child, but hey, let’s see what happens.

Everyone tries so hard to appear authoritative online.

I’m guilty of it.

But at the end of the day, I’m just a retard that figured out how to make my clients millions by typing words on my laptop.

No one has it all figured out.

Ask me a question, and let’s figure it out together.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

subject: Re: answering your stupid questions
content:
Yo.

This newsletter is growing a little bit, and it’s starting to piss me off.

Is a day coming when I’m gonna have to filter my deranged thoughts in order to protect myself from getting canceled?

I hope not.

Don’t share my newsletter anymore because I like it better when it’s just me and you, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

I should really build some stupid coaching offer to sell you.

Anyway, the other day I sent an email asking you to reply with a question, and a bunch of you actually replied.

Now I feel obligated to answer them. Here we go:

(if you asked me something and I’m not answering it, it’s because it was a stupid question. You should scroll down to the bottom of this email and click ‘unsubscribe’)

1. What’s the Ben Bader story?

I figured I’d start here to help anyone that’s new get caught up.

Long story that I don’t have the mental capacity to recite. I’m 22 (and still waiting for my brain to fully develop). Here are some recent highlights:

- Dropped out of College of Charleston after 2 years.

- Made my first $100k with a marketing agency for basketball trainers.

- Transitioned to info-products, and now I help big personal brands and “influencers” make more money with their courses and coaching.

- Now living in Miami high rise with a bunch of other idiot monkeys that make a lot of money.

- I also am severely addicted to Zyns.

2. How do you find clients to work for?

I talk shit on Twitter and have built a bit of a brand there. I share results, and people come to me inbound.

I also get a lot of referrals and work with my close friends.

3. Since you can work from anywhere, why Miami? Long-term to stay there or move somewhere else, or even buy a second home/apartment somewhere?

All of my friends are here. Good weather. Parents have a condo an hour and a half north. Great place to meet other young entrepreneurs.

I'll likely be in South Florida for a while… not sure how long it’ll be Miami.

Don’t think I’d get a second place any time soon unless it were necessary for biz, or I fall in love with some random girl that lives in bumble fuck Idaho or something lol.

4. If you were 19 years old and trying to get to $10-15k a month as quickly as possible, what would you do?

If female: OnlyFans.

If male: Learn a high-value skill, pitch a fuck ton of people, get a client, repeat.

It’s really that simple.

Send enough cold messages, connect with enough people, and hack your way into different groups… you’ll find clients. You just gotta look hard enough.

5. When you think about yourself 10 years in the past or 50 years in the future, does that feel like “Ben at a different time” or “This is a totally different person”?

Ben at a different time.

I thought differently.

I operated differently.

I had a different self-identity.

But at the end of the day, the current me was in there all along.

Okay, enough writing.

There actually were a few other decent questions, but this email is already getting too long. So if I didn’t answer you, don’t take it to heart.

Blame your fellow subscribers, actually. They have the attention span of a gnat, so I know I’ll lose them if I keep rambling.

If you guys liked this lmk, I’ll make this Q&A a weekly thing.

Love you {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Ben

P.S. I wrote a somewhat legible Twitter thread today. Read it here.​

subject: i'm currently locked in a hotel room
content:
I’m sitting in a hotel room, leaning back in this dark leather chair.

The carpet and paintings in here are a bit outdated, but It’s a nice room with a spacious bathroom.

But I have a problem.

The balcony door won’t open.

I can’t decipher if I’m too dumb to figure out how to unlock it…

…Or if it’s truly broken.

So now I’m sitting here at the desk by the “sliding” glass door.

And I’m stuck, staring outside at the chairs on the balcony… awaiting me.

Is this what it feels like to get cucked?

I swear I tried everything.

I turned the lock all the way to the left, right, up, down, halfway… nothing.

I looking in all the cabinets and all the drawers, scouring the room for a key...

...but found nothing.

Now I’m inside, miserable, looking at how perfect my life could be outside.

I’m not appreciating the nice cool temperature in here.

Or the comfortable chair.

Or the fast wifi…

I’m ruining my time inside because I want to go outside.

But what I don’t know yet, is that the outside has its own list of problems.

Maybe the chairs are uncomfortable, or the wifi doesn’t reach that far.

Maybe a bird will poop on my computer and ruin this email.

Or maybe there will be a gust of wind, and I’ll get blown away like a plastic bag.

But for now, ignorance is bliss.

I’m gonna keep dreaming about getting outside in the sun where all my problems will go away.

And I’m gonna put myself in a perpetual state of misery until I get there.

Because where I am now is not enough.

I’m not gonna accept it.

I'll get so caught up in the pursuit of getting to a place that I'm not, that I'll forget to be present where I am.

So I'll fail to realize that the key to getting outside was on the counter to my right all along.

Maybe if I weren’t so busy staring out the window, I would’ve noticed that I already had what I needed.

I lean back in my brown leather chair, exhale, look at the key to my right and type… if not now, when?

Ben

P.S. I didn’t actually find the key, and it’s still pissing me off that I can’t go outside. Also, I wrote this with zero caffeine or nicotine in my system, so if you hated it that’s why. God Bless.

subject: Confidence
content:
One day during my sophomore year of high school, I was talking about confidence with a teammate on my basketball team.

His name is Colin, and he’s probably reading this email along with you.

In that conversation, he said something that stuck with me to this day - hence the email.

I’d asked him how he seemed so unbothered when he missed shots.

He replied, “My confidence isn’t a rollercoaster.”

Colin went on to become the all-time leading scorer at our school.

I was on a walk today thinking about this idea of unwavering confidence.

As I write this email, I’m wrestling with where it comes from.

We can all agree that a large part of confidence is derived from preparation – but it’s not that black and white.

I was obsessed with basketball throughout high school.

I put in as many hours as anyone.

But when I’d miss a few shots, I’d start to hesitate.

When I turned the ball over, I didn’t want it the next play.

My confidence didn’t run parallel to my preparation.

It fluctuated. And when I’d get into a rut, it’d be a downward spiral.

But Colin was almost always emotionless.

Good game, bad game, didn’t matter.

He could miss every shot and still want the ball in his hands with the game on the line.

Maybe the recipe for unwavering confidence goes as follows:

Preparation - emotion = confidence…

Eh. I still think there’s something missing.

There’s an element of confidence that doesn’t rely on preparation.

It’s built on trust.

Ok, wait, that makes sense.

You just watched me hash this out in real-time, so thanks for your patience.

People that have unwavering confidence aren’t prepared for every situation – but they have enough trust in themselves to figure it out.

I could go down the rabbit hole of where that trust comes from, but that would take a lot more critical thinking on my end, and you’re not really helping here.

This newsletter was never supposed to offer profound advice or life lessons anyway.

There’s enough advice out there. I’d rather offer you my perspective and let you agree or disagree.

Last thing I’ve internalized recently:

Your reality acts as a mirror of your self-beliefs.

It’s a common saying in sales that “whoever has the most certainty wins.”

This couldn’t be more true, and it doesn’t just apply to sales.

If your beliefs about yourself aren’t strong, other people's beliefs about you will start to manifest.

If you don’t feel respected by those around you, it's because you don’t respect yourself.

Choose who you are, or let others choose for you.

Sounds simple, but something to consider in your own life.

That’s all for today.

Talk next quarter,

Ben

subject: reply for a chance to win a bag of dorritos
content:
Ok.

I’ve been staring at this blank page for 3 minutes now, so I just put a zyn in my upper right lip in hopes that I’ll have a nicotine-induced burst of creativity.

Um.

Ummmm.

Still nothing.

Why do I even write these?

I have nothing to sell you, and I get no benefit from this other than a slight ego boost when someone replies, “Wow, this almost sounded like it wasn’t written by an autistic toddler. Keep it up, Ben!”

The liberal-wagie-cuck army on tik tok is starting to get to me.

I’ve had a couple of videos go semi *viral* recently, and half of my comments are people calling me a trust fund baby.

The other half are girls commenting on my eyelashes.

Fuck off woman, no I don’t have a “lash tech,” and if I did, I wouldn’t refer you to them.

And to be fair, I did grow up in a great neighborhood, but every dollar I’ve made has been on my own.

I actively tell my parents and grandparents that I don’t want their money.

Business is going swimmingly right now.

Clients are crushing, and I’m getting close to being out of poverty (I can taste $100k a month).

But in all honesty, it feels a bit dull.

An extra $20k per month or so wouldn’t change much about my life right now.

Recently I’ve realized that money loses its value if you don’t utilize it.

My life now looks cool, but I was going out more and having more “fun” when I was making around $10k per month, living like a rockstar in a college town.

My favorite thing I’ve been able to do recently is impact people around me.

Roughly 6 months ago, this 18-year-old kid found me on social media and asked me to mentor him by sending me a dollar on Venmo.

I had some money sitting in my Venmo account, and I sent him $1k back.

Phillip used that money to buy a course from a friend of mine and is now making $10k a month in sales.

He’s moving out of his parent's house next month.

Another dude who I call Scooby, has been replying to my emails updating me on his life.

He was in a tough situation, so my friend Mason and I bought him a laptop to help him start making money online (love you scooby).

One of my best friends from college, Stevie, was born to be in sales.

This guy could make a brick wall laugh.

I helped him get into a great opportunity, and he closed his first deal (and made $500 in commission) today.

These 3 situations are some of the highest ROI things I’ve been able to experience recently, and they have nothing to do with me personally making more money.

Funny how that works.

Being a catalyst to help other people grow is really fucking cool.

Sorry for the jumpiness in this email, I guess the zyn worked.

Love you {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Ben

subject: the SIMPLE 5 step system i used to build my business
content:
This email’s about business.

So if you’re only here for manic rants where I say things that would jeopardize my chances if I were to run for president, go away.

Let’s get into it.

A little under a year ago, I started working exclusively in the info-product & coaching space.

I had some experience, but pivoting from working with local basketball trainers to course sellers was a whole new game.

Since then, I’ve been able to put myself in a position where I’m the go-to guy for many of the bigger names in the industry.

I’m making way more money than I ever did working with bball trainers.

I’m working with guys I used to watch on social media.

And I’m building cool shit with cool people and making a lot of money doing it.

It’s made business fun.

People commonly ask me why I don’t offer any coaching right now.

In short, there’d be so much to teach.

The way that I work with clients is fluid and flexible.

Almost no 2 clients need the exact same prescription.

I’ve learned a multitude of skills and accumulated knowledge that would take months or years to pass along to others.

And I also don’t really have systems.

My onboarding process is a bit messy, and I talk to clients through facetime and iMessage.

Clients come to me through my Twitter (where I mostly talk shit) and referrals from a network that’s taking me years to build.

But most of this wasn’t necessarily intentional.

I started tweeting for fun. It helped me connect with people who became friends and eventually clients.

The skills I’ve picked up have been a byproduct of me telling people I knew how to do things that I didn’t actually know how to do until I figured it out on the fly.

I get to rely on warm inbound leads, my website sucks, I don’t use a CRM, and my offer isn’t easily replicable for each client.

I’m doing everything wrong, but business feels easy.

And I think it’s because I’ve done the hard things right.

It’s taken me multiple years to build my Twitter presence and become a marketing “expert.”

And now everything is coming to a perfect storm.

My network is bigger, and I have the skills/ experience to meet the opportunity.

If I tried to teach someone how to do it the exact way I’ve done it, it’d take a while.

If they wanted quick success, I’d tell them to do a bunch of things that I don’t currently have to do.

But if you want to eventually stumble into a high-leverage position the way I have, do the following:

  • Post more content & don’t be a dork about it
  • Connect with cool people and be genuine
  • Say yes to any project that comes your way & learn as much as you can
  • Do everything in your power to get amazing results for clients
  • Post more content about those results

There’s your simple 5-step system.

Reply if you have questions, and I’ll get back to you within 337 business days.

Sweet dreams,

Ben

P.S. I’m taking on 5 students for coachi– lmao imagine if I just plugged a coaching offer after basically telling you how you’re too retarded to do what I do like an absolute asshole.

subject: I hope this went to spam
content:
Do you ever consider the possibility that we’re already living in the metaverse?

I installed an app on my phone that makes me wait 5 seconds and click a few extra buttons every time I want to use social media.

But I look at my screen time and see a number so large that I’m ashamed to share it with you here publicly.

I guess I’m not perfect.

Every now and then, I’ll go to war in the sauna.

It’s the kind of war where if you were to spectate this situation, you’d think I’m schizophrenic and belong locked away in an asylum.

My inner dialogue becomes audible, and it turns into a screaming match between the person I am and the person I tell myself I want to be.

Right now, I’m battling comfort.

There are some things I want to change about my life – and myself.

I’m stuck in the middle between desire and acceptance.

The desire hasn't been strong enough to elicit action.

But it IS strong enough to deter acceptance.

Does that make sense?

In any situation, you decide if you want to accept it or change it.

If the cost of change outweighs the desire, you do nothing – but it’s easy to fall into a trap where the desire is everpresent.

I don’t think it has to be this way, though.

There’s got to be a way where you can accept your current circumstances and your current self while continuing to morph into a new and improved version.

It’s a code I haven’t cracked.

And it’s dangerous.

If you only take action when your back is against the wall, your life will become a seesaw.

You’ll only see progress after you reach a new low.

You go up and then right back down.

Or if you’re really unlucky, you’ll just stay floating in the middle for eternity.

I don’t like being this vulnerable with you.

But I know if it’s something I’m struggling with, some of you may be able to relate.

Acceptance.

I know the answer is acceptance.

But I’ve been operating on this seesaw for my entire life, and it’s gotten me here.

I guess I’m not perfect.

Ben

subject: haaaaaaaapppppppiiinnneeeeeesssssss
content:
I like being alone.

It’s a superpower and a downfall.

If I wanted to, I could go months without talking to anyone but myself and the 9 other personalities in my head.

Maybe some of you can relate to this -

If I spend a few days constantly surrounded by other people and I don’t take an opportunity to reset, I lose my mind.

I start to forget who I am, and I become an extension of the people I’m with.

So sometimes it’s nice just to turn the world off and be with me, myself, and I.

I can hear myself best in solitude.

But I do understand this is a dangerous game.

Some Harvard dorks did an 85-year study on happiness.

Basically, they took about 800 people from around the world and monitored their happiness levels every 2 years.

The strongest correlation to happiness wasn’t financial success.

Or career achievement…

Or even health.

The happiest people were those with the best relationships.

Looks like I’m doomed because I hate you fucks.

Hahahaha.

Maybe schizophrenic people are actually the happiest because they always have someone to talk to.

You can only grow so much in isolation.

The depth at which you know yourself is limited by your experience with the outside world.

Your relationships with others reveal your true relationship with yourself.

And to have a truly happy relationship with yourself, you need to have strong relationships with others.

I’m kinda figuring this out on the fly here, but I think that makes sense, right?

No matter how great of a human you are or how much you THINK you’ve grown – interacting with other real humans is the litmus test.

And if you really are a good person, you’d be doing a disservice to the universe by not sharing your gifts with the world.

So if you’re like me and you’re content being a hermit – be careful.

(I say that as I sit on my balcony in the middle of Brickell, where I am literally surrounded by people all the fucking time)

Gonna go get a Cuban coffee from the nice lady at the cafe.

Let’s talk more, I enjoyed this.

Ben

P.S. I plug each of these emails into chatgpt and ask it to analyze them. The response it generates actually blows my fucking mind - try it with some of your writing.

subject: a bunch of random thots
content:
Any time I open a blank doc like this, my brain starts to fire.

I’ll come up with an idea and map it out to see if I can turn a thought into a coherent email.

Usually, I’ll churn through a handful of these half-baked thoughts before I arrive at what I follow through with.

Here are some of the ideas I’ve had over the last 63 seconds:

1 - How you show up in one area of your life is reflected in other areas.

If you’re hiding parts of who you are in one relationship, it subconsciously manifests in other relationships.

It dictates your level of authenticity and the way that you interact with the world as a whole.

I’d keep going, but I don’t want to get too personal. You’re a stranger reading my inner dialogue, and I don’t know what you’re thinking on the other side of the screen.

Next.

2 - Everything is a mental game.

I cold-plunged yesterday for the first time ever.

The first 5 minutes were torture.

I kept telling myself to get out.

But eventually, that voice got quieter. My body went numb, and 15 minutes later, I felt like a new man.

This mental fortitude shined through for the rest of the day in my mental state and the way that I spoke to people.

I guess this relates to my first point.

3 - With enough input, your desired result will unfold.

Some of the pieces of content I’ve put out recently kinda flopped.

Each of which I posted thinking, “This is a banger.”

Apparently, they weren’t.

But that’s okay.

Some of my favorite artists put out hundreds of songs before they had one pop.

If your results dictate your consistency, you will fail before you give yourself the chance to succeed.

Hmm.

Maybe all of these half-baked thoughts are intertwined.

Maybe this email was somewhat coherent.

I think there’s a deeper lesson in there, but I’ll leave it up to you to connect the dots.

I’d continue on with this stream of consciousness, but it took me 3 tries to sound out the spelling of consciousness.

I think that means it’s time to turn off my brain.

Have a good week {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Ben

subject: my first scam at 14 yrs old (fun! easy! simple!)
content:
Ding ding ding

The bell rings.

I grab my backpack and hustle out of the classroom so I can be the first one out the door.

The teacher tells me to slow down on my way out.

I pretend not to hear her.

I get to bus #5 and walk down to row 16 on the left side by the window, per usual.

Then I pull out my light blue iPhone 5 and start reading.

This was my routine every day for the past few years.

I subscribed to a newsletter from a guy named Taylor Allan.

His emails were absolutely incredible.

The vivid imagery he used made me feel like I was participating in any situation he described.

He articulated my thoughts and my exact situation in a way that connected the dots in my head.

I no longer felt alone.

This random stranger that sent me emails every day somehow understood me and my problems better than my parents did

Maybe even better than I did.

He was selling an online basketball training product in the early 2010s.

I don’t remember how expensive it was, but one day I found a link to get it for free.

So I put in my contact info and immediately got access.

Then I felt guilty.

I told my Mom what I did, and said that she could see me selling an online basketball course one day.

She let me use her credit card to go back and pay for the course so I could alleviate my guilt.

And now, I spam your email inbox and help people sell courses.

Such beautiful foreshadowing.

Anyway,

I’ve been getting a lot of replies to my emails recently, and I just wanted to let you know I appreciate you <3

My goal is to write such bangers that you experience the same excitement that I used to when reading Taylor’s emails.

Reply and let me know what kind of content you’d like from me going forward.

Honestly, I’ll probably discard your suggestion – not because it’s a bad suggestion but because I like to pretend that I come up with all my ideas on my own.

You probably do that too.

Thanks for reading, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

-Ben

P.S. Copywriting is the one skill I’ve used in every business I’ve ever tried – it’s made me rich for a 22-year old

My friend Mason is one of the only people that I sometimes get jealous of when reading his writing.

He’s fucking good, and he made a killing as a freelance copywriter.

​If you’re interested in getting paid to click letters on your keyboard like a retarded monkey, check out this free class.​

​

​

subject: quick story
content:
I was heading to my usual lunch spot today when someone who looked familiar walked in ahead of me.

I stood behind him and 3 of his friends in line.

The person in front of him whipped out his phone and started taking a video.

After about 30 seconds, I realized that two of the people he was there with didn't speak English.

"He's buying lunch for random strangers he found on the street?" I thought to myself.

This person is known to be extremely generous and commonly does things like this.

Both registers were open, and I ended up next to him as I was ordering.

I said "hola" to my friend behind the register and asked for some tacos.

To my right, they rang up his order.

Before he could pull out his card, I put my Amex down on the chip reader.

Honestly, I don't know why.

I wasn't trying to get something out of this and didn't expect anything in return.

I figured he does a lot of nice things for people, and it's probably been a while since someone did something nice for him

He gave me a sincere thank you, and we chatted for a bit.

He said that he'd actually flown out the people he was with from Japan and that they were staying with him for a few days.

I sat down and enjoyed my meal.

That concludes my story on buying lunch for SteveWillDoit.

Sometimes you get random inclinations to do nice things for people.

If you follow them, they usually open doors for you or, at the very least, offer you some good karma.

Ben
​

​

subject: Kobe Bryant wasn't confident
content:
I planned this email out in my head earlier today.

But right now, I’m hesitating to write it.

I was gonna tell you about how the need for confidence becomes a crutch.

I had a story prepared that demonstrated this example perfectly.

I was gonna tell you how I was sitting at lunch today when I saw a pretty wooman walking by.

Instinctually I thought, “I should go up to her,” but I didn’t.

My brain came up with a thousand reasons as to why that’d be an outrageous thing for me to do, and I talked myself out of it.

I told myself I didn’t have the confidence to do that right now.

I wasn’t wearing a watch.

I was dressed like a toddler.

It was a bad hair day.

Maybe I’ll do it another day when I’ve done the inner work to build up my confidence, and I look a little more presentable.

So I let the opportunity pass me by, and now I’ll never be able to impregnate this pretty stranger. She could’ve been my wife.

The thing is, it wasn't confidence that I was lacking.

It was courage.

And having the courage to act in the face of uncertainty is how you build confidence.

It lets you use real-life examples to change the story you tell yourself about who you are.

You give your brain data that says, "{{ subscriber.first_name }} you are this type of person. Remember when you did XYZ even though you were nervous?”

When you stop relying on confidence, you’ll no longer need it.

Because no amount of inner work – no amount of money – no fancy watch will magically turn you into someone that you’re not right now.

Only actions can do that.

Last point to drive this home:

Every star basketball player has bad games.

There were times when Kobe would go 3/14 throughout a game.

He literally holds the NBA record for the worst single-game shooting percentage when taking 5+ shots.

Yet he still wants the ball in his hands with one minute to go… no matter how the previous 47 minutes have gone.

Not because he’s feeling extra confident to step up to the plate that day.

But because in his world, confidence doesn’t exist.

It doesn’t matter.

And he doesn’t need it because he replaced it with courage.

Rip Kobe. Makes me sad just thinking about it.

Anyway, I’m not gonna send this email.

Instead, I’ll write a less personal email that makes me look like a perfect, confident person.

If you received this, no, you didn’t.

Miss her man,

Ben

P.S. Good article that Kobe wrote about obsession​

P.S.S. Chat GPT graded my email a 7/10 because I spelled woman with two O’s, and “impregnate this pretty stranger” wasn’t professional. Fukk you, Chat GPT

​

subject: Why you should give up on your dreams
content:
You’re in a hallway.

It’s a narrow hallway with white walls and fluorescent lights.

There’s a row of wooden doors on both sides.

You’re looking for a golden key.

You try one of the doors on your left, but it’s locked.

In a moment of panic, you turn and start running down the hall, past the other doors.

Eventually, you see a door with golden light shining from under it at the end of the hallway.

You make your way down and open the door.

There’s an empty room with an arrow on the wall pointing toward a new door on the right.

You walk to the new door and open it.

Another arrow and another door.

In the next room, you see the same thing.

You continue to follow the according arrows and open new doors.

Finally, you reach a room with glowing walls.

And on the floor in the center of the room, you find the key you were searching for.

You grab the key and get out of the hallway.

On your way out, you look back at the hallway.

And you see all the locked doors that you’d run past on your way to the first door were now open.

What I’m describing isn’t a psych ward or a never-ending maze.

It’s the law of surrender.

Many of the paths you take in life will lead you to the next path – a better-suited path…

IF and when you’re ready.

But you can’t unlock the next path until you’re ready.

And if you spend too much time banging your head against the wall in one path, the next one will never illuminate.

Let’s bring this back to earth a bit.

When I was a junior in high school, I gave up my lifelong dream of playing college basketball.

I saw the signs that it wasn’t for me, and I listened.

I let that dream die.

A similar thing happened that led me to drop out of college and dissolve my first business.

The thing is, I never got a direct tap on the shoulder telling me it was time to move on.

The universe whispers, I had to be quiet enough to hear it and surrender my control to trust it.

Looking back, I can see that those decisions led me right to where I needed to be.

But this wasn’t evident until I got there.

I gave you this analogy to show you this:

There is power in knowing when to surrender your control and follow your intuition.

When things aren’t working, no matter how hard you try to force it, it could be a sign that you’re missing a key.

And to find that key, you’ll need to open a different door.

Allow life to surprise you. It always knows.

- Ben

P.S. If you’ve noticed I’ve been more consistent with these emails, you’re right. This is a bit Hubermanesque, but I’ve built a ritual for myself when I want to enter creative mode. Dim lights, music in the background, lit candle & a zyn.

Try building a ritual for yourself when building a new habit.

P.P.S. Check out this podcast episode - trust me.​

​

subject: life lesson from instagram models
content:
I recently made a video talking about how we all have seasons in our lives.

Sometimes we’re in grind mode.

Sometimes we’re more relaxed.

I’ve come to realize that it’s a bit more nuanced.

There are a multitude of seasons that you need to experience in order to keep things interesting.

For me, life has been very peaceful recently.

I’m working a lot, but mostly on things I enjoy doing.

For now, I like it this way.

But eventually, this stage will no longer serve me.

I’ll need more stress.

More chaos.

More unpredictability.

“Everything is temporary”

This is a quote that one in every five girls will put in their Instagram bio.

Scroll down, and you’ll see rows of bikinis pics.

That part's unrelated.

When we fight these seasons, things start to feel misaligned.

We start swimming upstream.

Our minds have an interesting way of telling us what we need.

When you’re anxious, maybe it’s because you’re stagnating.

You need to add more to your plate.

You need to move to a different city.

You need to make a change.

The key is to observe the way you’re feeling and accept whatever stage you’re in.

Maybe this is why women have menstrual cycles.

That was a joke - but actually, considering women seem to be more intuitive than men, maybe there’s some truth there.

Either way, listen to the way you feel.

When things just seem to be “off,” it’s time to make a change.

Or you’re pregnant.

Ok, that’s enough.

I ate an edible for the first time in a bit, and it’s starting to hit me.

Should I still be telling you this now that my email list has doubled in subscribers?

Maybe.

Everything is temporary, I guess.

(that makes no sense, but it just sounded right in my head).

Have a good night, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Ben

P.S. If you made it this far, reply and let me know if this email made any sense to you because I can no longer tell if my realizations are intelligent or if I'm just stoned.

​

subject: i'm in a rush
content:
I’m leaving to pick up my friend Mason at the airport in 6 minutes.

It’s highly unlikely that I’ll be able to give you anything worth of value in our short amount of time here.

But I can’t miss this email today.

It’d be the 2nd day in a row.

And that would start a negative streak - which would make it harder to write an email tomorrow.

So this email probably won’t change your life.

But if you learn anything, I guess it’s exactly that.

If you skip any habit you’re trying to build for 2 or more days, it’s harder to start again.

I sound like I read the book Atomic Habits and made it my entire personality.

But anyway I gotta go.

Jkwfnefljwbeidbewnjifdnw,

Ben

​

​

subject: Do you feel like you know yourself?
content:
I’ve been avoiding this all day.

I’m sitting here watching this cursor blink over and over.

It’s been 2 minutes now.

Why is my mind still blank?

Are my new subscribers gonna think I’m an idiot?

I just grabbed my mouse to click away to another tab.

But I stopped myself.

Not today, Satan.

I’m gonna sit here and write this fucking email no matter what.

Should I talk about the shitty coffee I had this morning? (I cheated on my main spot).

Or should I talk about how failures make us who we are because they–

Never mind, you’ve heard enough of that lately.

Ok.

The depth in which we know ourselves determines the depth in which we interact with the world.

Let me say that in English:

When you’re aware of your motives, why you want what you want, why you do what you do – you see with more clarity.

It lets you trust yourself more.

And that trust shines through in your relationships.

On a related note, my least favorite people are those who lack self-awareness.

You may be reading this right now and thinking it’s ironic that I’m saying that – but at least I’m aware enough to acknowledge that possibility.

Those who lack self-awareness view themselves as someone they’re not, and that creates misalignment in the way reality is viewed.

They’re the kind of people that you never see eye to eye with - no matter how well you explain your perspective on a situation.

And this is created by a lack of introspection.

So if there’s anything of value that you take away from this – find a way to “talk to yourself” more.

Could be journaling, walking, driving, or whatever else lets you feel like you’re spending quality time with yourself.

Alriiiighty...

For whatever reason, this one’s been a struggle for me to write, so if you’re still here, thanks for sticking with me.

Hopefully, my thoughts will be more coherent tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. Watch this video if you want to feel like a stupid, incompetent, pre-pubescent child​

P.P.S. Reply and let me know what you thought of this email if you made it down here.

subject: 398 words that will help you
content:
Writing is the best skill you can learn.

I know some great salespeople that suck at writing, but I don’t know any amazing copywriters that suck at sales.

Case closed.

Here are 3 somewhat unique ways I’ve improved my writing over the years:

(I’m always cautious when giving tips about writing because it creates added pressure to be perfect).

1 - Daily journaling

I don’t journal as much as I used to – though I should.

But when I was really honing my writing skills, this is how I did it.

I’d write to my future self, updating them on my life and sharing lessons I’ve learned – very similar to the flow of these emails.

Writing a sales email is really not that different from *some* of my rant emails/journals.

Because there’s one characteristic your writing needs to have, no matter the purpose of it…

It needs to be ENGAGING.

If it’s not engaging, no one will get through it. And if no one gets through it, no one will buy.

This leads me to my second point…

2 - Reading good copy

You’re already subscribed to the best newsletter in the world (mine).

Why not add a few more?

Seeing different writing styles and the way various arguments are made will help you be more creative in your own writing.

Any time you see a good ad, sales page, email, etc. – save it.

I have a folder with 200+ funnels on my bookmarks tab.

I suggest you start to build one of your own.

Last and final point…

3 - Thinking & doing other shit

Many of my best realizations and ideas have come while doing something that isn’t writing.

One time I basically wrote an entire sales page in my head while I was at the gym.

I got home, and I just transcribed my brain onto a doc.

You need to give your mind quiet time to think.

The more you understand yourself and the way you operate – the more you’ll understand the world.

And a vast array of experience will give you a wider perspective which translates to you being a better writer.

Alrighty, this was a lot easier today.

If you actually implement anything I told you to in this email - you’ll become a better writer.

Thanks for reading,

Ben

P.S. Here’s a 3-minute info-product marketing masterclass for you​

​

subject: never send an email at 12:50am
content:
Every Sunday, I go for a ~2-mile run around this riverwalk close to my apartment.

To be clear – I’m not an apple-watch-wearing cardio dork.

But I enjoy getting out in the sun, and running provides a great opportunity to fight the voice in my head that wants to be lazy.

So today, I threw on my running shoes and went over to the path.

It’s almost always crowded, so I’ve made it a competition in my head when I see other runners in front of me.

My pace fluctuates a bit when I’m more motivated or going downhill versus uphill.

But there are two scenarios where I drastically increase my speed.

When I see someone in front of me, I turn on the jets.

I try to run by them as fast as I can, so they feel bad about themselves they decide to stop running altogether (this is my attempt to make the riverwalk less crowded).

On my way home today, I was coming up on this big intersection.

Usually, it takes about 25 seconds to walk across.

By the time I got up there, the countdown signal to cross the street was down to 4 seconds.

I had two options…

One - Stop and wait 2 minutes for the lights to turn red again.

Or two - Hit the gas.

I put my head down and ran faster than I had all day.

If I didn’t, maybe I would've ended up on someone's windshield based on how aggressive drivers can be in Miami.

My point – I ran the fastest when I absolutely had to.

Faster than when I’m tracking down another runner.

And faster than when I feel more motivated.

Because nothing can induce speed the way necessity will.

If you emptied your bank account and had to make a certain amount of money, or you’d be homeless in 30 days – you’d figure out a way to get it done.

At that point, motivation doesn’t matter, it’s just a buzzword.

It’s easy to take action when you have no other option, but it gets harder once you’ve had some success.

Let’s say you’re making decent money with X business model.

You want to pursue Y business model, but right now, X is paying for your lifestyle.

What I’ve done, and perhaps the practically “sound” decision, is to start Y on the side while maintaining X.

Once you’re making good money with Y, you transition into doing it full-time.

Logically it makes sense – but here’s where it gets dangerous.

If there's an idea that’s been on your mind for a while and you haven’t acted on it yet, it could be because your current situation offers you too much comfort.

And if that idea lingers for long enough without the according action, it’ll drive you crazy.

Maybe that’s when you consider burning the boats.

​You’ll figure out how to swim when you’re in the water.​

Ben

P.S. I’ve made my clients millions of dollars online, and I don’t know the difference between a metaphor and an analogy. I thought this running story was an analogy, but Chat GPT told me it was a metaphor. Maybe AI will replace us.

P.P.S reply if you liked this email <3

​
​

subject: can you help me think of a subject line?
content:
Following your passion is bullshit.

Kinda.

There is a route where your passion intersects with your leverage and knowledge.

It’s your job to find that intersection.

To think you can make a lot of money “doing what you love” without complementary skills is a naive approach.

There are times when you won’t be passionate about the vehicle you’re in.

But those times give you an opportunity to find a key that you’ll need later on.

I’ve always enjoyed writing.

If I could make millions of dollars sitting at my desk writing these emails, I’d do it.

But I wouldn’t have anything worthwhile to write about if it’s all I did.

I need life experience as a reference point.

And progressing in business allows me to share insights and bring value.

If writing was my sole focus, maybe I’d use bigger words or know the difference between an analogy and a metaphor.

But it wouldn’t matter because no one would read it.

It’s like trying to build a puzzle by finding the last piece you’ll need.

No bueno.

Being passionate about what you get paid for is a privilege that must be earned.

And the way to earn it is through experience.

Which in my opinion is one of the most valuable things you can optimize your life for when you’re young.

You simply need to taste everything to know what you like.

Work in different industries.

Live in a big city then move somewhere quiet.

Be a degenerate and then go into monk mode.

The best reference points and learnings are found on various ends of the spectrum.

And with enough experience, the connection between your knowledge and your passion will be obvious.

But only when you have the necessary toolkit.

When your work starts to feel more like play, it means you’re on the right path.

At least I think so.

But as always, I could be way off about everything in this entire email.

May Chat GPT be the judge.

Goodnight,

Ben

P.S. About to watch this Tai Lopez rant if you wanna watch it with me (no homo)

P.P.S Banger analogy from Chat GPT:

It's like setting off on a cross-country road trip without a map or GPS. You have an idea of your destination – it's a city you've always dreamed of visiting. But without understanding the terrain, the distances, and the possible roadblocks, you'll likely end up lost or going in circles. Along the way, you need to gather information, learn how to navigate, and understand the characteristics of your vehicle. Similarly, following your passion without developing relevant skills and acquiring necessary knowledge can lead to frustration or even failure. Experience and understanding of the real-world terrain of your passion is crucial to reach your desired destination.

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }} i literally wrote this in my sleep
content:
I had a dream last night where I was playing basketball.

I can’t recall the exact situation or where I was, but I know this – my team was up 7 points with a few minutes left in the game.

We started playing keep-away.

Instead of trying to score, we passed the ball around the perimeter to keep it out of the other teams' hands.

Then I started dribbling around, weaving through the defenders.

Eventually, I lost the ball, and that’s when I woke up (I never lose the ball, so my brain was like yup, this is a stupid dream).

In my delirious half-awakened state, I had an idea.

Most people are playing keep-away with their lives, and it’s fucking everything up.

They just try to get to a baseline level of comfort so they have just enough breathing room to not blow the lead.

And then they stop trying to score.

They’re no longer playing to win, they’re playing not to lose.

If you know anything about sports, this is how big leads get blown.

In life, it’s no different.

Avoid this at all costs.

I literally woke up at 4:44 am and said, “Hey Siri, text Ben Bader “Run out the clock” so I’d remember this idea.

You need to constantly be on offense.

When you start to feel happy with what you got, and you go into “preserve mode,” that’s when you’re gonna find yourself in trouble.

This is especially true as you start to make more money.

It gets easy to think you have a big enough “lead” (safety net or nest egg) to where you can coast.

I don’t know about you, but I just can’t see that working out well.

Stay on offense.

Keep attacking.

And run up the scoreboard.

Happy 4th,

Ben

subject: Why you need to be a drug addict
content:
When you were young, you wanted to be extraordinary.

Maybe you wanted to be an athlete, singer, painter, gamer, astronaut, etc…

Maybe you became obsessed with this idea.

You convinced yourself it’s what you were born to do.

Most of your days were spent practicing, envisioning, and thinking about this one goal.

But after a while, that dream was beaten out of you.

Something you’d been obsessed with for so long was now gone.

And like energy -- obsession cannot be created or destroyed. Only converted from one form to another.

This is where it gets problematic.

We’re naturally hardwired to stalk our prey, attack, and kill.

But the sad truth for most people is that they become their own prey.

Instead of finding a new outlet for that obsession, they try to stuff it down.

The world tells them who they should be, obsession is bad, and that they need to find balance.

So they listen.

Next thing you know, these are the people that are addicted to drugs, alcohol, gambling, porn, etc.

And perhaps just as miserable are the ones who bury their obsession to the point where it doesn’t have one of the above outlets.

They are the ones who eat themselves from the inside out.

They become obsessed with attacking themselves, overthinking, and fantasizing about what life could be like if they were dealt a different hand.

Because no matter what, you can’t outrun obsession.

It’ll eat you alive.

In 1854, Henry David Thoreau wrote, “The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation and go to the grave with the song still in them.”

You can’t outrun obsession.

Find an outlet for it -- And do it every day.

Unless that outlet is black tar heroin.

Thx for reading -- Reply and LMK your thoughts on this topic,

Ben

P.S. Read Kobe Bryants' article on obsession if you haven’t already​

​

subject: Only open if you brush your teeth
content:
I haven’t been super consistent with these emails the past few days.

Once upon a time, not too long ago – I set out to write an email to my list for 100 days in a row.

I made it about 9 days before I disappeared for a few months, and my subscribers probably thought I died.

If you remember that, you’re an OG.

Consistency is something we all struggle with at times.

But why?

You brush your teeth every day (hopefully) without any issues.

You scroll through social media every day.

You text your ex every day.

But sometimes, when you try to build a new habit, or you sit down at your desk to work, or you’re trying to make progress in the gym…

It just doesn’t happen.

And it’s because you’re trying too hard to be perfect.

When you brush your teeth, you don’t think about the “perfect” stroke. *pause*

You’re a robot.

You probably have the same brushing pattern every time, whether you’re conscious of it or not.

Sometimes you’re still drunk from the night before, and you’re a bit less thorough.

Other times your breath smells, so you’re more intentional.

But it happens no matter what (with some exceptions, of course).

As I felt the looming pressure of going another day without writing an email, I started racking my brain to get an idea.

I came up with a few things, but they all felt forced and repetitive – and now generating an idea for something that I usually enjoy doing started to feel like work.

Then I stopped and said to myself:

“Just do something.”

Use those 3 magic little words the next time you feel like you’re in a rut.

That something doesn’t have to be great.

It doesn’t even have to be good.

But it’ll protect you against the atrophy that would occur if you didn’t use your muscles that day.

Just. Do. Something.

Done,

Ben

P.S. In most of my recent emails, I keep coming back to the same few principles. One that seems to be ever-present is this idea of having trust in yourself – even in uncertainty. Trust that you’re on the right path and trust that if you just start, you’ll figure it out. The painting can only be completed after the last stroke.

P.P.S Just do something​

​

subject: i'm freezing.
content:
Today marks day one of making the cold plunge my entire personality.

So here’s a lesson I’ve learned from submerging myself in cold water:

It only hurts when you resist the pain.

When I first get in, all my brain says is, “This is freezing. Why are you doing this? Get me out of here. Joe Rogan is a liar. Ok seriously get out.”

But then I take a deep breath and relax.

I loosen the muscles in my body that are tensing up and tell myself it’s really not that bad.

And after a minute or so, the pain goes away.

Or maybe it doesn’t dissolve – but I learn to tolerate it.

Either way, it’s an interesting dynamic.

There are a few analogies we can pull from this.

The most obvious one is “run towards fear. Pleasure is on the other side of pain, blah blah blah.”

It’s a valid point, but I’m not gonna bore you with David Goggins-themed motivation.

I think there’s a deeper lesson here that may or may not resonate with you…

We feel pain when we resist our true selves.

It creates an internal conflict where the image that we’re presenting to the world isn’t congruent with our core belief system.

Because saying what you want to say and showing others who you really are, sounds intimidating.

It makes you vulnerable.

So you’d rather hide.

It’s more comfortable to just paint on a fake smile, fake personality, and fake belief system.

But after a while, you’ll realize that you’re pretending – and it’ll start to eat you alive.

And then you’re left with a choice.

Do you continue to cover up your authenticity with a bigger shield so that people can’t see in?

Or do you remove the layers that you’re hiding under and stop resisting who you really are?

Because maybe there’s a chance that it was all just a figment of your imagination.

Maybe raw authenticity won’t actually make you vulnerable.

Maybe you’ll unlock the desires that you were chasing and couldn’t catch.

And maybe you’ll finally find peace with that same voice in your head that tells you that the water is too cold.

Or maybe, I’m just kind of sleepy, and this made no sense.

Reply and let me know what you think :)

Talk soon,

Ben

P.S. Come to my friend Mason's free copywriting class this Sunday if you want to learn how to get paid to click letters on a keyboard like a monkey with an 80 + IQ​

subject: don't let your friend drive your trackhawk
content:
I’m staring at a page of semi-coherent thoughts.

For the past 20 minutes, I’ve been attempting to write to you about reliance on others.

What I’m trying to say to you is making sense in my brain, but I’m having difficulties translating it into legible English.

In short, here’s my point:

Odds are there are many things that you situationally rely on other people for - even though you could do them yourself if you tried.

Some of these things are as simple as being the one who drives, leading the conversation with the waiter, or planning the trip for everyone.

Other examples could be relying on a partner to operate a part of the business or lead the conversation on a sales call.

If you’re constantly taking the backseat, these little things add up over time and make you less capable.

Is this making any sense yet?

Feed your brain information that says, “I’m not the one who takes the initiative in this situation,” and you’ll start to think you’re incapable.

Let’s try to reel this in some more.

This became apparent to me recently when I noticed I take a different role socially depending on who I’m around.

When I go out with one group of friends, I’m the one who calls the shots.

I decide where we go, I walk up first, I order the drinks, and I go talk to the group of pretty blonde girls.

When I’m with a different group, I do none of the above.

This might sound elementary, but it’s important to take note of where this concept bleeds through in other areas of your life.

Reliance on other people allows you to limit yourself.

Notice the verbiage there. Other people don’t limit you – they allow YOU to limit you.

Let’s say your Mom “makes” your pop tart every morning by putting it in the toaster and clicking a button.

You were never cognizant of how she did it, and now you think you don’t know how to heat up a pop tart.

Extrapolate this to every part of your life, and I think this jumbled-up email will make a bit more sense.

What you’re aware of you’re in control of. What you’re unaware of controls you.

Reply if you liked this one {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

It’s been a while since I used the first name field.

I kinda like saying your name {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Ok bye {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Ben

P.S. Here's me in the cold plunge today

subject: i bought a richard mille for lunch
content:
Here’s a POV as I open my laptop to write this email.

I’m at my favorite lunch spot that I go to every day in Brickell.

I spend $40-$50 here every day (sometimes more if I get a sweet treat).

And honestly, I’d pay double for the hospitality, speed at which the food comes out, and ambiance in this place.

It’s the Richard Mille of lunch.

When I first started my business, I was closely attached to the money.

I wasn’t necessarily cheap, but I felt every dollar I spent – and when I was having a slow week or slow month, it was reflected in my confidence.

But recently, I’ve never worried less about money.

$400 dinners with the boys, 100 bucks to skip the line at the club, first-class flights, 100% tips on the bill, a few grand on new clothes…

I don’t feel any of it.

And I know some of you may be reading this thinking I’m a bombastic asshole, but that’s not my intention here.

The best part of making money is not thinking about money.

But we all pedestalize it to an extent.

“Making $10k per month will fix all of my problems and make up for the fact that I’m insecure because my left nipple is slightly smaller than my right one.”

No, it won’t – but I get it.

It’s a lesson that can only be internalized if you experience it firsthand, over and over.

You hit the arbitrary money goal in your head and immediately want more.

Go through a few cycles of this and then realize it’s turning you into a crazy person.

And eventually, you come to the realization that money is just a tool.

Solve the money problem, so you have the financial peace of mind to develop other areas of your life.

The biggest irony is when people say things like, “I don’t care about money!”

This attitude causes every decision you make to be limited by a lack of financial resources.

Those who TRULY don’t care about money – focus on it & make it – So they never have to think about it again.

Ok, enough writing for today.

I’ve been at this restaurant all day and have had a revolving door of friends walking in and out of here, so this email has been a highly distracted excursion, but I hope you liked it <3

Talk later bb,

Ben

P.S. Help me out real quick​

​

subject: i'm going through a quarter life crisis bc of my TV
content:
I woke up viscerally angry today that I don’t have more followers on Twitter.

​So plz go here and follow me real quick if you don’t already (it’s where I actually share more in-depth business advice).

Thx.

Moving on – this morning, I went through a brief quarter-life crisis on my walk.

You see, a few months ago, my TV randomly broke.

I tried everything to fix it – I turned it off and turned it back on (twice, actually).

But it didn’t work.

Most of the time, I don’t think about the fact that I lack a functioning TV until I sit down on the couch, grab the remote, click the on button, and see a black screen.

In theory, I could order a new TV or go to best buy, but it just sounds like too much of a hassle – so instead, I opt to grab my laptop and just watch whatever I want to watch on there.

It’s a tricky spot to be in.

I kinda want a new TV, but that desire isn’t strong enough to spur me into action.

So let's break this down…

Most of the time, we operate within a range of 2 levels of desire.

Things that we kinda want.

And things that we can’t not get.

The latter of the two usually eventually unfold - I felt like I had to drop out of college, start a business, build a personal brand, etc.

There was no other option, so the action became obvious.

You probably have some things like this in your life – those things that you can’t not get – you’re obsessed. You’re constantly thinking about them, and they're going to happen no matter what.

But you also have a laundry list of the things that you kinda want.

Maybe you kinda want to get jacked, take surfing lessons, learn guitar, go on more dates, start a YT channel, etc.

These unclosed loops become death by 1,000 papercuts.

They linger in the back of your head like a gnat that only bothers you occasionally.

Most of the time, you’re not thinking about it, but when it’s buzzing in your ear, you want nothing more than to kill it.

And in life, you’ll get occasional reminders about your “kinda wants” to the point where you’ll eventually need to start tackling them.

They could be completely unrelated to your main thing (the things you can’t not do) and feel like a pointless side quest.

But if they continue to linger, it means there’s something there.

It’s an urge you have to quench.

All this said, I likely won’t be getting a new TV until September 10th (first day of the Bengals football season).

Don’t be like me.

Start attacking one thing that you kinda want today.

​And follow me on Twitter plz,​

Ben

P.S. Chat GPT graded this an 8/10, which is lower than usual. I care more about your opinion bc you’re a real person. Let me know if this one resonated <3

​

subject: I'm getting a 9-5 (clickbait)
content:
I walk past the 9-5ers in Brickell on a sunny Thursday afternoon.

Most of them are dressed as men's warehouse mannequins. Shirts tucked in, pants the perfect length, and Apple watches on their wrists.

It’s 90 degrees outside, and they’ve gotta be burning up.

I can’t help but feel a sliver of guilt as I pass by shirtless – wearing nothing but kill crew shorts and running shoes.

At the age of 22, I have the freedom and am making the money that they’re trading 40+ years of their lives for.

I’m not saying this to sound like a pretentious asshole but rather to point out the inequity of our inputs.

Those of us who are in a similar position to me (where life effectively feels like a video game) are not inherently smarter than those trapped at a desk.

I’d be willing to bet some of those people would smoke us as entrepreneurs.

But the difference is in the way we view the world.

For whatever reason, we were lucky enough to be delusional.

So delusional to the extent that we brainwashed ourselves into believing a different reality was possible.

And this reality rewarded us for our delusion.

No matter where you’re at in life, you’re going to reach a multitude of intersections where you have to make a decision.

Do I continue living in my current reality by telling myself the same thoughts, ideas, and stories?

Or do I change the narrative I tell myself and thus adopt different beliefs that will let me see a new reality?

This might sound a bit “woo woo,” so to put it simply:

The guy hating everyone in tik tok comments lives in a different reality than the guy who’s making $10k/month.

The guy making $50k/month lives in a different reality than the guy making $10k/mo.

And the guy making $1m/month lives in a different reality than any of the above.

To reiterate – these realities are simply made up of the stories we tell ourselves. To change your situation in life, you must change your belief system.

Observe the ever-present thoughts running through your head.

Do they make sense?

Do they serve you?

Do they align with your goals?

OR have you just been identifying with them out of habit? They’ve been engrained so deep into your psyche that you don’t even question them.

Continue to audit your beliefs, continue to discard those which don’t serve you, and continue to watch your dreams unfold.

I must add -- all of this means nothing without taking the according actions and developing skills.

Love you,

Ben

P.S. My friend Grant helped me connect the dots and understand this concept - follow him on Twitter if you’re not weird​

P.P.S. I ordered a new TV this morning. I know – very courageous of me. If you’re new here and don’t understand why me ordering a TV is a big deal, check out this email from the other day.​

​

subject: {insert subject line here}
content:
The right answer can only become obvious once a decision has been made.

I could end the email here and leave that sentence open to your interpretation.

But there's almost nothing I love more in this world than to spew my thoughts across a computer screen, so here we are.

Your current situation in life is made up of a series of decisions and actions that you’ve chosen (consciously or unconsciously).

Whenever you're faced with a tough decision, the answer isn’t always obvious on the surface – but it’s only once you make a decision the right answer will reveal itself.

I’m kinda talking in circles right now, so let’s get more practical…

As I look back at the last few years of my life, every big decision I made eventually became the “right” decision – but in the moment, there were always doubts.

From when I decided not to play college basketball to when I dropped out of college, those felt like big moves at the time.

As I think about them now, it couldn’t be more glaringly obvious that those decisions served me.

But a lot of people get stuck trying to make a perfect decision, so they never do anything.

Even the wrong move will illuminate the right move – as long as you’re MOVING.

The first real business I started was a marketing agency for local basketball trainers.

I couldn’t have picked a worse niche, but in hindsight, it’s what led me to the info-product world, where I’ve been able to find success.

Someone I know reached an impasse in their career a little bit ago.

They had just shut down their previous business and were ready to start something new – but trying to figure out what that new thing was gonna be.

We were on the phone one night, tossing around an idea for what they could do next.

After some back and forth, they said, “what the hell I’ll try it."

They’re now in a position to make multiple seven, if not eight figures with that business and impact thousands of people.

But none of this would’ve happened if they didn’t simply decide and act.

So if you’re wondering why I’m telling you this and how it applies to you – I don’t know.

I can’t answer that question for you.

Maybe you’re contemplating a big life move right now, and you’ve been weighing your options for a bit.

Maybe the weight of the decision is making you anxious and unhappy.

Maybe it’s time to make the decision so you can finally figure out if it was the right or the wrong move.

And eventually, you’ll see that all you needed to do was decide because you’ll end up right where you need to be.

As always, reply and let me know if this one resonated.

​And check out this podcast I did recently with my friend Alex.​

Ben

​

subject: don't read this
content:
Start 7/24/23 10:08am

I’m sitting outside Starbucks, sipping on a cold brew.

I just watched this mid-20’s aged mom struggle to open the door with her stroller.

While I considered getting up to help her, I figured it would take too long to get up and walk to the door.

Now I feel like an asshole.

There’s a man standing about 20 feet in front of me.

I can’t determine if he’s homeless or not.

He’s wearing a grey wife-beater, champion shorts, and Birkenstocks while holding his(?) phone and dancing like a maniac to the music coming out of his wired headphones.

You might be thinking, “Ok Ben, well if he has a phone and headphones, that means he’s not homeless.”

And to that I say, most homeless people in Brickell actually make around $10k a month and have base model Rolex’s.

Stop 7/24/23 10:14am

Start 7/26/23 7:43pm

I wrote that two days ago and then got distracted.

Unfortunately, I wasn’t able to figure out if the guy was homeless or not – but he started aggressively yelling and laughing shortly after.

That’s when I left.

It’s now been 4 days since you last heard from me.

At the moment I have no idea what I’m gonna share with you, but I figured if I miss another day it could spiral into a long hiatus.

This is usually the point where I’d transition into how just showing up every day is better than trying to be perfect blah blah.

But you’ve heard enough of that.

In fact, you’ve probably heard enough of everything.

Once upon a time, I was addicted to consuming content.

I’d go down a dropshipping rabbit hole, then SMMA, then Amazon, etc.

For weeks I’d mindlessly watch Youtube videos and take notes so it felt like I was being productive and doing something that would help my life.

But I never implemented any of the stuff I learned.

Finally, I realized that I was effectively fantasizing about success and giving myself a false dopamine hit by watching this content, so I turned it off and stopped listening to all the gurus.

Then I made money.

Simple right?

The lesson here is that there’s no lesson here.

If you’re not where you want to be stop endlessly consuming content without taking action on any of it.

You’re basically getting off to other people's words.

And that’s weird.

Go do something <3

Ben

​

subject: i lost $28k today
content:
I’m back at the Starbucks I wrote to you about yesterday.

6 cops on motorcycles just drove by with their lights on.

The man I told you about in yesterday's email is here again, and I’ve concluded that he’s definitely homeless.

He’s wearing the same clothing except for a different pair of sandals (which actually look really comfy) and is carrying 6 worn down plastic Target bags – which I imagine hold the entirety of his belongings.

He’s still schizophrenic too.

The girl sitting behind me just asked me to watch her bag while she goes inside to get a drink, and now I feel morally obligated to defend it with my life.

I just fought off 12 large men.

The world is so interesting when you stop to observe it.

I could write about the Mehgan Fox-looking girl who just walked by or the man that just sat down in front of me, and I think is staring at me because every time I look up, we make eye contact…

Do you ever think about how maybe we’re the NPCs and the schizophrenic homeless guy that’s screaming in laughter is actually the awakened one?

This guy’s still staring at me.

He just nodded, and I pretended not to see it.

I’m not mean he just has a crazy look in his eye.

I fucked up.

He’s walking over here.

Ok, he’s gone now.

He definitely had a screw loose, but he seemed harmless.

He sat down across from me, shook my hand, and told me his name was Cornelius (I promise I’m not making this up).

He went on to tell me how his phone is broken and then started asking me if I live around here and if I have a working phone.

I said no to both and then pretended to be intensely working on my computer, so he said goodbye and walked away.

What an interesting morning.

Honestly, if I read this email, I’d think I’m either a pathological liar or that schizophrenia is contagious and that I should stay away from the homeless guy.

Anyway, I spent $18k this morning and then gave away another $10k.

Long story short, I realized I wasn’t getting billed for a mastermind that I’m in, so I let them know, and they offered me a $6k discount to just pay in full for the year.

I couldn’t say no.

And the $10k was a “misunderstanding” with a now ex-client where they claimed we agreed to a performance fee of bottom-line revenue (profit), but we actually agreed to topline (total rev).

Although I have a document (that they signed) that clearly states I’m entitled to roughly $10k more than they paid, I honestly don’t care enough to go through the headache of pursuing it.

Oh well.

Feeling like aggressively inflating my lifestyle, so I’m forced to make more money.

Stop taking life so seriously,

Ben

P.S. Good movie about a dog that I watched the other night​

​

subject: How to stop fumbling the bag
content:
Finally.

I’m so back.

This is the first ounce of creativity I’ve had in a week.

For a bit, I thought I was completely out of ideas, and I’d said every word of value that I could.

But I was wrong.

I have plenty to tell you about, and I just wasn’t giving my thoughts enough of a vessel to transfer into reality (whatever the fuck that means).

As I was sitting outside Starbucks this morning, it hit me.

The only reason people don’t find success in life & business is because they fail to recognize opportunities that are presented to them.

They wander through life, perpetually messing up every chance they have at making a lot of money.

All it takes is one good connection or one win to completely change your life.

They get a well-respected client who could send them hundreds of referrals…

Buuut they can’t get results, so it falls apart.

Or they meet someone who can open various doors for them…

And they don’t go above and beyond to add value to that person's life.

It’s like they’re either blind to the opportunity or so nervous to mess it up that they just crumble.

One of my first big personal brand clients was a guy named DJ Sakcmann.

He’s got about half a million followers on IG and is one of the main authorities in the online basketball training space.

I connected with him through a cold DM on Instagram.

We got on a call, and he said needed a new funnel.

I said, “say no more, fam” and spent the next 4 hours writing some of the best copy I’d ever written.

I built the entire landing page, and by the next morning, he had a new funnel.

At the time, I was making around 10k per month, so I obviously could charge for my work – but I didn’t ask him for a dime.

The funnel I built literally converted 5x better than the one he had previously, and it generated hundreds of thousands of dollars.

For the next 4 months, I basically worked with him as an unpaid intern, and it was one of the best decisions I ever made.

Not only did I eventually get paid a lot of money from DJ, but it opened so many doors for me.

  • He sent me a handful of referrals
  • It gave me confidence that I could get results in the info-product space
  • And DJ is now a good friend of mine and one of my most notable case studies

But it would’ve been so easy to fumble this opportunity.

I could’ve let my ego get in the way and asked for a lump sum of money upfront.

I could’ve stopped following up with him when he didn’t reply.

I could’ve half-assed the funnel and taken much longer to get it done.

But I recognized the potential upside in this partnership, so I seized it.

This is just one of many examples of the art of craftiness – the most overlooked skill in business.

I’m working with a kid right now named Kevin, who edited a recent podcast I did (without asking for money).

Not only am I gonna pay him, but I’ll send him intro’s to potential clients and give him advice on scaling his business…

Just because he has enough foresight to go out of his way to provide value for me and not be greedy by asking for a bunch of money.

Odds are you’ve had chances in your life to help someone who can open doors for you.

It’s up to you to recognize when those opportunities present themselves and go above and beyond to pounce on them.

Hope you enjoyed this email, I’m glad to be back.

​Check out the podcast I did with Cardinal Mason and Grant Lannin here.​

Ben

P.S. Reply if you liked this one :)

​

subject: I'm selling you something
content:
I’m once again sitting outside this Starbucks without any idea what I’m going to write about today.

I just chugged a cold brew and coconut water, so my bladder feels like it’s going to explode.

But I refuse to use the bathroom here because it’s one of those where you have to ask them for the code to unlock the bathroom door.

And that’s just not something I’m willing to do.

“Hey sir can you give me the code for the bathroom??” Nope. Couldn’t be me. I dropped out of school for a reason.

Okay, I’m stalling now.

What should I write to you about?

Uhhh.

I’ve been thinking about putting together a course or coaching offer for a while now.

I keep going back and forth on what I’d offer, how hands-on it’d be, and what people want to learn from me.

If I built an agency coaching offer, here’s how I’d position it:

I’d start by demonizing the traditional SMMA model.
