You may have heard the saying, “An enemy of my enemy is a friend of mine.”

This common enemy tactic is one of the most powerful tools you can use as a marketer.

You’re breaking the beliefs of your audience while simultaneously building a bridge to your solution.

This is how I’d sell you on the “full-stack marketer” business model.

I’d show you how it’s easier to get a few clients to pay you $5k-$10k+ per month rather than try to stack a bunch of clients on cheap retainers and constantly have to do outreach.

I’d tell you how I worked with 50+ clients that paid me $1k per month and how much of a headache that was.

And I’d show you how I now get paid $10k- $30k per month (per client) without needing a huge team.

With enough social proof and personal stories, I’d sell you on the business model, and I’d sell you on me.

Now it’s time to sell you on you.

This offer would be for people that have a client or two as a freelancer, so I’d speak directly to that archetype.

“Since you already have some results, this is the easiest way to scale. You’ll simply be selling more services to someone that already trusts you.”

This is where I’d use language that shows you how I was once in their shoes and transfer my certainty into their soul (if I can do it, you can do it).

This is how successful offers are created.

Sell an audience on a mechanism (business model), sell them on yourself as the authority, and sell them on themselves so they can actually visualize their own success.

Hope this gave you a better understanding of how to extract money from strangers on the internet.

Reply if you liked it :)

Ben

P.S. It's a miracle I finished this email without peeing my pants. You're welcome.

​

subject: Getting canceled on a podcast
content:
I’m sitting at the crowded coffee shop in my hotel lobby.

It’s kind of cold in here, so I ordered a hot latte with vanilla.

Fun fact – I went through a 3-day phase where I was drinking black coffee and felt like I was better than everyone else.

Then I missed flavor and switched back to sugary, milky coffee.

My airpods are dead, but I have them in my ears to try to drown out the noise from all of the other people in here.

There’s a guy sitting over to my right that I swear I’ve seen many times throughout my life.

Does that happen to you too, where you see people that you think have been following you from city to city since you were old enough to remember?

Because same.

I like asking you questions even though I know you can’t actually answer me because you’re a stranger on the other side of the screen, probably reading this on the toilet (unless you’re a female bc girls don’t do that).

Ok, I’m 173 words in now, and I’ve written nothing of value.

This is the part where I try to find some important life lesson to share with you that makes you go, “Wow, that’s super interesting,” and then you forget about it 2 minutes and 6 seconds later.

I’m going on a podcast in a few hours, and I’m a bit nervous.

I have no logical reason to be nervous, but I am.

The nerves are coming from feeling like I need to uphold or project an image of myself to the world.

I know when you’re 100% comfortable with yourself, the nerves go away...

But I woke up this morning to a (well-meaning) comment on my Tik Tok that said, “Having a conversation with you must be so insightful. Your friends are so lucky to be in your circle.”

And now, I feel the need for every word I say to be insightful.

What if I want to talk about Joe Burrow and Cincinnati Bengals?

Or my fear of fat people?

Or how I’m currently seated next to the line to order a coffee, and some dickhead is standing too close to me?

If you couldn’t tell by now, my newsletter is more for me than it is for you.

You’re just an innocent bystander getting hit in the crossfire of the combative thoughts in my head.

Thanks for reading, and as always lmk if you liked this one {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Have a great Saturday (if the day of the week means anything to you),

Ben

P.S. I wrote to you yesterday about how I’m considering offering coaching for agency owners that want to make more money with fewer clients and fewer headaches.

If you fall into that bucket, can you do me a quick favor?

Simply reply and let me know what type of agency you run and what your biggest challenge is with your business right now.

You can write 6 words or a full novel, thanks in advance :)

​

subject: it's getting late and i miss you
content:
I’m 34,000 feet in the air as I type this on my phone.

If there’s one reason to make multi-8 or 9- figures, it’s to avoid airports and only fly private.

Smelly fat people.

Idiots standing still in the middle of the aisle.

And NPCs standing up right when the plane lands as if their stomach rolls are gonna magically propel the plane to the gate.

This is the first time I’ve flown in a bit actually, and I’ve decided that I’m only sitting in first class from here on out.

Although I still had to deal with the airport people, the power trip of walking past the line at the gate, and sitting down in 1D is 100% worth the extra money.

I’ll stop being a judgmental asshole for a sec and share something that’s been on my mind recently.

Your eyes are a gateway into your soul.

You know when you meet someone that you can just tell us actually ALIVE?

They’re not just going through the motions of life or suppressing their true self.

They’re attacking every day with ferocity.

I’ve started to take note of this whenever I’m in public.

Walking around the airport is mostly an energy drain.

Most people look like life’s beaten every ounce of creativity and passion out of them.

I swear you can see it just by looking people in the eyes.

Here’s my hypothesis:

Every time you suppress a desire, it sacrifices a piece of your soul.

Working a job, you hate, staying in unhealthy relationships, not approaching the pretty brunette that you saw at lunch 2 months ago( miss her man).

These things eat at you.

At the end of last week's podcast, I was asked the following question…

“If you had to leave the world with one message, what would it be?”

Immediately I said, “follow your curiosity.”

I was never super religious growing up, but I’ve always noticed these signals where I’m simply called to follow an inclination.

You’re drawn to ideas, people, and places for a reason.

And you have the choice…

Do you ignore those desires and sacrifice your soul?

Or do you follow your curiosity no matter how intimidating it may be?

Just touched down in LA.

Hope you’re having a good hump day {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Ben

​

subject: Stealing my rich neighbors Porsche in Beverly Hills
content:
I just got a sugary iced latte from the most liberal coffee shop I could find in Beverly Hills as I start this email from the balcony at my Air BnB.

I’m in a nice residential neighborhood, and my across-the-street neighbor just pulled out in a black Porsche boxter with red rims.

His driveway looks like a luxury car shop.

Along with the boxter, he has a white 911 turbo, a new range rover, and a vintage beige Mercedes.

He drove the 911 yesterday morning.

I’ve become so accustomed to the sweltering heat in Miami that I’m wearing a hoodie on this cloudy 72-degree morning.

The energy here is quite different from Brickell.

It’s more laid back, and there seems to be a constant blue undertone in the sky.

As I think about ways to transition this email to a life lesson, my mind is drawing a blank.

I’ve been stuck for the last few minutes staring at this blinking cursor.

Whenever I feel like my well of original thoughts has run dry, there’s one thing that revitalizes my creativity.

Movement.

I’ll go on a walk, work out, or simply do anything to get myself away from my computer and back in touch with the thoughts in my head.

When I sit at my desk and try to force creativity, it usually eludes me.

The harder you try, the harder it gets.

I’ve realized that much of the progress I’ve made in business has been in times when I don’t feel like I’m trying that hard.

I’ll get obsessed with something for a period of time, and the work starts to feel like play.

I don’t have to force myself to sit at my desk – I simply do it because it’s the obvious thing that I want to do at that moment.

This trait seems to be a blessing and a curse.

It’s made it very difficult for me to do things that I don’t want to do.

In school, I absolutely hated homework.

I’d do anything and everything that I could to avoid it.

And in business, when there are tasks that I don’t feel like tackling, I’ll procrastinate until the final deadline.

Even if it’s something that literally takes me 3 minutes to knock out, it feels like a herculean feat.

Obviously, you can’t always neglect the things you're not excited about.

But there’s definitely a balance between doing work that allows you to enter a flow state and swimming upstream for too long and going in the wrong direction.

Not sure if that makes sense, but I have a handful of things that I’ve been putting off this morning that I need to go do.

They’ll take me about 3 minutes each.

I decided to write this email first because it’s something I actually felt motivated to do.

Weird how that works.

Talk soon,

Ben

P.S. Check out my recent podcast with Grant Lanin and Cardinal Mason if you haven’t already​

P.P.S. Reply if you liked this one (if you feel motivated enough to do so)

subject: skipping my flight to write this
content:
The doorman told me I should leave now for my 11:59am (PST) flight.

He said it’s one of the year's busiest travel days, and LAX will be a madhouse.

I don’t buy it.

I’ll leave in an hour or three.

(if I miss this flight to write this email, it’s 100% your fault).

I have too many things to write about today.

Instead of writing about one singular idea like a normal person, I’m gonna go rapid-fire.

You ready?

- I met a kind, early 30’s woman at the bar at Catch.

I told her I liked her bag, and we started chatting for a few. She’s a famous model/actress (isn’t everyone), and I’m thinking about asking her to fund my lifestyle.

- Have you ever had New Zealand licorice?

Go to Trader Joe's right now and get some if you haven’t.

- I kind of want to get a place in LA.

Only for a few months out of the year, so I don’t end up dying my hair purple and cutting off my [redacted].

Do I actually want to spend more time here, or am I idealizing it because it’s new to me?

- Business is easy once you’re good at making other people money. I’m gonna repeat that for the people in the back.

Business is easy once you’re good at making other people money.

Everyone tries to play the client acquisition game, but nobody plays the get results game (for lack of a better term).

I have inbound leads coming to me, following up with me till I finally reply (because I hate getting on calls), and then they transfer 5 figures to my bank account after a 20-minute phone call… Because they know I will make them wayyy more than that.

Keep your client acquisition systems dorks.

- I was originally going to leave yesterday, but I moved my flight, and first class was full.

I’m in 12C like a peasant.

- You guys kept harassing me, so I’m finally building a course about funnels.

It’s literally gonna be the bible for understanding types of funnels and when to use them.

And I’m gonna charge you an arm and a leg for it (lmk if there are some specific things you want to learn).

Okay, I think I actually have to go now.

The doorman is gonna be mad at me when I walk out of here an hour after he said I should leave.

I still have to pack up my stuff and go get a coffee.

Let’s see if I make it to Miami.

Deuces,

- Ben

​

subject: waste 3 min of your day with me
content:
I wrote one-fifth of an email to you yesterday.

It was about how I’d been spending too much time on my phone and how to get out of the “social media vortex.”

Then I got distracted by my phone and stopped writing.

The most honest people are hypocrites.

I’ve realized it’d be a really good idea to start taking more of my own advice that I write to you about in these emails.

The other day I told you how I’m creating a course about building funnels.

It’d be wise for me to spend the next couple of weeks talking more about business and priming you for when I drop the offer.

But I don’t want to.

Instead, I’ll write about how I finally took 47 seconds out of my day to hire a maid to clean my apartment.

It was something I’d been contemplating for weeks, and it’s one of the best decisions I’ve ever made.

She even got the stains out of my windows from months ago when I decided to launch blueberries at the glass (story for another day).

Remember the doorman I told you about at my hotel in LA? (context if you’re new here)

He told me I was gonna miss my flight if I didn’t leave right away.

I waited another hour and then left.

Turns out he was a paranoid liar.

I got through security in 3 minutes and had to stand there for an hour before my flight boarded.

And to make it worse, I had to sit next to a very large woman on the plane who wouldn’t stop trying to teach me bad words in sign language.

I was nice to her at first, and that was a mistake because then she attempted to give me her life story throughout the flight.

It got to the point where I was basically pretending to be deaf (hence the sign language).

I wouldn’t wish that experience on my worst enemy.

It’s a cloudy day here in Miami, and my energy is low because of it.

This has been a super jumpy email, and if you’re still reading, I applaud you.

Maybe you’re waiting for a life lesson or something to take away from this.

You’re gonna be waiting for a while because I’ve got nothing for you.

Sometimes I just want to brain-dump, and this was one of those times.

Maybe I’ll teach you how to solve world hunger and make a gazillion dollars tomorrow.

Thanks for wasting your time with me today,

Ben

​

subject: Outside bleeding in the rain waiting for you
content:
The back of my left sock is bloody again.

It’s a gloomy morning.

The sky is dark grey, and constant gusts of wind indicate it’s about to start raining.

I lace up my shoes and look out the window.

“It’s gonna pour. You should just stay inside and work out here instead,” I think to myself.

I go back and forth for a few minutes before deciding not to cancel this run.

If I get caught in the rain, I’ll be okay.

Four minutes later, I’m outside running, and the wind is picking up.

The people around me are hustling to their cars.

It’s not directly raining yet, but somehow, it feels like I’m getting hit with raindrops from the side.

Considering I’m running by a river, I guess it’s safe to assume the water is being blown from there.

My left shoe is starting to rub against the back of my ankle.

I already have a blister there from the same thing happening the other day.

As I continue along, it starts drizzling.

At this point, I’m honestly excited about the torrential downpour.

But as I get closer to the end of my route, it still hasn’t started.

I think my blister ripped open, but I can’t feel the pain because I’m hunting down the man in a blue shirt about 150 feet ahead of me.

I fly past him, and not too long after, I’m back at my apartment.

That’s actually when I tried to start this email, but I got distracted by a call from a friend.

I then tried to continue it at the coffee shop, but it was far too crowded for me to be able to hear my own thoughts.

You might be thinking, “Ben, is there a reason you just described your morning in vivid detail to me, or are you wasting my time again?”

Oh yeah, I had a metaphor for you.

Long story short, the “rain” is a future obstacle that’s keeping you from attacking a goal.

You don’t start a business because you’re worried about paying taxes (lol).

You don’t ask her out because you’re worried that you’ll look like an idiot.

You don't step in the ring because you're worried you'll get hit in the mouth.

It’s a tale as old as time.

But once you start running toward the things that scare you, you realize that the rain isn’t as bad as you thought it’d be.

Maybe you end up with a bloody ankle, but you don’t care because you’re finally in the game.

It's a feeling of aliveness that money can’t buy.

Don’t rob yourself of this gift – if you get caught in the rain, you’ll be okay.

Thx for reading.

As always, reply if you made it down here <3

Ben

​

subject: Advice for {{ subscriber.first_name }}
content:
I need to clean this computer screen.

I’m outside on my balcony, and the combination of the sun and dust on my laptop is making it difficult to see.

Maybe I’ll just buy a new computer instead.

I have a friend that doesn’t do laundry. He just cycles through a dozen new shirts every few weeks.

About a year and a half ago, I read Jordan Peterson’s book “12 Rules For Life” – and by “read,” I mean I skimmed about 70% of it.

One of his first rules was “treat yourself like someone you’re responsible for helping.”

At the time of reading that, I didn’t think much of it.

But for whatever reason, it’s on my mind as I sit here writing to you.

You have all the answers, you’re just letting your emotions get in the way.

You know how to make more money.

You know how to stop overthinking.

You know how to get over your fears.

And if someone in your exact situation came to you and asked for advice, you’d tell them exactly what they need to hear – even if they don’t want to hear it.

But when it comes to ourselves, it’s like we have blinders on.

We pretend not to know the answers to our problems because this state of “uncertainty” becomes comfortable…

Well, at least more comfortable than the real uncertainty that would occur if we changed what actually needs to be changed.

That make sense?

A lack of clarity isn’t the issue – it's emotion disguised as a lack of clarity.

I just reread that, and I think my breakdown made this concept more confusing than it really is.

Long story short, take the advice you’d give to a friend in your situation.

It’s easy to come up with a solution when it isn’t clouded with fear or doubt – just pure logic.

This was pretty jumbled, but at the end of the day, it’s really just advice to myself.

Maybe I should take it.

Good luck,

Ben

​

Hi {{ subscriber.first_name }}, sorry I haven’t been emailing you much recently.

I have a good excuse.

Do you notice how traveling, trying a new hobby, or going somewhere new unlocks thoughts you didn’t previously have access to?

If you get stuck in the same routine and virtually live the same day every day, your ideas will usually remain constant.

It’s not a bad thing – but for the sake of creativity, I think it’s good to switch things up every now and then.

That leads me to the lack of emails as of late.

I’ve been on a mini-bender.

Up until now, my well of creativity had run dry.

I’d sit down to write and type “good morning” or “hey” and then immediately get stuck.

I literally have 4 emails in the drafts from this week where I didn’t make it past the first line.

Usually, when I feel a creative lull, I go for a walk, and it fixes me.

But not this time.

I concluded that more drastic measures were necessary.

Aside from the bender, I started taking boxing lessons, playing tennis, I’m 5 days off the zyns, and I’m moving to a 2-bed apartment because I want an office.

I think it worked.

The lesson here?

When you get bored, simply change everything.

Don’t take that too seriously.

That advice probably isn’t the most practically sound, but understand that your environment will dictate your thoughts

When things feel off, and you don’t know why, maybe you need to shake the snowglobe.

Ok, I have a lot of work to do today, so this’ll end here.

I’m rusty, and my computer's light is hurting my brain.

Hopefully I’ll write to you tomorrow, but I can’t make any promises.

Have a good Sunday friend,

Ben

P.S. Here’s a clip of me spewing nonsense to a 6’8 woman​

​

subject: moon blue coffee black
content:
I’m starting this from my phone outside of Starbucks.

A cold brew sits in front of me, but something looks different.

Instead of the usual sugary vanilla cream that creates a smooth, lightly brown colored milkshake…. it’s…. black.

…

I started a 48-hour fast last night.

Why?

Something to do with a full blue supermoon.

And so that I could tell you I’m doing it.

I’ve got some thoughts today.

Holy fuck it’s windy I’m gonna walk home - be right back.

Ok, I made it.

Anyway, I was about to tell you about procrastination.

You familiar with that word?

Me too.

I’ve been procrastinating building the course I told you I was gonna build 2 weeks ago.

I was procrastinating taking boxing lessons for a year.

I procrastinated finding a couch for my new apartment that I’m moving into on Friday, but luckily, I caught a hail mary and found what I was looking for yesterday on Instagram.

I’m even procrastinating doing other work by writing this right now.

All of the reasons you tell yourself why you have to put something off until later are usually a facade.

They’re a pastiche. A simulacrum. A Potemkin village. They’re not the real McCoy.

The best example I can think of to illustrate what I’m trying to tell you is cold approach.

You see a girl. You want to go talk to her (if you’re a woman reading this, replace the girl with me, and you’re nervous to come say hi because I’m so famous).

Your brain starts feeding you objections.

“I need to learn how to approach girls first.”

“I don’t know what to say.”

“I actually like men.”

“My shoe is untied.”

Aaaand she walks past you.

The singular action you needed to take to succeed was to walk up and say hello.

But you found all these scapegoats for why that couldn’t happen.

Odds are this exact situation is happening in multiple areas of your life.

A big one for me was content.

I told myself for a while that I’d start making more content once I was making $10k per month.

But I didn’t really put effort into growing on TikTok until I started making over $50k/mo.

And I’m still not making YouTube videos like I wanted to.

The thing is, I’m getting a dopamine hit by telling you this right now.

It gives me an illusionary feeling that I’m moving closer to making YT vids.

The same thing happens when you tell your friends you’re starting 75 hard soon or you’re gonna start training for a marathon.

You get brownie points in your brain but don’t get closer to the goal.

Tricky territory to be in.

The solution is actually to do the singular action.

The unsexy action that you’ve known all along that you needed to do.

Like set up a camera and start talking.

Or walk up to her and say, “Hey, I’m {{ subscriber.first_name }}.”

That’s when you stop fantasizing success (like a cuck).

Love you, and happy blue full superhuman moon or whatever,

Ben

P.S. reply if you read all 510 words <3

​

subject: i didn't eat for 2 days
content:
Start: 11:32am

I’m 40 hours into this fast and concluded that food is a scam.

This is so easy that I watched a cooking show on netflix last night to try to make it harder.

I have a call in 30 minutes, so I have to be quick.

I’m sitting outside of Starbucks, casually sipping another black cold brew.

The dude I see here every day who drives an R8 with “forexxx” on the license plate is sitting across from me, getting a tarot card reading from a pretty girl.

Astrology chicks >

You guys seemed to like yesterday’s email, which gave me a lot of dopamine.

I’m moving tomorrow, and I still haven’t called a mover. Ugh.

There’s a new grey Ford Bronco parked to my left.

The new models seem to get hate, but I really like them.

If I get a place in LA, maybe I’ll get a 911 and a Bronco…

Stop: 11:47am

Start again: 10:52pm

A lot has changed since I left off here.

I broke my fast a few hours ago, found a mover, and even started thinking about packing up my belongings.

Oh, and I bought a rose gold olive dial Rolex Presidential today.

I didn’t mean to, but I finished my work early for the day and had nothing else to do other than drive 40 minutes to my boy Jamie and buy a new watch.

I don’t want you to think I’m flexing (even though I am).

I’m sharing this with you because I noticed this purchase felt different.

You know all the things that you envision coming with your “dream” life? The car, the girl, the house, the status, etc…

I remember thinking to myself at one point, “Wow, I’ll be so cool once I have Rolex – or Audi – or move to Miami.”

And every time I got one of those things, they lost their lust quickly.

I’d buy them expecting some grand feeling of accomplishment, only to be let down once the lust wore off.

But today, I didn’t feel that.

I bought the watch because I wanted it – I didn’t expect it to make me feel any better about myself or change my perception of who I am.

Dropping those illusionary expectations allowed me to find a different level of appreciation.

Everything that you own, you’ve earned in one way or another.

You have a right to be proud of that.

But understand that the things are not you. They are not a place to source for your own self-worth. And they are not much more than a subtle external trophy for winning internal battles.

Fuck I gotta start packing for tomorrow.

Goodnight,

Ben

P.S. I went on the Stick Talk podcast recently if you wanna check it out​

​

subject: I fought off a pack of wolves for wifi (story)
content:
I’m sitting at the counter at my lunch spot in Brickell.

Yes, I now call it “my” spot because it basically is.

Some chubby dork in a red tank top is standing right over my shoulder waiting for his food, and I’m seconds away from backhanding him.

I hope he’s reading this because he’s close enough to see it.

I will hit you buddy.

If you’re not brand new here and you actually read my emails, you’d know I moved a few floors up to a 2-bed apt the other day.

Moving sucks.

I swear it’s a less strenuous process for me to make $50k+ on an hour-long webinar with a client than it is to lug around boxes and disassemble/reassemble furniture.

Mr. Red Tank Top just left.

I’m sitting at this counter because I don’t have wifi in my new spot until 2pm.

And I had to fight tooth and nail even to get it that soon.

AT&T is the only provider you can use in my building.

I thought setting up new wifi would be as simple as carrying up the box from my old apartment to the new one, but that wasn’t the case.

Oscar (support agent) told me over the phone that they had to transfer and activate the signal to the new unit and then have a “technician” come out to verify it.

But before that could even happen, they needed the lady who lived in the unit before me to cancel her account to be able to transfer the signal.

I thought that was bullshit, but Oscar implored me that it was the quickest solution and that he’d reach out to the previous tenant and let me know when she answers.

So I did what any rational human would do and built an army of Phillipino (I’m guessing) AT&T agents.

Right when I got off the phone with Oscar, I called again, got placed with a different agent, explained the situation, and asked them to reach out to the lady.

I did this a handful of times until I had 5 or 6 agents literally harassing this woman.

For the next 16 hours… nothing.

I called again and told them the lady was dead so there was no way of contacting her, but still they insisted that it was the only solution.

About 30 minutes later, John (definitely not his real name), whom I’d just told that the lady died, called me back.

“Good news Ben, I got a hold of her and canceled her account. We’ll have a technician come out on Thursday, and you’ll be all setup.”

First, I told him I loved him for tracking down the lady and laughed at how she miraculously must’ve been revived from the dead.

And then I said, “Thursday isn’t gonna happen; what can you do here.”

Those nine words saved me 4 days of no wifi.

John (who is now my next of kin in my will) put me on hold for 30 seconds, pulled some Vudu magic, and said, “Ok, your signal will be back tomorrow at 2pm. You’ll just need to plug the router into the wall.”

I’m telling you this whole story for a reason.

There is always a way to get what you want.

Whether you’re building a business, trying to get into an exclusive venue, or want to connect with someone important…

If you’re persistent enough, you will find a way.

Even if it means employing half a dozen Phillipino VAs.

Or harassing staff to get an omelet at 3am (inside joke - if you know, you know).

Go harass an old lady today,

Ben

P.S. Check out my recent podcast if you haven't already (It’s a banger – I think. But I could also be spewing nonsense – what’s the difference?)

​

subject: The eyes chico
content:
I was walking around my house like an idiot 3 minutes ago, trying to find my computer to write this email.

It was hidden in plain sight, but I didn’t know where to look because it wasn’t in any of the usual spots.

Lesson in there.

On my walk back from soybucks this morning, I was trying to make a TikTok about how money means everything and nothing at the same time.

The video sucked because it’s easier for me to work out concepts like this in writing first, so let’s do it together, shall we?

Money gives you the autonomy to be who you really are.

My friend Mason has said something like this before.

The peace of mind in knowing you’re good financially allows you time to “side quest.”

And in these side quests, you’re gonna learn more about yourself and the world than you would if your only pursuit is money.

I neglected this for a while, but it’s how you start to live in a way that genuinely aligns with your soul.

And when you do that, you become magnetic.

This sounds woo-woo, but it’s true-true. Ok pretend I didn’t say that.

You can see this in people's eyes – It’s a glimpse into their soul.

The eyes chico, they never lie.

It’s why you get a weird feeling about someone when you meet them, but you can’t explain it, so you just say something's “off” about them.

It’s why you know she’s a good girl at heart even though she’s at the club every night (miss her).

And it’s why you naturally gravitate towards some people more than others.

They’re either truly themselves, and it makes you want to be around them more, or they’re pretending, and you can feel it on a subconscious level.

Here’s a litmus test for you: How many things do you do just because you want to?

There’s no real angle or motive; it just feels like something you were called towards.

That’s why I make content. That’s why I write these emails. That’s why I’m boxing.

These are just mini-side quests that I feel obligated to tackle.

At some point maybe I’ll make money from the content/emails (if I ever get around to building a course), but as of right now, I’m doing it for free.

And I’ll keep doing it even if I never make a dollar from it.

Find the things in your life that you would do every day even if the only benefit is quenching an urge that’s floating in the back of your mind.

Because honestly, doing that will make you feel better than money ever could.

But you need money to allow yourself the luxury.

Thanks for working this out with me.

Have a good Tuesday,

Ben

P.S. Here's me shamelessly plugging a recent podcast I went on for the 36th email in a row​

P.P.S. Reply if you liked this one <3

​

subject: Sorry i forgot about you {{ subscriber.first_name }}
content:
There’s a new (potentially) homeless guy next to me this time.

He’s somehow acquired a phone, Lululemon bag, and a watermelon ice puff bar.

I don’t think I’ve ever seen a more accurate representation of the word “disheveled” until seeing this guy.

He’s not in horrible shape, and honestly I hope my hair looks as good as his when I’m his age (probably in his 40’s or 50’s)

But he just looks… disheveled.

Other than that, he’s been arguing with someone on the phone for the last 7 minutes.

Except his phone is sitting face down across the table, and he definitely doesn’t have air pods or headphones.

So I guess the “someone” on the phone is actually another person(?) in his head…

The schizophrenics fascinate me.

Do they have access to a different dimension?

Are they enlightened??

Am I the crazy one???

I’ve missed you, by the way.

It’s been a week since we last spoke, and I’m starting to feel guilty.

Gonna walk home real quick because I don’t know where I want to take this email yet.

Ok, I’m at my desk in my new office, and my mind is still blank.

Well, blank isn’t the right word – I have infinite half-baked ideas I want to write about.

Do you ever think about how you would live your life if you were completely detached from the outcome of your actions?

Not in a mid-evil barbaric way where you have no consequences, so you run around like it’s GTA and kill people when they cut you off in traffic.

But in a way where you do the things you want to do without giving any value to the voice in your head that tells you it’s scared.

You simply take more shots.

I saw this Theo Von video where he was giving advice to his 20-year-old self, and he said, “Ask her out.”

Whatever “she” is – a business, a new city, a random inclination, or a real human.

I think that’s where you find fulfillment.

You just live in complete alignment with your soul.

Your doubts, fears, and worries likely don’t go away, but you don’t give any power to them. You run your life… you’re not on autopilot.

Do this enough, and maybe you’ll be so enlightened that you end up disheveled, sitting outside of Starbucks, talking to the voice in your head…

Or maybe you end up becoming exactly who you were meant to be.

Missed you, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

And if you’re new here, welcome. I know you’re probably wondering what you subscribed to, and maybe your finger is hovering over the unsubscribe button.

I was gonna offer an explanation, but honestly this email is long enough. So if you want to leave, it was nice knowing you.

Yep, schizophrenia is definitely contagious.

Have a good Tuesday and reply if you liked this email <3

Ben

​

subject: How to cure everything
content:
I’m convinced everyone has anxiety and/or depression.

It’s just a matter of what degree they listen to it.

Keep telling yourself bad things, and you will literally program yourself to always think that way.

Those constant negative thoughts end up shaping your entire identity and perception of yourself.

Once a belief is accepted as an unchangeable fact, our malleability gets diminished.

“I am an anxious person” or “I am a depressed person” gets repeated until it’s deeply embedded into someone's psyche.

And on a long enough time horizon, that person forgets that there was ever another option.

An option where they didn't have to give power to their negative thoughts.

Or where they understood they could decide who they are.

And as long as they don’t suppress their true desires, that evil voice gets a little bit quieter.

I don’t think it ever goes away – it just takes a backseat.

Even when you’re living your “dream life,” sometimes you’ll wake up on the wrong side of the bed.

You’ll never be completely immune to occasional highs and lows.

Every now and then, you’ll question everything about your life just hours after thinking you’re invincible.

That fluctuation is inevitable. It’s natural.

And accepting it is part of the solution.

It can be as simple as shifting from “I feel like shit right now, and I hate this” to “I feel like shit right now, and that’s okay.”

Of course, there are times when a negative situation shouldn’t be accepted and instead used as fuel for change.

But I’m talking about the other times where you just seem to hit a wall for no rhyme or reason.

That happens to me all the time. The same goes for almost all of my friends, so I imagine it happens to you.

The secret is discerning when a feeling needs to be accepted and when it needs to inspire change.

Before dropping out of college a few years ago, sometimes I’d quietly get anxious.

Although my life looked fun on the surface, I could simply feel that path wasn’t right for me (emphasis on feel, not think).

There was objectively no fulfillment.

I went out all the time and “celebrated” although I had nothing to celebrate – it was an escape from a life with a lack of purpose, ambition, or improvement.

If I didn’t change, it would’ve eaten me alive.

On the contrary, I’m now in a position that I was enamored by for years.

But that doesn’t stop me from occasionally questioning if I’m an absolute idiot and if I should move across the country to live on a farm with Amish people and cows.

Odds are that’s just a natural low – in fact, I know it is because it feels different.

So when those types of thoughts come up, I try not to give them power. I accept them as they are – the devil who will always be there on my shoulder.

And that’s okay.

Hope this all made sense. Let me know if you made it down here.

Have a good day,

Ben

​

subject: I'm going broke
content:
I turn 23 tomorrow.

I’m expecting to receive a bouquet of flowers from each of you.

That’s 8,395 days I’ve been alive, and I still botched the spelling of the word “bouquet” so hard that even autocorrect didn’t know what I was trying to say.

I had to type it into Google and play with the spelling until I got close enough.

Recently I’ve been spending 3-4x my normal expenses.

Between my upgraded apartment, buying clothes, watches, shoes, going out, and the very expensive short Jewish chiropractor that I put on a retainer to come to my place once a week…

Life hasn’t been cheap.

It’s been a bit nerve-wracking but also freeing.

I’m becoming detached from money yet realizing that I need more and more of it.

It’s shown me how easy it would be to spend $50k/mo+ on lifestyle consistently, which has given me a renewed sense of excitement for working.

For the last few months, there weren’t many things business-wise that I actually wanted to do.

Even when I hit new financial milestones, they felt meaningless because it was just a bigger number on a screen.

But now I can see the true utility of more money.

I know what I’d do if I tripled my income and now have a real incentive to get there.

I’m not telling you to go spend all your money but rather to pay attention to the way that you feel.

When life gets dull, it usually means it’s time to shake things up.

And dull doesn’t just mean boring; it can actually be the opposite.

After partying all the time for 2 years in college, that lifestyle eventually lost its luster.

That’s when I dropped out, moved to Mexico, and basically was in “monk mode” for 3 months.

Anyway, as I sit here on my balcony, I can’t help but think about how much can change in one year.

Put real effort into anything for 365 days, and you will come out on the other side with a completely new perspective.

A year ago I’d just moved to Miami – nervous about upgrading my expenses and in a very different spot mentally.

Above all – the biggest thing I’ve been able to reignite in myself this past year is trust.

I follow my gut.

I don’t do things I don’t want to.

And I say what’s actually on my mind.

This alone has made me feel like I know myself way better, and feels good to live in alignment with your soul.

I encourage you to start paying attention when you suppress what you really want to do or say.

Start with small things, take baby steps, and it’ll create a ripple effect.

Do that for a year, and who knows where you’ll be.

Thx for the bouquet in advance,

Ben

P.S. Here’s a video of me talking about living in alignment with your soul​

​

subject: Your wake up call
content:
I’m sitting in the hotel lobby, drinking a coffee that the liberal barista just made for me.

She’s actually sweet and made a hell of a latte, so I’m gonna refrain from saying anything hurtful.

I just got an email from the water company telling me I need to call and update my address. I’ve been putting off making this 4-minute phone call for 3 weeks now.

I’ll probably continue to procrastinate until I wake up one day and can’t turn on the faucet to brush my teeth.

Today is my first full day being 23 years old.

Birthdays are interesting because they are meaningless unless you give them meaning.

It’s not like you instantly reach a new level of wisdom or get your first grey hair the day after you hit a new number.

The only difference is the perception.

If a 29-year-old degenerate wakes up on his 30th birthday and decides that he’s now too old to smoke weed all day and throw together 19 leg parlays in hopes that $6 will turn into $800, and he changes his actions accordingly; then the arbitrary number now has meaning.

I’m feeling this right now, too.

The perceived gap between 22 and 23 is rather large in my head.

At 22, the bar’s pretty low – simply having my own apartment, a nice car, and smelling nice seemed to be impressive.

At 23, I feel more pressure.

$500k-$1m annually is cute. Enough to feel rich without being anywhere close to it.

My audience should be bigger. I should be employing more people.

It’s honestly embarrassing that I don’t have a supercar.

Why don’t I have $10m liquid?

I’m kind of kidding right now, but I’m really not.

I feel like I’m only tapping into 1/100th of my potential, and having to say a new arbitrary number when someone asks my age is a reminder of this.

Maybe you’re in the same boat, and you know that deep down.

But you’re waiting until it gets bad enough.

You wake up at 30 and realize your bucket list is full of unchecked boxes…

Your bank account hits zero…

You put on so much weight that you can’t see your toes when you look down…

Maybe you’ll change then, maybe you won’t.

Why do we operate this way?

Is an embarrassingly new low the only thing that can inspire change?

It can’t be.

Maybe the answer is to give ourselves a manufactured wake-up call instead of waiting for the arbitrary one.

If you're waiting for a slap in the face, here’s your sign to stop half-assing life while pretending to give maximum effort so you don’t have to accept the fact that you’re neglecting your true potential.

I’m gonna call the water company and update my address.

Happy Saturday,

Ben

P.S. First - thx for the bday wishes yesterday <3. Second - reply if you liked this one

​

subject: There's a hornets nest in my bedroom
content:
There's a pink a pink box outside of my apartment door.

I can read the text on the side of the box facing me as I get closer, which reads "cupcakes."

Do I have a secret admirer?

Was one of my wives feeling generous today?

Is it a bomb?

These thoughts run through my head as I pick it up.

Unfortunately, none of the above is true.

I pick up the box and see a girls name on the delivery address.

The mailman must've mistaken the number 7 for a 2 and accidentally put the package at my door.

I take the stairs up a few floors and drop it off at her door.

What's a good deed if you don't tell people about it on the internet?

The error that the mailman made is the same error that stops people from ever being successful in business -- or anything for that matter.

It's the thing that causes unnecessary headaches at the worst possible time.

And it's the reason a football team can lose to a much less talented team on any given Sunday.

Attention to detail.

Today has been hectic.

It's felt like a thousand little problems have popped up, and it's making my head spin.

These issues would've been avoided with the necessary planning and organization.

But those two things have never been my strong suit.

So now I'm left with all these mini-fires that need to be extinguished.

And the pink cupcake box outside of my door was a perfect representation of what happens when you take your eye off the ball for a moment.

Don't be like me.

Kill the hornets before they build a nest.

I'm back.

Sorry I forgot about you {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

And if you're new here, welcome.

I usually write a few of these types of emails weekly, sharing little lessons I learn like this one.

Happy to have you onboard,

Ben

P.S. Reply if you missed me <3

​

subject: It's okay to want more
content:
I often make fun of the dudes who constantly preach gratitude.

It can sound ingenuine as if they’re talking about how grateful or how “at peace” they are as a way to make themselves feel better than others, which couldn’t be more hypocritical.

It’s similar to those who use their belief and connection to God as a way to prop up their ego.

But there comes a time when gratitude stares you back in the face as the only answer.

You’ll go and get everything you previously dreamt of, and it won’t feel the way you anticipated.

How many times can you go through this process until you realize that you’re chasing your own tail?

Considering this is a topic I’ve written about frequently, the answer to the question above is obvious.

The truth is, you will always want more.

There’s always gonna be another mountain to climb, hoops to jump through, and levels to ascend to.

And that’s okay – as long as you accept it.

Acceptance is another thing that’s been on my mind recently.

Everything you do is a choice that you make.

Where you are right now, your habits, and your beliefs about yourself are all decisions that can be traced back to no one but you.

Unease comes from the lies that you tell yourself about your desires.

You say you want to change, but your actions do not correlate with change.

When your actions fail to follow suit with the things you claim to want, it creates a disconnect between your actual reality and your desired reality.

And that’s where unhappiness stems from.

Pause for a second and audit your current situation in life.

Consider your goals, routine, and beliefs.

Would the previous version of you from a year, 2 years, or 5 years ago be ecstatic?

Good. You have a lot to be grateful for.

But it’s also likely that you’re currently holding some desires that are causing you anxiety because your actions do not align with them.

It’s okay that you want more – just ensure that you’re taking the necessary action to fulfill those desires.

Enough rambling for today.

Hope this was semi-coherent,

Ben

​

subject: Why you feel uninspired
content:
I’ve spent the last 45 minutes contemplating the best route to more money and more freedom.

The past couple of weeks have been busy, and I haven’t had a chance to spend much quality time alone.

I define quality time alone as the uninterrupted moments between you and the 37 voices in your head.

These are the opportunities that allow you to think critically and perform a mini audit on your life.

I could write a whole email on the importance of prioritizing this and how most people are too sTuCk iN tHe MaTriX to ever figure out what they actually want.

But I’ll spare you today.

I went on a long walk this morning and let my mind wander.

After my walk, I sat down outside Starbucks with a cold brew, and now I’m here writing to you.

Sometimes, just the act of thinking about your “problems” will drastically improve your mental state because you realize how silly they are.

There are people dying, and I’m over here stressing about how I need multi 8 figures by age 30.

99.9% of the world would trade everything for my “problems.”

I could go on about this, but there are already enough people who talk about gratitude on the internet.

While I was walking, I was thinking about a friend of mine who recently ended up in a sticky situation.

His 7 figure business fell apart nearly overnight, and a series of unfortunate events drastically depleted his bank account.

Scary right?

There’s a level of freedom you reach when everything goes to shit like this — and it gives rewards the equal (or even greater) opportunity if you can get through it.

My friend started a new business and has been on an absolute tear for the last handful of months.

He’s working nonstop but just seems to be electric about the work and thinks that this new business could make him 8 figures over the next few years.

I’ve been envious of the excitement he has for this new project and asked him if he ever has days where he doesn’t want to work.

I’m paraphrasing, but basically he said, “Sure, there are, but I don’t give much power to it. The work just feels like something that has to be done.”

His answer makes perfect sense to me.

He’s not passionate about the day-to-day tasks. He’s not immune to the monotony that comes with building a business.

But the end goal and the vision are big enough that they carry him through the tediousness (plus the situation with his previous business adds some urgency).

My main takeaway here is this:

If the work always feels like a herculean task, you’re playing too small.

When you truly believe that what you’re building has the potential to be special, that passion puts you on autopilot and carries you through the boring stuff.

Take a walk today and think about where you want to be in 5 years.

Clearly envision it – money, lifestyle, relationships, impact.

Do your current daily actions align with that goal?

If not, now you know where to start.

Hope you enjoyed this one.

Much love,

Ben

P.S. Start paying more attention to the things that come naturally to you.

Write down a list of the things you enjoy doing the most, and do not neglect them.

P.P.S. I am not a self-improvement guru or life coach. My goal is simply to share my perspective through the lens in which I view the world. Nearly nothing I tell you is a universal truth.

Let me know if my perspective resonates :)

​

subject: Step in the ring
content:
I’m gonna keep this one relatively short:

Listen to yourself.

Listen to what you feel called to do.

Pay attention to the things that you are resisting the most.

Run towards them.

You’ll make it out on the other side and laugh about how you were ever scared or uncertain. The fear was an illusion.

It was a devil on your shoulder – or in your own mind – that desperately tried to preserve the previous version of yourself.

That version of you is comfortable the way they are.

They like their limiting beliefs.

They like their fears.

They like their perception of self.

That version needs to die.

I know this sounds like an intro to a corny self-help manifestation book, but bear with me.

A few months ago, I made a list of things that I wanted to do but was putting off.

I started checking them off the list, and every single time, I’m left with the same feeling that sounds something like:

“Why was I ever nervous to do that?”

I stepped in the ring, got hit, and it didn’t feel as bad as I thought it would.

I’ve actually grown to like it.

And Improvement has come much quicker than I anticipated.

This is both an analogy for everything that I’ve tackled over the last few months and my actual experience from boxing.

I’m telling you that checking these things off your “one-day” list is what will make you feel alive.

It’s how you end up living the life that you envision in your head.

It’ll make you look like you have fire in your eyes, and your aura will become magnetic.

And it’s how you become authentically you.

Reply if this one resonates :)

Let’s have a good week,

Ben

​

subject: Do more
content:
I use the background of the lock screen on my phone as a reminder to myself.

Up until the other day, it was a white background with the words “do more.”

I set it as that about a year ago, during a time when I felt like I was becoming too one-dimensional.

I’d just moved to Miami and honestly was a bit nervous to be here.

At the time, I was making $15k to $20k per month, which will quickly make you feel small in a city like Miami.

The social scene here was also intimidating to me. I’m not usually one to be anxious socially – It was just a lot of “new” at the same time.

New city.

New friends.

New routine.

Etc.

I immediately had a solid group of friends who I’d met through social media, but none of us were really “plugged in” here.

And because all of the newness was intimidating to me, I kind of just latched on to the friend group.

I never took the lead or planned anything – I would just go with the flow.

Then, after a few month period where I was almost never going out, I realized that I wasn’t living the fun “Miami lifestyle” I envisioned.

I also started to really despise working.

A $50k month vs a $100k month virtually had no difference to me, so I lost almost all motivation to keep pushing for new numbers.

So I took back control and started doing my own thing.

I hired a boxing coach, went out to new clubs and restaurants, and started meeting new people.

I learned to lean more into my uniqueness and have become more of myself.

And now, I’ve created the exact lifestyle that would play as a movie scene in my head when I pictured moving to Miami a year and a half ago.

I’m sharing all this with you to encourage you to do more.

-- You can grow your business while living the social life you want, trying new hobbies, and keeping up with all of your 16 wives.

-- You feel most alive when you get rid of the scapegoats you may blame for why you’re not as happy as you want to be. Take control of your habits, routines, and decisions.

-- It’s okay to do things for the “sake of it.” You have an inclination to do those things for a reason.

-- Do not settle when it comes to your true desires. Most get a tenth of the way there and justify settling for “good enough” along the way. Fuck that. We want Lambos and Pateks. Not a Model 3’s and Apple Watches.

Alrighty.

Originally, this email was gonna be about my new lock screen on my phone, but I got caught in the zone and felt like this deserved the spotlight.

Maybe I’ll write to you about the new one tomorrow.

Hope you liked it – let me know if you made it all the way down here <3

Do more,

Ben

​

subject: Do your best
content:
Oh no.

This is the first time in over a month that I’ve sat down to write an email two days in a row.

Are we… back??

I’m running on 5 hours of sleep, and I haven’t had any caffeine yet.

I imagine this is what the baseball players who weren’t taking PEDs in the Barry Bonds era felt like.

I’m at a disadvantage, but at least I’m honest.

In yesterday's email, I told you about my phone background that formerly read, “Do more.”

A few days ago, I changed it to “do your best.”

It’s corny, it’s cliche, but actually doing your best is often the answer to every challenge you face.

When the goal is simply to do your best, you become outcome-independent.

It shifts your attention back to where it should be – right here, right now.

There will be days when the work feels like a pain, and you don’t want to do it. But if you can simply bring yourself to do your best in that given moment, you’ll keep moving forward.

Doing your best also applies to your interactions with others.

Instead of worrying about what to say to impress someone or the perfect lines to make a girl fall in love with you – approach interactions with the goal of simply spreading good energy (corny again, but true).

This approach takes all of the pressure away, and It gives you control of any situation.

Switching gears - sometimes, I’ll run into moments like this when I’m writing, and I feel like I’ve completed the entire argument for the point I’m trying to make.

How many more times can I tell you to do your best?

I actually got this “do your best” concept from the book The Four Agreements, and it stuck with me for a few days, so that’s when I decided to make it my phone background.

I’m not gonna keep hammering this into your head – But just start to take note of your goals in different situations.

“Am I anxious when talking to this person because I’m trying to get something out of them or impress them?”

“Am I tired of doing the same monotonous work, so I procrastinate until the last second and then half-ass it, which makes me anxious because I know I could’ve done better?”

In those situations, changing the goal is the solution.

If you go into the interaction aiming to do your best to say what you want to say, or if you approach your work with the goal of doing what you need to in the most effective manner possible…

The anxiety goes away.

You feel your best when you do your best.

Anyway, thanks for reading <3

If you reply and tell me you love me, maybe I’ll even write another email tomorrow.

Much love,

Ben

​

subject: How to get out of prison
content:
The only rules you have to abide by are the ones you’ve created in your own mind.

A lot of anxiety comes from feeling obligated to do things that you don’t want to do.

You feel obligated to go get a drink with an old friend because they kept asking you, and finally, you gave in.

You feel obligated to get a safe job so you have something to talk about at Thanksgiving dinner.

You feel obligated to stay in a relationship that doesn’t serve you anymore because you’re comfortable, and deep down, you feel like you couldn’t do better.

You feel obligated to live where you live, eat what you eat, think what you think, and go where you go.

But the thing is, all of these obligations are imaginary – They’re pacts that you’ve made in your own mind that you never stopped to question.

You are simply imprisoning yourself.

Do you know how much freedom you truly have?

I was thinking about this after my Sunday morning run…

Right now, if I wanted to, I could pack up and fly across the country.

I could drop all my clients and start a completely new business.

I could stop running businesses altogether.

I could start making a different style of content, start posting on a different platform, or stop making content.

I could shave my head, start talking with a Russian accent, and tell people my name is Igor.

Am I going to do all of these things? No.

But recognizing the freedom and the options that we have will help us understand this:

Everything that is going on in your life right now is a result of decisions you have made.

You choose the stress you allow into your life; you choose the people, the goals, and the perception of reality that you make.

You choose whether or not you want to have difficult conversations with a friend, and you choose whether or not you tell yourself that you’re too hungover to go on your Sunday morning run.

You choose how much of yourself you express when you’re around different types of people, and you choose the way you react when things don’t go as planned.

You choose to hold yourself to a certain standard and to do or not do things that you commit to.

Now, I say all this to show you that if you are unhappy, if you are anxious, or if you feel like you’re not living in alignment with the life you’re meant to live – it’s on you.

You’re actively deciding to live the exact life that you’re living right now, and any conflict comes from failing to accept that decision as your own.

You have more freedom than you’re telling yourself, but you’re making shitty rules that keep you stuck.

Obviously, without any rules, chaos would ensue – just make sure the ones you abide by are actually serving you.

Happy Sunday and go Bengals,

Ben

​

subject: 3 lessons 1 email
content:
Happy Monday {{ subscriber.first_name }},

It’s easy to forget that you are in control of your state.

Yes, you will have bad days, you’ll go through ruts, and there are some circumstances outside of your control.

But half the battle is in just showing up for yourself and doing what you know needs to be done.

Yet sometimes, even though you know this to be true, you still manage to neglect the things that will make you feel fulfilled.

For me, I know that when I do the following, I feel better than when I don’t:

  • Long-form writing (this can be tweeting, journaling, these emails, or all of the 3)
  • Knocking out my to-do list and staying on top of everything in my business
  • Making video content
  • Walking outside & spending time in the sun
  • Going to the gym

I’m sure there are others that I’m missing, but these are the core 5 that come to mind.

It’s irresponsible to underestimate the power that little habits like this can have in our lives (speaking from experience, as you’ve seen some inconsistency in these emails lol).

My friend Miles is one of the most dialed people I know when it comes to his routine.

And it just so happens that he never seems to be down.

He knows the handful of things that have to be done every day for him to keep moving the needle forward, and he doesn’t miss a day.

Make a list of your non-negotiables and do them every day.

I kind of sound like the corny self-improvement personal brand guy that I make fun of.

Maybe they have a point?

Moving on – success is inevitable when you pull the one big lever.

I turn away most of the prospects that come to us because they simply don’t have enough traffic.

They’re trying to optimize all the backend systems and their offer – but even if those two things are the best in the world, it won’t matter because no one is seeing it.

If you have a ton of traffic, you can do everything wrong and still make money – that’s when you know you’ve found something.

Similarly, in dating, when a girl truly likes you, you can break all the red-pill rules of “game,” and it’ll probably make her like you more.

You can be goofy, and you don’t have to try hard to have “frame control” because you are the frame – You’ve developed into someone worthy of respect and admiration, so simply leaning more into your nature and showing your personality will make that person like you more.

Last thing that’s been on my mind that I’ll attempt to articulate:

Playing in the different arenas of life will expose you to the fact that you need a true mission.

You need to conquer your inclinations to side quest and quench those thirsts.

These can be new hobbies, traveling, dating, etc.

Only once you pursue them will you know that you cannot find fulfillment in them – and that’s a good thing.

You’ll be able to enjoy these pleasures as they are and return to your main goal with more firepower.

Not sure if this last point is making sense for you, but it’s one of the biggest things I’ve learned recently – let me know if it resonates at all.

I know this one was long and scattered, but hopefully, you enjoyed this somewhat rapid-fire style today.

Let’s have a great week,

Ben

subject: about to fall asleep
content:
Whatever your expectations are as you open this email, lower them.

I’m half asleep, but I can’t miss today as I was just starting to rebuild momentum with these.

A few things I’ve been thinking about recently:

1: Do girls drink water?

I swear any time I’m with a girl, they will not drink unless I basically force them to. It makes me wonder how they operate on their own and if they just go throughout their day without water.

2: We are hard-wired to be obsessed.

If you’re smart, you get obsessed with something that brings you fulfillment and makes you money.

Your purpose is to find the things that are worth obsessing over for you and carry them out to their fullest potential.

This is where you find the flow state.

3: I’m (probably) not smarter than you.

Sometimes, I see people comment on my videos or reply to my emails saying things like, “How are you so wise for being this young?”

The answer is that I trust myself. I’ve developed enough conviction in my own perception of the human experience that seems to resonate with others. You, too, have the same wisdom if you care enough to listen to it.

4: Being intentional and setting goals put your subconscious to work.

Almost every time I put “make 2 tik toks” or “write 3 tweets” on my to-do list for the day, my brain starts feeding me ideas.

This applies to any goal or desire in life.

5: When you utilize money to its maximum ability, you reach a new level of autonomy.

I buy $300 massages a few times per month (no happy ending). I didn’t realize this was “expensive” for a massage until the way a friend of mine reacted when I told them.

It made me think about other little things like this that make me appreciate money – fancy dinners, clothes, sporting events, paid parking, and subscriptions, are all effectively free.

6: I’m going to bed.

I’m not gonna proofread this, so if it was illegible or I spoke about my disdain for fat people - I’m sorry.

Hope this was half-decent. If ya liked it, let me know!

Gn,

Ben

​

subject: "Just wait till you're my age"
content:
I’m sitting outside people watching.

One of my biggest fears is becoming one of those people who love to tell you about how it all goes downhill after 40.

This fear was brought to my attention as I just watched this woman mock her husband's hand gesture when they crossed the street with their elderly parents/in-laws.

It was a small interaction that I’m sure the two of them forgot about in the following 30 seconds.

But is that just what happens when you spend years with someone?

The way they breathe, the way they sit, the way they chew, and the mannerisms they use while doing certain activities just become annoying.

Maybe this is why I like speed dating.

I had a series of brief relationships throughout college that felt like eternities.

Over the course of two weeks, we’d spend nearly every day together, share phone locations, and I introduced one of them to my parents on our 3rd date.

Then I’d usually get tired of the girl and all the little things she’d do would start to bother me.

The way her ponytail bounces when she walks, the brief moment where both of us would open our eyes at the same time when we kiss, the way she sleeps, etc.

I’d be silent about these things though and then completely blindside her when I pull away.

I’ve changed I promise.

And it’s not that I’ve never been in long-term relationships or haven’t met girls that make it past the 2-week honeymoon.

It’s just that it has to stay really fast-paced and exciting for me to be able to overlook the inevitable icks.

The finance bros just walked out of Starbucks and are heading back to the office.

That scares me too.

Fake smiles, the same 5 shirts they rotate through each week, taco Tuesdays with the wife, beer night and football on Thursdays with the boys, and a 401k that leaves you with just enough money for low-budget vacations twice a year.

To me, it just sounds like a slow, silently painful death that starts the day where you can semi-accurately predict what the rest of your life will look like.

I guess that’s what I’m scared of.

Too much predictability. Complacency. Living the same day for 50 years. Losing the spark with a girl and staying in the relationship only because finding someone else would be too hard. Or when the most exciting part of the day is hitting the green light at the busy intersection on the way home from work.

Does the spark inevitably fail after a while or is that a lie that’s been perpetuated by these doom and gloom water cooler conversation and “wait till you’re 40” types?

Or are they actually the enlightened ones because they’re able to seem outwardly content with the “simple life” and I just don’t have enough appreciation for the little things?

Maybe. These are questions I don’t have the answers to.

For now, I’m gonna go get the same tacos I eat every day for lunch, hop on the usual 3 pm meeting, hit the gym, and call it a day.

Ooh, it’s chest day. If it’s not too crowded and I can get a bench that’ll be the highlight of my day!

Some good basketball on tonight too.

Will circle back tomorrow!

Ben

P.S. Watch my most recent podcast if you haven't already​

​

subject: $1,000 on black
content:
I see about a dozen “Untitled Documents” as I open my email folder to write to you.

It’s the early afternoon here in Vegas, but I haven’t fully adjusted to Pacific time yet, so it feels like it’s later.

The untitled docs are emails that I started and never completed.

Some had a few sentences, some were too incoherent to send, and some were completely blank.

I was gonna write about how the untitled docs in our lives are the dreams that we started and never finished.

We tried to be too perfect, we got nervous, or we half-assed it.

But as I often do when contemplating an idea for an email, I discard it because it sounds too elementary or basic.

The last thing I want is to become a corny platitude, vanilla advice type of dude.

At the same time, I understand that there are very few things that I can tell you that would be completely new or unique.

You’ve heard every piece of advice there is, and you intuitively know what’s right for you.

The only time we go in the wrong direction is when we refuse to listen to our intuition.

We’re conditioned to silence it over and over until we can’t hear it at all anymore.

Anyway, Vegas is interesting.

It’s my first time here, and I didn’t really know what to expect.

I think it’d be extremely easy for me to get addicted to gambling, so I’ve been staying away from the Casino even though it’s just an elevator ride down from my suite.

Fuck I wanna go play roulette now.

Ok, last time changing the topic and then I gotta run:

No matter your current situation, you truly are 2-3 years away from your dream life.

I know that might sound like a long time right now, but I’m not talking about the “realistic” dream life where you get half of what you want and settle.

I’m talking about the life you envision that sounds a little far-fetched, and you don’t even know how to make it happen.

Between my (and a friend's) first-class flight here, my suite on the strip, dinners, shopping, and other activities, this trip will probably cost at least $15k.

It honestly could be way more, and I wouldn’t even know because my Amex is set to auto-pay.

I’m here with an amazing group of friends, business is hitting an all-time high this month, and I can’t even tell you the details of what I see when I look up from my computer while writing this.

All it took was a consistent effort for an extended period of time, and boom - nearly exactly what I used to picture in my head has come true.

And the best part is; money is a complete afterthought.

I don’t have to think about it, I don’t have to stress about it… I just pull out this magical card and put it on the reader.

I’ll leave you with this:

You owe it to yourself to make your dream life come to fruition. You will never experience the depth of life if you don’t attack the things you want and shape your reality to your imagination.

Just don’t forget to stop and enjoy the moment once you get there.

I guess this did turn into a motivational guru email, but I hope you liked it.
Let me know if you did – and finish your Untitled Documents.

$1,000 on black,

Ben

​

subject: Don't forget to water the grass
content:
I’m walking on the sidewalk in Beverly Hills, looking up at the beauty of the trees and surrounding scenery.

It’s 75 degrees and sunny, with no wind and not a cloud in the sky.

I like the way California license plates look. I like the ever-present blue tint in the air.

“It would be impossible to be unhappy living here.” I think.

And that’s when I stop and catch myself.

I already live in paradise.

Minus the aesthetic of the hills and homelessness, Miami is basically the same thing.

And I’m not unhappy in Miami at all – I’ve absolutely loved it recently.

But that thought of “better” still crept in.

That singular thought has the potential to be cancerous.

Imagine you’re dating your dream girl (or dream man if you're a girl).

She’s gorgeous in that unique, innocent way that you just don’t see every day.

You guys get along perfectly. She’s clever, she can banter with you, and most of the time, you know what she’s thinking before a word comes out of her mouth.

It’s that kind of chemistry that makes other couples fight after seeing you out because it makes them question the depth of their relationship.

But one day, you start to develop eyes for a different girl.

She’s equally beautiful, and you’re intrigued. So you start fantasizing about girl number 2.

“What would life be like with her? I bet she wouldn’t get mad at me for leaving the toilet seat up the same way my girl does.”

And here comes the poison.

You start observing your girl in a different light.

The things you loved about her begin losing their luster.

You think more and more about what she does wrong and what you don’t like about her.

Over time, your relationship is silently in shambles. Neither of you have acknowledged it yet, but you’ve been fighting way more about little things.

You’re no longer the person she fell in love with, and you’ve warped your perception of her to the point where you think she’s the problem.

Eventually, it all goes up in flames, and you find your way to girl number 2.

Except she’s not just number 2.

You’ve ben doing this countless times with nearly everything in your life.

You get what you want, and stop watering your own grass.

You slowly poison it, evade to the next one, and start all over.

This is a vicious cycle – Water your own grass and be careful of these thoughts that there is always something better.

They will sprout quickly, and soon enough, you’ll live in a forest full of poison.

Avoid looking for problems where there are none – because you will find what you seek.

The grass is always (and never) greener when you fail to water your own,

Ben

P.S. I had fun with this one. My creativity is way better here than it is in Miami. I think I’d like it here better, for sure. After all, the constant reggaeton in Miami gets annoying. And everythings so congested! Hmmm.

P.P.S. ^ that is sarcasm to illustrate my point if you’re slow and didn’t catch it.

subject: I'm officially a guru
content:
One million dollars.

I used to think that was “never-have-to-work-again” type of money.

I guess it can be if you want to live modestly.

But me?

Noooo.

I’m far too pretentious and egotistical to settle for a measly $1m.

Last week, I got this stupid little plaque in the mail:

It’s the Clickfunnels Two Comma Club award.

When you make $1m using their software, they graciously let you pay them $500 to get one of these.

They built their entire business off this thing.

The software sucks.

It has random bugs, it’s incredibly limited, and the funnels just look scammy.

But everyone seems to accept that it’s part of the game in pursuit of the guru plaques.

This is my second one with my name on it — though the first was for a client who was nice enough to throw me on there.

But this one is just me.

I remember the first time I met someone with a 2CC award.

It was this guy I was working with on a basketball training offer.

Every time we’d hop on Zoom, I’d see this shiny plaque sitting behind him on the wall.

At the time, I was aiming for my first $20k month.

I couldn’t even imagine making $1m in a year.

That award felt like the pinnacle of success.

Fast forward a few years and now I’ve got two of them.

Like most arbitrary milestones, neither feel like I thought they would.

That’s just how it goes.

You work really hard chasing what you think you want, only to get there and realize it’s not all it’s cracked up to be.

I guess what’s cooler than this plaque are the lives changed in its pursuit.

I’ve helped 18 year old kids make their first $10k online.

Just the other day Joao, one of our earliest members sent me this message:

He lives in Portugal, joined with very little experience, and is now hitting $14k/mo.

On top of that, nine members of Artisan Lab have hit their first $100k months.

And in early November I’m hosting my first ever in person mastermind, exclusively for AL members.​

We’ll have a couple dozen info-agency owners at the PH for a two day info-bender.

Now that is pretty cool.

Meanwhile I’ll throw this award in the closet to collect dust next to its counterpart.

To slinging info,

Ben

subject: How to buy a $10M mansion (Tutorial)
content:
I’ve started a bad habit.

Well, I have many bad habits.

But this is a new one. And it actually isn’t all bad.

53 minutes ago, I sat down to write this email.

That means what you’re reading right now is 53 minutes worth of work.

On my way here, I got distracted by something shiny…

Zillow.

Do you know $5m in Miami Beach gets you?

A mansion on the water.

Butler included.

And playboy models feeding you grapes!

Just kidding.

For 5 MILLION DOLLARS…

You can get a shack.

You’ll have to share this shack with four homeless people.

They don’t bite but you have to feed them occasionally and put a needle in their arms regularly.

I’m only half kidding.

You can get a nice place for $2-$5m.

It’s not the type of house where you’d walk in and hear an echo as you say “wowwww!”

But it’s cute.

You only enter “wow” territory if you spend around $10m+.

I feel poor.

“Well Ben, you don’t need a mansion in Miami, you can get a beautiful place in Kansas for $1.5m!” Blah blah.

I don’t wanna live in Kansas.

So I guess my lesson for you today is:

If you want to stretch your relationship with money, go to Zillow.

Pick your dream location and look at some houses.

This will likely result in you considering how you can accumulate a lot more money a lot quicker.

Then – once you’ve had your existential crisis – start an AI lead gen agency for dentists.

Close every dentist in your state for $1k/mo.

Take that money straight to the casino.

Put it all on black.

If it hits, congrats.

You can now almost afford a shack in Kansas.

See you in Miami Beach.

Ben

P.S. If you don't wanna live in a shack, go here.​

subject: How to turn a bad idea into a good email
content:
Good morning, happy Monday.

We’re gonna try a fun experiment today:

You and I are gonna write this email together.

If it sucks, it’s your fault.

If it’s great, it was all me.

Ready?

Alright…

On my walk back from the coffee shop, I came up with the lesson for this email.

It’s kind of basic, so we’re gonna have to dress it up.

The core message I want to articulate is this:

To get what you want out of life, you simply have to ask for it.

Well, and you have to work towards it.

Oh… and you can’t be a complete idiot.

This idea sucks.

We sound like if Mark Manson had a baby with a reformed hoe who turned into a self-improvement podcaster.

I don’t think you can say hoe in an email {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "bro" }}, that’s offensive.

We should delete this.

No, no.

We just need to start off with a story.

You: Got anything?

Uhhh I guess the other night when I was at dinner.

Go on…

They tried to seat me with the poor people.

You can’t say that.

Sorry, they tried to seat me on the terrace and I wanted to be in the main dining room.

Okay…?

I said to the GM “hey brother, any chance you can move us to the main dining room?”

He said “let me check,” and walked to the host stand.

20 seconds later he took us to our new and improved table.

And then what?

Uhh that’s it.

That’s your whole story?

Yes.

And you think we can write an email about that?

Well, it’s deeper than that – we just have to explain it to the reader.

How so?

When you want something, you don’t settle.

You don’t buy the Corvette C8 when you really wanted the Ferrari F8.

You don’t stop following up with the prospect until they tell you to fuck off.

You don’t accept a life that’s “good enough.”

Sure, sitting on the terrace would've been fine.

They’ll still bring us the same food.

The atmosphere is almost as good.

But it’s not what I wanted.

So I asked.

And sometimes, that’s all you need to do.

Winners don’t settle.

That's the whole lesson – it’s simple, obvious, and easy to forget.

But you might just settle your way into a life you didn’t want.

Would ya look at that! We turned a shitty idea into a decent email.

Good work, my friend.

To building a life we actually want,​

Ben

​

​

​
