subject: Passion is a scam
content:
You cannot “find” your passion. Get to work, and your passion will find you.

When I first started playing basketball as a kid, I had no idea that it would consume the following decade of my life.

I figured, “What the hell?” I’ll try this thing out and see if I like it.

A few years later, I was still lukewarm – I enjoyed the sport and was decent for my age, but it wasn’t too serious.

Then I started working with a trainer who played in college.

I still remember walking into the gym in my first session with him and seeing orange cones sprawled across the hardwood.

And the following workout changed the course of my entire life.

It was the most challenging 1.5-hour session I’d ever done – and in those moments, I fell in love with the pursuit of mastery.

For the next 7+ years, this pursuit of mastery became my life.

I cherished the times when I’d walk into an empty gym.

The sound of the ball hitting the court was like music to me.

I felt completely present, and that’s when I knew I was alive.

The thing about this feeling is it can never leave you.

It’s almost like you can’t unsee it once you see it.

If you’ve ever been obsessed with something and have spent every waking hour at your disposal consumed by said thing, you can never go back.

If and when that thing ends, that fire is still in you, and it must be transmuted into something else, or it will burn you alive.

But let’s rewind real quick.

I got so distracted by the power of obsession that I forgot why I started this email.

It’s no secret that life without purpose is a bland life.

Everyone wants to “find their passion,” but few seem to do so.

The problem is people assume that this intensity towards a calling is just gonna slap them in the face one day.

They’ll just be frolicking through the dairy aisle and get hit with a carton of milk that says, “Dedicate your life to XYZ.”

Not how it works.

You have to go out there and hunt. And after hunting for a while, maybe you’ll find your prey.

But if you don’t, that doesn’t mean you’re broken. It simply means you aren’t opening enough doors.

You’re not giving luck enough of a chance.

So you keep hunting and building until you realize that you’ve found exactly what you’re looking for.

And when you stop and pause, you’ll see that passion actually did slap you in the face. It was already inside of you, and you just had to let it out.

Happy Monday {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Ben

​

subject: Now what?
content:
Perhaps the best thing about buying expensive material items is that it quenches the thirst of a desire.

Yes, you’ll enjoy the watch, car, shoes, etc. But the hidden value is the fact that the desire is no longer taking up mental bandwidth.

Have you ever been out to dinner with someone that just can’t decide what they want?

They go back and forth between menu items and keep changing their mind.

Maybe they want the more expensive dish but are hesitating to spend the extra money.

It’s been a while since I’ve been around such a person, but this indecision has always disgusted me.

The way they’d stress over such a meaningless decision would, in turn, stress me out.

And finally, once they decide, it’s like a weight is lifted off of everyone’s shoulders.

My first big purchase was my Audi RS5.

I’d moved to Miami a couple of months prior, and although I didn’t buy it with this intent - the car ended up being a symbol of a new chapter in my life.

The same thing can be said for the Rolex’s I’ve purchased.

Buying each of these things has helped give me clarity and steer me back to what’s really important.

It’s like when the cat finally catches the mouse. It’s a surreal feeling. But life goes on.

And all you’re left with is the question:

Now what?

However, there’s been one common theme that hasn’t sat right with me among my bigger purchases.

I’ve always waited for some arbitrary permission.

I bought my Audi days after a friend bought a new car and the same goes for my first couple Rolex’s.

I’ve told myself I need to get to a certain revenue milestone before making other purchases.

That’s one trait I’d like to discard.

An ungovernable man does not need to justify his desires with made-up rules.

He simply listens to his own voice and follows his intuition at his own speed.

The other day I woke up with a visceral urge to buy a Porsche 911.

It’s always been my dream car, and I’ve found myself talking about it a lot recently.

Here’s a pic of my new turbo.

Hope you’re having a good Tuesday :)

Ben

P.S. The game never ends, and you never win.

You simply collect a combination of trophies and battle scars along the way.

The collection of these memories is the actual "win" because it means you're living a full life full of a variety of perspectives and experiences.

Go get everything you want.

But just know that they're trophies to add to your shelf -- not the end goal.

​

subject: this email lacks coherence
content:
People-watching is so fun sometimes

There’s this one dorky, curly-haired kid sitting to my right

I always see him outside of Starbucks, and he makes me grateful for the type of business I run.

I overheard him on a sales call one day, and it was apparent he runs the same kind of lead gen agency I used to run in the basketball space, but he’s in a boring financial niche.

A tall man in work clothes just walked by while holding a book up to his face and reading.

Could you do that? I certainly couldn’t.

And then this Asian girl walked out of Starbucks really quickly and really… hard.

I’m not sure how else to explain her strut.

It was like she was exerting all of her force into each step and swaying aggressively from side to side.

Similar to the way you’d see the nerdy, overly excited, yet timid girls walk in school.

I didn’t even mention the homeless man to my left, who’s been murmuring random sentences for the last few minutes, but let’s move on.

Often times when I don’t have an immediate idea to write about, I’ll start the email the way I did above.

Just a bunch of random little observations of my surroundings.

Maybe that’s a lesson.

I feel much more present now than I did a few minutes ago.

I also think it helps put me in a different state where I no longer approach this blank page with the thought of “I need to think of something to write about.”

But rather, I just start writing, and whatever comes to mind goes on the page.

Let’s extrapolate these two things to life:

You know how all guided meditations start with presence?

“Focus on your breathing, feel the seat beneath you, place your attention on your chest, etc.”

It serves as a reminder that you are here — where unless you’re in some immediate danger or physical pain, nothing is wrong.

And when you’re fully present this way, that’s when you’re at your best.

Ok, quick detour, the homeless guy to my left is starting to get into an aggressive argument with someone in his head and growing increasingly loud.

If he mistakes me for the person in his head, I’m ready to throw hands with this guy.

He just got up and scurried away.

It’s interesting because I’ve seen this guy in particular a lot and sometimes he’s been semi-normal.

I heard him having a conversation about the Ohio State and Michigan football rivalry, and it sounded perfectly sane.

I guess that’s schizophrenia for ya.

I’m sidetracked now and forget what I was gonna say before that detour. Ironic for an email about presence.

Anyway, the last thing I’ll share with ya...

My agency has consistently been over $100k a month for a few months now while working with just 6-9 clients at a time.

A few notes:

  • Rev shares are how you make real money with an agency
  • Getting clients through inbound and referrals is far superior to cold outreach.
  • Do not be afraid to sacrifice some margin and delegate — this has been a big one for me as I started to feel burnt out with client work.
  • Learning direct response copy is the first fundamental skill you need. Over time you can add complementary skills that make you more valuable to businesses.

Alrighty, that’s all for today.

If you have any specific questions - whether it’s about business or anything else I ramble about here, reply and lmk <3

Ben

​

​

subject: How I make 6 figures per month
content:
Let’s talk about business.

If you have zero clue what I do and how it works, here’s a brief TLDR:

I run a marketing agency where I work with many of the big personal brands that you see online with hundreds of thousands of followers.

Over the last few months, we’ve consistently been over $100k per month with minimal expenses.

I have a team of 3 people, and we work with around 7-10 clients at a time.

The majority of clients we work with are making anywhere from $100k- $600k per month selling info-products and coaching programs.

Most of the revenue we bring in as an agency comes from our 10-20% performance fees on the revenue we generate.

Our bread and butter as an agency are webinars and new product launches.

We provide full-stack services to our clients, meaning we build their funnels, script VSLs, script and build slides for webinars, run email marketing, and provide a few other services, including general consulting.

All of our clients come to us through referrals and my Twitter account.

Make sense so far?

Here’s how I ended up here:

A few years ago, I started a different agency working with basketball trainers.

I was able to work with many of the trainers you may see on social media that had big audiences, and in that process, I got really good at one thing:

Getting people to take action through the written word, otherwise known as copywriting.

I also accumulated a handful of other skills that I use with the clients we work with, including funnel building, backend system setup, and a deep understanding of info-product businesses as a whole.

I don’t know how this all may relate to you, but perhaps you’re an agency owner or freelancer who wants to make more money with fewer clients.

Here are some of the biggest things I’ve learned in going from $25k/mo - $100k/mo+ over the past year:

  • The real money is in revenue shares. To be able to get rev shares where clients pay you $20k+ without batting an eye, you must become irreplaceable in their business. This is where the multitude of services we offer (and do better than 99% of other agencies) comes in handy.
  • You need a team, but hiring doesn’t have to be difficult. I’m a horrible operator, and I didn’t want to have to babysit new team members I brought on. So, my team consists of 2 of my closest who were already very skilled in the work we do. And although I sacrifice some margin, it saves me so much time and headache that I would have if I tried to do everything on my own.
  • Client results & personal brand is the best form of outreach. Two months ago, I closed a new client who found me through Twitter and knew some of the people we work with. He’s paid us over $50k, mostly from our performance fees. I have opportunities like this come up frequently because of the two assets I mentioned above (client results & personal brand).
  • Do not be afraid to cut ties with clients when things are not going the way you need them to. I am selective with who I bring on, and I’ve learned that short-term cash is never worth the headache when I see red flags. I turn away most of the prospects that book calls with me if they don’t fit the criteria that I know we need to succeed.

If you’re working in a similar type of business, I hope this helps. Feel free to reply and fire away with any questions.

Let get richer,

Ben

​

subject: Re: your question
content:
I got many questions from our chat about business the other day.

​Read it here if you missed it.​

I’m sorry if I didn’t get back to you, but I promise it’s for good reason:

I’m lazy.

And actually, the questions I received helped me come to an important realization that you might benefit from.

Most of you already know exactly what you need to do.

And if you don’t, it’s probably because you haven’t taken the time to think critically and objectively about the situation at hand.

I remember being in this exact position.

I’d hit a plateau in business and invest in a coaching program or mentor.

Just by taking the time to explain my situation to them, what I needed to do became obvious in my own head.

By the end of my spiel, I’d usually answer my own question, and if I didn’t, the advice I’d get would be incredibly simple.

And that’s exactly what I needed.

The answer to most of the problems you face right now is the following:

Think about it and do what you think is best.

You aren’t lost; you just want to be told what to do.

This reminds me of these two younger dudes who I recently started consulting with because they kept harassing me and offering me money.

They come to our calls with a world of ideas, fancy diagrams that track their data, and a bunch of new buzzwords and KPIs.

Most of the calls are filled with one of them rambling about any of the things I mentioned above and me saying something along the lines of “That’s cool, so why don’t you just do more of this one simple thing that’s already working for you to make more money.”

Sometimes, I feel bad because they’ve paid me, and I’m not necessarily bringing any revolutionary ideas to the table for them.

But honestly, that’s the secret – the revolutionary ideas don’t exist.

And by simply providing a vote of confidence that they’re on the right track, I’m able to help solidify the things they already know to be true.

Sure, there will always be some nuances and information that you unlock with more time in the game, but most of the time, the right answer is the obvious answer.

Avoid pretending not to know what to do in order to procrastinate doing the thing you know you need to do.

I don’t know why, but that’s a common trap that I’ve fallen victim to frequently.

Trust yourself my friend.

Happy money Monday,

Ben

​

subject: The safest thing you can do is floor it
content:
It’s 1:37am and I’m on my way home.

I’m driving with the top down as I merge onto the highway.

The car in the left lane (autistically) creeps into my lane, and there’s a car on my right, so I can’t move over.

I hit the gas and narrowly weave between the 2 cars.

Sorry it’s been almost a week since I last emailed you.

I went out Monday through Friday.

I know everyone talks about how this whole entrepreneur thing is a grind, you have to sacrifice fun, blah blah blah – but I’ve legitimately spent more time in the club over the last 5 days than I have at my desk.

“Life’s about balance, and the balance is in her (the bottle girl) account now” - Socrates.

Anyway…

The purpose of the driving tidbit I shared above was to illustrate the cliche lesson of going on the offensive.

If I hadn’t hit the gas when I did or if I tapped the brake, I might’ve gotten hit.

So, in hindsight, the safest thing I could’ve done was to floor it.

This reminds me of my thought process when I decided to drop out of college.

I remember weighing the two options and coming to a realization that it actually wasn’t as risky as everyone made it out to be.

Spending 4 years of my life to get a sheet of paper that barely proves a baseline level of competence in hopes of getting a $60k/year job out of college sounded riskier.

I was gonna go on and on about this topic, but I’m extremely sleep-deprived, and I keep nodding off.

Lesson in there.

I’ll write something longer and more valuable tomorrow, but for now goodnight {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Ben

​

subject: Might as well
content:
When I stepped foot on a college campus 4 years ago, I had no intentions of joining a fraternity.

Rush week started, and I began going to parties and events with my roommates

If you don’t know how the whole Greek life thing works; basically rush week is when all the frats throw these parties and events to recruit new members.

After that week, I figured this whole pledging thing couldn’t be that bad.

Next thing you know, I got a bid and became a pledge in a fraternity.

This is not the fun part.

For the next 3 months, my 11 pledge brothers and I were constantly running errands for the members of the frat, setting up events, and of course, having our fair share of… “welcome to the frat” moments.

If you know me, you know I love my time.

There are few things I dislike more than feeling like I’m not in control of where I go and what I do.

Pledging a fraternity completely ate up all my time.

There was a moment early on when I was thinking about dropping (quitting).

It was maybe 2 weeks in, and I started to come to the discouraging realization that this wasn’t going to end any time soon.

I was going back and forth thinking about it and honestly was ready to get out of it.

But by that time, I’d made a couple of close friends, and I didn’t want to bail on them.

I also felt an obligation to myself to finish what I unknowingly started.

So I did.

I would’ve never pledged had I really known what I signed up for, but once I was in it, I couldn’t bring myself to back out.

The words that come to mind when I think about this situation are the following:

“You’re already this far in; you might as well finish the job.”

And if we extrapolate this to life or business, it’s a valuable lesson to pull from.

The hardest part of doing anything new is the beginning.

You suck at the thing. It sucks. And change is hard.

But once you start, inertia starts to build.

Even when you keep getting caught with a right hook…

Or a prospect cusses you out and hangs up on your cold call…

Or you look like an idiot in front of your date because you stumble over your words and accidentally tell the waiter, “you too,” when they say, “have a good meal.”

Momentum carries you through the shitty parts like this. Once you’re in, there’s no going back because it’s like you can almost taste what the other side will be like.

Yesterday, I was reminded of this very concept.

I sat down to record a YouTube video, and 36 tries later, when I was about to quit, I told myself that this was my last try and I was following through with it no matter what.

I imagined how I’d feel after finally making and uploading the video.

And I told myself, “You’re already this far in; you might as well finish the job.”

​You can watch that video here.​

Hope you’re having a good week, and show some love on the YT vid if you like it :)

Ben

​

subject: Just get an easy bucket
content:
I used to watch basketball religiously.

Whenever I studied the greatest shooters in the NBA, I noticed a commonality: each of them had their go-to shots that they would try to get to towards the beginning of the game.

Guys like Steph Curry and Damian Lillard would do this to get into a rhythm.

And whenever they got a solid look and knocked down an easy bucket early on, you could just tell they were locked in, and it was gonna be a long night for the defense.

Similarly, for nearly any task you want to complete consistently, you need to find ways to get yourself in the right mental state.

My creativity has been at a high the last few days.

It’s like my brain is feeding me tweet after tweet and video idea after video idea.

And I think it’s because of the exact same reason that Steph is ready to go off after he gets that first bucket to drop…

I’ve been forcing myself to write a singular tweet early in the day.

Even if it’s not my best work or if it takes 10 minutes to get over the initial resistance, I simply get it done.

It’s my version of an “easy bucket,” and after that, it’s like the pressure is gone.

That very act builds enough goodwill in my brain that it rewards me by continuing to keep creativity flowing in spurts throughout the day.

And this concept applies to a lot more than creativity or basketball.

Have you ever been on a date where your conversations are kind of dry?

You keep asking each other questions, but you’re unable to make the vibe more lively and drop the filter that both of you are upholding.

Then, one of you says something that makes both of you feel more comfortable, and the mood instantly switches.

You can feel the weight being lifted off your shoulders as you conversate, and you’re finally in that carefree state in which you operate best.

That’s the zone.

And if you understand how you operate, you can put a protocol in place to give yourself the best chance of accessing it in different scenarios.

For example, sometimes when I have work to do that I’m dreading, I’ll start by completing a few easier tasks to build some momentum and get the ball rolling.

Does it work 100% of the time?

No.

But can it occasionally help me do that thing that I didn’t want to do with more efficiency and focus?

Yes.

Get an easy shot, get your first rep out of the way, go home with a four (or don’t), write one tweet, etc.

And boom, you now have access to one of the most valuable assets that can propel you to success: Momentum.

Good chat today.

I’m selling you something soonish btw.

Hope you’re ready,

Ben

​

subject: You were sold a lie
content:
You scroll through the internet and see dozens of people sharing various opinions.

Perhaps you adopt some of them and begin to abide by them.

“A capable man needs to get rich, fight, shoot guns, and get jacked.”

You do as you’re told, and not long after, you’ve acquired many of the traits and skills that others proclaim as necessities.

You’ve accepted the values, opinions, and rules of others.

On paper, you’re exactly what you “should” be.

And these things were supposed to make you happy, to set you free, to build you into someone worthy of respect.

But there’s an emptiness that comes with these traits as you’ve “transformed” into the person they told you that you need to be.

Under all these arbitrary obligations, you’ve buried the most important one.

Who are you?

“You” are no longer there.

You’re a hodgepodge – a mosaic – an amalgamation of a variety of opinions and features that you didn’t come to on your own regard.

Self-improvement or self-actualization is not the act of blindly accepting the ideals of others.

It is piercing through their opinions and standards to formulate those of your own.

Don’t forget who you were before they told you who you should be.

Value your instincts, your inclinations, your personal experiences, and your unique perception of truth above all else.

This is freedom.

This is what a “man” does.

This is access to the autonomy that likely seduced you into this game in the first place.

As you become free financially, you must also become free mentally and spiritually.

Don’t neglect the last two.

Happy Saturday,

Ben

P.S. Check out my recent YouTube video if you haven't already <3​

​

subject: When to "jump-ship" VS stick it out
content:
I’ve been going to a different coffee shop recently.

This one’s a bit more liberal, and I think they pump estrogen into the air. All the employees are wearing reindeer ears and the male barista attempts to hold eye contact with me for a few milliseconds too long.

I evade and tell him to make me an $8 iced latte with vanilla.

Before I got here, I was scouring my apartment. I tore up my office, dug under the couch, swept through the kitchen, and even looked in my bathroom although I knew there was little chance I’d find what I was looking for in there.

It’s not that I even wanted to find the item that bad, it’s that I knew it was there somewhere which was driving me crazy.

But for now, I’m listening to Christmas music at this cafe because I had no luck finding my airpods.

I rarely wear headphones. But when I do, it’s because I’m in a noisy area and I want to write. Listening to my own music helps me feel like I’m in my own world where I can ignore the dorky-looking man at the counter to my right wearing a fanny pack around his shoulder.

I literally remember putting them on my counter yesterday.

Maybe someone broke into my apartment, ignored the expensive watches, my car keys, and any other more valuable items they could’ve taken, and decided to run away with my disgustingly earwax-stained airpods. Hahaha.

I had something I wanted to write to you about, but I’ve gotten so sidetracked that I completely forget it now. I guess it’s just that kind of morning.

Something that’s been on my mind however is career paths.

I don’t understand how people can stay in one role in the same field for more than a few years.

Especially as entrepreneurs. Maybe I’m just immature, but thinking about doing the same exact thing I’m doing now for the next 3 years makes me want to chew glass.

Sure you can always make the argument that “feelings don’t matter. Do it anyway” blah blah.

And I know there will always be some things I don’t want to do in any business I run. But to me it just makes sense to upgrade or switch business models every few years (if that’s what feels right).

I get bored doing the same thing every day after a while.

Again, you can make a sound argument that it doesn’t matter how you feel and that you should power through the things you don’t want to do.

But you can also make the counterargument that if you can find excitement in your work, you’ll be much more effective than when you’re dreading it. Even if that means your business model has to change or evolve every so often.

Last point on this and then I gotta run: I’m not saying you should constantly be jumping from one completely different business to another.

You likely have innate skills that can be applied in a variety of different ways, and sometimes being open to the application of your skill set in a similar or parallel field may make sense.

You with me here?

I could be completely wrong, but thanks for reading anyway. Let me know if you liked this one.

Happy Christmas and Merry Hanukkah.

Ben

P.S. Watch my recent YouTube video Or...Watch my recent Podcast​

​

subject: How to dissipate any chance of regret
content:
I found the airpods that I told you I lost in yesterday’s email.​

Any guess where they were?

If you said “the washing machine” you’d be correct.

I guess that’s one way to get earwax off.

Last night I was thinking about the last organized basketball game I ever played.

We were losing by double digits, and I fouled out with a couple of minutes left.

As I ran off the court, I didn’t realize that it would be the last time until I saw the look on my coach's face.

It was a mix of sorrow and regret.

I had a fine high school basketball career, but it never felt like I truly played at the level I was capable of - and like I’d left something out there on the court.

By the look in my coach's eye, we were silently in agreement on the statement above, and I think he felt some guilt (although I don’t offer him any of the blame).

Knowing that you could’ve done better and that you squandered an opportunity to display your gifts to the world is one of the worst feelings there is.

It can be as simple as an awkward interaction with someone you respect or as big as dedicating years of your life to a project and never seeing it come to fruition.

But as I think more about this situation now, I genuinely think that it’s the best thing that could happen to you.

That feeling will light a fire inside of you.

If you carry that flame into your next project, your relationships, and your general approach to life, you begin to become a light.

Your underlying goal is now to express your true, genuine self.

When you do your best to represent that version of yourself, you’re no longer robbing the world of your unique gifts.

Getting kind of spiritual here but I hope you’re still with me and can resonate with this a bit.

Don’t run off the court feeling like you could’ve done more.

Don’t walk away from a relationship feeling like you didn’t adequately represent yourself.

And don’t take your last breath wondering what could’ve been if you had just approached your life with a true effort to do your best.

Thanks for sticking with me here and as always, let me know if this one hit.

Ben

P.S. Watch my recent podcast here​

​

subject: Holidays are for women children and wagies
content:
Merry belated Christmas.

Not gonna lie I’m kind of excited for the Holiday season to be over and to get back into the natural swing of things.

To me, it’s always felt like Holidays are just for people who hate their normal lives and want to soak up their annual two-week break from reality.

Maybe I’m just a grumpy asshole, but I like my normal reality.

I went to the dentist for the first time in a while today, and he was asking about my business.

There’s an art to being able to describe what you do to people who are not in your world.

I explained how I run marketing for people who sell coaching and information online.

To help him understand, I told him that if he were to get on social media and make educational videos about how he started his practice, he would naturally garner an audience of people who would pay to learn more from him.

He then understood. And I had no cavities, so that was pretty cool.

The online education industry still blows my mind sometimes.

Nearly anyone who has acquired any niche skill has the capability to share their story on social media and find people who are willing to spend hundreds or thousands of dollars to learn from them.

With the boom of short-form content, it’s never been easier to start making minute-long videos from your iPhone, and *boom* now you have a potential seven-figure business.

This is the situation for every single one of my clients.

We’ve been working with a client who buys small local businesses.

It’s a much more complicated process than I’ll make it sound here, but basically, he has a system that allows anyone with a stable income and some money to invest to acquire a “boomer” business that cashflows around 6-figs per year right off the bat.

The process of finding a type of business that’s a good buy is the most complicated part, but once an acquisition is complete, he can operate the business remotely and only spend about an hour per week on each business, making sure nothing catches on fire.

He started making content on social media, and just months later, we’re doing multi-six-figure months, and he’s got dozens of successful students.

There’s no real lesson here today, but I just wanted to make it clear how simple it can be to launch and scale an online education company.

I’ve got something coming for you soon if you’re someone who is building this type of business or something similar, so be on the lookout for my emails over the next few weeks.

Let’s hit the gas and build a life in 2024 where you don’t have to “look forward to the Holidays” because your whole life feels like a Holiday :)

Thanks for reading my words today. Let me know if you liked this one.

Ben

​

subject: 4 traits that *might* correlate with success
content:
I’ve been in the online marketing space for about three years now.

Throughout this time, I’ve met a lot of people who were trying to “make it” as entrepreneurs. Some completely failed, some stagnated, and others have been on par with the same level of success I’ve seen or have found financial success quicker than me.

Obviously, there are unicorns, but for the most part, intelligence doesn’t seem to play a huge role as long a baseline level of competence is established.

It’s similar to being a professional athlete – at the highest levels, everyone is a “freak” athlete. It’s the minimum standard, and generally, the intangibles are what separates the good from the great.

Here are a few of the less tangible traits I see in my more successful friends (which those who stagnate or fail seem to lack):

1. Ingenuity & craftiness: In the world of entrepreneurship, rules are meant to be broken, loopholes are meant to be found, and the lines between what works and what doesn’t are blurred.

There’s a proclaimed “right way” to find success, and then there's the way that actually works for you.

Creativity and persistence will (sometimes) take you much further than blindly following a “proven system” that other people tell you to.

2. Discipline & the ability to create order in chaos: Freedom causes most people to lose their minds. When you’re accustomed to being told what to do, what to think, and where to be, having to tell yourself those things is a big adjustment.

Build a system for yourself that works for you. Again, it doesn’t have to be what other people are doing as long as it puts you in an environment and mental space that allows you to do what you need to do.

3. Comfortable with the unknown: Eventually, you come to the realization that no matter how much you plan, no matter how hard you try, and no matter how badly you want something to happen, you are not in complete control of the outcome.

Certainty makes us feel safe. And if you’re too attached to that feeling of safety, go get a desk job and a 401k. Or prepare to always have a voice in the back of your head that thinks everything is gonna crumble at any given moment.

Bonus trait 4 - The gut feeling paradox: There’s a balance between listening to signs from the universe that tell you that you need to make a change versus jumping from one shiny object to the next.

Sometimes, when things don’t feel right, it’s a sign that you need to make a change.

Other times, when things don’t feel right, it’s a sign that you’re on the cusp of something great if you can power through that feeling.

This is a constant game. I don’t have any advice on how to navigate it because truthfully, I don’t know if anyone does.

I guess that brings us back to trait #3, huh?

Alrighty, hope you liked this one. Keep pushing these next few days and build momentum going into 2024.

Happy hump day, let me know if you read this whole thing <3

Ben

P.S. If you still haven’t watched my recent YouTube video, go here plz.​

​

subject: How to fail in 2024
content:
“Here’s how to make your goals come true in 2024!!!”

I hate the sentence above because everyone is using this angle to sell their stuff right now.

So, this email will be about why you won’t accomplish your 2024 goals.

Most people will probably tell you to write out your goals and reverse engineer the steps you need to take to get there.

If you want to make $100k/month, figure out how many clients you need, and then figure out how many outbound messages you need to send daily to book calls with potential clients, given your close rate.

And now boom, you have the goal to “send 30 messages per day.”

It’s a sound system and something I’ve used over the years.

But as I think about times when I felt stuck or fell short of my goals, it wasn’t because I couldn’t devise a simple plan like the one above.

It was because the execution of those actions was harder than it looked on paper.

I’d wake up on January 1st and think, “Ah shit, I told myself I was gonna start this thing today… ok, let me scroll through TikTok first.”

By the time I’d get around to attempting to complete whatever task was at hand, my focus was horrible, and I couldn’t muster up the discipline to actually sit there and do it.

I objectively was in a situation that I didn’t want to be in.

I knew the steps I needed to take to change.

But actually doing them felt like I was attempting to lift up a Ram TRX with my pinky finger.

Why is this?

Inaction can be caused by a plethora of factors, but here’s one I used to face:

I was scared to raise my standards because I knew the further I got from the bottom, the harder it would be to go back.

There’s a lot of comfort in stagnation.

Even though I was telling myself I wanted to change, I could see that the road to my destination was filled with potholes and dead ends.

I was gonna have to become somebody that I wasn’t presently – and that’s a painful experience.

And you know what’s less painful?

Turning on the TV and watching another episode of South Park because after all, being a normie doesn’t sound THAT bad.

This mental battle was a constant dilemma I faced every time I tried to start something new.

If this sounds familiar to you, here’s my advice:

Drop everything that you tell yourself you want, and accept the fact that you weren’t born to do anything special.

Deal?

No…?

Fine - If that advice doesn’t sound like something you want to do, then stick with me.

All you have to do is dive in.

When the cold water hits your body, you’re gonna want to get out.

You’re gonna think of a thousand different reasons as to why you should get out, why Ben’s advice is stupid, and why it’s not the right time.

Don’t listen to the voices for long enough, and you’ll get over the flinch.

On the other side of the flinch, you’ll find that the things you were scaring you are actually not that scary.

The monsters under your bed look more like teddy bears and less like Dracula.

And maybe you’ll learn to love the cold, uncomfortable, unchartered water.

Just don’t bitch out. Simple.

Hope you enjoyed my anti-self-improvement turned self-improvement email.

Love ya,

Ben

​

subject: finally back 2 work!
content:
I'm stoked for the new year.

Mainly because all of the tourists will leave Miami today and my morning coffee walk will be far less crowded.

Back to the natural swing of things we go.

I crawled out of bed at noon today and saw a text asking me if I wanted to speak at a Mastermind later this month.

Truthfully I don’t like public speaking. Shit makes me nervous.

I immediately started thinking of excuses I could come up with to get out of it.

Maybe I’ll plan a trip that weekend so that I have a legitimate reason to say no.

Or perhaps I’ll say my dog ate my computer and I can’t make the PowerPoint presentation. Or maybe I’ll start licking door handles and kissing homeless people so I can be sick that day.

Ugh.

As my conscious thoughts run through a variety of excuses, I have a feeling in my stomach that tells me that I have to say yes.

This is a common occurrence among the things we don't want to do.

It can be as simple as when someone invites you to dinner, and you initially try to say no, but somehow you get roped into going.

Then you end up having a good time, and you're glad you went.

But our ego wants to protect us. It wants to talk us out of putting ourselves in any position where there’s an opportunity to look like a fool or be challenged in any way.

I could get up there, start my presentation, and forget how to pronounce my own name and lose my ability to speak english.

Imagine I do the whole thing in Spanish and no one understands it.

But in reality — detached from the fragile, overbearing ego that’s inside of all of us, I know that it’s an experience that’ll be good for character development in the movie that I star in inside my own head.

And the last email I wrote to you was literally about how getting over “the flinch” is all you need to be successful.

So that’d be extremely hypocritical of me to bitch out because I’m nervous.

If there’s one thing I want you to take away from my rant today, it’s this:

You have conscious thoughts that your ego feeds you as a protection mechanism.

And then you have your gut feeling.

Learn to decipher the difference between the two when you’re making a decision, and it might lead you to experiences that are necessary for your development.

Or you’ll embarrass yourself and never listen to me again.

Happy New Year,

Ben

​

subject: How to make $100k per month by doing everything wrong
content:
My agency website is quite horrible.

​You can look at it here.​

It’s almost been a year since I last revised it, and we have loads of client results that I’ve been too lazy to compile.

I can’t remember the last outbound DM I sent to a prospect, and just spent 4 minutes looking for one before giving up.

It’s been months since I last tweeted about what we do, and I’ve never done one of those corny auto-dm tweets in order to get new prospects.

We communicate with most of our clients through iMessage, I don’t really have any SOPs (standard operating procedures), and if it weren’t for the basic Notion doc I use to plan my days, I’d completely forget what needs to be done each week.

I am the epitome of most things that people tell you what not to do in order to scale an agency.

Yet we’ve been consistently doing over $100k per month, whereas most ‘agency experts touch $20k per month one time and jump into coaching.

This is a result of a few fundamentals that we seem to have gotten right:

- Client results

Results create happy clients, and happy clients create referrals. This one’s simple, so I won’t spend too much time here.

- Clear idea client avatar

We’ve become quite strict on the type of business for which we can provide the best work.

If a prospect comes to us wanting a funnel, webinar, VSL, or email list management, yet they have little traffic and a minimal email list, we do not pitch them.

We usually refer them to a friend who can help them with their organic content or simply give them pointers on how to build their audience.

They sometimes end up coming back months later after they’ve taken the steps we gave them on the call.

- Personal brand & network

If you go to my Twitter or TikTok, there is proof that I am a real human doing real things. It’s also clear that I’m not another self-proclaimed “expert agency owner” who regurgitates the same three talking points.

This makes it so people develop a bit of a relationship with me and my idealogy before we ever get on the phone.

I’m telling you all this in order to show you that many things you may think you need to find success are often a facade.

Whether you run an agency or a completely different type of business, your success often boils down to a few key factors.

Once you understand what those factors are, double down on them rather than wasting time trying to find the next magic pill that will carry you to the promised land.

Repeat successful actions, and success becomes inevitable.

Let me know if you liked this one,

Ben

P.S. I’m making another YouTube video this week. Reply and let me know if there’s anything you’d like me to talk about in my next video, and click here to watch my most recent video.​

​

subject: No Half Measures
content:
Have you ever thought about what your life would be like if you gave it your all?

I’m not referring to the lies that you tell yourself about how hard you’re working, how you just need some more guidance, how things are good enough as they are, or how one day you’re gonna do it.

But truly.

What type of person would you become?

How high would your standards be for yourself?

What would your life look like?

If you can read the questions above and picture the exact life you’re living right now, congrats. You’re doing it right.

But if you’re like me – and like most people, you know in your core that you’re not even scratching the surface of your potential.

Even if things are good.

Hell, that’s honestly more dangerous. You get some money, a fun lifestyle, a girl or 10… it’s easy to throw in the towel and feel like you’ve won.

And maybe you have won by most people’s standards.

But you know that it’s not complete. It’s not even close.

That doesn’t sit right with you. So even though you’re “living the dream,” that voice in your head doesn’t go away.

It’s the same voice you heard when you felt compelled to start a business or make any life-altering change.

It eats you up silently.
You suppress it and tell yourself false narratives and stories in an attempt to remove its power.

Perhaps it works temporarily.

But on a long enough time horizon, you just can’t seem to shake it.

Eventually, you’ll be left at a crossroads where you have to decide whether or not you’re going to quench those urges and step into the reality that you know is possible for you.

Or continuously attempt to fool yourself and risk sabotaging your life in the process.

After all, the only way to ensure that you’re rarely disappointed is to do your best.

As long as you do that, there will never be “what ifs.”

Sure, things won’t always go your way. But you’ll sleep knowing you did everything in your power with the resources you had on hand.

You’ll find peace in the fact that you actually fucking tried.

You get one shot at this. Don’t half-ass it.

Alright even motivation, can we stop saying “Happy New Year” now?

It’s the 4th. Nobody was saying Merry Christmas on NYE.

I hope this made you feel some fire in your soul if you made it all the way down here, and if it did, you’ll probably like this too.​

Happy 4th day of the new year,

Ben

​

subject: Keep it simple, stupid
content:
After waiting 8 minutes and 27 seconds for the elevator, I threw in the towel and took the stairs 30-something floors down from my apartment.

I’m refraining from telling you the exact floor in case someone has infiltrated my email list to gather information and rob me.

If that's you, you’re gonna need backup.

I have nothing to write to you about today and was hoping that sitting down at this cafe would give me a surge of creativity.

I’ve grown to hate the word “value.”

It makes me think of minute-long Instagram reels with yellow captions and tweets that contain the words “here’s how” and a ball of yarn emoji.

Everyone is talking about the same shit over and over.

“9-5 is evil, college is a trap, you have to escape before it’s too late… Become an appointment setter!!!”

It’s no secret that you can go to YouTube or spend some money on courses to learn just about any way to make money online.

The abundance of information has made it incredibly easy to build a business while simultaneously making it more difficult.

There are simply too many options.

If you don’t have the discipline to stay locked in on one thing, you’ll jump from one business to the next for eternity.

Everything is so simple when you just focus on the basics:

1. Learn how to provide a service or build a product that solves a problem for other people.

2. Find a mechanism to get clients or customers.

That’s it.

Repeat that process a bunch of times, and then you no longer have to look at price tags.

I’ve grown to believe that you cannot develop into the highest version of yourself until you’re in complete abundance financially.

When you have to worry about menial expenses and constantly chase cash, it distorts your lens of reality.

Your broke “life coach” has two motives. First, they need to keep you as a client. Second, they want to help you just enough but not too much so that you’re “fixed” and can leave.

Sorry, I’m rambling here.

Last thing I’ll share today:

I’m opening up a small consulting group exclusively for people on this email list.

It’ll be fairly expensive and isn’t for complete beginners.

But it should be pretty dope and “VaLuAble” for people who are in the online coaching space, run agencies, or simply want to chat with me on a more intimate basis (no homo).

If you’re interested, just reply to this email and let me know so that I can have Russian hackers send you a phishing link and steal your credit card info.

I know this one was a bit all over the place, so thanks for sticking with me {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Happy Monday,

Ben

P.S. I’ve condensed my best tweets into my “highlights” section if wanna check them out here.​

There’s some gold in there. But also a lot of nonsense and stuff that I’ll probably cringe at in 3 months. Such is life!

Okay, bye love u.

​

subject: How we accidentally made $3.5M in 9 months
content:
I just knocked out most of the client work I had for the day as I sit here in a crowded coffee shop in the middle of Brickell.

I’m drowning out the noise in here with a random Spotify playlist blasting in my headphones.

The song “Sweater Weather” came on a few minutes ago. Absolute banger.

Anyway, I've got a good one for you today (I think).

I’ve never publicly shared a ton about the ins and outs of how we’re scaling our clients' info-product businesses because it’s always felt a bit boring.

Honestly, scaling a coaching program or course business to $500k/mo+ is shockingly simple.

I know that may sound like a crazy amount of money, but here are some of the main things I’ve learned about how we got there *by accident.*

- Traffic solves all. You can have the best offer in the world, pay me $20k to build out your funnels, and hire Jordan Belfort as your closer. But none of it will matter if you don’t have eyeballs.

- If you can’t crack organic content, you should probably get a 9-5. Seriously. If you have something to sell and you’re unable to get attention on the internet in 2024, you should be an accountant instead. The entire multi-7-figure business I’m writing about was built off of short-form content.

- Do not forget to build your plane while you’re flying it. Because these businesses scale so fast, there’s a lot of added complexity to the product and fulfillment side. If you neglect the customer experience, you will crash and burn on a long enough time horizon.

- Systems only matter at scale. We neglected a lot of the optimizations and organizational aspects of the business until we were already making multi-6-figs per month. Until then, we only focused on more traffic, more webinar registrants, and more booked calls.

- There is no secret sauce. I can’t emphasize this enough: Build offer, get attention. Build offer, get attention. Build offer, get attention. Fix everything else later. The degree to which you can scale is dependent on your ability to consistently bring more people into your funnel who know, like, and trust you.

Enough writing for today.

I hope this helped you in some way, and if it didn’t, thanks for wasting some time with me.

By the way, there were a lot more people than I anticipated who replied to my email yesterday about the consulting group that I’m opening up.

I’m still mapping out the details in my head, but I’ll have more info for you soon.

Thanks for chatting with me today.

Talk soon,

Ben

​

subject: Time freedom is a trap
content:
Sometimes I get lazy.

I procrastinate.

Tasks that should take 3 minutes to complete end up taking weeks because I put them off for so long.

On the contrary, I’ve had periods where I’m super locked in and productive.

After I dropped out of college, I spent the following 3 months in Mexico.

I’d wake up early every morning, hit the gym, bike home, take sales calls, spam more prospects, check in with my clients, write copy, and make content.

There was no room to be lazy.

If I skipped one thing, everything else would fall apart.

The whole “time freedom” fantasy is a bit of a trap.

Not having any obligations sounds great in theory, but if you don’t have the discipline to fill your time with productive activities that help you generate momentum, you’ll fail.

Think about these three instances:

Guy quits his job.

Kid drops out of school.

Girl breaks up with guy.

Each of these usually acts as a catalyst for a big life change – either positive or negative.

All the time and energy that was spent working, studying, or reminding your girlfriend to drink water is now freed up.

Some people replace those things with a structured routine, and others don’t.

Most cannot handle freedom.

But obviously, this is all paradoxical because too much structure makes you a dork, and too much freedom makes you lazy.

Here’s what reminded me of this concept:

Last night, I ordered a cheesesteak on Uber Eats.

This isn’t just any cheesesteak.

Imagine God himself transmutes into a hard-working (likely Mexican or Cuban) man who sets up a ghost kitchen on Uber Eats called “Chef Pepper.”

As I waited for Liana to weave through traffic on her motorbike to deliver my order, I remembered that the last thing on my long to-do list for the day was to make a YouTube video.

I’d already had a busy and productive day, so why not see if I could knock out a video in the 10 minutes that I’m waiting here?

I set up my iPhone camera and started yapping.

7 minutes and 19 seconds later, I had a semi-coherent ramble that I had enough confidence in to upload on the World Wide Web.

​(you can watch it here btw)​

Funny how that works, huh?

I’d procrastinated for 27 days since making my last video, but once I entered a race against a cheesesteak, I was able to knock it out in less than 10 minutes.

Pressure spurs you into action. If you’re not competing, you’re likely stalling.

Even if it means you have to find creative ways to jumpstart your productivity.

Happy hump day,

Ben

P.S. Don’t forget about my YT video​

P.P.S. I’ll be opening consulting spots in one of my next few emails. Keep an eye out if you don’t want to miss it (thanks for your patience).

​

subject: Stop avoiding punches
content:
I’ve been boxing for the last few months and sparred with a guy yesterday who was way better than me.

It felt like every time I’d throw a combo at him, he’d counter with some shit I was completely unprepared for.

Even my jabs would rarely make contact.

By our 4th round, I was mostly just trying not to get hit.

Instead of continuing to attack, I became reactive.

I tried to guess what he would throw next rather than being focused on my own game.

As I ran around like a chicken with its head cut off, I looked up at the clock and saw that there were only 32 seconds left in the round.

“Thank God,” I thought to myself.

But those next 32 seconds were the longest of my life.

It felt like 32 minutes.

That’s a feeling I haven’t experienced in a while.

Remember in school when you’d tap your pencil on the desk, waiting for the clock to hit 3pm?

Those last 30 minutes before the bell rang felt like an eternity.

Yesterday’s sparring session made me think about the dangers of trying to play against the clock.

You’re not trying to win.

You’re not improving.

And you’re not present.

You’re simply trying to hang on for dear life until it’s over.

That’s not a winning recipe in the ring, and definitely not a way to live your life.

You want to anticipate, play offense, and create opportunities for success to find you.

Instead, most people are constantly in a reactive state:

They hate their job, are obsessed with other people, and just trying not to mess up too badly or piss anyone off while they’re here.

It’s the same thing when you’re in a destructive relationship, and you’re just waiting for your partner to do something bad enough so you can justify leaving.

Or as an entrepreneur, you don’t give your full effort and push off problems that need to be dealt with.

Eventually, that comes back to bite you, and you have to react to a tsunami of issues that you created.

Don’t spend your life scrambling for answers and trying to wait out the clock.

Make shit happen. Play offense.

If you’re gonna be here, you might as well make the most of it.

TGIF (every day is Friday),

Ben

P.S. Watch my recent YouTube video and leave a comment if you’re not fake.​

P.P.S. The Bader Group is opening soon.

If you’re in the info-product space, you’re a freelancer, agency owner, bad bitch, or simply someone who likes my content and wants to make a 4 figure donation to me monthly, this might be for you.

We’ll have fun. And you might learn a thing or two.

Details soon. <3

​

subject: What would you do if you lost everything?
content:
Before I get into today's message, quick update on the consulting group I’m putting together:

To be quite honest, I’ve been going back and forth on the idea, debating whether or not it’s the right time.

But if you’ve been reading my emails for a while, you’ve probably heard me say the “perfect” time never comes.

I decided to take my own advice.

This week, I’ll be launching “The Bader Group.”

Once launched, the application window will be open for a few days, and then I’ll close the doors for a bit.

More details on the way in future emails.

That being said, let's get into it…

I often think about what I’d do if I lost everything.

Bank account gets wiped clean, housekeeper steals my watches, and all my clients drop me.

This thought honestly excites me more than it scares me.

I could throw in the towel, sell the rest of my possessions, and move back home with my parents.

Or figure out a way to make money fast so I can uphold the lifestyle I’m living right now.

Let’s pick the latter.

If I still had my personal brand, network, and skillset, I’d be absolutely fine.

It’d probably light a fire under my ass to go 10x harder than I am right now.

The three assets I mentioned above are the ultimate safety net.

Once acquired, it’s nearly impossible to go broke.

But one thing I realize as I think about this hypothetical situation is that my next move becomes rather obvious.

If I needed money fast, I’d start pitching people on Instagram and Twitter. I’d sell anything I could to my audience. I’d find ways to help my friends in their businesses.

And because I’d be on a real-life clock against time, I know I’d be absolutely relentless.

Take a second now to think about what you’d do in this situation.

Who can you go to for help?

What’s the easiest way you can make an extra $10k?

What value can you provide to other people?

When you picture yourself in this predicament, you may realize that the solutions you come up with could be implemented right now.

If you feel like you’re stuck or you’ve stalled out at a certain income threshold, odds are you’re just not being resourceful enough.

Maybe you’re a bit too comfortable, and although you tell yourself you want to progress, your desire doesn’t outweigh the pain of change.

This leaves you with a few options:

1. Do nothing and stay in this constant state of unease where your actions don’t meet your desired reality.

2. Do nothing and accept that you are comfortable where you are, even if you’re selling yourself short.

3. Act like you just donated your livelihood to a stripper and get back to work with a newfound ferocity.

The choice is yours – Just some food for thought.

Talk to you tomorrow {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Ben.

P.S. Watch my recent YouTube video here.​

subject: do not join
content:
My least favorite part of my day is the time spent twiddling my thumbs, waiting for the elevator.

If that’s the worst part of my day, I’m pretty lucky, huh?

I’m on my 5th coffee shop since moving to Miami 15 months ago.

This means I’ll frequent one place every day for roughly 3 months, randomly get sick of it one day, and start going somewhere else.

I’ve noticed this desire for periodic change as a trend in many other areas of my life, including those that bring more consequences than a slightly different-tasting latte.

Over time, things just seem to get dull if you’re not iterating – business, relationships, habits, lifestyle, environment, etc.

Oh wait real quick before I continue…

If you subscribed to this list yesterday to apply for my consulting group, you can go here to do so.​

If you applied and I haven’t gotten back to you yet, I will shortly.

Anyway, back to what I was saying:

I think this habit of switching things up once you get bored can be both good and bad.

You see people like Hormozi talk about doing one thing over and over for a very long time.

I know he has like $100m’s or whatever but that sounds boring.

Gym, work, missionary with Leila, gym, work, missionary with Leila, gym, work, missionary with Leila.

Actually, do you think she– never mind, I’m being rude.

Variety gives life flavor.

It broadens your perspective.

You learn what you like and what you don’t like.

You try out different lifestyles and business models and voyage on different side quests.

A man goes and gets what he wants. And then sometimes realizes that he didn’t actually want it once he has it. But at least he knows now.

To me, it’s at the point where you’ve tried everything and quenched the majority of the desires that you actually have the perspective to say –

“Okay, here’s the way I want to live the rest of my life.”

Adults vaping has to be one of the most cringe things I’ve ever observed.

Sorry to get sidetracked here, but I just saw a woman who looks like her name is Susan tilt her head back and blow a fat cloud into the air as if she’s smoking hookah at a club.

I guess I’m an adult too, and I do occasionally vape, but I don’t act like I’m Rick Ross in a sea of large women while sitting at the coffee shop.

And I’m not a 30-something-year-old woman.

I know today's email has been all over the place, but I’m doing this to ensure you that my list will not become an “escape the matrix, gain remote freedom” sausage fest now that I’ve opened consulting.

I frankly do not care if you join, but it’s here if you want it :)​

Gonna go smack this vape out of Susan's hand.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. If you’re newer here and were hoping for super in-depth information about how I run my agency and how we scale our clients' offers to half a million per month, this might not be for you.

Every now and then, I’ll give specific business advice, but most of these emails are little rants and observations I find interesting.

Too many people become carbon copies of big gurus when they take the “give value” approach, and I never want to be one of them.

Stick around if you’d like, and maybe you’ll enjoy it <3

​

subject: Is selling an info product immoral?
content:
Question for you:

Would you kill 1,000 terminally ill people to save 50 healthy children?

What about 10,000 to save 100?

What if you knew one of the children would go on to cure cancer?

This is a tough one for me. Sure, the terminally ill people are likely gonna die soon anyway, but that’s a lot of blood on your hands.

This is the way I see the majority of the info products on the market.

Most people will fail.

As an education business scales, a few things happen that start the degradation of their client success rate.

First, they start selling to beginners and idiots.

Oftentimes, if you want to get to $300k/month+, this is the only way to do it (although there are anomalies).

And naturally, when the quality of your customer decreases, so does the effectiveness of your product.

They buy courses and never open them. They ask for a refund or chargeback after doing 1% of the work.

These are the terminally ill. They were never gonna make it anyway. And you’re better at spending their money than they are, right?

The second reason success rates decline is because it’s fucking difficult to manage hundreds (or thousands) of customers.

Many won’t get the support they need unless they proactively seek it out.

Plus in some situations, teaching a large batch of people the same methods to start a business can make those methods less successful.

Does this make selling info products immoral or evil?

Here’s the flip side:

Let’s say 100 people buy a course that teaches them how to start a marketing agency.

95 people give up after a few months and lose the few hundred or few thousand dollars they’d spent on the course.

But 5 people actually commit to building this business.

6 months to a year later, they’ve completely changed their lives. They’ve quit their 9-5s, dropped out of college, and paid off their parents' medical bills.

Fast forward a few years, and one of them has amassed millions of dollars.

That person now employs a dozen people, supports their family, and inspires thousands of others online.

So, was that worth it?

Sure, a little blood was spilled, but think about all the good that came out of it.

And after all, who are we to be judges of morality?

If you read this far, hit reply and let me know what you think.

Two last things for you:

1. Enrollment for my 1-on-1 & small group consulting is closing in a few days.

​Go here to apply before the deadline on Sunday.​

2. Internet Kids clothing is back.

​Check it out here.​

Good chat today my friend,

Ben

​

subject: I paid $20k for this advice
content:
I’m in a coaching program by a guy named Jeremy Haynes. I pay about $20k per year to be in the group.

He hosts a quarterly mastermind at his house in Miami, where he’ll have a handful of speakers talk about a variety of topics and give a presentation of his own.

If you were reading my emails earlier this month, you may remember me saying that he invited me to speak.

I gave my presentation this morning.

Here are some things that I found interesting from giving my own talk and some of the other speakers today:

- Most of the time, you’ll be glad you said “yes” to doing things you initially felt resistance towards.

Whether it’s a business opportunity, speaking at an event, or saying yes to the voice in your head that tells you to go up to the pretty girl.

The more you can overcome that resistance, the more it loses its power, and you’ll laugh that you were ever nervous.

- You do not need to be back against the wall to find motivation. You need to manufacture internal dialogue that tells you to make more money.

It’s easy to be inspired when you have no other options. But as you find success, you need to move out of “survival mode,” and your vision needs to get bigger.

Set goals and envision a lifestyle that gives you a reason to make more money – especially if you have enough money to live comfortably for the next 3 years sitting in your checking account.

- Your current reality is a lagging indicator of your previous actions and habits.

The future version of you 6 months – 1 year – and 10 years down the line is the result of what you do today.

Figure out what you want that future to look like and reverse engineer the daily actions you need to take to make it inevitable.

The three lessons above may sound basic or elementary to you, but most of the time, we don’t need revolutionary new advice.

We need to be reminded of the fundamental elements that lead to success and we need to actually practice them.

These masterminds always remind me how small I’m playing and how much further I have to go.

If you feel an equal need to get substantially richer, the application for my 1-on-1 and small group consulting is closing tomorrow.

No pressure and no fake scarcity, but this is one of your last chances to apply before our calls start on Monday.

​Go here now to learn about The Bader Group.​

I’m exhausted so apologies for the lack of personality in this one, but hope you liked it.

Need moor monies,

Ben

​

subject: Four lokos and the secrets of the universe
content:
I met a homeless man while restocking on zyns a few minutes ago.

He wasn’t all the way there mentally, but enough to tell me his name was David and make some small talk that didn’t necessarily confide within the usual “weather and sportsball” chit-chat.

He first told me that God had answered his prayers and that he was going to see his family in 13 days.

We walked towards the back of the rundown 7/11 together to get him a “brew.”

He said he was from New York, and that word was a part of their slang.

In this case, “brew” meant a large gold four loko (which is utterly insane to be drinking casually).

As we made our way back to the counter, he told me that he’d spent 15 years in prison for trafficking cocaine, and it’d been tough ever since.

“I thought I was God, and it was a big mistake,” he exclaimed.

I told him I’d been there (not prison but rather feeling immortal).

It was a refreshing interaction.

Although the cards may not have fallen in his favor, he was in good spirits and seemed excited to enjoy the brew and pack of Newports I’d just bought him.

On my way home, I walked by Myron (fresh and fit guy) and Sneako filming a video.

They’d set up a table and chairs on the street corner with a sign that read “Why women deserve less.”

As I walked by, a bus full of large, screaming women drove past slowly.

It’s one of those 2 story party buses that blasts music through the street.

My friend Mason has coined them the “brokie buses.”

I think we all appreciated the perfect irony as they panned the camera from the “Why women deserve less” sign to the brokie bus full of hippos.

I’m sure that made for good content.

Anyway, I’m excited for the coming week.

Life has a way of reminding you of what you need to hear at the perfect time – if you’re open to receiving it.

It’ll guide you in the right direction when you’re looking for answers and shoot you down when you’re flying too close to the sun.

The more I’ve relied on intuition and divine guidance, the more I see how everything is connected.

Your relationships, work, habits, and even quick interactions with homeless people.

It’s all intertwined and likely relaying an important message if you’re cognizant enough to receive it.

Have a killer week, and don’t participate in drug trafficking,

Ben

P.S. Let me know if you read this one :)

​

subject: Have you been in Vogue?
content:
I forgot my headphones today.

This is one of the many minor inconveniences that come with living in a box 30-something floors up in the middle of a city.

I realized I’d forgotten my headphones the second I got off the elevator.

But at that point, I’d already taken the trek down.

Am I really gonna click the button to go back up, stand there like a wagie, and bobble my head to the non-existent elevator music back up to my room?

No. I’m a man.

However, the crying baby in the coffee shop is making me reconsider this decision.

I think when I have kids, I’ll be out of their lives until they turn 4 or 5.

At that point, I think they’re supposed to be potty trained, and I can start breeding them to go to the NBA.

This is why I like tall girls. We’ll make a bunch of future all-stars and live vicariously through them as I grow old and start taking TRTs so I can keep up with my much younger model wife.

Hahaha.

Speaking of girls, I’ve been reflecting on some things I’ve learned about dating recently.

First, women are amazing.

Nearly every girl I meet is pleasant to be around and has their own unique vibe (if they’re comfortable enough to show that side of themself to you).

Don’t listen to the losers who tell you Western women are ruined.

Sure, not every girl you meet is gonna be a potential wife, and that’s okay.

Understanding this allows you to appreciate them for who they are and simply have fun.

It also gives you a more complete perspective on what qualities you look for in someone you would take more seriously and potentially date.

Next, take it slowwwwwww.

If you scroll through TikTok, you’ll see “dating coaches” say that you need to commit to someone within 1-3 months.

This is absolutely crazy in my opinion. Normalize 6-12 month talking stages. Sometimes longer.

Seriously.

It takes time to get to know someone. There are many things you’ll learn about them that will only come out over time.

Rushing into a relationship is a surefire way that it’ll go up in flames.

And no, this isn’t just a way to keep your freedom and avoid exclusivity.

It ensures that you guys actually know each other before you put a label on it. Because that label will only complicate things.

Little fights turn into UFC matches (not physically, I hope) and if the foundation of the relationship isn’t rock solid, it’ll collapse.

Last thing and most important one.

If you’re a girl reading this, you should stop here. I’m sorry it has to be this way, but it does.

The solution to 99% of your “girl problems” is solved by having…

options.

Lots of them. 3 Barbies, 2 Cinderellas, a Tinekerbell, and maybe a Harley Quinn or 3.

This sounds bad when I say it out loud like this, but I’m doing so for a reason:

Detachment.

Neediness has to be the #1 turn-off for women. And when she’s your only option, she can feel it.

Women are intuitive little creatures. They’re actually harder to deceive than men.

When you’re someone who truly has options, you care less about losing one of them, and it changes your entire demeanor.

You’re not a dancing monkey trying to impress her. You’re you.

They’ll never admit it, but they like a man with options.

Crucify me. But I’m right.

Ok, enough for today. Lmk if you liked my takes on this topic and want to hear more.

Take a pretty model on a date tonight,

Ben

P.S. One of my subscribers suggested I take my old emails and basically turn them into a little blog. Any suggestions or ideas on how to do this (platforms, organization, etc.)?

​

subject: Tend your own garden
content:
It was my 6 month anniversary with my wife yesterday.

We’re not dating, and we break up every three days.

But I was appalled by the absence of “Happy Anniversary” messages I got from my loyal subscribers.

Extremely rude of you {{ subscriber.first_name }}, but I guess we can move past it.

I want to make a documentary called “Normies In The Wild.”

It’d be a compilation of people freaking out while trying to navigate basic human tasks.

Have you ever observed the mid-IQ wagies in airports? Or coffee shops? Merging onto a highway?

It’s like their systems get overloaded, and they revert to monkey brains, where they just start making sounds and looking for bananas.

Anyway, let’s talk about more important things.

Imagine you’re building yourself a car.

You get all the parts you need and spend countless hours configuring your vehicle.

Finally, you’re ready to hit the road.

You hop in and start driving.

At first, it’s great. You’re excited to finally enjoy the fruits of your labor.

But after a few hundred miles, the engine starts making a strange noise.

You pull over and pop the hood.

It’s a minor problem, and you know exactly what you need to do to fix it.

You close the hood and tell yourself you’ll fix it later.

As you continue driving, you see another car and are immediately enamored.

“That’s the kind of car I want,” you think to yourself.

When you get home, you order parts and set out to build it.

Over the next few months, you start neglecting car #1, and the minor problem with the engine has turned into a much bigger issue.

Instead of fixing it, you spend all your time building a new car.

And finally, once your “perfect” car is ready, you hit the road. And the cycle continues. You see a new car you like better, neglect your own, and start all over.

See where I’m going with this?

This is how many of us treat our businesses, relationships, and a variety of other endeavors.

We spend so much time laying the foundation for what could be something special.

But once the novelty wears off and we realize the constant maintenance that’s necessary for continuous progression, we start looking for the "new thing."

Instead of putting our feet on the gas and maximizing what’s in front of us, we let what we’ve built deteriorate so that we can have an excuse to start all over.

It’s a familiar comfort. It allows for the illusion of productivity. But it keeps you stuck.

And don’t you want to find out how far you can go if you can resist the urge to turn your head every time you see a new girl in a red dress?

Water your own plants. Today, tomorrow, and especially in 6 months when it’s no longer as exciting.

Thx for reading,

Ben

​

subject: Don't be dumb, get rich
content:
Fuck it’s only 9:49 am.

I haven’t even been here for 2 hours yet, and I’m already counting down the time until I can leave… Gonna be a long week.

This is how I remember Mondays sitting in class.

Odds are you can relate, and maybe those thoughts are going on in your head as you read this if you’re in school or at a job you don’t like.

Side note: There’s about $600,000 worth of Patek Phillipes on the wrists of the two men sitting across from me at the coffee shop right now.

Let’s talk about money.

Odds are, it’s at the forefront of your mind.

It’s the reason why you’re living the life that you are right now.

Whether that reality aligns with what you want or not is completely on you.

Before I had money, I hated Mondays.

Today, I woke up at 7:31 am, got dressed, and walked over to the coffee shop to knock out some work and write this email.

I enjoy this routine.

My life has gotten exceptionally better as I've made more money, and I’m still relatively poor.

The lesson I have for you today is this:

You owe it to yourself to make money.

You owe it to yourself not to have to think about money.

You owe it to yourself to be able to live wherever you want, with whoever you want, and actualize the lifestyle you dreamt of while you were naive enough to think you could do anything.

And you will never be able to experience the full spectrum of what life has to offer if you’re trapped worrying about expenses.

But I have good news:

Making money is easy.

All you have to do is crack the “money code” once.

Develop a skill set that people are willing to pay you for…

Or learn how to build and sell products…

Or solve some other niche problem for people.

Boom, now you have some kind of value to add to the financial ecosystem that you can sell repeatedly.

Do that until rich.

You don’t have to be exceptionally smart, creative, or ingenious.

You just have to be stupid enough to not be stupid.

Action. Action. Action.

That’s it. Don’t be stupid.

This email is especially simple to prove to you that I am no smarter than you.

All of my friends are relatively rich.

And all of my friends are likey no smarter than you either.

Do not be dumb. Get rich. It’s easy.

Enough motivation for today.

Gonna go do things that will make me money!

I recommend you do the same :)

Ben

​

subject: You are that guy (or girl i guess)
content:
Gm.

When was the last time you thought about how lucky you were to be alive?

I’ve found that I’m usually more grateful in times of stress or when I feel like things aren’t going my way.

It’s these times that force you to zoom out.

You’ll be beating yourself up, feeling like the walls are caving in, and then boom - you have a glimpse of consciousness that puts it all in perspective.

And you realize that your problems are amazing problems to have.

Maybe you don’t want to hear this right now.

Maybe you think I’m turning into a life coach who lives in Bali and makes $3k/mo selling breathwork classes.

But let's just take a second to appreciate what we have.

…

On to today’s lesson.

Developing magnetism in yourself will change your life.

It’s not something you’re necessarily conscious of but rather a byproduct of living your life a certain way.

You know people who seem just to have this special aura about them?

It makes you respect them and want to be around them. They lift your energy and make you feel better about yourself.

Recently, I’ve noticed that people generally perceive me quite positively.

I’ll get random invites to things, girls will pursue me to an extent, service workers love me, and I have absolutely amazing friends in my life.

I’m not saying this to gloat here.

I’ve had times in my life where it feels like I’ve been perceived as the exact opposite of what I just described above.

If I had to boil down what’s changed for me into one word, it’d be this:

Expression.

People like it when they can be themselves. They like it when they know they’re not gonna be judged or used for some ulterior motive.

And the easiest way to get people into this state is to be in it yourself.

When you’re truly you – you say what you want, you’re honest, you’re observant… it creates this genuine look in your eyes and your smile.

People can just sense it.

But this is only developed when you cultivate enough respect for yourself to stop suppressing who you really are.

So let me remind you:

You are uniquely you.

You’ve overcome every hurdle you’ve encountered.

You’ve relied on yourself in times of hardship and uncertainty.

And you got yourself through it.

There's a voice inside you that knows the way.

That trusts you fully.
That accepts you for who you are.

You owe it to that voice to bring it to life.

And when you do – you deserve the world.
