Be you, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Love ya,

Ben

​

subject: Life is working
content:
Sorry for the week-long hiatus, but I’m back.

It’s been frigid the last few days in Miami, like mid 50’s- low 60’s cold.

I’m going to New York tomorrow, and I don’t imagine it’ll be any warmer there.

Such a tough life!

I can’t remember if I’ve told you about one of my friends who works in my building.

He’s a Hispanic dude in his early 40’s but looks much younger.

We see each other nearly daily, and he talks to me in Spanish as I nod and smile in confusion.

I don’t know his name so I call him Papi. I genuinely think he’s the happiest person I know.

Papi always has a smile on his face and just radiates energy that lets you know he’s grateful to be alive.

Yesterday in the elevator I told him I just went to the gym (fui al gimnasio) and was about to get work done (voy a trabajo).

In English he said, “Life is working.”

Papi probably knows a total of 100 words in the English dictionary, but those three together can be quite powerful.

I recently realized that I’d developed a bad habit.

No matter how great things are, I’m constantly pondering every detail of my life – even the things I already understand and have no reason to be stressing about.

“How am I gonna make more money?”

“How is this relationship gonna work out?”

“Why don’t I feel the way I anticipated when I envisioned the lifestyle I’m living now?”

“What do I need to change?”

All I’m doing as I think about these things is reinforcing the idea that there is some future Utopia that I don’t have access to right now.

No bueno.

Most of us need to think less and do more.

You can analyze and reflect once you reach the top of the mountain.

But until then,

Feet on gas.

Head down.

Quiet mind.

Life is working.

Thanks for reading - glad to be back.

Talk soon,

Ben

​

subject: 3 steps to life-maxxing
content:
I saw my ex today.

She’s not really my ex because I never asked her to be my girlfriend, but nonetheless, we shared a lot of time together and many amazing memories.

Seeing her from across the restaurant that we used to go to together was strange.

We waved and briefly said hello as she walked by on her way out.

I got back from a 4-day bender in New York yesterday.

We didn’t do much other than go to dinner and the club with the 20 girls (literally) that we brought, but it was fun for obvious reasons.

My sincere apologies for neglecting you over the last two weeks.

Over the last 6 months, my lifestyle has taken a complete 180.

I barely went out during the first 10 months I lived in Miami.

While I had a circle of a few close friends, I was never the one to initiate the plans or make an effort to find exciting things to do.

After a while, it started feeling like I wasn’t my own person.

I became an extension of my friend group, who lacked his own interests, hobbies, and network.

And most of my nights were spent sitting at my desk with a lit candle and some music in the background, clicking buttons on my computer.

Now, nights like this are rare, and I have an added appreciation for them.

While the work I did during the time when I lacked a social life laid the groundwork for us getting to 6 figure months with my agency, life feels a lot fuller now.

I’m sure there will be a time when I go back to being a bit more of a hobbit, but this work-hard, play-hard lifestyle is much more enjoyable for my current stage.

Here are some of the things I did that allowed me to build a fun social life while continuing to grow my business:

1. Delegation

I sent a $30,000 wire to a team member/friend today.

Bringing him on was one of the best decisions I’ve made.

It’s made it much easier for me, freed up my time, and the quality of work we’re able to deliver has improved.

After all, money is just a number on a screen until you put it to use.

If you’re unwilling to sacrifice some margin, have fun being trapped at your desk all day.

2. Branching out

I went out of my way to make new friends and build a bigger network in Miami.

Once I met one or two well-connected people, it created a snowball effect in my social life.

Outside of just my network, I started to “branch out” by taking up new hobbies, like boxing and tennis.

Finding new interests and hobbies like this helped me reinvent my perception of myself.

This helped reshape my identity and made me feel like I had more exciting things going on in my life.

3. Social media

If you go look at my Instagram toward the end of July, you can see a shift occur.

Even my facial expression and demeanor appear more confident in more recent photos.

I know it may sound superficial, but putting effort into making a better-looking Instagram and posting consistently on TikTok has opened so many doors and brought me a world of connections.

These three things helped me enter a version of myself that I couldn’t access previously.

My lifestyle is exactly the way I envisioned it when I pictured living in Miami.

Although this is just a “side quest” to the main mission (getting disgustingly rich), it’s brought me a lot of clarity and taught me lessons that I couldn’t have learned at my desk.

Cheers to life-maxxing.

Call your ex today,

Ben

P.S. Reply if you read this whole thing and happy early Valentines Day baby <3

​

subject: You create your problems on purpose
content:
The “make money online” info-product space is starting to give me a headache.

Everyone is teaching things that they’ve never done to naive beginners who have a better shot at getting struck by lightning than they do to succeed with whatever business model they’re being sold on.

Am I bitter that some of the people selling these courses are making more money than me?

Yes.

But as you frequently see people do online, I’ll take the moral high ground in order to opt out of feeling envy.

I just want to print cash by writing words in a cafe for a few hours daily.

No fulfillment, no calls, no community.

Just cold hard course content.

Recently, I’ve had 692 things on my mind at any given moment.

I’ve found creative ways to stress about things that don’t need to be stressed about.

You know how sometimes you’ll have days when you’re constantly anxious and feel like the world is ending?

It’s interesting to observe yourself on these days.

You’ll realize that you’re repeating the same negative thought pattern repeatedly.

Whatever you’re thinking about likely only requires a few minutes of consideration, but you let it consume your mind all day.

Next thing you know, you’re super stressed out for no reason.

And it’s almost like you enjoy this stress.

I guess feeling something is better than feeling nothing.

This brings me back to a topic I frequently revisit: Acceptance.

When will you learn to accept what is?

You’re creating problems out of boredom.

It’s like you’re taking out a magnifying lens and analyzing a painting to see if you can find any tiny flaws.

Once you find them, you obsess over them, even though they only account for less than 1% of the entire portrait.

Now you’re distracted.

You can’t focus on what really matters.

You start neglecting the things that you know are good for you.

And now that your attention is scattered, you can’t show up as the full, present version of yourself because a large portion of who you are is trapped inside your own head.

The solution?

Idk. Maybe write an email about it.

Tends to help me.

I hop this one made sense. I have to get on a call and don’t have time to proofread or revise it.

I WILL send you an email tomorrow (maybe),

Ben

​

subject: Dumb = Rich
content:
I’ve been grinding all morning and am now trying to switch my brain back to creative mode to write this email.

This would be a lot easier with a zyn, but I quit (again) 3 days ago.

One thing I’ve realized recently is that everyone is dumb.

Even smart people.

Actually, especially smart people.

All of the rich young dudes that you see on social media are likely no more intelligent than you.

They’re unorganized, naive, and negligent.

The key to their success is simplicity.

They have a few personality traits and skills that allow them to thrive – and they’re dumb enough to double down on those two things.

Yesterday, I was telling a friend how the majority of advice I give to people who are trying to scale their agency or coaching program goes as follows:

Me: “What have you done that’s worked so far?”

Agency guy: “I got 3 clients by sending cold DMs.”

Coaching guy: “I sold 5 people who found me on TikTok.”

Me: “Okay, do more of that.”

Do you see how stupidly simple this is?

But it’s literally the secret.

Find something that works – do it a lot.

The same thing goes for your day-to-day life.

Highs and lows are natural.

I’ll have part of my day where I feel like the world is ending and other parts where everything seems perfect.

I know that I am in a better mental state when I occupy my mind with productive tasks.

The more progress I make, the less stressed I become and the better I feel.

I think the key here is identifying your non-negotiable daily habits that keep you sane.

For me, some of these are writing, making content, journaling, walking, and boxing or lifting.

No matter what, you won’t be in a peak mental state every day – that’s just not realistic.

But if you identify a few things that keep you at least around a 6 or 7 out of 10 each day, and you’re consistent with them, you can decrease the power of the tide in your emotional state.

This email is kind of a culmination of half-baked ideas, but I gotta go meet a friend for lunch, so we’re gonna end this here for today.

Talk tomorrow, thx for reading,

Ben

​

subject: Who are you competing with?
content:
Yesterday, I saw a clip of Johnny Manziel talking about how depressed he was during his first couple of years playing in the NFL.

He said Lebron, who was his childhood hero, would call him a few times a week to hang out, and he’d decline because he didn’t want to leave the house.

Looking at this from the outside in, here’s what I gather:

Once you begin to get the things you want, you gradually internalize that they won’t change anything.

By “things you want,” I don't just mean material items or lifestyle, but also your outward perception.

You can get all the praise, respect, and validation.

You can be the guy other dudes envy and girls want to be with.

This comes with a lot of pressure, which can break you if your self-image isn’t rock solid.

The expectations of others start to weigh on you, and your standards rise to a level that takes a lot to maintain.

If you feel undeserving, you manifest that idea into reality.

Your motivation dwindles, you lack discipline, and you start to let your problems add up.

“You can’t outperform your self-image.”

The weight of the contrast between how others perceive you versus how you perceive yourself causes you to crumble.

That make sense?

Anyway, a guy in front of me at this coffee shop is reading the book “7 Habits Of Highly Effective People.”

He’s mouthing the words as he reads, which I find interesting.

When I walked in to order my coffee, the barista told me she liked my hoodie and replied, “Ben 10” when I told her my name was Ben.

I found that endearing, so I gave her the Van Cleef bracelet off my wrist.

One time, I sat next to Johnny Manziel at dinner (I think I told you about that in an email months ago).

Not long after, he DM’d the girl I was with that night.

Shooters shoot, I guess.

Last thing – Yesterday, I was journaling and asked myself, “What would make your life better than it is right now?”

It was easy to come up with an answer to that question, and I found it interesting that my answer had little to do with more money or anything flashy.

I encourage you to ask yourself the same thing when you have 20 min today.

Thanks for reading, and hope you enjoyed,

Ben

​

subject: Self improvement doesn't work
content:
Spotify and I haven’t been getting along recently.

Sometimes, I’ll hit shuffle and it’ll give me one banger after another.

Other times, it force-feeds me the same 6 songs until my mind goes numb from the repetition.

For the last few weeks, it’s been the latter.

Per usual I’m sitting at an ultra-liberal, hipster coffee shop, hoping that I’ll get a good idea to write about before I bore you.

There’s a bulletin board of post-it notes in front of me with a bunch of Pinterest-esque quotes.

“Be happy! Enjoy 2024”

“You are loved!”

“Smile! Today’s a great day”

Outside the quotes, a combination of people likely identify as “creatives” are promoting their work.

“Need graphics? DM me on Instagram! @arthoe6969”

There are over 100 sticky notes and “business” cards on here.

Plus a lost cat flyer in the top right corner.

In the middle, nearly covered up by the self-love propaganda, there’s a note that says, “Be here now.”

Probably a lesson in there.

Being present is something that’s a constant battle for me.

Two summers ago, I was on a beach in Greece, watching the sunset with a bunch of friends.

Instead of admiring the view, I was stuck in my head, stressing over whatever was happening in my business then.

I remember looking around at my friends and wondering if they were thinking about something else too, or if I was just broken.

Last night, a client of ours ran a webinar (where we made over $100k) and was asked the question:

“How do you deal with stress as an entrepreneur?”

He said, “I don’t… Nothing that I do is stressful,” and moved on to the next question.

As simple as this answer was, I found it interesting.

What you give your attention to grows.

The people who wrote these stupid little quotes on the board in front of me are probably unhappy.

They’re so obsessed with positive affirmations – and fearful of anxiety, that they bring their fears to fruition.

The “self-love” reminders attempt to convince themselves that they don’t hate themselves.

A happy person doesn’t need a reminder to be happy. They just are.

It’s almost like when you’re overly conscious about improving your mental health, it has an inverse effect.

Dictating how you feel can be as simple as making a decision.

Simply decide not to stress over something, stop giving it power, and it goes away.

When my client on the webinar was asked that question, it was like the idea of stress didn’t even exist in his world… he was almost confused.

And, after all, worrying and over-analyzing do nothing but exacerbate the problem.

Maybe the answer is to bE hEre noW!

Corny but true.

I’m gonna start meditating.

Hope you and your Spotify shuffle get along today,

Ben

​

subject: it is what it should be
content:
I got multiple messages today asking when I’d write my next newsletter.

It made me feel bad for neglecting you, so here we are.

My sleep schedule is out of whack after a few late nights in Puerto Rico.

Here’s a thought that’s been rattling around in my brain:

We make decisions based on how we feel in the moment.

If you ask a girl to marry you after a long night of fighting because you told her that her sister is hot, she’ll probably say no.

On the flip side, your chances are much higher if you propose during a romantic dinner on the Amalfi Coast while listening to old Frank Sinatra music.

Similarly, your potential customers must be put into a buying state when you ask them to purchase your product.

That’s why webinars have worked so well for our clients.

Every slide in the presentation is strategically placed to steer them into an emotional high.

They need to feel understood, they need to understand, and they need to believe.

Meaning you’ve demonstrated that you empathize with their pain points and their exact dilemma.

You’ve broken down how your method works, and they’re confident in it being the vehicle that will take them from pain to pleasure.

Lastly, you’ve put them into a state where they’re hopeful they can overcome their previously held limiting beliefs.

And just like that, they’re ready to pull out their wallet when presented with the right offer.

When you want someone to do something, it’s your job to understand how they feel in the current moment.

Even the words on this page are reflective of the current state I’m in.

Switching gears a bit, life is beautiful.

Do not miss it.

Do not take it for granted.

Do not tell yourself something is missing, as you will always find something to look for.

The thing you are looking for is you.

You have the power to bend reality to your will.

A few years ago, I was at a frat party, looking around at everyone happily drinking, and I remember this moment when the lights turned on in my brain.

I had no purpose and was going down a route that would lead me to a lifetime of emptiness.

In that instant, I decided I’d change my path.

Fast forward to now; these past few days have felt like a movie.

I celebrated my friend's birthday with amazing people, took a jet to and from PR, and hopped in my dream car to drive to dinner at Carbone.

It’s all possible, my friend.

And when you get here, don’t forget to enjoy it.

Goodnight,

Ben

​

subject: The opposite of locked in
content:
Happy Friday {{ subscriber.first_name }},

I wrote this one yesterday and forgot to send it once I got to my hotel, so I am sending it now.

Enjoy <3

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I’m on a flight to LA right now.

I land in about 30 minutes and have spent the last 4 hours finding clever ways to procrastinate writing this email.

It started with the usual scroll through social media, but that can only last so long.

So I got creative. I took a personality quiz, changed my return flight, got ahead on some work, and did enough research on LA restaurants that I could write one of those gay “Top 10 MUST TRY spots in LA” blog posts.

Just so you know, I’m in seat 1A. There’s no reason for me to tell you this, but I figured I’d tell you anyway.

Let’s talk about money and identity.

When I first started making some money a few years ago, my mental well-being became entirely reliant on my monthly income.

When I’d hit a new all-time high, I’d be over the moon.

I was more confident, I spoke with conviction, and I generally felt and acted much more positively.

Conversely, when my monthly income stagnated or regressed, I lost all confidence and was in a constant state of panic.

When I’d talk to people, I wasn’t really there. I was physically there, but my mind would drift, drowning out the person who was talking with my own thoughts.

These times were interesting.

This fight-or-flight mode wasn’t pleasant, but I think it helped me progress quicker.

All I thought about was business.

Recently, it’s been the opposite. I honestly don’t know if it’s been a good or bad month for the agency numbers-wise.

We did help a client make $400k in 4 days recently which was pretty cool.

He paid us our commission in crypto, so I threw all that money into a meme coin.

Back to the main point - I’ve been the opposite of “locked in” recently.

Locked out?

Opened in?

Not sure of the correct term.

Everyone loves to act like they’re always working so hard.

This may cause you to feel like you constantly need to be at war, as it did for me.

It also meant my self-image was tied to my income.

While I think that can be a good thing to an extent, it’s a hamster wheel that no amount of money can get you off of.

Sure, if you’re not growing, you’re dying — but growth can come in many forms.

It doesn’t always mean you’re doubling your monthly income or spending 12 hours a day at your desk.

Maybe it means you’re traveling more, building deeper relationships, beating your friend Jimmy in 2K, etc.

Simply side questing.

And know there will be a time when you need to lock back in.

You can’t just coast forever — but sometimes, momentary coasting can help you return to work with an added excitement.

Or at least that’s what I’m telling myself.

I'm about to land and gotta wrap this up, but there is one last thing I want to add…

*Everything I just said does not apply to you if you don’t have enough money to fulfill the immediate image that pops into your head when you think about having money.

For me, that image is the exact life I’m living now.

I imagine for me to find the motivation to push beyond where I’m at now, that vision must evolve.

Ok, I just landed. Gotta go. Missed you, let me know if this one made sense to you.

Bye from 1A,

Ben

​

subject: Why you need to get punched in the face
content:
I just got home from sparring with my boxing coach.

We were going pretty light, though he caught me in the head a few times.

Maybe I’m a weirdo, but it feels really good to get hit in the face.

We’ll be trading punches, somewhat messing around until boom…

I’ll move the wrong way and position my face perfectly into his jab.

There’s this feeling of aliveness that comes after that moment.

It’s like a signal goes through my brain that says, “Okay, time to lock in,” while I simultaneously realize that I’m not going to die.

Immediately after, I enter a new state where I’m much more free-flowing, and my energy is revitalized.

I’m ready to attack because once that first punch connects with my nose, I’m no longer scared of it.

I know I’m gonna be okay no matter what.

There’s an equally powerful lesson in there that we can extrapolate to life.

Sometimes, you have to let yourself get rocked.

When you’re comfortable at a certain income level or have enough money in the bank to where you wouldn't have to work for the next couple of years…

You have to punch yourself.

You’re trying to live comfortably and ignore the possibility that reality could rock you with a right hook if you’re too slow.

Over the last few months, I completed the vision that I’d been aiming at for a while.

My business reached six-figure months, I bought my dream car, my social life was thriving, and I was living in the exact movie that I used to dream of.

After a few months of fun, my anxiety started to increase.

I’m not growing. I’m not evolving or working towards anything.

And admittedly, I started to take my foot off the gas.

This life I aspired to attain began to feel empty, and I was left with the feeling of…

“What now?”

Stagnation served as a punch.

Stay in the same place for too long, and you become predictable.

Become predictable, and you get hit.

But the solution is simple.

You gotta keep moving.

Reach a milestone, great. What's the next level you can get to?

Picture it.

Maybe it’s a house in the hills, more supercars, and the ability to fly private whenever you want.

Or you don’t want to feel an ounce of anxiety on any purchase under 6 figures.

You want a penthouse, your girl wants a Birkin, and you want to put a family member on payroll to do nothing.

Sure many of these are materialistic, but it’s your reality – you can design it however you’d like.

You’ve just begun to taste freedom. You’re not even scratching the surface of how you could live, and you’re getting comfortable.

Don’t rob yourself.

True freedom has no bounds, and the only limits come through your imagination.

Let your imagination run free, and you’ll create a new movie in your head that you aspire to live in.

That's your new goal.

Start building towards it now unless you want to wait until you get knocked on your ass.

And by then, it’ll be a hell of a lot harder to get up.

Thanks for reading, and I promise I’m really back for good this time.

Lmk if you liked this one,

Ben

​

subject: How to manifest without being weird
content:
There are some elements of spirituality that I find rather stupid.

Once upon a time, I hired a “life coach.”

After our first call together, I decided I didn’t need him and would instead take life advice from myself.

He was one of those meditate in Bali, peace and self-love types.

This is loosely related to the topic of this email, but it popped into my head when I started thinking about spirituality.

If manifestation and the law of attraction sound a bit out there to you, I’m gonna try to break down what I believe these concepts to be as simply as I can.

Your subconscious is constantly working either for or against you.

When you set goals and intentions, you give your subconscious a direction to follow.

When you fail to do so, your brain finds another way to occupy itself that likely isn’t conducive to the reality you want to build.

The most simple example of this that I see is in my habits and daily routine.

Making content every day has been a priority of mine for a while.

I’ve noticed I’m the most consistent, and content ideas come to me easily when I’m intentional.

If I write “tweet 3 times” or “make 2 videos” on my to-do list for the day, my subconscious starts to help me out.

I’ll be walking to the coffee shop to get an iced vanilla latte from a blue-haired barista with an Adams apple who calls him(her?)self Megan, and boom – I’ll get a random idea for a video.

Could it be a coincidence?

Sure. But nearly every time I set intentions like this, completing the action becomes easier.

Although this is just one basic example, I hope it’s starting to illustrate the point.

What you focus on and put your attention toward grows, even if you’re not conscious of it.

If you’re obsessed with reaching a new income level, your brain is constantly working on that problem in the background.

You’ll get an idea while you’re driving or doing some other mindless activity, and it’ll be the key to reaching that next milestone you’re aiming for.

You might feel like the idea came out of nowhere, but it’s likely because you’ve given your subconscious something to occupy itself with.

And eventually, it finds the solution.

The same thing goes for anything that you want in life.

If you can create a clear image of the lifestyle, people you’re surrounded by, what you’re doing for work, how your routine looks, and the general way of life you want to build…

And you work towards those things…

The combination of the work and setting intentions will eventually reach a perfect storm and you’ll feel like everything somehow ended up exactly how you wanted it.

The way that your goals unfold likely won’t be how you imagined, but that’s a topic for another email.

Hope you enjoyed this one and it made sense to you.

Happy Friday,

Ben

P.S. I finally compiled my old emails and aded them to this site – you don’t have to opt in over there, just scroll down to view previous newsletters.

​

subject: Angry normies & how dating is like an iceberg
content:
A large corner of the internet is very angry at me right now because of this tweet.​

They’re calling me a scammer posting rage bait to sell my course.

If you’ve been around for a while, you know I don’t have one – although I probably should.

This reaction has been surprising to me as I didn’t think much of the post when I sent it.

The thought was formed while I was in a crowded elevator going up to my apartment.

There was a guy who looked a few years older than me with airpods in and a bag of Chipotle in hand.

He was visibly disgruntled, carrying a black work bag.

When we stopped to let others off on the way up, he spammed the “close door” button, almost shutting it on a few people who were too slow for his liking.

Considering it was a Friday around 5 pm, I imagined he’d just gotten off work after a long, boring week and was eager to get home and devour his burrito on the couch.

I could be completely wrong in my assessment, but I then started thinking about what my life would’ve looked like had I continued on the college, 9-5 route.

And that tweet is what I came up with.

I didn’t mean to attack this life path but rather paint a vivid picture of what I wanted to avoid – who knows if it would’ve actually been my reality.

My Twitter is unusable right now, as every time I refresh, I have dozens of new notifications from wagies who felt attacked by my words.

If anything, they’re proving my point to be true; if they didn’t partially identify with the person I described, they wouldn’t be offended, right?

To me, it looks like they’re trying to defend the lie they’ve sold themselves that they’re happy with an average existence.

I guess every hive needs worker bees.

Anyway, I’ll stop being mean and move on to a completely unrelated topic.

Something that’s been on my mind recently is the difference between short “flings” and hookups compared to longer-term relationships.

Any guy who’s casually dated many girls knows at some point, the game gets a bit too easy.

Although it’s fun, it’s kind of like an iceberg.

You show someone just enough of your personality for them to start to romanticize you.

By nature, you end up saying similar lines, sharing the same stories, and cultivating a particular image of yourself.

You can do this endlessly – revealing a glimpse of your character to new people over and over.

Once you reach the stage where the entire tip of the iceberg has been revealed (pause, no homo), you bounce to the next situationship to do it all over again.

You never give anyone the chance to get to know you past the image you aim to portray.

And there’s nothing wrong with that. Maybe it’s just a phase of life that you’re in, or you’re especially selective about who you spend an extended period of time with.

But if and when you move past the casual fling stage, you realize there’s no longer a place to hide.

Your flaws and insecurities are reflected back to you when you let someone get to know the real you, and that process reveals your self-image.

Fake confidence only lasts for so long, and if there are areas in your identity that you’re not comfortable with, you’ll be forced to make amends with them.

I hope this makes sense to you. I’d go a bit more in-depth, but I just realized that I have hundreds of new subscribers here.

Some of whom are probably ops that were angry at my tweet and will do anything they can to take what I say in this email out of context.

So I’ll let them weed themselves out, and then we’ll continue our regularly scheduled programming.

Anyway, It’s date night with sweet pea tonight!

Can’t wait to try the restaurant and watch our favorite show on the couch!!!!

Hah.

Happy early Easter,

Ben

P.S. If you’re new here, watch this to learn more about me and how I built a 7-figure copywriting business.​

P.P.S. Check out my previous emails here.​

​

subject: The antidote to resistance
content:
I’ve grown to love the peaceful Sunday night at home.

When I was in school, this day was always dreadful.

Monday morning was around the corner and the looming stockpile of work I’d been procrastinating was staring me in the face.

I was just debating whether or not I’d write an email to you today.

There are a million excuses my brain could come up with as to why I shouldn’t.

But then I thought about the feeling I get after completing one of these.

It’s like when the endorphins kick in after a tough workout.

Maybe you didn’t want to do it, but you always feel better once it’s done.

There are many things that we resist even though we know they’re good for us.

If you’re building a business you can likely think of a few off the top of your head.

The boring 30 minutes of outreach.

The long meeting with your sales team.

Or the time spent planning your week to stay on track with your next income goal.

Usually, with tasks like this, the only immediate reward you get is internal.

Going to the gym once won’t add 15 pounds of muscle.

You won’t close a client right after sending 20 DM’s.

And writing this email does nothing for me financially at the moment.

But these things give us that type of dopamine that can only be earned when we know we’re doing something positive for our future selves.

When a goal is accomplished, it’s a lagging indicator that shows you consistently completed those sometimes monotonous actions that yield you next to nothing in the short term.

As I contemplated writing this, I considered how I felt yesterday after I clicked send.

I knew replicating that same feeling would be worth it (plus, I actually enjoy writing these).

So I guess that’s my first piece of advice:

Any time you resist something good for you, think back to how you felt after the last time you did it.

And if it’s something that you’ve never done before, replace that image with anything else you once felt a sense of accomplishment after completing.

If you can’t think of anything, you’re cooked.

But if you can, use it as fuel to complete the task in front of you.

This is how you rewire your brain to crave long-lasting, deserved dopamine rather than cheap, social media-infused dopamine.

It’s like how you view a relationship with someone who is easy to get versus someone you have to work for.

You’re always gonna place more value on the person who’s a challenge because you had to earn it, which shows they value themself.

When you bring a girl home after buying her two drinks and making fun of her shoes, that usually means she isn’t wifey material because if you could do it that easily, so could someone else.

Compared to the more elusive girl, who, although she likes you, wants to make sure you’re really the person you appear to be before she fully trusts you.

And that’s the difference between cheap dopamine and deserved dopamine.

The more you can teach your brain to run toward the hill that’s harder to climb, the better.

Anyway, hope you’re avoiding the Sunday scaries and ready to crush the week.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​Read my previous emails here​

​

subject: indirectly following your passion
content:
Ok, I know it’s probably past your bedtime, but I wanted to talk {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

If you’re reading this in the morning, gm.

I have an important topic for you:

Money.

The way you’re gonna get rich is to find the intersection between what you’re naturally good at/passionate about and what you can make money with.

Sure, you can figure out how to make money with a “passion project” or collect some shekels doing something you hate.

But these two elements are most powerful together.

When I think about the people I know who are crushing financially, their business fits their personality type.

My friend Mason built a multi-seven-figure business by yapping on TikTok and being relatable.

My friend Rob (who is worth many millions) is absolutely obsessed with building brands and actually uses the products he sells.

My Dad has always been a car enthusiast and makes his money flipping cars at auctions.

I was obsessed with basketball growing up and built my first business running ads for basketball trainers.

In school, I always enjoyed writing and built my second business using the skill of copywriting.

In all these examples, we ended up in vehicles that allowed us to make money using our predisposed interests.

Had we directly followed our passion, we’d be in very different spots.

I’m a few decisions away from being a journalist making $50k per year or teaching people how to dribble balls for a living.

If you need some direction, odds are you'll find it in discovering how to use your innate abilities to add value to other people's lives.

To get a bit more practical, if you’re a people person, use your networking skills to connect wealthy people and take a cut of the business they do together.

If you’re organized and good at managing multiple tasks, you can use that skill to be an operator in a company.

If you’re a hot girl, use that to swindle old men into giving you money.

I’d dive deeper into this idea, but I’m getting sleepy, and Glenda (my cleaner) is coming tomorrow morning, so I have to get up early.

Let’s talk more tomorrow, and hope you enjoyed this somewhat inconclusive ramble.

Goodnight,

Ben

​Read my previous emails here.​

​

subject: Decide, commit, act
content:
I’m 37 minutes into an hour-long Tai Lopez rant on YouTube and just clicked pause to write this.

Yesterday, I wrote a tweet about shifting your identity and wanted to expand on it.

It’s long, so it’ll take up the majority of this email, but I genuinely think this is one of the keys to making continuous progress in any realm of life.

Here it is:

The speed at which you progress is dependent on your ability and willingness to shift into a new identity when you complete the vision you were formerly working toward.

When you actualize financial/lifestyle goals, it’s like you’re beating a level in a video game. the next level is an entirely different game, and you’re starting at zero with new obstacles that you’re unfamiliar with.

Sometimes, you may fail or refuse to move to the next level because you’re comfortable with the current level you’re operating at and the problems associated with it.

This is where you get trapped.

Stay in one identity for too long, and your lack of progression starts to eat away at you.

So, you begin to sabotage your current reality because you want to feel like you’re moving forward.

The only way to do that while avoiding a complete shift in your identity is to first move backward and then go back up the ladder you already climbed.

So you’re now spending your time beating the same level of a video game only to click the reset button and start over.

This is the trap of stagnation, where you give yourself the illusion of progress.”

I’ve found that whenever I feel stuck, it’s because I’m simply refusing to step into a new identity.

Perhaps you’ve heard the saying, “The vehicle that gets you to point A isn’t the vehicle that gets you to point B.”

Similarly, the person you are right now has a ceiling.

You can reach a certain level financially, emotionally, and spiritually.

Once you reach the peak of that level, you have the choice to continue progressing or stay where you are.

And change is hard.

This is especially true when that change requires you to discard your previous beliefs about yourself and replace them with beliefs that will suit you in the new arena you are stepping into.

You can spend eons avoiding this and fool yourself into believing you’re making progress when you’re actually sputtering.

But this will only create an internal hell.

You know you’re capable of more, and you’re resisting.

The solution here can be summed up into three words:

Decide, commit, act.

Devise a plan to reach your next level, paint a vivid picture of how this new version of you operates, and execute that plan.

It’s the work you’re avoiding, the habits you’re refusing to develop, and the beliefs that hurt to change.

It’ll be painful, but so will the feeling of staying the same.

And this is the only way through.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​Read my previous emails here.​

​

subject: Your standards determine your reality
content:
We procrastinate on the things we know we need to do most because we are afraid of becoming the person who is capable of doing them consistently.

For the last two weeks, the words “make a YouTube video” have been at the top of my to-do list.

Every day, I wake up and look at that task only to put it off to the next day.

Today, I finally got around to it, and it was a struggle.

Over a dozen takes later, I gave up.

I told myself, “At least you tried,” and turned off the camera to go buy zyns.

As I stood in the hallway waiting for the elevator that was taking obnoxiously long to arrive, I thought about how I still wouldn’t be able to cross that off my to-do list.

Then, I considered how I’d feel if I’d accomplished it.

That’s when I turned around, walked back into my apartment, and made this video.​

And the weight of the unfinished task was finally lifted off my shoulders.

Recently, I’ve been thinking a lot about standards.

It’s your standards that hold the invisible bar for what you believe you are capable of.

Whenever you want to transform into someone new, that bar has to be raised.

We know this, and it’s the reason that we sabotage ourselves.

You’re likely comfortable in the reality that you’re currently operating in.

Sure, you want to improve, but committing to the actions required to do so is a whole lot different than fantasizing about progress and telling yourself you’ll get around to it one day.

So you place a ceiling on yourself and resist anything that forces you to step out of that box because you’d then show yourself that the ceiling is imaginary.

You’re capable of more, and you know it, but you’re refusing to give yourself data to solidify that.

Because then you can no longer be naive, and you have to exit the box of limitations you’re comfortably situated in.

And you’re forced to step into a new identity.

With that new identity comes a reality you’re unfamiliar with.

Challenges you haven’t faced and standards you’re not accustomed to.

It might be easier to stay where you are for now, but that voice telling you to do more won’t go away.

It’ll torture you until you either quench it or suppress it enough to where you’re comfortably numb.

And the light that shines with hope behind your eyes will be gone.

That’s probably not a recipe for a happy and fulfilled life.

Don’t let that light go dim.

​Watch my new YouTube video here :)​

Thanks for reading,

Ben

P.S. Read my previous emails here​

​

subject: Clarity is earned
content:
I’m sitting on my balcony, watching boats go by.

The buildings are lit up, and the city is buzzing.

I have a 10:45pm dinner reservation at Carbone.

My friend Mason convinced me to go to the club after (against my will).

Opportunities are a lot like puzzles.

If you try to build a puzzle by mapping out where all the pieces will be placed, you’ll never start.

You can sit there for hours, thinking about each piece individually and where it will end up.

But if you don’t combine any of them, you’ll never get closer to a finished product.

Similarly, if you try to predict every step you will take to achieve a goal instead of taking step one, you’ll never move closer to the goal.

Simple right?

Although this is an easy concept to grasp, it’s much more difficult to put into practice.

When you feel stuck, the problem is likely because there are too many different directions you could go in.

Obviously, you want to pick the best one, so you sit there thinking about how everything will work out.

This puts you in a state of inaction.

You tell yourself you’ll start moving toward your goals once you have clarity on where to go.

But as you wait for some divine sign telling you what to do, the clarity you’re looking for continues to elude you.

So, you go back to the drawing board and start thinking more.

You can do this for eternity if you let yourself.

But the truth is opportunities are created through action.

You open one door, and the next opens up.

You take the wrong turn, and it reroutes you to the right one.

You must earn clarity.

When you’re lost, it’s because you’re refusing to step on the gas despite the fact that you don’t know where the road you’re going down will lead you.

Do the things that feel right, even if they offer no immediate reward.

Eventually, you’ll end up in a situation where everything aligns, and you find the last piece of the puzzle.

That’s when the road becomes clear, and you can finally floor it.

It starts with step one.

See you at dinner,

Ben

P.S. Watch my new YouTube video here​

​

subject: 5 steps to make more than an investment banker
content:
Happy Monday.

I genuinely think 90% of the people I meet sell info (courses and coaching).

Literally.

I met a 96-year-old woman named Dorthy on my coffee run this morning.

We started talking because she complimented my eyes and told me she hoped her granddaughter would find a guy like me one day.

She then started telling me how she sells a course teaching elderly women how to keep their husbands happy by learning how to bake her special apple pie with a secret ingredient.

The ingredient reinvigorates their marriage and helps them find that spark they felt years ago.

It’s called Viagra.

Dorthy grabbed my arm and asked if I wanted to try it.

That’s when I stole her cane and ran away.

Now, I’m writing this fictitious story to you with Dorthy's imaginary cane leaning up against my desk.

Jokes and fictional stories aside, EVERYONE SELLS INFO.

If you’re a copywriter, I don’t think finding opportunities working with coaches has ever been easier.

All you have to do is:

  1. Become a competent writer and gain a fundamental understanding of how coaching businesses work.
  2. Send loom video pitches on Instagram until you get someone on the phone.
  3. Talk to the potential client and see what they need. Maybe it’s email copy, ad copy, video scripts, VSL scripts, funnel copy, etc. You are a copywriter. That means your skillset is versatile, and you should be able to fill whatever gap they have in their business to get your foot in the door.
  4. Once you close the client, go above and beyond. The bar for service providers is so low that if you simply put in more effort than what is asked, you will be rewarded. They’ll send you referrals, give you a case study, or trust you to operate other parts of their business (meaning you can now charge more + rev share).
  5. Now, you turn a $3k/month client into a $10k/month client.

Complete the process above a few times, and you’ll be making more than the average investment banker at Goldman Sachs.

Plus, you didn’t have to snort Adderal and cheat off your smart Asian friend named Kevin for four years while getting your bachelor's degree.

That’s what I’d do if I had to start all over.

Even if you’re not a copywriter, the process I outlined is basically all you need to do to accelerate your success in any service-based business.

Your skillset gets you in the door, and you decide what happens now that you’re in the room.

If you earn the trust of the right person, one connection could change your life.

Just be competent and over-deliver.

Now you’re rich.

​Thank me by watching this video and leaving a like and comment :)​

Peace,

Ben

P.S. If you’re trying to build a copywriting or “growth operating” business, hit reply and let me know what your biggest roadblock is right now. Building something cool for you.

​

subject: i was wrong
content:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }}, big news…

I ordered a whiteboard.

It comes with a stand, markers, and erasers.

Cool right?

A problem I sometimes encounter when I sit down to write is that I start questioning whether the immediate idea that comes to mind is important enough to warrant an entire email.

As I sit here thinking about where to take this, I’ve probably discarded five ideas.

All of which could have made for a banger email.

But because I don’t feel they’re worthy, I sit here telling myself my mind is blank.

I recently wrote about how your standards determine your reality and that if you want to improve anything, you have to raise the internal bar for what you perceive as acceptable.

I’m now realizing the opposite is also true.

I believe nerds call this a paradox.

(side note real quick – Grammarly fucking sucks. It’s a tool that gives you suggestions on your writing, and everything it tells me to do sounds like it’s attempting to be an off-brand Shakespeare).

Anyway, back to the standards paradox.

Sometimes, if you don’t lower your standards, you won’t do anything.

You want to write the perfect message, make the best video possible, say the right line to the girl, or impress someone you look up to.

The desire for perfection has an inverse effect.

You don’t start, or you filter your thoughts, and you find any excuse not to approach the girl.

This is because the measuring stick is in the wrong place.

Instead of setting an incredibly high bar for the quality of the output, the bar needs to be set for the quantity of the input.

“I need a big idea for this email” becomes “I need to write an email today, no matter what.”

“I need to say the right line to the girl” becomes “I need to walk up and say anything.”

“I need to impress this person” becomes “I need to express myself and say what I’m thinking.”

You’re optimizing for reps instead of trying to protect your ego by being perfect.

Sure, I want to “wow” you with every email I write.

But if I wait until I have a groundbreaking idea every time, I’d be writing once a quarter.

If I make sure to get this done even when I don’t feel heavily inspired, the quality of the output increases in correlation to the input.

That means do more of the thing, and you will get better at it way quicker than you would if you tried to do it perfectly.

There's a Harvard study about this.

Long story short, students in a ceramics class were separated into two groups. One group was told to make the “perfect” clay pot, and the other was told to make as many as possible.

All of the best-looking pots came from the quantity group rather than the quality group.

You should get the point by now.

Be wary not to conflate having “high standards” with a defense mechanism to protect your ego.

Odds are that when you fail to take action, you’re trying to save yourself the embarrassment of realizing that you have some improvement to make.

So does everyone else – and those who improve the fastest are the ones who get the most reps.

Grammarly keeps giving me more dumb suggestions, so I’ll wrap this up here, but go watch my recent YT video if you haven’t already.​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. Reply if you liked this one :)​
​

​

subject: My thoughts on "growth operating"
content:
I was having an amazing morning until now…

It’s a beautiful 78-degree day in Miami.

Birds chirping, sun shining, and people genuinely seem happier here.

I walked to Soybucks to grab my iced shaken espresso. They greeted me with love and told me to have a great day.

I smiled and tossed the barista the keys to my G Wagon.

Then, everything changed.

I opened my phone and went to Instagram.

Boom, I see another pitch from some little ass kid telling me he could be my “growth operator.”

He said, “Ben, did you know you could monetize 1% of your audience??? I can make you $30k per month!”

If you don’t know what “growth operating” is, let me fill you in.

You partner with someone who has a big audience, help them set up a Skool community, and take 50% of the profits.

It’s basically a simplified version of what we do at my info-product agency.

Obviously, I think it’s a solid business model to run, and it’s made me 7 figures.

But I think there’s a bit of a misconception about how it’s been positioned online.

From firsthand experience, I can promise you that helping someone scale an info-product is complex.

There are many moving pieces in these types of businesses, and you need to have a broad skill set along with a general understanding of the info-product space to succeed as a service provider.

You write email copy, build funnels, script video sales letters, build systems, and orchestrate the sales process.

If you’re a complete beginner, it’s damn near impossible to learn all these skills at once.

Instead, it makes much more sense to start by learning one thing and one thing only – copywriting.

It’s the foundation of my business and the reason I’ve scaled to 6 figures per month with my info agency.

We’ve scaled offers from zero to $600k/month and orchestrated over a dozen multi-six-figure launches.

We helped a client go from $30k/mo to $350k/mo in a month and a half, and our smallest clients are making a minimum of $1m/year.

But I didn’t end up in this position by saying I wanted to be a “growth operator.” That term didn’t even exist.

I worked as a freelance copywriter/marketer and eventually accumulated the skills required to run a full-stack agency for info products.

If I were starting all over again, I’d start by becoming the best copywriter I could be. I’d study all types of copy – emails, ads, sales pages, VSLs, direct mail, billboards.

Then I’d start doing outreach to get clients while continuing to learn supplementary skills like funnel building, the different types of funnels, when to use which, how to navigate zapier, sales process management, etc.

Once I had a better understanding of these things, I’d pitch my copywriting clients on more services.

Get one really good case study, and boom – now you have a real business.

Let me clarify, though: I’m not saying the growth operator business model is bad. The guys who teach it are legit.

But it’s not a beginner business model, and you won’t get anywhere close to 50% profits from any creator who knows what they’re doing.

If you’re starting from scratch, learn copy, and the next door will open for you.

Hope you enjoyed this one,

Ben

​Read my previous emails here.​

​

subject: why your beliefs will change
content:
Goood morning {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Before I start rambling and forget to tell you, I made a new video explaining how I’ve made $124,255 in a month as a copywriter. You can watch it here after you read this.​

I’m sitting on my balcony as I write to you, and the dude who parades around the streets in Brickell while dancing on his bike is blasting the song “Dance Monkey.”

If you’ve ever been here, you probably know who I’m talking about.

He usually annoys me, but I’m in a good mood today, so I’m refraining from sniping him.

Anyway, whenever I see someone online pushing a narrative really hard, it makes me think they’re trying to convince themselves that it’s true.

I’m sure we’ve all been guilty of this at some point.

But I keep seeing Alex Becker pop up on my Twitter timeline, talking about how “fulfilled” he is by getting up at 3 am and sitting at his desk all day.

He’s a pioneer in the online money space, so no shade directly at him – I just think that someone who is truly happy doesn’t have to tell you how happy they are.

In the same way, someone who’s found the right path for themselves doesn’t tell you how your path is wrong.

And a person who has a true relationship with God doesn’t judge you for not following the same rules they follow.

This problem seems to arise when you deeply subscribe to a belief and discard anything that may contradict that belief. You don’t understand that most things are temporary and there are few universal truths.

But because you’ve fully convinced yourself that your way is the right way, when you encounter a situation where that belief is challenged, you take it as a threat.

It’s why someone who follows the college, 9-5 route gets angry when they see a 16-year-old with their annual salary on their wrist.

And on the contrary, it’s why a struggling entrepreneur feels the need to criticize 9-5ers so they can solidify that they made the right choice in their own mind.

There’s a sliver of doubt that they’re attempting to cover up by denying that any alternative could be true.

But that’s the thing – the alternative can almost always be true.

One thing I know with 100% certainty is that my outlook on life will change over time. It’s supposed to.

Different seasons in life bring additional perspectives.

I’m not saying you should lack conviction in your current beliefs if you’ve thoughtfully crafted them.

Just understand that they may change over time.

Don’t marry your beliefs, or you’ll end up bitter when you see someone succeeding in a different lane than you.

There are a million ways to win. Choose yours.

Alright, I gotta go to boxing, and you gotta watch this video.​

Happy Friday,

Ben

​

subject: Two habits that will change your life for the better
content:
Hello and happy Sunday, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

If you’re in a cold or grey climate right now, I feel bad for you because Miami is absolutely beautiful.

I’m wearing Birkenstocks without socks, which could be considered a crime against humanity but is also indicative of the sunny 80-degree day we have here.

First, I want to say thank you for the love of my recent YT videos. Your validation is giving me the motivation to upload consistently, so please keep it up.

Recently, I’ve been thinking about how copywriting has impacted my life.

Not only has it helped me build my business, but it’s served as an outlet for me to develop more concrete ideas.

For the last couple of years, I’ve been journaling, tweeting, or writing an email nearly daily.

It feels like a form of art.

In simple terms, I’m taking ideas that are jumbling around in my head and assembling them into a series of words that form a complete thought.

This has made me a more articulate speaker as well.

Whether talking to friends, on a date, or making content, I feel the ripple effect that comes from writing consistently.

Being able to use your words and share your perspective with someone in a way that may persuade them to agree with your beliefs feels like a superpower.

Whether or not you want to build a business that involves copywriting, I genuinely think getting into the habit of writing consistently is one of the highest ROI activities you can do.

Once you hone this skill, a world of opportunities opens up.

It can lead to a successful business, deeper relationships with others, and/or a loyal audience of people on the internet that resonate with your beliefs.

And as I think about the most successful entrepreneurs I know, this is almost always their unfair advantage.

Switching gears a bit, another thing that’s been on my mind is the value that comes with continuous learning.

School tricked us into thinking that education is a boring chore.

This causes most people to put little time into gaining new information once they graduate.

But learning new things should be fun.

I’m sure there are dozens of topics that you are naturally curious about and would enjoy exploring further.

And who knows – maybe it could lead to more money, a better social life, or at least give you an interesting topic to discuss at the dinner table.

When you’re constantly learning new things, you become more unique and interesting. And being a wealth of knowledge is cool.

I encourage you to take some time each day to learn about something new. It doesn't have to be about money or anything that even offers you any tangible benefit.

Simply allow your curiosity to lead you and someway, somehow, you’ll be glad you did.

This is a part of how you develop into a well-rounded version of yourself, which I talk more about here.​

Anyway, I gotta record some course content (which you’ll have access to soon), and Grammarly is pissing me off again because it keeps suggesting retarded edits to my writing.

Go watch my latest YT video if you haven’t already :)

Love you,

Ben

​P.S. Read my previous emails here.​

subject: the only way to get better at anything
content:
I was working out with my boxing coach the other day, practicing a new combination.

While we train, he frequently pauses to give me an analogy or anecdote to help cement new concepts in my head.

In this particular session, he said something that gave me no other choice but to reply with the word “bars” because it applies to any area of life that you are aiming to improve.

He said, “Confidence comes through competence, which comes through repetition.”

In other words, the more reps you get, the better you become, and the better you become, the more confidence you build.

I’m noticing this already on YouTube.

The first time I sat down to make a video, it took me too many tries to count.

I’d start talking and stumble over my words, lose my train of thought, or find an issue with the lighting or how the camera was positioned.

Because of this, making a video felt like I was climbing this big mountain.

Although I still run into occasional issues, it’s become much easier to sit down and knock out a video.

While the quality is subjective, I also feel that my ability to articulate the concept I’m discussing in each video has improved.

The words flow more smoothly, I’m more comfortable being expressive, and I’m getting closer to losing the filter that naturally comes with making videos for the internet.

It’s a perfect example of the quote from my boxing coach.

I don’t want to harp on this one point for too long because it’s so simple yet so difficult to actually practice.

The last thing I’ll say here is that I promise you with full certainty that when you stop putting off things you want to do, it’ll be worth it.

You have to get over the immediate flinch that comes with starting anything new and sometimes have to say, “fuck it if it sucks, it sucks,” and do it anyway.

Over time and repetition, you will get better.

Anyway, I gotta hop on a coaching call, so I’ll keep this one short.

Thanks for reading – and go here to check out the video I uploaded today about why “monk mode” makes you less productive.​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​

subject: HOW TO NOT BE A BOT
content:
I sneezed on my walk to get coffee and a stranger said, “Bless you.”

I found that endearing.

Then I saw a grown man wearing a bulky helmet and work clothes zipping through traffic on a scooter.

Those are for children. Grow up.

A couple things on my mind today:

1. Craftiness is the most underrated skill in business.

It’s the reason some people seem to get lucky.

I know a newer copywriter who’s gotten to multi-five figures a month way faster than most people.

He’s a smart kid but considering he’s brand new to copywriting, it’s safe to assume there are many better writers than him.

But it’s the intangibles that have allowed him to scale to quickly.

I’ve watched him relentlessly follow up with prospects in a nonaggressive way that doesn’t piss them off.

He’ll confidently say “yes” when someone asks for something he has little idea how to do and figure it out on the fly.

He’s simply the boy.

I was talking to my friend Mason about this the other day.

When I describe someone as “the boy” it’s one of the biggest compliments I can give.

It means that they just get it. They’re a good vibe, people like them, they’re socially calibrated.

It’s the highest rank in the Bader-dialogue hierarchy. A step up from “the homie” even.

When someone has the traits above, they "make it" — even if they’re not the most skilled.

My mentor when I was building my basketball trainer SMMA used to always say that if we can get someone laughing on a sales call, they will close.

It's a high ROI tip — in a world of cookie-cutter, boring, lifeless robots, be expressive. Crack the borderline offensive joke. Tell your prospect they need to hire you so they can afford better wifi when their connection cuts out on the Zoom call.

Smile. And be handsome.

I got carried away writing this first point and now I forget the other things that were on my mind.

Hmmm.

I’m sitting outside at Starbucks and another corporate drone just rode by on a scooter.

Oh, next thing that that I was thinking about:

2. If getting clients is a struggle, you’re being a bot.

This relates to my first point but THINK OUTSIDE THE BOX.

“I can’t get any clients, I’ve been sending the same retarded pitch to everyone for 3 months and no one replies.”

CHANGE YOUR PITCH.

Test shit. That’s life. You test until something works for you, even if it goes against the “proven system” that cornballs on the internet give you.

One of the copywriters I consulted with got his first couple of clients by digging through Youtubers channels, finding their email addresses, and pitching them via email.

No one taught him that. But that’s ingenuity.

The first time I heard the word “ingenious,” I had just broken into my high school gym to play basketball.

There was a hidden key in the storage closet to turn the lights on and lower the hoops. I’d found it months before, but one day, I walked in there, and it was gone.

“Goddamnit, Terry,” I thought to myself. She was the athletic trainer who would always kick me out because it was a liability for a minor to be in the gym without supervision.

I bent the metal part of an old lanyard I found in my backpack and made a new key. It worked.

A few days later, Terry walked in right after I used my makeshift key to get the baskets down.

She asked how I did it, and I told her I had made a new key. That’s when she said, “Well, that was ingenious of you.”

In my head, I was like “fuck yeah it was Terry.”

Anyway, I’m rambling, but if you’re stuck right now, BE CRAFTY. BE INGENIOUS. DONT BE A LUKE BELMAR IMAN GHADZI ANDREW TATE CLONE. STEAL YOUR GRANDMAS COMPUTER. SELL YOUR KIDNEY ON THE BLACK MARKET. SEND THE MAFIA TO A PROSPECTS HOUSE.

Ok, thanks for reading all this, now go here to uncover the secrets of the Universe.​

Talk tm, sorry for yelling.

Bye,

Ben

​

subject: how to overcome the voice in your head
content:
The hardest part of starting anything is the beginning.

When I open this document to a blank page, and a blinking cursor, a voice in my head tries to convince me that today isn’t the day.

“You’re out of ideas for now. You’re uninspired. Just wait until it comes to you,” it says.

This is a familiar voice.

I hear it whenever I turn on the camera to make a video.

It screams at me when the cold water touches my body in an ice bath and tells me to get out.

Maybe you’ve heard it too.

When you listen to it, you’ll be convinced not to go to the gym, avoid approaching the girl, and wait until the “perfect time” to start the business.

A few years ago, I listened to an audiobook about this topic during a plane ride.

It’s called The War Of Art by Steven Pressfield.

He refers to this voice as “resistance” and describes it as “A universal force that has one mission: to keep things as they are.”

You’re likely aware of the things you resist – consciously or unconsciously.

You also probably don’t want to stay the same forever.

And you know that the only way to change is to overcome your initial desire to flinch when taking the first half step.

You can ask yourself three questions to identify what you’re resisting right now and make a convincing argument for moving toward it.

Answer these with me real quick:

1. What’s one thing I want that I’m not getting right now?

2. What’s stopping me from getting this thing?

3. What would happen if I could do this thing?

Got it?

Okay.

By answering question one, you thought of something you want to do that you’re avoiding.

In question two, you selected the first excuse that came to mind for why you couldn’t do it.

And in question three, hopefully, you realized how stupid that excuse is because of the benefits, the person you become, and the new life you unlock by overcoming your resistance.

It’s literally impossible to make a logical argument for why you should avoid the things you’re avoiding.

Your excuses are bullshit.

That’s your ego trying to defend against change.

Because with change comes the possibility that things don’t go as planned.

Maybe your video gets three likes, and they come from your grandma, mom, and little brother.

Even your cousin gave it a thumbs down.

Or maybe you get rocked in the face the first time you step in the ring.

If those are big enough reasons to stay where you are, be my guest.

But by making that decision, you’re also closing the door to the possibility that it will eventually work out.

Sure, maybe it will start slowly.

Maybe things won’t go as planned even after you beat resistance.

But one day, your efforts will compound.

You’ll hang in there long enough and have the results to show for it.

That’s when you’ll laugh at the fact that you ever were scared to pursue the things you want.

You in?

Cool.

​Now, go here and let me tell you about the one trait you need to make as much money as you possibly want.​

Love you,

Ben

​

subject: stop feeling sorry for yourself
content:
Today was a tough one for my speaking ability.

I probably have over 100 clips on my camera that will all be deleted.

Earlier today I was trying to make a VSL for a new offer I’m putting together where you can work with me directly.

After dozens of takes, I finally had a video that I thought was sufficient.

I exported it and was about to call it a day.

Then I watched it a couple more times and decided that I didn’t like it.

I took a walk to clear my head and was inspired to make a Youtube video once I got back.

20 takes later, I still didn’t have a complete video. The sun went down and the lighting in my apartment makes the video look grainy once it gets dark.

I turned off the camera and am now sitting here writing to you.

It’s funny because yesterday I wrote an email to you about overcoming the initial resistance you feel when starting something new.

And today, I couldn’t beat it.

I started to feel bad for myself after the initial VSL failure.

And then during my walk earlier, I opened an email reply from someone on this list.

They said “Thank you Ben for rekindling this flame inside me with these emails.”

That’s when I realized that the decision to pity myself after things didn’t go as planned is incredibly selfish.

I’m making videos and sharing content on the because it feels like something I have to do.

As a byproduct, I get to inspire other people and impact lives for the better.

Obviously, I’m not on the front lines here risking my life for the benefit of humanity, but making

content like this is probably one of the most influential things I can do with my time at the moment.

When I think about, the possibility that I even impact a few people for the better vastly makes up for days like today, where I struggle.

I get messages and comments every day from people telling me that I’ve helped them in some way.

And to say “woe is me” while sitting and pouting about a couple of unsuccessful videos is childish, bitch-like behavior. I have a responsibility here, and it’s my obligation to uphold it. I’m too blessed to feel sorry for myself. The mission doesn’t allow for pity.

This is the pep talk I heard in my head. Perhaps it applies to you as well.

In general, I think the worst thing you can do in any situation is to feel sorry for yourself. It makes you powerless. It’s a slap in the face to anyone who supports you or roots for you, as you’re not even giving the same level of respect to yourself.

No more pity parties. You have responsibilities to tend to and a divine calling to follow.

Don’t be a bitch.

Ok bye thx for reading Happy Friday.

Ben

P.S. Did you watch my recent YT video yet?​

P.P.S Lmk if you liked this one <3

subject: How to build a copywriting business from scratch
content:

The trail was abnormally crowded today.

It was windy, to the point that the water from the Miami River to my left was blowing up onto the walkway.

The trees were rattling, but I pierced through the wind in my white Nikes, which I’ve been wearing for the past year.

subject: The anti-robot approach to getting clients
content:
The other day, I sent you an email titled “HOW TO NOT BE A BOT.”

It’s the most important life hack you can understand.

It’ll get you clients, friends, perceived status, etc. Simply put, not being a bot makes you a winner.

Today, I want to dive into the psychology behind this.

In college, there was a kid in my pledge class who we called a robot.

For the sake of the story, I’ll call him Robo-Joe.

Robo-Joe had one goal in life:

Get with sorority girls.

He was decent-looking and our school was literally 70% female, so the odds were stacked in his favor.

But there was a problem…

He had the charisma of a rock.

Joe was the type of person that likely doesn’t have inner dialogue, but if he did I imagine it would sound as follows:

“I want gorls. I go to school that 70% gorl. I join frat to seem normal so I get mor gorl. I go gym to get big and strwong so gorl like me.”

Because he was a robot, he took a very direct approach to the above goal.

He thought that all of the things above would make him desirable.

And while he did have some ‘success,’ Joes intentions became clear to anyone with half a brain.

He didn’t pledge a fraternity because he wanted to make genuine friends; he did so to make it look like he had friends.

He was obsessed with the gym because, in his mind, it would make him desirable to women.

Robo-Joe tried to cover up his intentions by becoming your typical jacked frat bro.

And he wasn’t the sharpest tool in the shed, so it didn’t really work.

Fun fact: our wardens actually made him play brain games for 20 minutes a day and report back with his progress because he was quite slow.

Anyway, I’m telling you all about Robo-Joe because this is the approach most people take when they want something.

Let’s say you want to get your first client and decide that you’re just gonna spam DM a bunch of people without doing any research on who they are or what you should offer them.

You do that for 3 months, and it doesn’t work because you’re retarded so you quit.

That’s the direct Robo-Joe approach.

Let’s talk about the better way to get what you want…

The first five info-product clients I got were all online basketball trainers.

I went 4/4 on outreach, and one of them (who had half a million followers) reached out to me first.

So, to make it clear, I sent four messages and got five clients, which is statistically impossible if you’re not named Ben Bader.

The reason this worked wasn’t because of my script or even any crazy case study.

It was because of two things:

  1. I existed on the internet. I was posting content about basketball trainer marketing and running ads.
  2. I used my brain to reach out at the right time. If they posted a new offer or something that I thought I could help with on their story, that’s when I’d send a DM.

Actually, I guess I lied — the third element was that I was half decent at writing copy and providing the other services I was offering, so I was confident in the way I spoke to them.

That’s the anti-robot approach. It might sound like it’ll take longer, but it diminishes your need to get lucky by spam DM’ing a bunch of people.

I don’t know if there was any saving Robo-Joe, but if he had put the time into becoming someone who was desirable to women instead of trying shallow fixes to fake it, maybe he would’ve had a shot.

​Anyway, I figured out the key to happiness and share it with you in this video.​

See you over there,

Ben

​
​

​

subject: Opportunity for you {{ subscriber.first_name }}
content:
As I walk past the joyful construction workers on my way back from the coffee shop, I can’t help but feel a sense of guilt.

It’s only 9am but the dirt covering their hands and clothes indicates they’ve been up working for hours.

They’re blasting an upbeat Hispanic song while smiling and laughing, probably making fun of stupid gringos clutching their coffee cups tight to their chests as they walk by.

I’m sure they have a long day ahead of them, but the spirit in their eyes shows that they’re okay with that.

“These are the people I envy,” I think to myself as I sit here clicking buttons in my air-conditioned box in the sky.

I’ve spent much of the morning in my head.

Thinking about how I need $100m yesterday, my dead hoop dreams, and the mountain of things on my to-do list for the day.

But when I walked by the jovial construction workers, it brought me back to the present.

They were sitting there on the edge of their truck, completely here.

No moping, no whining, just utter appreciation for life itself.

The lesson that resonated with me the most in The Four Agreements was “Do your best.”

Those three words make up the background on my phone, and although it’s a simple message, it truly diminishes the possibility of disappointment.

It gives you a sense of pride as it ensures that you always show up as the best version of yourself.

When you do your best, you make the most of every opportunity. It makes time fly by, even when you’re completing a rather trivial task.

The construction workers show up every day and do their best. That's what makes it fun.

Sure, they have other goals, aspirations, and worries.

But for now, they are where they are.

And you are where you are.

Accepting that fact doesn’t mean you’re forgoing your hopes and dreams, as you don’t need to constantly create an internal Hell to continue progressing.

You perform best when you find a way to enjoy what you’re doing.

Be here, do your best, and life goes from black and white to color.

Anyway, this was supposed to be a launch email where I tell you about my new partnership and offer for you.

As you can tell, I deviated from that plan, so I’ll just plug it here quickly.

If you’re trying to build a copywriting business, become a ‘growth operator,’ or build an agency, and you want my help…

​Go here and I’ll give you all the details.​

Have a good day and don’t forget to be where you are,

Ben

​

subject: how to stop drifting through life
content:
I was sitting at lunch today with a couple of friends, and we talked about what people do after college.

All three of us could think of a handful of people we knew in school who are now just drifting.

They either moved back in with their parents or they’re working some dead end job “figuring things out.”

This is absolutely asinine to me.

Wasn’t the point of college to find some direction and career path?

Many of my friends who graduated about a year ago have reached out to me, expressing unhappiness about the situation it’s left them in.

They’d spent the last four years (and hundreds of thousands of dollars) pretending like this day would never come.

Now, it’s not like they’re doomed for life, but it’s definitely a hell of a lot harder.

I’m not writing this to shame them but rather to warn you about what could happen if you try to ignore the inevitable destination that it will lead you to.

How long will you lie to yourself and say you’ll make a change “one day?”

That day will never come if you don’t create it.

It starts by making the conscious decision to design your life in a way that will steer you in a new direction.

Your habits, thoughts, and beliefs must begin to change.

This is how you step into a new identity.

The worst place in life is in the middle, drifting between what you want and what you have.

If your actions aren’t in alignment with the life you want to create, you’re in danger.

You can continue ignoring that feeling that tells you that you want more, or you can decide to actually commit to building this new reality.

I know this sounds simple, but if you objectively audit what you’re doing right now, and it isn’t propelling you to where you want to be, you have a problem.

If you choose to ignore the problem, it will grow like a parasite in the back of your mind.

Eventually, you’ll be the unhappy 50-year-old with a life full of “what ifs.”

Stop drifting, my friend.

Life is beautiful when you create it. I’m telling you firsthand that the hardship that comes with change is worth the experiences and freedom it grants you access to.

Take control of your life before it’s too late,

Ben

P.S. If you want to build a copywriting business, I have an opportunity for you.

You may have seen that I recently partnered with my friend Cardinal Mason inside of Copy MBA.

It’s his birthday tomorrow, and we’re running a $1,000 discount for the next few days.

This is limited and won’t be available for long.

​You can check it out here.​
