subject: Preparation is the enemy of success
content:
When I moved to Miami almost two years ago, I was a very different person.

I was making around $15k-$20k per month, I had less confidence, and the move here was intimidating to me.

The last ~20 months have been transformational.

My income has increased by more than 5x, and my social circle has expanded while I’ve developed tighter bonds with the few people I’d consider brothers.

The entire way I view myself has changed.

I started doing many of the things that were on my “one-day” list.

My personal brand has grown, I’ve picked up new hobbies, and my lifestyle is exactly the way I used to dream of.

I’ve taken a series of actions that have created a ripple effect.

When you do one thing that you’re a bit nervous to do, your brain realizes that the fears you have around that thing are self-imagined.

The ceiling that you’ve placed on yourself starts to get removed.

This makes it easier to tackle the next thing you’re putting off, and so on.

But knocking down that first domino is always the hardest.

Right now, you have beliefs that align with the person that you are in the present.

To do something new, those beliefs have to change – but they won’t change by standing in the mirror and telling yourself affirmations, watching self-help YouTube videos, or meditating in front of a Tony Robbins poster.

You must go out into the world and give yourself real data that an alternate identity is possible.

Obviously, I can sit here and tell you this over and over, but it won’t mean shit to you until you actually put it into practice.

Throughout my days as a basketball player, this was something I struggled with.

I was always in the gym, watching film, writing down goals, and doing everything I could to make my hoop dreams come true.

But I was never fully able to step into that new reality and play to what I knew my true ability was in real games.

It’s almost like I was rewarding myself for all the preparation I was doing rather than actually applying it where it mattered.

This is similar to rehearsing the “perfect” lines to say to a girl at the bar, but when you get there, you stand in the corner refreshing the weather app.

Or you could do all the research possible about copywriting, read all the books, and buy courses, but never send a DM and try to get a client.

Practice means nothing without action.

Sometimes, it’s better to be less prepared and dive in head first rather than sharpening your sword to never pull it out.

Do the things that are difficult for you and watch your limitations evaporate.

I promise it’ll be worth it.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. Our $1,000 discount on the Copy MBA Inner Circle is live – go here to start building your copywriting business.​

subject: brain dump for {{ subscriber.first_name }}
content:
Happy Friday! TGIF!!! Any fun weekend plans???

Hahaha.

Grow up.

It’s such a beautiful day here that I feel bad for anyone who isn’t in the state of Florida.

Besides those who are in Orlando. Or even worse… Tampa. Ew.

Imagine the highlight of your city being a predatory theme park or a place called “Meat Market.”

At least Tampa has “The Edition” - a 3.5-star hotel in any major city, but seems to be the main attraction since there’s nothing else to do there. They also only employ members of the LGBTDJKD community.

I’m not trying to be homophobic, but members of this community don’t seem to have the best work ethic, so things tend to take longer at this hotel. However, they are very good at making lattes.

Anyway I’m sitting outside Starbucks, sipping on a cold brew with vanilla cream and sugar, and thinking about how much of a hypocrite I am.

I just got jealous of a homeless man because he looked happy and had really good posture.

I can’t help but judge the man a couple tables away from me wearing a suit on his lunch break.

I started off this email by making fun of those who look forward to Fridays and weekends, but I’d be lying if I said my mood isn’t slightly better on days like this.

And if I actually followed the majority of the advice I give on the internet, I’d be a billionaire by now.

A wise man once said, “The most honest people are hypocrites.”

The wise man who said that is the same one who’s writing this email.

And if you’re still reading by now you’re probably wondering where the lesson is or what I’m gonna “teach” you here.

My goal is not to teach but rather entertain.

The richest people are the entertainers. Think about Tate. His message wasn’t something that others hadn’t said prior.

But he blew up because the guy is just outrageous. The way he speaks, the stories he tells, and the unapologetic expression of his thoughts.

It was refreshing to see someone who genuinely seemed not to care if people didn’t agree with him while simultaneously saying what everyone else was thinking.

On another note, most of the successful people I know are really lazy when they’re uninterested.

Myself included — I’ve always had a really hard time doing things I don’t want to do.

I’ll wait until the final deadline, half-ass the project, cheat off the Asian kid, and do everything I can to get by while putting in minimal effort.

But when I’m bought in and find something that I’m interested in, I turn into an autistic computer engineer.

I can spend hours at my desk without losing focus. It occupies my mind constantly.

Maybe you’re the same.

One thing I’ve started to understand about this is that obsession is created, not found.

You don’t “stumble” upon something you’re passionate about.

But rather, you create that passion by diving into a project and learning to love the mundane tasks that come with it.

Ok, I gotta hop on a call, but before I go, I’m feeling generous today, so I’m giving $100 to a random subscriber who watches and comments on my recent YT video.

​Go here and watch this video (leave a comment with your favorite thing I said in the video).

Considering my audience is still relatively small, you have like a 1/10 chance of winning probably.

Bye love you,

Ben

P.S. If you want me to help you build a copywriting or “growth operator” business, check this out.​

subject: secret to enjoying your life
content:
Happy Mother’s Day.

I’m mildly hungover and going to lunch in 10 min, so this will be a quicker one.

I saw a tweet from my friend Grant this morning that goes as follows:

“If your work doesn’t get finished, you can’t enjoy anything

So if your habit is avoiding work, it is also a habit of living without enjoyment”

Couldn’t be more true.

Odds are, you know that exact feeling.

You could be out with friends, walking on the beach, or in bed with the love of your life.

But when there’s something that you’re avoiding, you still hear that voice in the back of your head.

It mocks you while you try to forget about it by doing literally anything but confront it.

It doesn’t let you find peace. It doesn’t let you enjoy the moment. It’s a constant chatter that won’t be shut up by ignoring it.

Whether it’s work you’re avoiding, a decision, or the direction of your life entirely — your soul knows when your actions aren’t in alignment with your desires.

You’ll be in a constant state of anxiety when you’re avoidant.

You can lie to others, but you can’t lie to yourself.

But honestly if this sounds familiar, you’re one of the lucky ones.

You now know that there’s some fire in your soul.

And you know that there’s a direction it’s pulling you in.

It’s up to you to follow it :)

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

subject: The money you want is right in front of you
content:
The money you want is right in front of you; you’re just looking in the wrong places.

This is something I think about often.

Every now and then, I’ll hop on calls with people who are clearly sitting on a goldmine.

Maybe they have an in-demand skill, a large audience that isn’t properly monetized, or some other form of leverage they are not accessing.

From the outside looking in, the right move is so clear to me.

But it’s almost like they’re wearing tinted glasses that are blocking them from making the obvious decision that could drastically increase their income.

It’s like when you have a friend who gets into a relationship with someone who clearly isn’t good for them.

They’re “drunk in love” and can’t see the red flags or problems associated with the relationship.

Once the glasses are removed, their vision becomes clear, and the problem vanishes.

This works the same way in business.

People continuously look for the next shiny object, the next move, or the alternative direction they could take.

But they refuse to look at what’s right in front of them.

Let’s say you get a copywriting client who pays you $3k per month to run their email marketing.

You think to yourself, “Okay, this is great. Now I just need to get a few more clients, and I’ll be at $10k per month.”

You then spend the majority of your time trying to get more clients.

It doesn’t go as planned, and the client you had dropped you after a few months because they weren’t getting the desired result from email.

Now you’re back at square one.

The problem?

You were looking in the wrong place.

Had you objectively assessed their business, you would’ve noticed that their funnel needs work, their VSL is shit, and their sales team isn’t following up with leads.

Because of this, your emails didn’t increase revenue because there were other holes that needed to be patched.

But you weren’t focused on that.

You were spamming strangers on the internet, trying to get another client.

What if you had fixed the other gaps in your clients' business?

Let's say you rewrite their VSL, build them a new funnel, and help the sales team manage their leads.

Between these changes and your email marketing efforts, the revenue increases by 2 or 3x.

And because you were the person who helped them make more money, they’re happily giving you a percentage of the revenue.

Boom - you just turned your $3k/month client into a $10k/month client because you maximized the opportunity in front of you.

Here’s the part where I shamelessly plug the Copy MBA Inner Circle and show you how Vagner is doing exactly what I described above.

He’s already made an extra $2k because of it.

To get access to the same information he has, a community of other copywriters, and direct coaching from me and the Copy MBA team, go here now to learn more.​

See you over there,

Ben

subject: Winners And Losers
content:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

I don’t know why, but I have this deep disdain and partial jealousy for people who “sell out” for the info bag.

By “sell out” I mean normify their offer.

All their videos turn into hyper-edited VSLs.

They talk about extremely basic and broad concepts.

And their sole goal is to convince the masses that the business model they’re selling is the “easiest way to hit $10k/month.”

This works. You dumb down all of your content and sell the dream to naive beginners.

You know 90% or more of your customers will fail, but this is usually how to make the most money in coaching.

Is it unethical?

Not necessarily — if your program is good and some people still get results, you can make the argument that you did your best.

But it’s just not my style.

Even though I’m now partnered with Copy MBA and am financially incentivized to tell you how “easy” copywriting is, I can’t.

No business model is easy.

I think it’s a better option than dropshipping, trading, wholesale RE, and many other business models.

But is it any better for a beginner than doing sales or TikTok shop affiliate?

No.

And will most people who buy any course or coaching program fail, no matter the business model?

Yes.

I don’t mean to be pessimistic here. I just firmly believe that the intangibles make or break you.

There are winners and losers.

​The best copywriting program in the world can help you, but at the end of the day, you will never outperform your self-image.

And if you’re unable to transform yourself into a person deserving of financial success, it will always elude you.

No matter if you’re a copywriter, dropshipper, TikTok shop affiliate, or onlyfans thot.

Actually, OF might be the one exception.

Anyway, I’ll always keep it real with you. Even if that costs me money.

You will succeed at any business if you’re a winner. If you’re a loser, good luck.

Enough rambling for today — I made a vlog yesterday and will give a random commenter $100.

​Watch me live a normal day in Miami here. (and comment your fav part of the video to enter the giveaway).

Love you,

Ben

P.S. Just so you know I'm not capping about the $100 giveaways, here's a screenshot of me sending money to the last two winners:

subject: 3 important reminders
content:
It’s gotten to the point in Miami where the second you step outside, you start sweating.

I just got back from a 30 min walk, and I’m very wet (pause no homo).

As you may have seen, I recently started uploading on Youtube.

It’s been my obsession for the last month, and I’ve been reminded of many lessons, three of which I’ll share with you now:

1. You allow for the possibility of greatness when you stop trying to be perfect.

The other day, I woke up scrambling for an idea.

I wanted to start my next Youtube video with narration and b-roll.

As I walked to Starbucks to get some shots and try to think of an idea, I realized it was right in front of me (watch the video for context)​

The lesson:

Your best work and most fruitful business ventures usually happen by accident.

Just get the ball rolling, and things will work out.

As long as you’re aware and conscious of the opportunities that appear in front of you, you’ll stumble into greatness.

2. Don’t let your fear of heightened standards stop you from starting.

This is something I talk about often, as I’m frequently reminded of it.

As you progress in any endeavor, you add more pressure by revealing to yourself what you are capable of.

You’re probably subconsciously aware of this now, and it could be the reason that you’re putting off a goal.

I’m reminded of this with each video I post. There's this voice in the back of my head that says, “What’s next? How are you gonna top that?”

It’s a constant pressure that comes with a certain standard. But I can promise it’s far better than the anxiety that comes with suppressing your desires.

3. The best lessons are pulled from the trenches.

Any time I take on a new endeavor, I’m able to see many similarities between each pursuit.

I’ve learned more from things like boxing, lifestyle maxxing, and making content than I have from any coaching program or course.

Side quests are often life's best teachers.

And who knows, maybe you’ll learn a lesson or open a door that’ll help you financially as well.

Anyway – here’s the link to my new Youtube video.​

As always I’ll give $100 to a random subscriber who comments their favorite part from the vid.

Love you, and lmk if you liked this one :)

Ben

subject: ATTENTION
content:
“Attention is the new currency.”

You’ve likely heard this before.

Make content, build an audience, and sell them something.

It’s one of the quickest ways people are getting rich.

Over the last few years, it seems like the floodgates have been opened.

Everyone and their Grandma are content creators.

I can’t go to lunch without seeing people with hundreds of thousands of followers.

It literally seems like it’s one in every three people.

This is what has allowed me to build my agency.

As you may know, I work with people who have a big audience and sell information.

We write their copy, build their funnels, script their videos, and basically manage the entire backend for them, so all they have to do is make more videos and get more attention.

The more eyeballs they get, the more money they make, which makes our services more valuable and they end up paying us more.

This is the simplest way I can explain my business's role in the “attention economy.”

We’re leveraging a vast skillset, time, and expertise to capitalize on creators' existing audiences and help them make way more money than they would without us.

For most of our clients, our work is relatively the same – we build the similar landing pages, write similar emails, and even the VSL and webinar scripts are relatively templated.

On our end, there’s minimal difference in the workload between a client who pays us $5k/month versus one who pays us $30k/month.

The singular variable is attention.

We recently started working with a guy who has a really solid audience.

He has multiple six-figure followers, good engagement, and his content is fire.

From one post on Instagram and Tik Tok, he’s gotten the number of leads that we should be able to generate around a quarter million dollars from over the next week.

From one post.

Let me reiterate – the one difference between him and someone who makes little money from info is the audience.

Someone else could have the same story, results, success, expertise, etc.

But if they don’t have a loyal audience of people who know, like, and trust them on the internet, it means nothing.

Attention is everything.

Whether you’re trying to build your own coaching business or you’re doing something similar to me.

Your marketing efforts, systems, and positioning do not matter if no one is seeing it.

So if you’re a copywriter or “gRoWtH oPeraToR” keep this in mind when trying to get clients.

To get a killer case study, you need a killer client – a pig with lipstick on is still a pig. lol.

Anyway, I’ve been having a ton of fun working with the students inside the Copy MBA Inner Circle, and it’s dope to see them getting results from it.

​If you wanna make money as a copywriter or growth operator you should go here and apply so I can make you rich ok? Ok.​

Talk later,

Ben

​

subject: The "easy bucket method"
content:
I was crossing the street this morning and there was a red Tesla quickly approaching me.

Considering it’s an electric vehicle, I figured if it hit me I would do more damage to the car than it would to me.

Luckily, it stopped, and we didn’t have to find out if that hypothesis would hold up.

I have a quick tip for you tn…

I’m on the couch scrolling through Youtube and watching Kyrie Irving dominate against the Timberwolves.

As I begin writing this, he has 26 points. Early in the first quarter, he hit two open shots in a row, and from that point on, he’s been lighting it up.

This is something you’ll commonly see amongst the best scorers in basketball.

If they get an easy shot early on, this will help them get into a rhythm, and it’s going to be a long night for the defense.

This “easy bucket method” is something I use almost every day (off the basketball court).

When I sit down to work, most of my tasks each day fall into one of two categories:

1. Easy to complete, low time commitment

Or…

2. Difficult to complete, higher time commitment

I almost always start with one of the easier, lower-friction actions, and once I knock a few of those out, I build momentum – Which makes it much easier to move on to the more time-intensive stuff.

This is one of my best “productivity hacks,” and I use it whenever I am trying to achieve a bigger goal.

Very simple concept, but try it out next time you find yourself procrastinating.

Anyway, check out my recent video if you haven’t already 👇

​

I have $100 for a random subscriber who leaves a comment about their favorite part of the vid :)

Night {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Ben

subject: The best things in life are earned
content:
All of the best things in life are earned.

This is especially true for men and is something that you’ll constantly be reminded of as you “level up.”

There are no shortcuts.

True genuine friendships, the girl who loves and admires you, and the impact on other people are all things that you cannot access by finding a loophole.

You have to become “him.”

Money alone won’t do this for you.

There is one thing that usually has the biggest impact on the quality of experience you get to access.

And it’s your relationships.

First with yourself and then with others.

Let’s say you get “lucky” financially.

You hit a big crypto rug pull, you run scam eCom brands, or you start selling Viagra to old men and pimp out your grandmother on OF.

It works, and you get “access” to all the money you could need, which, in theory, will buy you the best experiences that life has to offer.

But there’s this deep-seated belief in your head that feels like you’re unworthy.

While you earned the money you wanted you didn’t improve your relationship with yourself along the way.

Maybe your back was never against the wall and you didn’t develop the grit that comes with digging yourself out of a hole. Or maybe you don’t fully respect yourself because you’ve found success through nefarious means.

Because of these factors, you aren’t the type of person that other amazing, genuine people want to be around.

You end up attracting shallow people into your life – guys who would slander your name if it’s in their best interest and a girl who would leave your table at the club to go to Futures table (rip).

You see a lot of these types in Miami and they’re usually dripped out in Chrome Hearts.

These are people who “beat the system.”

They found the financial success that others dream of, perhaps without having to go through the usual hardship or personal development process.

But they don’t get to fully enjoy the money because they haven’t become the person who is worthy of incredible relationships, as you attract what you are.

And even if you “earn” all the money in the world, you still have to earn your relationships.

Laying on the beach in Barbados means nothing if you aren’t with people you love.

Driving your dream car through the Hollywood hills doesn’t hit the same if the girl in your passenger seat only likes you for your money.

Opening your banking app to a number that would allow you to retire at any moment feels empty when you don’t like the person whose face you see in the reflection of your screen.

Your relationships are everything and there are no shortcuts that will earn you respect.

So if you’re in the trenches right now and you feel like you’re not reaping the rewards of your efforts…

Congratulations. You’re in the process of developing into the person who is worthy of the reality that you want.

Sorry for the hiatus. Good to be back,

Ben

subject: One habit that improves every area of life
content:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Four years ago, I started one habit that's been the single biggest driving factor of my growth and success.

Not only has it made me seven figures and helped me build an audience online…

But this one habit has acted as my therapist, improved my mental clarity, and has made me a more articulate and effective communicator.

And the fact that you’re reading this right now is proof of all of this.

Let's rewind to 2020.

I’m a 19 year old sophomore in college and I’ve started to dip my toes in the water of entrepreneurship.

There’s a lot on my mind on this particular summer day in Charleston so I decide to open a Google doc and start writing.

I write about what I’m trying to do in my business and what’s been stressing me out.

After a few paragraphs, I close my laptop and realize I feel a lot better than I did before I opened it.

I didn’t realize it at the time, but my life had just changed.

This became a habit I’d do almost daily for the following years.

Over time, I started to notice the benefits.

I became a better writer, my brain felt less cluttered, and holding myself accountable became easier because I was reporting back to myself on progress I’d made each day.

I began writing on Twitter, I put together this newsletter and picked up a few copywriting clients.

Writing became a part of me.

My outlet, my income, and my vessel to share my thoughts with others on the internet.

It led to the lifestyle I’m living now.

It bought me my dream car.

It connected me with my best friends.

And this is why I think it’s one the most valuable skills you can learn and habits you can develop.

Whether you want to build a copywriting business, grow an audience online, or have an outlet to close the tabs in your head at the end of each day…

Start writing.

You won’t regret it.

Have a good weekend,

Ben

P.S. If you want my direct help in building your copywriting or growth operating business, I'll show you exactly what we do for our clients with millions of followers (plus how we're able to charge singular clients up to $40k/month) -- check this out.​

​

subject: Why you should tell more lies
content:
Last night my girl and I tried to make Carbones spicy rigatoni at home from scratch.

We left the sauce on the heat for a bit too long so it got kind of soupy but other than that it was good.

The only problem is my apartment still kind of smells like onions.

This information is completely irrelevant to you but I thought I’d share it anyway.

Moving on – the other day I watched a video my friend Rob made titled “tell a lie 1,000 times and it becomes the truth.”

Many successful people are examples of this.

It’s like they “crown themselves” prematurely and after enough time, they become what they were pretending to be.

Let’s use your average agency owner turned course guru as an example.

They get to ~$30k/month with their agency and build an audience online in the process.

Eventually they start to feel “burnt out” from their agency and realize they’re sitting on a different goldmine.

They have this big audience of people who knows, likes, and trusts them as an authority in the agency space.

Now, are they the most “qualified” agency owner in the world?

Definitely not.

There are plenty of agency owners making 5x, 10x, and even 100x their revenue.

But are there hundreds of people ready to pay to learn from them?

100%.

And now they reach a crossroads…

Do they keep trying to scale the agency as the main focus, or do they launch a coaching program?

That’s when they “crown themself.”

They become the agency guru, make a bunch of money coaching and then stop running an agency.

And because info is typically an easier business model to scale, now they’re making $200k/month.

They simply decided that they were qualified to consult other people for a price.

Because they gave themself this permission, they became "qualified" and were heavily rewarded for it.

This is how most coaching programs and info products are born.

The only issue that eventually arises here is when the coach stops doing what they are teaching.

After a few months or a year, their knowledge becomes obsolete.

This is why it can actually be good to learn from people who teach you the exact marketing system they used to get you to buy their product.

Long story short – give yourself permission to become the person you want to be or start the business you want to start, and that reality will come to fruition for you.

Make sense?

Cool.

Happy Monday,

Ben

P.S. Get my help in building your copywriting or growth operating business to $10k/month+ here.​

P.P.S. Watch my new video where I share 10 rules to change your life in the next 90 days.​

​

​

subject: no ones thinking about you
content:
I'm sitting at my favorite coffee shop watching an asian man in a yankees hat have an episode.

He's sitting about 10 feet to my right in a white tank top with black shorts and his legs crossed.

There are three empty bottles of corona in front of him and he just knocked one over.

He's now struggling to open his black leather backpack.

Part of me hopes he’s reaching for a weapon because this would be the perfect time for me to become a hero. I'm seated slightly behind him so he wouldn’t see me coming.

Plus he can’t be more than 140 pounds and one right hook to the temple should knock him out.

Damnit. no weapon, just airpods.

From the moment I sat down he’s been talking abnormally loud.

Most of which has been mumble nonsense but at one point he asked the man in the floral shirt at the table in front of him if he could come sit with him.

The man politely declined.

He just took a final sip out of each of his three bottles and is now flailing his arms above his head.

Smoke break. He put a cigarette in his mouth and walked outside.

This is fun. It's usually only homeless people that you get to see have outbursts like this.

Other than a few staff members, no one else in the restaurant has even noticed him.

Everyone is just in their own little bubble, dealing with their own ambitions, obstacles, and problems.

I guess if there’s a lesson here it’s that letting the opinions of others stop you from doing something you want is so silly.

First of all, you’re gonna die one day.

Second of all, who cares what they think.

And third, they’re probably not even gonna notice you.

Our friend is back from his smoke break.

He asked for another beer and the waiter reluctantly told him that they aren’t legally allowed to serve more than three alcoholic beverages.

I wonder if that’s true or if he was just worried that this guy was gonna start dancing on the table.

Instead the waiter went and got him some water. The manic man got up and gave him a hug.

He drunkenly said, “Thank you. I’ve had such a rough day,” grabbed his things and walked out with hope in his stride.

Aw. What a nice happy ending.

I guess everyone’s dealing with their own shit and it's not good for us to judge.

Anyway – This video is one of my favorites and it’s something that helped me go from being a normal college kid to building my dream life over the last 4 years.​

See you over there,

Ben

​

subject: Lesson from $100m man
content:
Before I get into today’s email, I have a new opportunity that may be a good fit for you.

If you’re a coach, consultant, or course seller and you want to scale to 6 figure months, check out the video on this page.​

Alrighty, pitch out of the way - let’s get into it.

On my walk today I passed by former NBA player Amar'e Stoudamire.

He was sitting on a bench with his dog’s leash tied around the leg of it, while reading a torah with a cigar in his mouth.

According to Google, he made $165,683,566 over the course of his career.

But there he was, enjoying his day while doing something that costs zero dollars.

I saw a quote the other day that said:

“A rich man works all is his life to live like a poor man in a village by the sea”

That’s a bar.

Another wise man once tweeted “The best things in life are free but you can only appreciate them once you buy everything else.”

That wise man was me.

And this is the truth. The best thing money does for you is it offers peace of mind and freedom.

You earn yourself the freedom to take a long walks or enjoy a cigar on a bench on a random Thursday afternoon.

Without having to worry about bills, drama at a job you hate, or any of the other things that normies have to worry about.

You can say what you want. You can think how you want. You can side quest. You can try new things and embark on “meaningless” pursuits.

Money is freedom.

And it 100% makes your life 100x better because it lets you live like you don’t have it, while giving you the peace of mind of someone who does have it.

Getting rich is the most selfless thing you can do.

Because then you have the clarity to go figure out what you're supposed to do here.

Make sense?

Let me know if you liked this one,

Ben

subject: How to buy a bugatti asap
content:
Happy Sunday.

I just posted a banger video about how I’d make $100k asap if I had to start all over.

Go watch that after you read this, or be poor and sad forever.

A man named Luis is currently on his way to my apartment on a motorbike, carrying the cheesesteak I just ordered.

The NBA finals are playing on the TV behind my computer screen.

What a life.

They just showed a stat about Luca Doncic, who is averaging 34 points per game in the playoffs, which is the most since MJ in the 90’s.

The interesting thing about Luca is he simply does the basics.

He’s not incredibly fast or athletic and he isn’t super fancy with the ball.

But he’s incredible at the basics and makes everything look simple.

Every movement is precise, from his footwork to the way he uses his body (no homo).

He makes the right read coming off of screens and just plays at his own speed.

Because he is so exceptional at the simple “big levers” he’s better than 99% of players in the league.

Business works the same way.

Many of the richest people I know aren’t the most… meticulous.

They stay away from complex systems and focus on the one to handful of actions that produce the most results.

If you’ve seen this jacked dude named Wes Watson on social media, he’s the perfect example of this.

Go watch his content right now and he’s regurgitating some Bruce Lee quote with motivational music and a workout compilation over it.

He’s yelling at the camera with veins popping out of his eyelids.

Clearly he isn’t the most intelligent or articulate person in the world.

But he’s posting multiple times per day and if you opt-in to his funnel, you’ll get a text and a dial from his sales team within minutes.

And based on his social media and the fact that I constantly see him on Brickell avenue in an orange Bugatti, the guy is fucking rich.

He has one job – get attention.

The more eyeballs he gets, the more the sales team can harass new leads and quite literally sell them air.

That part is unimportant.

He does the basics better than everyone else.

He knows what the big levers are in his business.

He yells. A lot.

And it bought him a Bugatti.

Fuck. I want a Bugatti.

Let’s do more of the basics and have a great week,

Ben

P.S. Go here if you sell info and you want to scale to $100k/month.​

P.P.S. Go here if you want my help in building your copywriting business.​

subject: Got a haircut and figured out how be rich forever

subject: NGMI or FITFO
content:
There are two types of people in this world.

The first type of person is the one who hesitates to start a business because they’re worried about how they’d pay taxes if they were to make money.

They sit there and think about every possible problem that they could possibly run into.

“What happens if I get a client and then they ask me to do something that I don’t know how to do?”

These are the types that want a “full step-by-step playbook” to start a business.

It’s like they’re taking the 9-5er approach to business and need to be told what to do every step of the way.

There’s an acronym that accurately describes this type:

NGMI (not gonna make it).

They’re effectively toddlers.

The second type of person is the one who adopts a different mindset.

Sure, they still have hesitations, fears and doubts.

And they don’t know what every step of the staircase will look like.

But they take action despite these factors.

There’s a different acronym that they follow:

FITFO (figure it the fuck out).

Yesterday I found a perfect example of these two people in the comment section of one of my Youtube videos.

One person commented “This video is ABSOLUTELY POSITIVELY POINTLESS” and right underneath him was a comment that read:

“Exactly what I’m going through rn. Your YouTube was really put in my life for a reason. The timing of this video is impeccable”

Can you guess who’s who in this example?

Sure I’m biased because it’s my own video but this was interesting to me.

How can two people watch the same exact video and have completely opposite reactions?

Perception.

Your reality is colored by the lens in which you view the world.

If you think someone is coming to save you, or you think there’s a step by step system that everyone who “makes it” follows, you will find information that lacks training wheels useless.

Instead you’ll watch hyper edited videos that follow a script and have gay animations over them.

You’ll get a dopamine rush and think you’re doing something useful.

But you’ll never actually find success because you’re type one.

You need everything to be predictable – which is the opposite of entrepreneurship.

On the contrary, if you understand that anything worth having takes time and that your reality lies on your shoulders alone, you will eventually achieve your desired result.

And when you consume information that reminds you of this, instead of getting angry that you weren’t handed an “A-Z blueprint” you’ll feel inspired that others see the world the same way you do.

Every day you have the power to choose which of these two people you want to be.

One will serve you and push you towards your goals.

And the other will keep you stuck in the same mindset that has gotten you nowhere.

Choose wisely.

Ben

P.S. Join Copy MBA if you're a FITFO person.​

​

subject: How to easily be a better writer
content:
Happy Saturday {{ subscriber.first_name }},

It’s been rainy and gloomy here in Miami for the past few days.

The sky is white right now but there’s no rain coming down so I’m sitting on my balcony as I write this to you.

Over the last few days I’ve really noticed how the weather impacts my mood.

I’m a firm believer that 99% of problems can be fixed with a long walk in the sun.

When it was constantly raining and I was unable to do so, I started to go crazy.

Anyway it’s unusually quiet for a Saturday in the middle of Brickell.

Usually there's this dude who bikes around carrying a beat box.

He’ll stop on random street corners and start break dancing.

Imagine you’re hungover at 8am on a Saturday and you’re woken up by a Bad Bunny song.

You get up, walk out onto your balcony and see some guy with pink hair and the shape of a heart on the back of his head.

He's blasting music and dancing like a freak.

You’d probably try to snipe him right?

I tried once but hit an old lady by accident.

Maybe someone finally got him because it’s quiet today.

Anyway, the other day I hosted a group call inside of Copy MBA.

Someone asked a question about “writers block” when first starting out.

Whether you want to build a copywriting business and you’re trying to practice, or you just want to start writing in general, this is inevitable.

This student was trying to write a sample email for this supplement brand, but whenever he opens a google doc, he stares at a blinking cursor and eventually closes his laptop.

Happens.

I asked him what sport he played growing up.

He told me he does mixed martial arts so I recommended that he find someone who is selling MMA courses or pick a clothing brand in that space and write for that instead.

The reason this is effective is because it’s much easier to write about things you’d be in the market for.

Especially when you’re first starting out.

When I started, I was writing copy for basketball trainers.

In every email, every ad, and every funnel I built – I was writing to my previous self.

I understood the pain points and desires of the market because I was the market.

And this made practicing 100x easier.

Between this and building the habit of writing every day, I got better quickly.

If you want to get better at copy, you need to write for fun.

Start journaling.

Start tweeting.

Write a love letter to your ex.

Go sit down in a coffee shop and write about the barista that held eye contact for too long when taking your order.

Write about the idiot who’s standing in the middle of the doorway.

Write about the poor bastard who passes by on a scooter in work clothes with a backpack on.

Describe what you see in detail.

Make it entertaining and don’t hold back

Just write.

It will make your life better. And eventually, you’ll be half decent at it.

Alrighty I’m going to the gym.

Let me know if you liked this one,

Ben

P.S. I posted a free 30 minute live call on Youtube where I map out the launch of a coaching program.

​Check it out here.​

​

subject: Please stop pitching me
content:
Every day I wake up to two things:

1. The ear-itating (Dad joke – happy belated fathers day) sound of construction workers drilling.

And…

2. Pitches in every digital inbox I own.

Instagram, Twitter, TikTok, Gmail, even Venmo…

People on the internet are constantly trying to get me to buy their services through cold outreach.

And my audience isn’t even that big.

99% of the outbound messages I read are absolute trash.

With every word they are showing more incompetence and only proving to be someone who I don’t want to work with.

They barely do any research on me or what I could potentially need, their messages are too long, they sound retarded, etc.

But honestly, it’s not their fault.

Outreach USED to be a numbers game.

If you blindly send enough cold DM’s, eventually you’ll get a client.

It doesn’t work like that anymore (especially if you want to get GOOD clients that will pay you a decent retainer).

Your success is now correlated to the quality of your message and the way you are perceived online.

Yes, volume still matters.

But failing to put yourself in a more credible position before doing outreach is like DMing Instagram models when you have 29 followers and one picture of yourself holding a fish.

Not gonna work.

There are three things you can do that will improve your online perception, thus increasing the likelihood you get replies to your cold pitches.

1. Post content

2. Lead with material that proves competence

3. Network

The first point (content) is self explanatory.

If you’re a beginner I understand that it may be difficult to know where to start in that regard.

But I’m not just talking about video content or even posting information related to what you’re pitching.

If you look like a normal, cool person on Instagram, you will get more responses.

Simple.

This second element (material that proves competence) is absolutely crucial as well.

I get pitches with shitty sample emails and clips from my videos.

The time put into these assets is meaningless if they suck.

If they don’t suck, they get a reply.

Last element – network (without being a dork).

Everyone is more likely to respond to someone they have mutuals with.

Strangers don’t get replies. They stay poor for eternity.

Friends do business together.

Got it?

Stop spraying and praying.

Use the three principles of online credibility above, and your chances of landing clients will greatly increase (and now it becomes a numbers game).

Hope this helps – go show some love on this new video if it did :)​

Please stop pitching me,

Ben

​

​

subject: One question you need to ask yourself
content:
I think I just called a they/them “bro”

It was an accident.

I walked into the coffee shop to get my latte and it (they?) greeted me.

At a glance it was 100% a man.

But as I got closer I realized it had feminine features and no Adam’s apple.

Oops.

Anyway I heard someone say a really interesting quote the other day.

“The only stupid questions are those that we fail to ask ourselves first.”

In other words, use your own brain and critical thinking ability before asking for help from others.

When you build the habit of constantly seeking advice, you start to lose trust in your own word.

You reach an impasse or situation you haven’t encountered prior, and feel helpless.

So you turn to others and want to be told what to do.

This basically turns you into a female uber driver:

Absolutely useless.

(Sorry I couldn’t resist — I know there are some women who are not horrible drivers).

I actually had a female uber driver for a 30 minute ride this past weekend and I’m still alive so W’s in chat for her.

Back to the point - you have the answer to probably 90% of your problems.

When someone gives you advice, generally they’re just flexing the same critical thinking muscle that you have.

And your guess is as good as theirs.

Over time, the more you rely on others your self-reliance muscle will atrophy.

You’ll lose all the trust that you had in your own judgement and seek approval, validation, and direction constantly.

This is even true when you have solid mentors and people that are giving you “good” advice.

Someone may tell you the right move to make on paper but that doesn’t mean it’s actually right for you.

It’s often the inclinations, or the trails that you recklessly and delusionally follow that end up leading to the biggest opportunities.

Now I'm not saying that gathering perspective from those who know more than you is always a bad thing.

Obviously there are times where direction from others can really help.

Just remember to listen to your own voice from time to time.

And before you go looking for help,

Ask yourself first.

Bye bro,

Ben

Since you’re on this list you’ll have the opportunity to get in before I launch it publicly.

subject: True freedom can't be bought
content:
The other day I talked to two different business owners.

One of them was making $1m a month.

The other was making about a 20th of that.

After the two calls, I noticed something interesting.

I had much more respect for the guy who was making less money.

On that call, we talked a bit about business but the conversation quickly turned more philosophical.

He shared some of his goals with me and explained why he's doing what he's doing.

I could tell he was really thoughtful and intentional.

He put effort into considering what he actually wanted -- Not what would appear "cool" to strangers on the internet.

The other guy was far less interesting to talk to.

Sure, he'd reached a higher number in his business, but he was a dork.

He had an Amazon automation offer (which are typically a scam).

And was stressed because a few things had gone wrong in his business recently causing revenue to decline.

I wrote a tweet yesterday expanding on this which I'll share with you now:

"After a few years in business I’ve stopped “looking up” to people simply because they’re making a lot of money.

Most guys end up losing the traits that make them interesting.

They get so bought in to adopting a worldview that others tell them to have.

With that, goes their autonomy.

They’re no longer thinking for themselves and what they want but rather for what other men will perceive as higher status.

I have more respect for the broke guy who figures out a way to live a dope life.

Or the entrepreneur who follows a more creative path, even if it costs him money.

Freedom of the mind can’t be bought.

And $1m a month is meaningless if you never stopped to figure out why you’re doing it.

Money can be an outlet to live how YOU want. It’s not an identity."

I'll never be someone who tells you not to make as much money as possible.

But just remember to continuously audit the path you're on and ensure it aligns with what you want.

And whatever path you choose -- follow it with conviction.​

Talk later,

Ben

​

​

subject: Do this to guarantee you never go broke
content:
It’s 11:02am on a Monday morning as I start writing to you shirtless from my balcony.

I’m thinking about what I would do if everything got wiped to zero tomorrow.

Bank accounts drained, car stolen, watches donated to the homeless, all of my clients fire me, etc.

And I realize that I’d be fine.

There are three things I’ve done over the past few years that have made me “recession proof.”

Meaning if some event occurred where I had to basically start all over, I have full conviction that I’d get back to where I am quickly.

And that’s good news for you, because the three things that give me that confidence are resources that anyone can access.

If you want to ensure that you can never go broke, do this:

1. Learn high income skills

2. Use social media to build a network

3. Build a personal brand

Those three assets turn you into a weapon.

The first step (learning skills) is simple.

Simply learn copywriting and sales and you’re in better shape than 99% of people.

Watch Youtube videos, pitch strangers on the internet, learn more on the fly.

Step two (building a network by being a normal cool person) opens doors and gives you a safety net.

If you can just start to connect with more people who are on a similar path as you (or ahead of you) opportunities flow your way.

The best way I’ve found to do this has been through Twitter and by joining mastermind and coaching programs.

And lastly, step three (personal brand) is perhaps the most valuable resource you can build in 2024.

Now, not everyone is meant to have tens or hundreds of thousands of followers.

But that doesn’t mean that you can’t share some insights on social media and utilize the platform.

This goes hand and hand with networking in step two.

Even if you don’t end up building a huge personal brand, posting content online can only help you.

All three of these things will give you security and the best safety net possible if things ever go south.

It’s the peace of mind that a college degree is supposed to give you.

Let me know if you liked this one :)

Btw I have something really cool for you launching this week and I’m excited to share it with you.

Talk soon,

Ben

subject: How to go from good to great
content:
I cracked the code.

It’s summer 2015.

An hour in to a grueling basketball workout, my trainer makes a new rule.

“If the ball hits the rim it counts as a miss and you have to run sprints. Swishes only.”

I think to myself “this mf crazy, I need a new trainer.”

But I keep shooting, now aiming only for nylon.

The ball hits the back of the rim and goes in. Doesn’t count.

Front rim. Side rim. Rattles in off the glass.

Doesn’t matter, I’m running.

“This is ridiculous. I’m literally making these shots and still being forced to run,” I complain to myself.

But then something cool happens.

I find the sweet spot and the ball stops hitting the rim.

The way I’m shooting feels different now.

I’m no longer just aiming for the basket.

I’m aiming for a very specific part of the back of the net.

I’m conscious of exactly how the ball has to leave my fingertips.

Everything is incredibly precise.

I’ve reached a level of attention to detail and focus that I wasn’t accessing previously.

This is the difference between good and great.

It’s what keeps some business owners stuck at $10k, $50k, or $100k per month.

It’s what causes tens of thousands of dollars worth of leads to fall through the cracks in a sales process.

And it’s what created the opportunity for me to make 7 figures as a marketer for info-product businesses.

I get paid to fill in the gaps.

To improve the copy, or the sales process, or the video script.

I bring a new level of attention to minor details and make an extra 6 figures a month for my clients.

They pay me a percentage of it.

This is how you win as a service provider for coaching business.

Find the broken piece(s) of their business.

Identify a solution using your critical thinking ability.

Get paid.

For example if an usually low amount of leads end up on sales calls, my job is to find the crack in the system.

Maybe the email sequence sucks or there’s none at all.

Maybe the leads aren’t getting dialed.

Maybe the video sales letter is horrible.

Maybe there’s a lack of congruence between the content and the messaging on the funnel.

Whatever the problem is, the way to make money is to identify and fix it.

Boom, now you’re a valuable piece to any coaching business.

subject: Why successful people are lazy
content:
July 1st.

Before I was doing anything with my life, it was usually around this time of year where I’d start to panic.

In the beginning of the year, I’d set a bunch of lofty goals.

I’d promise myself that this year is gonna be different.

But my New Year’s resolutions would remain as unchecked boxes on my computer screen.

By March, I’d start feeling the pressure.

“Ok, you gotta lock in bro.”

I’d change my routine for a few days or maybe a week.

Then something would throw me off and I’d revert back to old habits.

I’d continue on autopilot for the next few months and then this time of year would hit.

That’s when I’d reach panic mode.

We’d be more than halfway through the year and I hadn’t made nearly any progress on my goals.

If this sounds familiar and you woke up in a frenzy this morning, good.

You’re just a few actions and a few months away from a very different life.

I’m writing to you from the lobby of one of the nicest hotels in LA where they filmed the movie Pretty Woman.

In a couple hours, I’ll order a $200 uber black lux to take me to the airport even though I could get a normal one for $50.

On my flight back to Miami I’m in seat 1A and my girl is in 1B (as long as they don’t rug pull me again).

My life looks a lot different than it did when I’d procrastinate taking action on my goals for the better half of a year.

But I’m that same lazy kid.

I hate doing things I don’t wanna do.

I hate not knowing exactly how things are gonna work out.

I hate change.

But more than all of these, I hate the idea of living a life that I don’t want to live.

And that fear was powerful enough to help me overcome my lazy nature and habit of procrastinating.

So if you want to spur yourself into action, picture in vivid detail what your life will look like if you keep stalling.

And if that doesn’t do the trick you’re probably cooked. Sorry.

Talk to you when I’m back in Miami,

Ben

P.S. I uploaded a new narration style video yesterday — let me now your thoughts ⬇️

​

​
​

subject: my subconscious wrote this email
content:
Quick one for you today.

You need to make your subconscious your friend.

Once you activate your RAS (reticular activation system) to work in your favor, opportunities and ideas fall into your lap.

It’s like when you start thinking about a certain car and begin seeing more of it on the street.

Similarly, when you become intentional and get a general idea for the direction you want to head in…

Your subconscious starts to conspire in your favor.

You get a random idea that turns into a breakthrough.

You get a weird inclination to start a new habit, or connect with a certain person.

That inclination create an opportunity.

This starts by doing the following:

When yo u want something, write it down. Think about it. Start taking actions that will move you towards said thing.

I’m frequently reminded of this when I make content.

Since I’ve developed the Tuesday, Thursday, Sunday, Youtube video schedule, I start getting ideas on these days.

It begins when I consciously decide, “Okay, I need to make a video today.”

As I continue thinking about what I want to talk about, sometimes my subconscious will throw me a random thought.

I’ll be on a walk or in the shower and boom.

I figure out what I want to talk about.

I could keep going on about this but I have to leave for dinner so maybe we can revisit another day.

​Here was today’s thought by the way.​

Okay love you bye,

Ben

subject: $10 and spaghetti can create your dream life
content:
“I would much rather fail gloriously than not try. I’m not interested in telling stories with competence. I’m looking to tell them with some style, originality, and creativity.” - Anthony Bourdain

Happy Saturday {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

The other day I was on a 90-foot yacht for the 4th of July, having a brief conversation with a friend about YouTube.

A few years ago, he had 27k subscribers but wasn’t making any money from his channel.

Then he got a piece of advice that changed his life forever.

In passing, one of the biggest YouTubers in the world told him to change the thumbnail on a video he’d posted 6 months prior.

So, he paid someone $10 to take a new thumbnail photo and uploaded it.

Over the following 24 hours he went from 27k subs to over 100k and quit his job at Subway.

He eventually reached over 1m subscribers before his channel was banned by the platform (you might know who I’m talking about here lol).

What’s crazy to me is that all happened because of one small adjustment.

Here’s how this pertains to you:

A single decision can completely change your life.

It could be a seemingly miniscule decision that you don’t give much thought to.

It could be a risk or hail mary attempt that leads to a big break.

Or it could be the decision to power through a tough time and change a behavior.

Genuinely, sit there and think about this for a second.

You are one decision away from everything you could ever dream of.

Right now, you don’t know what that decision is.

Odds are, you won’t know the ripple effect that it’ll create even when you make it.

But if you keep throwing spaghetti at the wall hoping that it sticks, eventually it will.

Maybe you’ll have to get creative and change from spaghetti to penne, or marinara to alfredo.

Maybe Anthony Bourdain will descend from heaven and casually tell you to add a single ingredient that makes it stick.

Or maybe you just have to keep throwing it over and over, past the point that you would usually quit.

One day, it will stick.

The culmination of all of your formerly unrewarded effort will be paid back 10 fold in an instant.

To others, you’ll appear to be an overnight success.

But you’ll know that’s not the case.

It was a result of tens, hundreds, or thousands of decisions and repetitions…

Plus a disdain for the run of the mill, competent effort.

Eventually, it works.

Keep firing, and test the occasional aberrant idea.

Ben

P.S. Let me know if you liked this one.

Someone recently left a comment on a video of mine saying “Anthony Bourdain energy.”

I was somehow unfamiliar with Anthony until then and just watched this video where I got that quote in the beginning of the email.

​

​

subject: The superpower you don’t know you have
content:
I have a superpower.

It's a singular strength I’ve really developed over the last few years.

It’s helped me in my personal life, business, and social media.

It seems to have made me more likable and has played a role in client acquisition and results.

Meaning it’s the reason people buy things.

And it’s probably the same reason you like my content (unless you hate it and you’re just here to talk shit in my replies).

The cool thing about this superpower, is it’s something you have too.

Maybe you’re accessing it right now, maybe you’re not.

But I think it’s one of the key factors in finding success in all the above domains.

“Ok Ben, I get it, this thing is important. Now would you tell me what it is???”

No.

Don’t you understand?

Right now, you’re either using your superpower or you’re not.

You’re either hearing me, or you’re not.

And that’s the secret.

My superpower is I listen.

I listen to others when they talk. Not just what they say, but what they mean.

When my girl says “it’s fine” I know that’s code for “you fucked up but I’m not telling you what you did, so you have to figure it out.”

When a prospect tells me about their business, I put myself in their shoes.

I think about their motives, desires and roadblocks.

And I assess their situation as objectively as I can.

This is obviously a huge part of copywriting and sales. It’s having the empathy to prescribe the right solution to a certain problem.

And if you don’t listen, you won’t be in tune with the problem.

Furthermore I listen to myself.

What do I actually want?

Why am I doing or not doing a certain thing?

Are my actions in alignment with what I say I want? And if not, am I willing to change?

I honestly think my habit to intellectualize my life is a blessing and curse.

It keeps me quite in touch with the underlying narratives going through my head.

Which helps me create content that feels really personal.

If it’s ever felt like I’m articulating an exact problem you have, and the way you think about it, this is why.

But sometimes it also stops me from taking action as quickly as I should.

Two sides to every coin I guess.

Anyway - listen more.

Stop jumping to conclusions.

Get off your high horse.

And do your best to be empathetic. Both with others and with yourself.

Remember - you’re one decision away from turning everything around.​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. My community, the Artisan Lab is in the works and launching soon.

If you want to learn from me in any capacity this is gonna be for you.

Plus it should be a really dope “networking” opportunity if you want to meet more people in the online money space who aren’t dorks.

Excited to let you in :)

​
​

subject: Don't forget about data
content:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Let’s talk about data.

Personally, I hate numbers.

I cheated in every math class I ever took.

But sometimes only data can reveal a clear answer when things are stagnant or you’re not getting a result you want.

This can be quite obvious when looking at quantifiable data.

If you’re spending $10k on ads and only making $5k back, clearly there's an issue.

Any reasonable person who doesn’t want to lose money would then try to figure out the problem.

To do this, they’d look at the more granular data.

The click through rate, cost per click, cost per impressions, conversion rate, etc.

Using this data, they’d attempt to identify the problem and test a solution.

Rinse and repeat.

This is a pragmatic, data-driven approach that will result in objective truths.

And if you’re not progressing in a certain area of your life the way you want to, this is what you need to apply.

Let’s say you’ve been trying to put on muscle for 6 months.

Your approach hasn’t been very meticulous and you stepped on the scale today and saw that you’ve only gained 2 pounds.

As a sensible person, capable of critical thought, what would you do in this scenario?

Answer in your head real quick.

If you said something along the lines of “I’d audit what I’m eating and how I’m working out, and see what needs to be changed,” you’ve come up with a solid answer.

Now for whatever reason, this ability to analyze data gets forgotten when the data is less quantifiable.

Meaning if you’ve been in a situation you don’t like for an extended period of time.

Whether it’s:

Trying to start a business and not making much progress

Stagnating in your business

Lack of growth on social media

Or even in your personal life:

Maybe you’ve been wanting to improve a relationship, you’ve had a list of hobbies that you wanted to try but haven’t, or you want to build better habits…

Whatever that thing is, you eventually need to take an objective look under the hood.

“Why am I not solving this problem I have? What are the variables that go into the problem? If I were to solve this problem, what would need to change?”

And just like that, you’ve given yourself action steps to execute on.

Don’t forget to look at the data in your life and perform mini-audits.

Be pragmatic, and find the objective truth.

Ben

P.S. I finished recording the last few modules of the Artisan Lab today.

It has basically become a digital version of my brain.

Here’s some of the info inside:

  • How I’ve built my agency to 6 figures/month
  • How we’ve scaled info businesses to $500k/month+
  • My full copywriting guide I’ve used to generate millions
  • The daily habits & routine that took me from being an average college kid to successful entrepreneur

Plus a lot more.

Thinking about launching it in the next couple days. Do you want more info?

​

subject: Hack to an easier life and effortless success
content:
I’m on my balcony watching a boat go by in the river in front of me.

It’s early in the morning so there's a really cool blue/white-ish/yellowish tone in the sky.

I’d take a picture and show you {{ subscriber.first_name }}, but my phone's inside and I don’t feel like getting up to go get it.

Anyway, I have an important topic for you today.

If you understand this one thing, you gain complete control of your life.

It creates a reality where everything becomes a choice.

From making more money, to improving your relationships, to feeling good about your daily routine.

You simply decide to make something happen and reality follows suit.

And luckily, the key to all of this is incredibly straightforward.

Ownership.

Taking ownership is how you make things happen with the push of a button.

I’m not referring to the “everything is your fault” type of narrative that you might hear online.

But rather understand that everything is your choice.

When you make a concerted effort to accomplish something, the outcome is largely dependent on you.

Sure, there are variables that you don’t control and you need to accept that.

But obsessing over, or placing blame on those variables will make you powerless.

So when you hear yourself start to blame external factors for why things aren’t working out in your favor, simply cut that narrative.

Even if it’s partially true, it doesn’t serve you.

It’s like if you’re playing a sport and you have a bad head coach who doesn’t let you play the way you want to.

You can complain about it, underperform and be miserable.

Or you can keep doing your best regardless of the situation.

Taking this approach to life makes you unfuckwithable.

If there’s a situation in your business that isn’t going according to plan, you fix it.

Even if that means a client is slacking on their responsibilities.

Or a team member isn’t performing the way you need them to.

Or there was a change in the algorithm and your old system isn’t working the same.

You take the problem into your own hands.

And you don’t do so with bitterness for other people in the equation, for they aren’t on my email list and didn’t get equipped with this superpower.

You are the master of your reality and no one and no thing can throw you off your shit.

That’s the mindset that serves you best and makes success effortless.

Take ownership of your shit and you’ll be a hell of a lot happier.

​And join the Artisan Lab if you want to accelerate your growth.​

Ben

subject: Benjamin is a loser
content:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }},

I'm sitting here with my friend Mason, who you probably know as the baby faced assassin copywriter.

We're about to go to dinner with our friend Tyler (TJR Trades) who you may also know as the day-trader who looks like a rapper.

There's a guy on Tik Tok named Benjamin Graham.

He must not have been loved as a child or he hasn't seen naked woman since the day he came out of his mothers womb.

This guy has taken it upon himself to become "the internets white-knight."

Basically he's the fat chick in a group of girls who tells you the pretty one isn't interested.

In every video he "calls out" someone new.

He'll cherry pick information and find a way to make the guy out to be a scammer.

His audience loves him.

Everyone in his comments will be like "Yeah! you exposed that guy! rEnteD LamBo course seller ScaMmEr!!!"

And then they probably continue putting the groceries in the bag during their shift at Publix.

THIS is the exact mindset that will keep you poor and miserable forever.

You'll be the guy who complains that the "bad guy" gets the girl.

You'll be the skeptic who hopes for crypto to crash, or the historically great sports team to lose.

You'll be the divorced single Mother who yells at the T.V. while watching Leonardo DiCaprio talk about his new 20-year-old super model girlfriend.

You'll be the unhappy, pessimistic, smug 50 year old who tells hopeful kids to "wait till you're my age because it all goes downhill."

But one time you'll be right.

You'll hang your hat on the fact that once upon a time, your skepticism was accurate.

Even though you get pissed off watching young guys on social media drive what was once your dream car.

While living where you once dreamt of and dating the girls you salivate over on social media...

You'll justify it all because every now and then, you do find a scammer.

So you elect to believe that it's all a scam and nothing more was ever possible.

Does that result in a fruitful, beautiful life?

No.

If you're reading this right now, it's in your best interest to believe that it's all possible.

You can be the guy in the supercar.

The business CAN work if you put the work in.

And making money online is possible for you because you're watching other people who are just like you do it.

Don't be a depressed, miserable dork.

Adopt the mindset that it can all be real, put in the according action, and eventually it will all unfold.

​And join The Artisan Lab if you want my help :)​

Ben

subject: How I land the best clients in the info space
content:
Gm.

I forgot to write to you yesterday.

Not because I don’t love you (I do).

But because I was quite busy.

I had a few one-on-ones with new members of my mastermind, I boxed with my trainer, and I brought in a special guest to do a group call with my community.

Then I was scrolling through Tik Tok and saw a creator with a huge audience and a really ugly funnel.

He probably had some 18 year old kid who calls himself a “growth operator” set it up for him.

It was a $27/month Skool community.

Now listen, I haven't sent an outbound dm since you were in diapers.

You’re probably around the same age as me, so that was a really long time ago.

But this guy was sitting on such an opportunity and I was so disgusted to see it being squandered.

So, I ran into my office and made him a loom video pitch.

It took me 2 seconds to find his email, I wrote a few lines of copy and sent the loom.

Using my little spy tool, I saw he opened it instantly.

Then I got a notification that “someone” watched my video.

He didn’t reply yet, but he went over to my instagram and followed me.

We’ll see. I honestly don’t care if he closes or not.

But it’d be really cool if I could flex on all of you who’ve been doing outreach for a while.

Imagine you’re working your ass off sending 30 pitches a day.

And then you see me, scrolling through tik tok in my pajamas when I find your ideal client.

I open my laptop, click the loom button and start rambling about how we’ve made a lot of clients a lot of moneys.

Next thing you know I’m on a call with your ideal client and he loves me.

We talk about the weather and he tells me about his favorite spots in Miami when he was my age.

I show him the keys to my Porsche 911 turbo and then tell him I can help him make the equivalent of 3 of them in a month.

He’s wowed.

I pitch a price 100x the average growth operator or copywriters net worth.

He says “YES!!!” and asks if he can add a tip.

I receive the wire on the call, my team builds him a new funnel, and we make him $1m next month.

Hahahaha.

That would be cool.

I shared this whole outbound process (including the loom and email I sent) inside the Artisan Lab btw.​

I didn’t expect to write a rather arrogant email to you today, but here we are.

It would also be funny if this whole thing blew up in my face.

I’ll keep you updated.

This inspired me to start doing outbound again. It’s kind of fun.

Anyway, you can apply to join my mastermind here if you want to get a behind the scenes look at it all.​

Talk to you tomorrow,

Ben

subject: Moooooooooove
content:
A lot has changed since the last email I sent to you.

First, I moved.

Here’s my new POV as I begin writing to you:

I’m now 80 something floors up with the water view you see above.

It’s much more peaceful than being in the middle of the city (and better than being on a poverty floor under the clouds).

I was reminded of a very valuable lesson during this move.

You see, I’m the type of guy that does everything last minute.

ESPECIALLY if it’s something trivial or a task I don’t want to do.

So I waited until 6pm on the day before I was supposed to move to start clicking around on the internet to find a moving company.

I filled out a few forms to get quotes and assumed they’d reach out within a day or two.

Next thing you know, I get a call from a local number.

Keep in mind, it’s Sunday at 7:24pm EST, less than an hour after I filled out the form.

Some kind woman is on the other end with the moving company and she tells me she can send movers as early as tomorrow.

I’m sold.

I don’t care about the price.

I don’t care to get quotes from other companies.

I had a problem and this woman Kathy (not her real name but she sounded like a Kathy) extinguished that problem quickly.

That’s the lesson.

If you’re selling agency services or coaching, or literally anything…

MOVE FASTER.

I’ve personally lost deals because I was too slow or wasn’t “available” until a few days later.

By then the urgency is gone.

And the pain that comes with a fresh problem is diminished, meaning getting the sale is gonna be harder.

This is why it’s a good rule of thumb to have a sales team that dials every lead immediately (if you run a coaching business and you’re not doing this, that means you enjoy poverty).

One of the first lessons I was taught when I started running ads for local basketball trainers 4 years ago, was “speed = lead.”

I was in this coaching program and my coach told me to drill this message into the heads of my clients.

My job was to get them leads, but if they don’t contact those leads ASAP, then they’re throwing money down a furnace.

As you know, business is just a game of solving problems.

The bigger problems you solve and the faster you can do so, the more money you make.

The first moving company that called me late on a Sunday got my business and charged me $1,200 to move me 5 minutes down the street.

Maybe there was a cheaper option.

But the problem was resolved and I’m happy to pay a premium for the efficiency.

​Don’t be slow or you’ll get left behind.​

Ben

​

​

subject: Spend more money
content:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }},

I have a quick money lesson for you today.

Once upon a time I was extremely attached to money.

When it was a good month in my business, I was happy.

When it wasn't a good month, I wanted to go play in traffic.

This obviously made my internal state a bit of a rollercoaster.

I'd get hung up on a number in my bank account and if it wasn't growing -- or even worse, if it was declining, it'd make me anxious.

In my opinion, frugality and neuroticism are not traits that result in fruitful life.

So one day, I started spending money a lot more freely.

I stopped thinking about paying for food, hotels, flights, or any investment that would help my business.

Over time, the number that felt like a lot of money to me drastically increased.

This is what broke my attachment to the number in my bank account.

I've watched that number go up by $50k-$100k in a day.

But I've also cringed while tipping the bottle girl the equivalent of a decent email marketing retainer on a $15k night out.

My current lifestyle is expensive.

And it's part of what helped me expand my mindset around money.

The less I've hesitated to send a $20k wire to grow my business, buy first class seats, doordash every meal, etc...

The more money I have made.

If you view a number as small and achievable, it becomes exactly that.

If you're scared to spend money on yourself, then why would anyone spend money on you?

Lesson in there.

Anyway I gotta get on a call for Artisan Lab -- which you should totally join here if you want to spend money on yourself :)​

Ben

​

subject: One thing you should've started yesterday
content:
Inside my new mastermind, The Artisan Lab, I bring in a new guest speaker each week.

This keeps it fresh and it’s interesting to hear various perspectives from people who have found success in their domain.

Last night my friend Miles was kind enough to host a call.

He’s one of the most reputable personal brands in the Amazon seller space (@flips4miles on all platforms).

Miles has been creating content since the day I met him 3 or 4 years ago.

He documented his entire journey from zero to selling 7 figures worth of products on Amazon.

The guy is autistically consistent – and I mean that in the best way possible.

If you want to see, go look at his socials right now.

He’s constantly posting.

In fact, he’s written a Twitter thread every day for nearly 2 years now.

As a result, he’s grown multiple successful businesses off the back of his personal brand.

2 software companies and a coaching business that you will only see positive reviews from.

But on last night's call, he said that he made basically no money from his first 3 years of posting online.

He actually wasn’t even trying to monetize his brand, he was posting content as a way to build good will and connect with other people in the Amazon space.

I’m telling you all of this because I want you to understand one thing:

If you plan on being in the online business world for a while and you’re not posting any content, you likely have a room temperature IQ.

There are a few exceptions to this but let’s disregard that for now.

More people knowing and trusting you can only make you more money.

Period.

Even if you’re towards the beginning of your journey, get the ball rolling and then start documenting the process.

You don’t have to build a Hormozi type brand.

You don’t even have to grow a large audience.

But simply existing as a normal human on the internet will only open doors for you (as long as you don’t say anything that will get you canceled).

Even if you never want to sell coaching, you can make money without your personal brand, and you think your teeth are too crooked to show your face on camera…

It will only serve you, I promise.

It’s how I met all of my best friends you see me hanging out with.

And it’s the only reason you’re reading this right now.

Now before you say “I dOn’T kNoW whAt tO poSt AbOut.”

It doesn’t matter.

Just start. Talk about what you find interesting. Talk about why you’re poor. Talk about your dog, or your girl, or your obsession with sports betting.

Just don’t say the N word or call fat people disgusting hippos.

You’ll be glad you started.

​Get access to the next guest speaker call by going here.​

Bye,

Ben

​
