subject: how to practice your writing ability
content:
Hey.

I’m starting this email completely blind.

Meaning I have zero idea what’s gonna come out onto this page.

Hopefully it’s kind of coherent.

I went for a walk this morning.

My new apartment is right by the water so it’s nice being able to go outside, cross the street, and start moving.

It seems like everyone else who walks during this early morning shift is one of two things:

1.Old

2.Dog

I’m neither of the two.

Although I did find a gray hair on my head the other day and I accidentally barked when I saw a pretty girl in the elevator.

Hmm.

Ok, this leads me to a lesson for you.

If you want to become a better writer, you need to enjoy it.

So far in this email, I’ve said nothing of value.

But I’m having fun. And you’re still here, so that means maybe you’re having fun with me.

I’ve never deliberately “practiced” my copywriting ability, I just wrote.

I started sending emails to this list in September 2021.

There were probably 6 people who’d subscribed, including my 4 burner emails, my mother, and grandma.

On top of that, I was effectively an autistic Chinese child who didn’t speak a word of English (if that offended you, grow up).

I had no idea what I was talking about, nothing to sell, and very few people who cared to listen to what I was saying.

But I started anyway.

I developed my own style, my writing became more clear, and I began articulating the ideas that were rattling around in my head.

Along with the newsletter, I was consistently tweeting and journaling.

This was the “training camp” that prepared me to work with clients.

I’d read a few copywriting books, I practiced every day (even though it didn’t feel like practice), and I became half-decent at this writing thing.

It’d be impossible not to.

One of my favorite copywriting books is The Boron Letters by Gary Halbert.

The reason I like it is because it feels personal (he wrote it to his son while he was in jail).

Instead of writing in a super authoritative tone, it reads as if it’s a journal with insights and tips sprinkled throughout.

You can tell he clearly enjoys writing and isn’t putting any pressure on himself to be grammatically correct or follow any rules.

This is how you have to practice.

Write about your day.

Write about something you enjoy.

Write about how you overcame a difficult time in your life.

Write about the weird crush you have on your cleaning lady (creep).

It doesn’t matter what you write about, as long as you find a way to enjoy it, and it doesn’t feel like work.

Ok?

Ok.

Enough for today.

​Join me in the Artisan Lab if you want to get rich.​

If you don’t want to join me in there, that’s fine. But at least reply and tell me you made it all the way down here to make me feel good.

Thanks,

Ben

​

​

subject: nice try diddy
content:
I’ve been a bit stressed out lately that my content hasn’t been doing super well.

YouTube views are down, Tik Tok only pushes my videos when I say something controversial, and half the retards in the comments tell me to “put the fries in the bag.”

This is the new normie army insult and it’s pretty funny.

They’ve also started leaving “Nice try Diddy” in the comments on ads.

If only they put that energy into something that would actually improve their lives.

Anyway, whenever I’m stressed, I do one of three things.

The first thing is bad.

If I do this, I lose.

It temporarily numbs the stress but doesn’t revolve anything.

And it’s scrolling through social media.

Now the other two mechanisms I use to combat stress seem to work like magic for me.

The first is doing what I’m doing right now, writing.

I wrote a whole email to you yesterday and made a Youtube video about how writing will change your life, so no need to repeat myself.

Just trust me. Start today if you haven't.

The second thing is walking.

What better way to clear your head?

It’s literally impossible to be sad when the sun is shining and birds are chirping.

I could watch my best friend get eaten by a lizard but if it’s a nice day I’ll get over it.

Ok maybe that’s an exaggeration.

Back to the point.

On my walk in the sun this morning, I thought about my life.

I realized that success comes in waves.

There will be times where I can pull out my phone, make a minute long video and get a million views.

And there will be times where I feel like I’m spewing gold into the camera only for a couple thousand people to even see it.

Every wave eventually crashes.

But the ocean never stops moving.

Your time will come.

And if you’re riding a wave right now, get as much as you can out of it.

Last thing:

I also realized how ungrateful I was being by complaining about metrics.

People leave comments and reply to my emails telling me how much I’ve impacted their lives, but I’m unhappy because the views are down?

What a bitch.

Do not take for granted what you have, just because you want more.

Greed will make you lose it all.

I appreciate you {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Thank you for reading my emails and engaging with my content.

I’ll stop taking you for granted.

Have a great day,

Ben

P.S. Join Artisan Lab here​

P.P.S Reply if you liked this one <3

​
​

​

subject: how to stop the Chinese from infiltrating your mind
content:
Cdhsuifhinfkfbedbfqbef!

Hey.

Ignore the gibberish in the first line. I’m just excited to talk to you.

Hope you’re having an amazing Thursday morning.

What do you want to talk about today?

Oh, I got something.

Decisions.

Isn’t it crazy how our entire reality is shaped by countless micro decisions we’re making on a daily basis?

Like you could just wake up one day and start speaking with a British accent.

Or you could simply decide to stop being poor and take the actions necessary to make money.

Orrr you could decide to stop pulling out and build an NFL team of babies.

Everyday you choose to either take actions that will further align you with the person you want to be, or do the opposite.

When you open your laptop and the voice in your head tells you that you need to scroll through TikTok for a minute before starting work – can you shut it out or do you give in?

Because you know ‘one minute’ usually turns into three hours.

You simply cannot compete with the Chinese artificial intelligence algorithm.

They figured out, “Oh, all we have to do is show men titties and show women travel videos and Hermes bags and they just keep scrolling forever. Stupid little lizards.”

Can you resist the double D’s and birkins?

Or will you give in to the Chinese?

Hahahah.

Sorry I got carried away on that one.

Recently I had to make a big decision.

It was not easy but I knew that it would be better for me in the long run.

My brain tried to do everything in its power to stop me.

Because with this decision, much change would come.

And that’s painful.

Even days after I’d made up my mind, I’d still find myself trying to revert back to old habits.

I quite literally had to view the voice in my head like a toddler.

“No, you don’t actually want that. It’s just a narrative you’re telling yourself because it’s easier than the alternative.”

I used logic to constantly remind myself that I was making the right call.

And there was this underlying feeling in my gut that knew that was true.

I’m telling you all this because I want you to make the right choices.

You know what you need to do.

You know what needs to change.

And you know that further contemplation is just a way to occupy your brain so that you feel like you’re being productive.

Don’t let the Chinese control you.

Resist!

​Lmao,​

Ben
​

​

subject: everything is bad and that's really good
content:
Three days ago I sent you an email about how my content hadn’t been getting many views.

Yesterday, I had three videos go semi-viral on Tik Tok.

Whenever this happens, it fries my dopamine receptors for a few days.

Every time I refresh the app, I have more comments, follows, and dm’s.

And since I’m addicted to dopamine, I end up spending the whole day staring at my phone.

It’s funny how this works.

In my email the other day, I talked about how success comes in waves.

It felt like I’d been paddling, trying to catch a wave for a while and I was getting restless.

But I knew I just had to keep trying.

Two days later, I caught three waves in a row.

The obvious lesson there is that you never know when your time will come but if you keep shooting, you can’t go wrong.

The less obvious lesson is that “good and “bad” do not exist in reality, they are constructs of the mind.

I know it might sound like I’m reaching in an attempt to sound insightful right now and you’re like, “Ok buddy whatever the fuck that means.”

Allow me to explain.

When I was frustrated about my content not performing, it was a lot easier to sit and work on real business tasks.

It was the source of the lesson in my email the other day.

And it forced me to not let my desire for external validation control and discourage me.

You could make the argument that my content flopping was actually a “good” thing.

On the contrary, because I’ve had these few videos go viral, it’s been really difficult to do anything else.

Sitting at my desk to do real work feels like a herculean feat.

I’m constantly checking my phone and I now feel an added pressure to make my videos continually perform.

Again, we could make a solid argument here for why virality is a “bad” thing.

But in reality, neither of those conclusions would be completely true.

It simply is as it is.

There are countless pro’s when a situation isn’t going as you’d hoped.

There are countless con’s when a situation is going exactly how you wanted it.

It’s your perception that makes it good or bad.

Don’t get caught up in that perception.

And remember, every hurdle is part of a bigger plan.

Alright I gotta get back to scrolling.

But before I do, quick plug – I went on this podcast recently and discussed some things I haven’t talked much about publicly.​

Go watch that and happy Saturday,

Ben

​
​

Ok, last thing for today.

On my walk this morning it started raining.

It wasn't pouring, but it was enough to where others scrambled for cover.

At first, I was going to join them.

But then I figured what the hell, a few raindrops never killed anyone.

I continued on as if nothing was happening.

A few minutes later the rain stopped.

And not long after that, I was completely dry again.

Because I kept moving, the rain didn't effect me.

It would've been worse had I stopped.

In life, you have to choice to do the same thing.

When it's "raining," and bad things are happening to you, or your mind is pulling you in a million different directions...

You can just carry on as if nothing is happening.

And most of the time the "problem" dissolves.

After the rain, comes the rainbow. Lol.

Ben

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }}, we're going to Vietnam
content:
Good morning {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

I went for a run and then tried to meditate but it didn’t really work.

Now I’m here, typing to you.

I’m actually sitting at the desk in my “office,” which is really just a den.

Since I moved about three weeks ago, this has been the last area of my new apartment that still needs work.

The lighting in here is kind of depressing and I have a bunch of random belongings on the floor.

Because of this, I’ve avoided this room.

My phone is in the kitchen because I’ve been really addicted to it recently.

It’s cool that you can get rich and all from your fingertips but wow can that device be destructive.

On my run earlier, I thought about what it must’ve been like to be a young man who was shipped off to fight in the Vietnam war.

Imagine you’re a 19 year old kid, fresh out of high school.

You’re awakened in the middle of the night by Forrest Gump.

He grabs you by the ear and takes you with him.

Next thing you know you have an AK-47 in your hands and you’re shooting at anyone who has squinty eyes.

What a turn of events, huh?

All of the problems you had prior to being drafted have now vanished.

You’re no longer worried about what career you’re gonna go into.

You stopped thinking about what to say to the girl you have a crush on.

And you couldn’t give a singular shit about the decor in home or clothes on your back.

You now have one goal;

Survive.

If you’re reading this, I assume that the Vietnamese are not currently trying to blow your head off.

What a lucky guy (or girl) you are.

I’m in the same boat.

And although this is obviously a privilege, it comes with consequences.

Naturally, you want a war.

You want a mountain to climb, and a communist to shoot at.

But because life is relatively easy, you have to avoid the trap of getting caught up in bullshit problems so that you feel like you’re progressing.

In other words, don’t stress about inconsequential things because you don’t have a life or death thing.

You need to find your Vietnam war.

Actually, let me rephrase that.

You need to make your life the Vietnam war.

Build businesses, go hard in the gym, nurture beautiful relationships, get famous, fight a homeless man (lol), travel the globe…

Just do something.

Preferably something that’s actually productive instead of worrying about things that have little impact on your life.

That’s how you avoid becoming a Karen who gets mad at kids for skateboarding on the sidewalk.

Or becoming a fat incel whose only joy is yelling racial slurs at the TV.

Or even a manic 46 year old housewife who yells at the gardener because he missed a blade of grass.

You need real(er) problems.

Stuff that’s actually worth stressing about.

And you’re likely not gonna get sent to Vietnam any time soon so you have to bring Nam’ to you.

You’re lucky. Don’t waste your luck.

Ben

P.S. Join me in the Artisan lab here.​

P.P.S. Lmk if you made it all the way down here, soldier.

​
​

​

subject: this is the opportunity of the decade
content:
Happy Monday.

On my walk this morning I overheard a guy talking about the hospitality industry.

It sounds like times are tough right now.

A friend of mine who works in nightlife told me the same thing recently.

Allegedly, a lot of the bigger clubs and restaurants are losing money.

Like, lots of money.

I began thinking about how complex it must be to run a hospitality group.

Between staffing, opening new locations, logistics, operations and a myriad of other factors I’m probably overlooking.

And then finally on top of all that, the most important piece; marketing.

You have to deal with all of these annoying logistical issues and even once you solve all of them, you will still fail if you don’t get people in the doors.

That does not sound like a fun time.

Let’s compare this to an online service based business or coaching business.

There are two main objectives in each of these.

1. Create an attractive, in-demand offer.

2. Generate demand.

It’s actually the same process of building a club or restaurant, without the world of complexity attached to it.

With an internet business, all you have to do is learn some skills and build the offer.

That can take a week.

And basically costs nothing.

Once the offer is built, you can dedicate the majority of your focus to acquisition.

If your content gets attention, or you build a lucrative outbound system, or you can profitably put a dollar into Facebook and get $2 back, scaling becomes easy.

You double down on the acquisition system and you make sure nothing breaks on the backend.

Next thing you know, you have a $5m/year business that was built off a couple TikTok videos, loom pitches, or cringy ads.

Obviously I’m oversimplifying this a bit, but it really is this simple.

You lose when you try to make it more complicated.

If you’re struggling to grow as a service provider or a coach, one of two things are happening.

1. You’re focusing on the wrong things and distracting yourself from the actual needle movers.

2. You’re just really dumb. No offense, but you are cooked. I think McDonalds is hiring though.

You might not realize it, but opportunity in the info-product space right now is similar to the way paid ads were 10-15 years ago.

I was in diapers back then, but a friend of mine told me he was getting 1 cent cost per click on his ads.

1 cent.

Meaning, holy fuck, you’re gonna get rich.

But over time, that opportunity diminishes and it gets more expensive.

Right now, in 2024 you can whip out your phone and make a 48 second selfie video that millions of people could see.

If the content in the video is somewhat useful and you have an offer that correlates with it, you now have a seven figure business.

I’m not exaggerating.

Idiots are getting rich.

​Do you want to join them?​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​

​

subject: Does success come down to luck?
content:
Gooooood morning!

I’m sitting on my balcony and the sun is beaming in my eyes so I’m squinting at the screen.

My neighbors just let out their dogs to take their morning piss on this mat of grass that they’ve been trained to urinate on.

They have these two little beige pugs named Ricco and Rocco.

Those aren’t actually their real names but it’s what I would have named them.

I’m going to steal them one day.

Anyway, let’s talk about how to get lucky.

Some people say luck doesn’t exist.

Others believe everyone who’s successful gets lucky.

In my opinion, both of the above statements are true, even though they’re contradictory.

This is called a paradox, in case you slept through that part of English class.

I watched a movie last night that had Miles Teller in it and began thinking about how you end up as a world famous actor.

Sure, he’s great at what he does.

But so are the tens of thousands of broke actors.

There are plenty of people with the same look, talent, and work ethic.

Why is he one of few who makes it?

Is it luck?

No.

Well, yes.

Well, kind of.

If you run a quick Google search on Miles Teller, you’ll see that he made his first feature film in 2010.

Three years later, he starred in “The Spectacular Now” which put him on the map.

And then the film, “Whiplash” a year later was his big breakthrough.

Now he’s one of the more popular actors and was recently in Top Gun with Tom Cruise.

But you don’t hear about all the projects that flopped.

From 2004-2010 he was in a bunch of movies neither of us have ever heard of.

Then he had a few “big breaks” and his life changed forever.

This is how success works.

The majority of the time that you put in, especially in the beginning, will feel like it’s all for nothing.

You’ll think to yourself, “why am I even working this hard? Nobody’s gonna notice me anyway.”

It’s an uphill battle and you have no idea where the top of the hill is.

You just keep climbing and hope that eventually you find it, which isn’t guaranteed.

You could climb for decades and still end up as one of the unknown actors who never found a good role.

It’s a gamble.

Maybe you’ll get lucky, maybe you won’t.

However, there are ways that you can increase your chances.

Consistency plus iteration creates luck.

I think that's the smartest thing I’ve said all year.

If you don’t quit and you continually strive to get better at the craft, you have a chance.

Worst case scenario, it’s likely that your effort will result in an opportunity, even if it’s not the one you were anticipating.

And best case scenario…

​Well, the sky's the limit.​

Happy hunting,

Ben

P.S. Reply if you made it all the way down here :)

​

​

subject: pain
content:
Up until my junior year of high school, I was dead set on playing college basketball.

Being a “hooper” was my entire identity.

But over the previous year, some doubt had started to creep in.

“Maybe this isn’t right for me anymore,” a voice in my head would tell me.

I tried to ignore it, but it wouldn’t go away.

When I’d consider what life would be like if I decided not to play collegiately, it was daunting.

All of my friends and family knew me as this basketball guy.

It’s how I viewed myself.

How embarrassing would it be to change that?

I’d look like a crazy person.

And I had no idea what’s on the other side.

But I couldn’t shake that feeling in my gut that knew it was time for a different route.

In a single moment, I made the decision.

I was no longer going to play in college.

It was time to let that story go and when I did, I became free.

“Walking away from anything you love because it’s not working for you is the only character building exercise there is. People can't comprehend how much you have to screw yourself over to get self respect.” - Brute

It’s no secret that change is difficult.

Changing your habits is painful.

Changing your career path is painful.

Changing your negative thought patterns is painful.

Because of this, most people elect to endure situations that aren’t right for them in order to avoid the pain that comes with change.

Sure, working a job you hate sucks, but quitting that job to bet on yourself would be temporarily more painful than staying in it.

Your willingness to exchange this low level, long term pain for high level, short term pain is what makes you grow.

You choose to dig the hole a little deeper.

You choose to put yourself in a tough situation.

You choose to sacrifice your (illusionary) peace for struggle.

And then you’re free.

It’ll be difficult and even after making the decision your ego will try to pull you back into comfort.

But if you can withstand that tide, you’ll make it to the other side as a new person.

Comfort kills you slowly. Pain kills you instantly.

And maybe that’s what you need.

Happy Monday,

Ben

P.S. Join me inside my mastermind if you’re ready to grow.​

P.P.S. Watch my new video with 8 figure info-product seller, Tim Luong​

subject: when it rains, it pours
content:
Around this time last year, I hit my first $100k month as a growth partner.

If you’re completely new here, here’s how my business works in a nutshell:

I partner with “influencers" who sell courses (think trading influencer or eCom guru).

I help them build a program from scratch or improve their current offer

My team and I run all of their operations.

From their sales funnels, to email marketing, automations, scripting videos, sales team, etc.

My client's job is to make content.

My job is to help them get the people who watch their content to buy their course.

Make sense?

I hope so, because I just explained that to you as if you’re an autistic monkey.

Anyway, about 2 years ago, I was stuck between $10-20k per month.

It was frustrating seeing people who I deemed incompetent make way more money than me.

I was working really hard but just couldn’t get through that ceiling.

And then, something changed.

I hit $25k.

Then $30k the next month.

Then $35k.

$50k.

I hovered around $60k-80k for a bit.

And then, I finally hit $100k.

It was all because of one thing:

Positioning.

When I was stuck under $20k/month, I had no leverage.

I would take any opportunity I could get.

I was writing a ton of copy, building funnels, managing CRMs, and it all felt discombobulated.

Every client I got basically felt like I had a boss telling me what to do.

But then, I got one really good win.

I helped a client go from $30k/month to $350k per month in 2 months.

A couple months later we were past $500k/month.

Not only did that result in a multiple 5 figure rev share for me, but it put me on the map.

It changed the way I was perceived by others because I could flex that case study.

And it changed the way I perceived myself because I saw my actions result in such a drastic impact.

That singular win is all it took to give me endless opportunities, and the conviction I needed to be able to handle them.

If you’re trying to build a copywriting or growth partner business right now, keep this in mind.

Just get one fat W, and the floodgates will open my friend.

Extrapolate this to any life pursuit you’re stagnating in.

When it rains, it pours.

​Come check out Artisan Lab if you want to learn from me directly.​

Later,

Ben

subject: famous and broke
content:
I officially know what it would feel like to be a broke influencer.

You may have seen some of the skits I’ve been posting on Tik Tok as they’ve gotten over 15m views in the last 30 days.

It’s wild.

As cool as it is, it offers me almost no monetary benefit (at least for now).

I always wondered how ‘micro-influencers’ made their money and I now understand that most don’t.

Sure I’ve gained some followers, gotten a bunch of DM’s and have been recognized in public a bit more.

But I’ve made $0.00 from it.

Obviously, it’s a different story once you reach real fame and can make solid money from brand deals.

However, if you want to monetize your personal brand, you’re better off making niche educational content and building an audience of a few thousand people.

Then you can sell coaching and happily make millions without having to rely on brand deals.

On a similar topic, I’ve been thinking a lot about the intersection between comedy and philosophy.

The funniest people are often the most observant.

They can turn a niche observation into a joke.

They can articulate the thing everyone is thinking, but can’t express.

They can use analogies to connect two seemingly unconnected ideas.

Similarly, the most profound insights are often gained from uniquely personal experiences.

The lesson is articulated in a way that is so personal, that it becomes universal.

Again, it’s the thing that everyone thinks but no one says.

Ironically, I don’t really have a lesson for this email.

These are just some insights I’ve gained as of late and figured I’d share because what else is there to do other than attempt to entertain and educate strangers on the internet?

Anyway, let’s have a good week.

Focus on the needle movers and stop stressing over nothing, okay?

Progress is simple, you just have to get out of your own way sometimes.

Happy Monday, join me in my mastermind if you want to get rich selling info.​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

subject: No business model will make you rich
content:
Let’s talk about money.

When you’re a beginner, you typically think you need to find the right business model.

In reality, it’s not the label that’s important.

Whether you’re a copywriter, IPGA, IPO, growth operator, growth partner, etc.

All of these terms are different ways to say the same thing.

You offer ‘done for you’ services to online businesses.

This is important to understand because a business model doesn’t make you money, your skillset does.

People like me, Pierre Khoury, and others who’ve had success in this space have been able to do so because we can offer a multitude of services and truly increase revenue.

It’s definitely NOT because of a fancy label we placed on our services.

This brings me to my second point, which is that the market decides your niche.

In my business, our biggest wins have come through webinars.

It’s the main reason I’ve gotten to 6 figure months.

But that happened on accident.

We tested a webinar for a client and it worked.

We figured we’d try it out for other clients and it kept working.

That doesn’t mean that your business has to work the same way as mine.

Your big wins could come through VSLs.

Or you could figure out that you’re really good at scripting YT videos or short form content.

Or maybe you end up specializing in email automations.

My point here is that you’re a marketer, not a robot.

If you label yourself as a growth operator and you’ll only work with creators who have an audience but don’t have an offer yet, your TAM (total addressable market) is limited.

But if you drop the label and think of yourself as a marketer, you can fit into different roles.

That’s how you get your foot in the door with a client (solve one niche problem they’re facing) and then you start to take over other pieces of their business.

Get one big win, and you have a solidified offer.

This doesn’t happen overnight, but it’s the best way to do it if you wanna work with coaches and course creators.

Learn some skills, pitch a bunch of shit, see what works, double down.

Now you’re rich. You’re welcome.

​Go here if you want my help in growing your info-product agency or coaching business.​

Ben

​
​

subject: An email about nothing
content:
Good morning.

I’m sitting on my balcony with an iced latte and a dream.

I don’t know what the dream is, but I thought that sounded cool.

It’s September 5, 2024 which means I turn 24 in 17 days.

Does that mean I’m… old? Do I need to start taking viagra? Am I developing cataracts?

Oh no.

I’m going to New York with my friends Jimmy and Mason today.

We have quite the weekend planned, but if I told you about it, I’d have to kill you.

I don’t think I could ever live in NY.

I have one major flaw and it’s that I’m geographically challenged.

I don’t know what body of water I’m looking at off my balcony right now.

I don’t know if I’m facing east, west, north, south, or upside down.

I don’t know how to get nearly anywhere without a GPS.

Miami is relatively small and I have a hard enough time navigating it.

I can’t imagine how lost I’d be in New York.

Plus I’d have a bunch of angry neurotic people yelling at me.

Speaking of, the other day I watched a clip of Jerry Seinfeld and Larry David.

They were talking about Seinfeld, and how it was “a show about nothing.”

This is an email about nothing.

Well actually, I guess I do have something to tell you:

Sorry.

I’ve been slacking on Youtube.

I was growing really quickly at first, then I hit a plateau, and got too caught up in the numbers.

My focus went from “how can I make content that I enjoy?”

To “how can I hook these stupid little lizard brained monkeys into watching more of my video so the algorithm pushes it?”

And that took the fun out of it.

I’m gonna get back on there and stop worrying about the metrics, I promise.

But it might be a few days because there’s a solid chance I get lost in New York.

Anyway, here’s my last thought for you today:

You can always find a reason to stress when you tie your sense of self to your accomplishments.

In that sense, you’ll never be complete.

Sure, this can be a way to motivate yourself but it also stains every experience with jaded glasses.

You’ll be in the club in New York with a dozen models around you and your favorite song playing as you dance with your best friends.

But you won’t be all the way there.

There will be a part of you that’s anxious, worrying about how you don’t have $100m yet.

Instead, learn to accept what is.

You’re on your journey and that’s that.

Stressing doesn’t fix anything, so you might as well be where you are.

Congrats. You’ve completed this email about nothing.

Let me know if you made it all the way down here.

See you in NY,

Ben

P.S. Join my mastermind here.​

​

​

​
​

subject: How to write an email
content:
I’m on the run.

I just let housekeeping into my hotel room and am now homeless for the next 30 minutes.

Should I join the crackheads that roam the streets of NYC?

Actually, I have a better idea.

The other day, someone asked me about my process for writing copy.

So this is an email about how to write an email.

If you’ve been on this list for a while, you know that my style is a bit more casual than your average newsletter.

Sometimes I ramble about random thoughts, other times I hash out an idea or concept, and every now and then I’ll send you a harder pitch for Artisan Lab.​

No matter what, I have one goal in every line of copy I write.

And it’s to get you to read the next line.

Typically I start this by bringing you into my world.

This is where I set the scene.

I’ll tell you where I am, what kind of state I’m in, and try to make you feel like you’re right here with me.

It’s personal and casual style.

My best emails seem to be when I describe an idea in a way that’s so detailed to where you feel like I’m articulating your own thoughts.

It creates this feeling where we’re solving a problem together.

Me and you against the world, baby.

This is where I think I have a bit of an edge on your average copywriter.

Most end up talking down to their audience.

They put themselves on this authoritative pedestal, and are so obsessed with “giving value” that it eradicates the value.

Because people hate being told what to do for no reason.

If you tell someone why they should live a certain way or think a certain way, without giving them context as to how you arrived at that conclusion, you’re just preaching.

It’s the personal aspect and storytelling that makes the lessons hit.

If I tell you a story about how I overcame a fear and then connect the dots for you as to how you can do the same in your own life, that’s when it resonates.

Versus if I were to impose my own beliefs on you without providing any personal anecdotes, you’d have stopped reading by now.

You read my emails because I talk directly to you.

I don’t think about “providing value” because I know that if my email is personal enough, it becomes valuable.

Is this making sense?

I hope so.

I’m dying for a bacon egg and cheese here so I have to run, but the last thing I’ll leave you with is this:

You just have to trust yourself.

I often start these emails without any idea of what I’m going to say.

But I know that if I just begin writing, my subconscious brain starts to work for me.

It feeds me an analogy or story that I can use to articulate my point.

And by the time I get to the end, it ends up being pretty coherent (most of the time).

Ok I’m starving.

Hope you enjoyed my email about emails, join me in the Artisan Lab if you wanna learn more from me.​

Love you,

Ben

​
​

subject: F*** the audience
content:
Gooooood morning, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

I got back from New York last night, ready to lock back in and make some money.

Hope you’re doing the same.

As I sit here pondering what to write to you about, I found myself thinking, “what will my audience get value from?”

This is a really stupid question.

I could sit here and try to guess what you would find valuable.

I could think of an angle or analogy to drive my point home.

And then I could pitch you my mastermind and a handful of you would apply.

It works, but it lacks some personality.

You want to know the lessons that seem to hit the hardest?

They’re the ones where I don’t give a fuck about you.

I don’t try to think of what you need to hear.

I don’t tailor my message to hook you in or get you to click a link.

And the word “value” doesn’t cross my mind.

Instead, I write about what I want to write about.

Typically it’ll be a problem I’m overcoming, a recent observation, or something else that’s very personal to me.

I can articulate the idea with so much detail, because I don’t have to imagine what it would be like.

I’m in my own shoes.

Couple that with the fact that I’m not trying to appease the audience (you), and that’s what makes you feel like I understand you.

It’s like when you’re trying to win over a girl.

When you’re an idiot, you think “oh, if I just agree with everything she says and try to say all the right things back to her, she’ll like me.”

Then you learn that’s not a recipe for success.

You’re not expressing yourself freely.

You’re uncomfortable.

You’re trying to gain something from her, and you both subconsciously know that.

Plus it's exhausting.

But what happens when you let go?

When you stop caring about winning someone’s approval, you take back the wheel.

You make the jokes you want to make.

You say the thing that everyone else is thinking but too nervous to say.

You’re comfortably, freely, you.

And that’s the most attractive state you can be in.

Pure indifference because you are who you are.

Whether you’re speaking to an audience or courting your future ex baby mama.

Think less about what they want and more about what you want.

It sounds counterintuitive, but it’s actually a much more selfless act than the alternative.

Hope you enjoyed this one.

​Hop in here if you wanna get rich selling info.​

Ben

​
​

subject: Become a Swiss army knife marketer
content:
Once upon a time, you could get away with being a one trick pony.

You could go to a business, pitch them a singular service, and close them.

When I started out, that’s what I did.

I’d pitch course sellers on building them a new funnel.

This worked to get my first few clients.

But I quickly learned that when you solve one problem, it exposes three more.

I could build the best funnel in the world but if traffic was low or if their emails sucked, it wouldn’t make a difference.

So, I started to take over more pieces of my clients' businesses.

Because I understood copywriting, it was easy.

I began writing their emails, scripting their VSLs, scripting ads, etc.

And then on the operations side, I built automations, managed their systems, and set up CRMs.

I know this sounds like a lot, but it’s actually quite simple.

Once you learn the fundamentals of direct response marketing, you can add new skills to your toolbox in a couple hours.

It’s exactly what I did and next thing you know, I had clients paying me anywhere from $10k-$40k per month each.

The reason this model works is because it turns you into a Swiss army knife.

You can work with just about anyone, because you have a multitude of skills.

If they already have an email copywriter, you can build them a new funnel.

If they already have a funnel builder, you can write them a new VSL or script short form content.

If they’re just starting out, you can help them build from scratch.

This is actually how one of my biggest wins happened.

I helped an offer go from zero to $600k per month and that was all the social proof I ever needed.

The opportunities in the info-product space are endless.

You just have to know where to look and be equipped to handle it.

subject: 3 steps to hit $30k months
content:

The other day I figured out that 15 minute walks in the morning are the perfect distance.

If the walk is too long, it makes me feel like I’m wasting time.

If it’s too short, I’m too restless to sit at my desk.

Anyway, today I want to tell you how to get rich.

So if you’re towards the beginning of your journey, here’s my braindead simple process for you to get to $10k-30k/month ASAP:

Read books, watch Youtube videos, and start writing sample copy.

Start before you feel 100% ready, as most learning is done on the fly.

This part is a grind but the bar is low because everyone else is dumb.

If you understand copywriting, learning other skills is easy.

Same with managing CRMs, automations, and literally any other relevant skill.

Just because you haven’t done something before doesn’t mean you’re not one Google search away.

If you get an opportunity, take it.

That’s literally how I learned everything.

A client would come to me with a need, I’d say “yes I can do that” and boom, I figured it out.

It’s really that simple.

Just don’t get distracted along the way.

subject: why fake urgency is ethical
content:
I have a much needed haircut in 20 minutes so I have to type fast.

Which is a perfect segue for today's lesson:

Urgency.

If you want people to buy your stuff, you need to provide a reason why now is the right time.
You see marketing ploys that do this regularly.

Discounts, bonuses, limited time offers, scarcity, and when all else fails…

Tell your audience that the opportunity is fleeting and if they hesitate they’ll be a matrix slave forever.

The truth is, most urgency is a facade.

A copywriter came up with an angle and made it sound good.

If it’s effective, it gets the people who were on the fence to take action.

Now I’m not saying that all angles or tactics are lies.

But rather, in reality, there is no reason to do anything urgently.

You could wait till tomorrow, three weeks from now, 6 months from now, or even 10 years.

There is always a reason why now is not the right time.

And that’s why urgency in marketing is important.

You’re fighting the imaginary demons in your audience's head.

Let’s say you want to change your life and start a business.

You go back and forth between business models.

You convince yourself you need to learn more and you hesitate to take any action.

You tell yourself that once XYZ happens, you’ll be in a better position to attack it with full force.

I’ve been there.

When I was in college, I got a tattoo on my left forearm that says “if not now, when?”

Because I understood that nothing happens until I make it happen and the perfect opportunity I was waiting for doesn’t exist.

It will never exist.

And until you beat this into your head, you will wait.

You will find a new reason why you can’t do what you want, live how you want, and be who you want.

Now will never be the “right” time, but it will always be the only time.

Sure new opportunities may be around forever.

The ‘limited spots’ angle might be a gimmick.

The discount will probably reactivate in a month or two.

And the special bonuses might be something everyone gets anyway.

But you and I both know there’s no perfect time to start anything.

In fact, most of the decisions I’ve made that resulted in the most growth were completely impulsive and somewhat manic.

I got tired of waiting and followed an inkling in my gut.

​Maybe it’s time for you to do the same.​

Boom.

That’s how urgency is created.

Love you,

Ben

​
​

subject: How to close $10k/month clients
content:
I just sat in front of the camera for 30 minutes trying to make a Youtube video.

Typically once I get the camera out and start talking, coherent sentences start to come out.

But today, that didn’t happen.

I stumbled over my words.

I’d start talking for a minute and then lose my train of thought.

And eventually I was ready to throw my camera off the balcony.

So, I quit.

Very inspirational, I know.

Instead, I’ll write to you about what I was attempting to say in the video.

Let’s talk about how to get good clients that will pay you lots of money on rev shares.

This is a code that once you crack, getting past $50k or even $100k per month becomes easy.

But before you get to this stage, you have to go through the trenches.

At first, you’re limited to the bottom of the barrel.

Those clients who want to negotiate on price or refuse to pay any money up front.

I had my fair share of these, but I made the most of them.

I still went above and beyond, using it as an opportunity to sharpen my skills and build case studies.

That was crucial.

It put me in a position where I had some results to show for, which gave me leverage to get rev shares.

The first lucrative deal I got was with a client who I had on a $3k retainer just for email.

I proposed a webinar funnel to him and asked for 10% of the rev we generate from that funnel.

He agreed.

The next month he paid me $10k and my biggest month with him was $18k.

That was a lightbulb moment.

I figured if I could do that, I could get even bigger and better clients on rev shares.

I did, and now I’ve been paid up to $50k in a month from single clients.

If you want to scale an info-product agency, this is how it’s done.

Grind outreach until you get some shitty clients.

Do everything in your power to get results for them (even if you’re underpaid).

Use that as leverage to get rev share deals with good clients.

Next thing you know, you’ll make an average annual salary from one client.

Boom.

​Go here if you want me to show you exactly how it’s done.​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

subject: Stop trying to get rev shares
content:
{{ subscriber.first_name }}, let’s talk business.

I have a secret to tell you.

It’s a secret that may alter your current view of the info-product space.

And it especially applies to you if you’re trying to get clients.

Here it is:

It is extremely unlikely that you close a good client on a rev share.

This notion that the best way to work with creators is to get them on a 30-50% rev share and run their entire backend is a pipedream.

Almost no good potential client would agree to that.

Plus most of the good ones are already working with someone like me, Pierre, Bo, one of my students, or they have an in-house team.

But that doesn’t mean you’re cooked.

It means you have to work your way up to rev shares.

The way to do this is to find small gaps in info-product businesses instead of going for the whole pie.

Think of yourself as a marketer, not a growth operator.

Your goal is to solve one problem, earn trust, and then solve other problems.

That’s how you eventually end up on a rev share where you can make $10k+ from a single client.

But that doesn’t happen overnight, it happens when you “earn your stripes.”

If I started all over, there are three services I’d mainly be pitching right now:

1. Email copywriting

2. VSL scripting and funnel build

3. Short form scripts

Those are all easy to learn and they get your foot in the door.

You can get an upfront fee or a retainer to start.

Once that goes well, you then start to offer other services and take over more elements to your clients business.

Two years ago, I hit my first $25k month doing exactly this.

I didn’t have any big “whale" clients.

It consisted of a few email retainers, and I closed a couple clients that needed new VSL funnels.

I went above and beyond for my clients, and that’s how I eventually got rev shares.

The point I’m trying to make here is this:

Do not put yourself in a box.

Pitch email retainers, VSLs, scripts, funnels, etc.

Once you get some experience, you'll have more leverage.

That's when you can get rev shares.

By then you'll have results to show for, and actually become a skilled marketer.

Skills last forever, “business models” do not.

​Join me over here if you’re ready to build your Info-product agency.​

Ben

subject: you asked, i answered
content:
I did a Q&A yesterday on new business Instagram (follow here).

There were too many questions to get through all of them on IG, so I’ll be answering more here.

Let’s get it:

What’s something about you that hasn’t changed after being financially free?

Nothing.

Money doesn’t change you, it serves as a tool that allows you to be more of who you already were.

I’ve become more comfortable expressing my true self as I’ve had financial success.

It was always there, I just didn’t have the confidence to show it until I proved to myself that I could design my life however I wanted.

Did your college friends get what you were doing at the time you dropped out?

Sort of.

They didn’t know all the details, but they knew I was running some form of marketing business.

Not to throw shade at all, but I was actually surprised how few of them were curious enough to ask.

Once they graduated and started normal jobs, more have reached out asking for info.

Do you do low and high ticket offers with your clients that make over $100k/month?

Almost all high ticket offers.

In 95% of cases, having a low ticket offer is quite dumb.

Only caveats are when its purpose is to liquidate ad spend, the personal brand has a huge audience, or the offer doesn’t have a direct ROI (teaching a hobby).

How do you lock in and work when you don’t feel like it?

I’ve always been horrible at doing things I don’t want to do.

But my biggest leaps in business have been made when I can get over that initial resistance.

Starting anything from scratch is difficult.

That’s natural. If you expect it to be easy, you’ll quit.

But on the other side of resistance, you start moving with the tide.

The work starts to feel like peace and you develop this love for progress.

It’s one of the most beautiful emotional states that you can access in life.

But you have to earn it by getting over that resistance in the beginning.

So either do the work, or be a pussy forever lol.

Ok last one - there were a bunch of questions about doing outreach.

And this is the problem.

You’re looking for an “outreach system.”

This is why every pitch I see absolutely sucks.

You’re trying to rush the process as if you’re attempting to get a girl to go home with you 3 minutes into a date.

It’s creepy and you didn’t demonstrate any value or status.

Why would someone trust you?

The only outreach tip you’ll ever need is to use your brain.

If you’re competent, you’ll figure out a way to get in touch with people.

If you’re not, well someones gotta flip the burgers.

I know that’s a bit harsh but it’s the truth.

Thanks again for all the questions, sorry if I didn’t get to yours.

​Anyway, check out this new interview I did with Sean, one of my mastermind members.​

He’s making $30k/mo working with some big names like Charlie Morgan and Joel Kaplan.

See you over there,

Ben

​
​

subject: How to live by your own rules
content:
I turned 24 yesterday and now people are calling me “Unc.”

Please stop.

Unc status doesn’t happen until 27 at the earliest.

Thank you to everyone who wished me a happy birthday.

However, I do have a problem with some of you.

You know how you’ll have a cousin or old friend that you only text on birthdays?

The text chain will be like:

“Happy birthday {{ subscriber.first_name }}!”

“Thank you!”

*year passes*

“HBD! Hope you’re doing well!”

“You too, {{ subscriber.first_name }}!”

Yeah, that shit needs to stop.

If you go two years where your texts with someone only consist of birthday wishes, lets just all agree to end it there.

Ok?

Good.

This sounds like a Seinfeld bit.

Anyway, I’ve now written 120 words without saying anything of value.

The biggest lesson I internalized in my 23rd year of life is that there is no rulebook.

You can truly live however you want.

Which is freeing, yet terrifying.

I don’t think most people want to accept that truth.

Because then, you become the author.

You have to take everything into your own hands, and make your own rules.

It’s easier to follow the standard of those around you.

I ‘side quested’ a lot over the past 12 months.

I started hobbies and pursuits that didn’t impact the number in my bank account, but felt right.

In these quests, I learned a lot about myself and became more comfortable showing who I am.

Although this didn’t push me ahead in this imaginary game we’re all playing, it made me feel like I’m winning.

It’s my own game, with my own rules and scoreboard.

I learned that I could decide what I wanted and go get it.

There’ve been challenges, twists, turns, and everything in between.

It’s been a fun year, but not an easy one – although it may look that way on social media.

But maybe that’s the goal?

Life will always come with roadblocks and hurdles, but as long as they are conducive to a mission that is your own, that’s okay.

You don’t want to lose yourself fighting someone else’s battle.

As Dostoevsky said, “Your worst sin is that you have destroyed and betrayed yourself for nothing.”

You have to continuously and intentionally grab life by the balls.

Design the reality you want.

And the hardships that come with it are building you into the character who is capable of accepting it.

​Just keep moving,​

Ben

​
​

subject: The 2 elements of success
content:
Good morning, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

You know, success is really simple.

There are only two things you actually need.

Everything else is just noise.

The first thing is you have to be smart… enough.

Being smart enough doesn’t mean you’re wicked smart.

It means you can walk and talk at the same time.

It means you can figure out how to use Google when you don’t have an answer.

It means you can consume simple information and understand it.

90% of people I meet are smart enough.

The problem is most people doubt themselves.

They feel unprepared to start.

They over contemplate every potential action.

They think success is supposed to be difficult, so they avoid taking the obvious actions that will push them towards their goals.

So sure, you have to be smart enough – but you also have to be dumb enough to trust yourself.

The second element of success is this:

You have to consistently work.

Notice how I didn’t say work hard.

But literally just work consistently.

Genuinely, making your first $10k online isn’t difficult.

Even making $100k in a month isn’t difficult once you’re in the right position.

It’s just a battle of distractions.

Can you consistently take one or two actions daily over an extended period of time?

Or will you get distracted, discouraged, or lose ‘motivation’ and tell yourself you need to find something you’re more passionate about?

If you can resist the latter, eventually you win.

And this doesn’t mean you’re going “balls the wall” working 16 hour days.

But rather that you’ve identified your highest ROI tasks and committed to them.

For example, say you want to build an info-product agency.

Once you learn enough about copywriting and marketing (which can take a week or two), there’s one main thing you should do every day…

Outreach.

That’s it.

If you send pitches daily and make a concerted effort to improve your pitches, you will get a client.

You don’t know when, but it will happen.

You just have to work consistently.

And if you’re smart enough to understand this email, you’re good.

Now, you just have to be dumb enough to get out of your own way when you want to perfect every little detail instead of taking action.

​You ready to get rich now?​

Godspeed,

Ben

P.S. If you’re a complete newbie to online business, I have something exciting coming for you.

If you hit ‘reply’ and say the word “info” there’s a good chance I’ll tell you about it tomorrow.

Hint – Pierre Khoury and I have been working on… a powerpoint presentation ;)

​
​

subject: Success is an accident
content:
“Your success is largely dependent on your ability to shut out the voice that tries to talk you out of action. There will always be reasons to go back to the drawing board. But it’s impossible to intellectualize your way to a goal. Sometimes you just have to jump.” - Ben Bader

Yes, I just quoted myself.

Because there’s one thing I want to drill into your head on this beautiful Friday:

YOU WILL NEVER BE READY.

You’ll never be ready to start a business.

You’ll never be ready to take up a new hobby.

You’ll never be ready to get into a relationship.

Please discard the idea that one day all of the stars will align and you’ll end up with the perfect opportunity to start something new.

Progress doesn’t work like that.

Almost all of my best opportunities have felt like accidents.

When I first started making some money, I was doing freelance videography.

That led me into the agency world.

I then started a lead gen agency for basketball trainers.

That led me into the info-product space.

By then, I’d started posting on Twitter and built connections.

Those connections ended up getting me clients.

I didn’t plan any of this. It’d be impossible to do so.

But throughout that time, I accumulated assets.

I became a skilled marketer.

My network grew.

My personal brand became more prevalent.

Action created the perfect storm.

I didn’t wait for it.

But before that, I wasted so much time trying to plan the perfect route.

It’s a fool's game.

If you resonate with what I’m saying and you find yourself looking for the perfect business model or waiting for some magical moment to start, I empathize with you.

I wanted to know exactly how it’d all work out before I started.

I’d sit at my desk mapping out the exact steps I’d take to hit $10k months.

I’d bounce from one project to the next telling myself that I just needed the right vehicle.

But eventually I realized that intellectualization is NOT a substitute for action.

It’s a way to make yourself feel productive without being productive.

And it won’t get you any closer to where you want to be.

Just jump and trust that you’ll grow your wings on the way down.

Are we clear?

I hope so.

​If you want to take that first step towards action, this can help you.​

Have a good weekend,

Ben

​
​

​

subject: How to avoid a miserable life
content:
It’s Monday.

Because of this, I feel an added pressure to be productive.

But before I start rambling, I need something from you.

If you’re not signed up for my free class this Thursday, you either don’t like money or your thumbs don’t work properly.

​Use your thumb to click this and go save your spot now.​

It’ll be a full masterclass on copywriting, launching offers, getting clients, etc.

Be there, or be poor.

Anyway, let's talk about “the flinch.”

This is something you need to avoid at all costs.

It will keep you on the sidelines forever.

Your exuberant spirit will be suppressed and depleted.

And no matter what you do, you’ll always have this lingering anxiety in the back of your head.

It’ll take you out of the present moment and taint everything you experience.

Unless…

You get over it.

Here’s how:

When you start something new or make a big change, you’ll reach a point where you want to hit the brakes.

This is where your mind starts to reason with you.

You’ll begin talking yourself out of taking action and use “intuition” as the scapegoat.

“Hey I know I said I was gonna commit to this new endeavor but now that we’re here, it doesn’t feel right.”

Bullshit.

That’s not your intuition telling you there's a better route for you.

It’s your ego trying to protect itself.

Change is scary and there’s a part of you that will do everything in its power to resist change.

This is where most people flinch.

They go back to the drawing board.

They look for a different solution.

They blame their lack of progress on external factors.

But what happens if you get over the flinch?

You stand there calmly, as the pocket collapses around you, resisting the urge to cower.

You see a receiver downfield and let go of the ball.

For the first time in your life, you let it fly.

Maybe it gets caught for a touchdown.

Or maybe it gets intercepted.

But guess what?

You’ve now accessed one of the most beautiful games life has to offer…

You got off the sidelines and you’re in the arena.

And you’re finally taking shots that can lead you to success.

Now as long as you stay there, one of them will eventually hit.

Your receiver will catch the ball and you’ll hit you’ll dance together in the endzone.

It’ll happen eventually, IF you start firing.

​It all starts by getting over the flinch.​

Ben

​
​

subject: 3 ways to be a better communicator
content:
If there’s one skill that leads to success in nearly domain, it’s this:

The ability to communicate.

It impacts your dating life, friendships, content, sales, and just about any other human interaction you have.

Over the past two years, I’ve become a much more effective communicator.

I used to be timid.

You could hear a lack of confidence in my voice.

I’d overthink nearly every word that came out of my mouth in an attempt to present myself as someone I wasn’t.

This is how most people end up living their entire lives.

It’s rare to meet someone who is articulate and thoughtful.

Like anything, you won’t get better at communicating with others unless you get a lot of reps.

And that doesn’t include the pre-programmed responses that are embedded into your head when people ask about your day.

In my experience, there are three ways to improve your communication skills.

1. Writing

2. Making video content

3. “High pressure” interactions like a sales call or date

Take a second and ask yourself when was the last time you did any of the three things above.

And if it was recent, are you getting reps daily?

If not, that needs to change.

Consider that last interaction you had with someone who you’d deem a good communicator.

How was their energy?

Did they seem content in the life they’re living?

Did you feel good around them?

Odds are, that conversation was a breath of fresh air.

And this is the reason I’m telling you all of this.

To get anything you want in life, you need to demonstrate your value.

If you can’t do that, it doesn't matter how smart or kind you are.

It’s like being a basketball player who’s incredibly skilled but doesn’t perform well in real games.

All of the work is eradicated by the fact that it isn’t presented when it matters.

Don’t let that be you…

​He who communicates most effectively, wins.​

Ben

​
​

subject: How to justify your spending problem
content:
Hey,

This is my first email since last Thursday's free class.

If you were there, I hope you enjoyed it and learned a lot.

If you weren’t, sorry for your loss.

Before I get into todays email, quick heads up:

The price of Artisan Lab is increasing in a few days.

We’ve got some absolute studs in there who are crushing.

Kidous closed a $6k retainer plus 10% rev share.

Otavio hit his first $50k month.

Dean closed his first info-product client less than 48 hours after joining.

​Check out more wins and apply before the price increase by going here.​

Moving on…

There’s a hurricane coming.

It’ll likely miss Miami, but the weather will consist of gray skies and clouds all week.

So yesterday, I decided to flee.

I texted my friend Mason and asked if he wanted to join me.

And then opened my phone and started looking at flights to LA.

But as we looked, we ran into a problem.

There weren’t any nonstop first class flights until Wednesday.

We hopped on a facetime call and the conversation went as follows:

Me: “This is fucked.”

Mason: “Well, we do have alternative options…”

Me: “How much would a jet be to LA?”

Mason: “Let me text my guy right now.”

Jet’s now booked and we’re flying out at 5pm.

I’m mostly telling you this to flex, but also to show you how cool it is to increase the amount of money that feels expendable to you.

I’ve spent a lot of money over the last year.

I’ve wasted a lot of money on dumb shit.

But this has shown me how replaceable it can be.

It isn’t a scarce resource that I need to cling onto.

When I spend freely, it comes back to me.

Now, I’m not encouraging you to spend more than you have.

However, if you occasionally splurge on experiences it can help you conceptualize larger amounts of money, thus helping you make more.

Or maybe I’m writing all of this to justify my spending problem.

Who knows, I gotta pack for LA.

​Go here to check out Artisan Lab before the price raises.​

Talk soon,

Ben

​
​

subject: The rational man takes "risks"
content:
Hello from a coffee shop in LA.

I’m sitting outside with a large iced vanilla latte that has a bit too much milk in it.

Let’s talk about risk.

Recently, one of my newest students in Artisan Lab got a client within 48 hours of joining.

He closed someone on a VSL script and funnel.

As of right now, he has no idea how to do this.

But he figured he’d close the deal anyway and use the resources inside my mastermind to learn what he needs on the fly.

How irresponsible and misleading, right?

Let’s weigh the potential outcomes here:

Best case scenario, he builds a solid VSL funnel (which should be easy because he has me as a resource) and the client is happy.

They continue working together and it makes him 5-6 figures over the next year.

Worst case scenario, he builds the worst funnel in the world, the client hates it and fires him.

And then…

He goes back to the way his life was before.

Now with a rep under his belt, knowing what he needs to improve.

That's it.

Meaning the worst case scenario is still a win.

This is how most “risks” actually work.

They’re win-win situations, and the only way you lose is by not taking them.

When you think critically about it, this is the rational way to operate.

A few years ago when I dropped out of college, here’s how I saw it:

I could stay in school, get my degree and hope I find a job that makes me over $40k per year when I graduate.

I’d be absolutely miserable but at least no one would look at me like I was crazy.

That would be the “safe” route.

Or I could drop out of college and take the “risky” route.

I’d try to make this online business thing work and if it does, my life would be changed forever.

Over the next few years I’d end up making multi-7 figures, move to Miami with my best friends, inspire thousands of people online, buy a porsche 911 turbo, and book a private jet across the country because it was raining.

Obviously that’s how it ended up ;)

But even when I looked at the potential downside, it’s not bad.

Let’s say I didn’t get online business to work.

I accept the fact that I have the IQ of an ape and go move back in with my parents.

Maybe I’d use the skills I learned while trying to start a business to get a decent job.

Maybe I’d do doordash and spend my free time in the sun.

Maybe I’d go back to school and get my degree.

And now, at least I can close my eyes at night knowing I wasn’t supposed to build a business because I actually tried and it didn’t work out.

Getting that clarity is a win.

When you break it down like this, NOTHING is risky.

It’s all an illusion!

They don’t want you to be rich, famous and handsome.

But you’re here and you’re still reading this.

​And that means you’re meant for more.​

Love you,

Ben

​
​

subject: how to enjoy life even though there's work to do
content:
“It was the best of times. If only someone had told me.” - Hank Moody in Californication

What makes you happy?

Well, let me rephrase that:

If you were watching the sunset on the beach with your best friends, what would you need to have completed to fully enjoy that moment?

Let’s break this down.

Would you be thinking about the work you haven’t finished, answered emails, or the thing you told yourself you’d do but haven’t gotten around to?

Would you let that thought take you out of the present moment and cloud what could’ve been a beautiful, unique experience?

This is a position I often find myself in.

My life is the exact way I formerly dreamt of.

The freedom, relationships, lifestyle, and impact are the things I wanted years ago.

Yet I still find myself ‘missing it’ sometimes.

And by that, I mean not appreciating the good times because I’m in my head contemplating a decision or feeling guilty because I didn’t accomplish a task.

It’s a cloud that can feel everpresent.

But when I think about this, the solution is quite simple:

Do the things that make me feel productive and fulfill my creative desire.

That’s it.

If I do those things, I can enjoy my life.

If I don’t, I can’t.

It doesn't matter where I am, who I’m with, or what I’m doing.

My unfinished business will sit in the back of my mind like a parasite.

I could be across the table from the most beautiful girl I’ve ever seen while she yaps about her hair, makeup, or whatever women talk about.

Instead of listening, I’d be thinking about the text I got three weeks ago that I didn’t reply to.

Or the fact that I didn’t write an email that day.

Or the random side quest that I promised myself I would start and haven’t.

This sound familiar?

It’s impossible to be happy if you fail to do the things that make you feel accomplished.

Many of which may have nothing to do with financial gain.

But that desire sits in your soul for a reason.

It’s a thirst you must quench to be able to live freely.

The alternative is a life where you’ve entrapped yourself in your own mind.

You’re on the sidelines, watching yourself pretend to be happy.

But if you can just identify the few things you need to do to turn each day into a ‘win,’ that cloud will go away.

You won’t let unfinished business ruin your peace…

​And you’ll fully experience the fruits of your labor.​

Let’s have a good week,

Ben

​
​

subject: How to make progress as fast as possible
content:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }},

I’m sitting on my balcony writing to you on a beautiful day here in Miami.

There’s a common dilemma that everyone faces when trying to build a business.

It’s the thing that drastically slows down or halts progress entirely.

And it’s this idea that business has to be complicated.

We often look for complex solutions to simple problems in order to avoid action.

Odds are, you know what step you need to take right now.

If you’re trying to get clients in the info-product space, it’s pretty simple:

1. Learn about copywriting and marketing

2. Start doing as much quality outreach as possible

3. Close a client, get good results and repeat

But maybe you’re telling yourself you’re not ready.

You need to learn more or find some outreach system that you’re currently unaware of.

That’s your mind playing tricks on you.

In reality, you’re scared to start because you don’t know what you don’t know.

And committing to this process will require you to step into a new version of yourself.

It’s the version of you who doesn’t hesitate and knows you can figure things out on the fly.

With this, comes additional pressure.

“What if I get a client and run into a problem?”

“What if my outreach is horrible?”

It’s easier to stay where you are (and who you are) now while fooling yourself into thinking that you’re not ready.

There’s a harsh truth of the universe that you need to understand:

You will never be entirely prepared for anything.

The stars will never align perfectly until you take the imperfect action.

You can wait forever.

And you’ll sit there, watching others who are no different from you get the results that you could’ve gotten, if you had the balls to start.

This is something I’ve learned while coaching the members inside of Artisan Lab.​

The biggest value I’m able to provide people with is conviction.

Because they’ve paid me for coaching, they value the messenger more than the message.

Meaning if I just confirm to someone that the logical action is right (even if they already knew that) my conviction and assurance is enough to get them to actually do it.

The secret is understanding that there is no secret, and you’re as prepared now as you’ll ever need to be.

It’s a cliche, but an accurate one.

Progress is simple.

Just actually do the thing that you know you need to do.

Anyway, I dropped this video yesterday that people seem to really enjoy.​

See you over there,

Ben

P.S. Here’s your last chance to get into Artisan Lab before the price goes up​

​
​

subject: Read this to sell anything to anyone
content:
There are three ‘micro-sales’ that need to occur if you want someone to buy coaching.

In this email, I’ll reveal them while simultaneously utilizing them to sell you.

Should be fun, let’s dive in:

1. The mechanism sale

This is where you sell someone on the vehicle.

The goal is to show them why your method to get the desired outcome is effective.

Example – you want to make money online.

There are countless business models you could choose from.

All of them can work, but that doesn’t mean they’re all created equally.

Many require capital, years of experience, or rely on finding gimmicks or hacks in the market and don’t teach you valuable skills.

That’s why the Info-Product Agency is a solid option.

It’s not a “business model,” it’s a skillset that makes you a valuable asset to any business.

And because the online education industry is rapidly growing, it makes logical sense to work with people who sell info.

There’s an abundance of potential clients you can work with and your ‘competition’ is horrible.

Believe me, the pitches I get in my inbox are barely legible.

So this means all you have to do is learn how to apply the skill of marketing to info-product businesses.

And then go find them – which is easy because they want to be found (that’s how their business works).

Oh, and it’s basically free to start.

See what I did there?

I made a logical argument as to why my mechanism works.

That’s micro-sale #1.

2. The authority sale

If you’re gonna buy from someone, you have to trust them (obviously).

To do this, you need to:

A. Show that you know what you’re talking about

B. Show that you have no special advantages or ability that the audience doesn’t

Let’s see this in action.

Your typical guru hits a $20k month one time, then they turn around and start selling courses.

90% of their income is from their info-product, not the business they claim to be an expert in.

I hit consistent $100k months for nearly a year before I ever sold my own info.

This business has given me my dream lifestyle.

And I know it can do the same for you, because I was once in your shoes.

I bounced from one thing to the next, and felt like making money online was impossible for me.

I’d make some money here and there, but nothing was sustainable or scalable.

That was until I found the Info-Product Agency.

After years of trying to make money online, I hit my first $15k month just four months after pivoting to the info-product space.

And it’s why I’m so confident that this can work for you.

Boom, there goes micro-sale #2, now you trust me.

3. The personal sale

At the end of the day, people's biggest hesitations come from their own mind.

They don’t believe in themselves.

And it's your job as a marketer to change that narrative and give them hope.

This is where you use social proof to show them that there are people who are just like them getting results.

Here’s what that looks like:

My student Briar joined Artisan lab 3 months ago, making just $3k/mo from his 9-5 (none on his own).

With my help, he just hit his first $10k month with his info agency.

Just two months after joining, Kabrin hit $20k/month after starting from scratch.

And lastly, Kidous (who runs a software company and is just doing this for fun) closed his first info client for $6k/mo + 10% rev share. client.

Everyone you see here is no different from you.

They've simply implemented the systems I've given them and they're reaping the benefits.

​Go here now to join them.​

Aaaand that concludes micro-sale #3.

See how this works now?

Good.

​Now hop in Artisan Lab and you'll become and money making machine.​

Later,

Ben
