subject: DCA - {{ subscriber.first_name }}
content:
The answer only becomes clear once a decision has been made.

You can float in the abyss forever.

You can contemplate, analyze, and hypothesize.

You can tell yourself you need a sign.

You need a jolt.

You need the grim reaper to come remind you that the clock is ticking.

But you don’t know, until you go.

This is the common dilemma of the critical thinker.

It’s a blessing and a curse.

It’ll help you see through the whole 9-5 rat race trap.

It’ll lead you to many answers you have about the world and yourself.

But as you know very well, it comes with downsides.

It’ll lead you to continue ruminating even after you’ve come to a reasonable conclusion.

It’ll convince you that you’re not ready – and you’ll never be ready.

It’ll fool you into thinking that thought alone creates progress when in reality, it’s the very thing holding you back.

You’re the voice of reason and your biggest enemy all in one.

Will you learn when to shut out that voice who avoids change?

Will you let internal conviction take control and start before you’re ready?

Will you understand that nothing changes until something changes, which is impossible without…

A decision.

Left or right.

Shoot or pass.

Hit the gap or slam on the breaks.

If you keep floating in no man’s land, you’re gonna get hurt.

​Decide, commit, act.​

Ben

​
​

subject: Lifestyle curation
content:
“The only real test of intelligence is if you get what you want out of life.” - Naval

{{ subscriber.first_name }}, sorry I ghosted you for a week – I’m back.

Let’s talk about living life by design.

Everyone wants to create their dream lifestyle.

It’s what initially attracts many of us to entrepreneurship.

You begin to imagine a future version of you with more freedom and confidence.

You think about how incredible your life will be once you just crack the money code.

But even when you make the money you want, that doesn’t mean the rest of your life will improve.

Sure, money solves money problems, which is great.

It gives you more freedom and the pursuit of it can create internal fulfillment.

But if you really want to enjoy your life, there’s one main thing most people fail to do:

You must consciously and continually consider if the life you are creating aligns with what you actually want.

It’s simple, but easy to overlook.

Just because you have financial access to your dream lifestyle, that doesn’t mean it’ll happen by default.

I first internalized this around a year and half ago.

Although I was making more money than I ever had, my lifestyle hadn’t changed.

It felt like it was time for an upgrade.

I made a conscious decision to start doing things that I wasn’t doing.

I went out of my way to meet more people, both in person and through social media.

One thing led to the next, each connection opened another door, and my life started improving.

It was magic.

A decision was made, actions were taken, and the goal was accomplished.

Fast forward to now and I really don’t know if it’d be possible to drastically improve my lifestyle.

I have everything I want.

From my friend group, to the access I have in Miami, and the clout from social media (which can be vapid, but it’s cool).

I’ve proven to myself that I can create what I want from scratch.

And that’s the biggest benefit of all.

Every endeavor forces you to become a completely new version of yourself.

This doesn’t always come with immediate financial gain but it’ll help you live a much fuller life.

Progress is not black and white.

Money is just a tool that allows you to curate your life – don’t forget to do so.​

Good to be back,

Ben

​
​

subject: Everyone will love you if...
content:
It’s a 78 degree, sunny morning in Miami.

I’m sitting on a park bench, looking at an advertisement for Jimmy Butlers netflix show go by on the water.

Imagine a billboard placed on top of a 20ish foot boat.

On my way here, I held the door for a lady with a stroller.

She was further than the typical distance that I’d hold a door for someone, but because her hands were full, I waited.

After patting myself on the back, I realized this is the perfect topic for today’s email:

Awareness.

Those who win, are typically the most aware.

They know not to stand in the middle of crowded hallway.

They know how to make their date feel comfortable.

They know how to make the shy person feel included in the conversation.

They know how to adjust their pitch to their prospect on a sales call.

They know to hit the breaks when a driver looks like they’re gonna pull out in front of them without looking.

All of these seemingly minuscule examples indicate a level of consciousness that’s higher than the average person.

Socially this means you’re calculated, but not too calculated.

You’re considerate of those around but you don’t entirely discard your own beliefs and standards to fit in.

You can walk into a party, make connections and leave others feeling energized.

In a business setting, you’re able to see opportunities for what they are.

Because you’re aware, other people like you. They want to connect with you. They want to help you.

Nearly every business is built off of relationships.

And awareness is the foundation of the way you interact with the world.

Without it, you’ll struggle.

Nearly anyone I’ve ever cut out of my life it’s been because of this reason.

There’s just something that they’re missing from a social calibration standpoint.

I don’t trust people like that, and neither does anyone else.

If you’re still here reading this and you’re thinking “how do I become more aware?” That's up to you.

There’s no tutorial here —

But if you’re a conscious observer of your inner dialogue, you pay attention to the micro-expressions of others, and you have the confidence to act accordingly without exchanging your authenticity…

​You’ll be further ahead than most.​

Bye,

Ben

​
​

subject: Trust me bro
content:
It’s another sunny day.

I’m starting this from a park bench as a pale shirtless man walks past me pushing a stroller.

As I sit here pondering what to write about, I keep returning to one idea:

Trust.

Your ability to trust yourself is the ultimate test.

Pursue anything and there’s a million problems that you don’t know how to solve.

You can let that stop you.

Or you can trust that even the things you can’t control will work out the way they’re supposed to.

Because you’re you.

And YOU will keep moving forward and figure it out.

When you do this, you open the door to endless possibilities you didn’t have previously.

Every endeavor I've started or change I’ve made in recent memory has worked out positively.

From moving to Miami before I felt entirely ready.

To posting on Youtube and building Artisan Lab.​

To starting my comedy/skit arc on Tik Tok and Instagram…

Even though these aren’t huge changes that immediately impact my direction in life, there’s a level of micro-anxiety when starting anything new.

You don’t know what you don’t know, and that’s nerve-wrecking.

In my case, I’d proven to myself that I can thrive when I take on new challenges.

This has allowed me to get over that resistance.

And even now, I don’t know how everything’s gonna work out.

I don’t have a 1, 5, or 10 year plan.

But what I do know is that Im planting seeds that will continue to sprout.

From my comedy side quests, to business content, to my info-agency…

As long as I just keep moving forward, I have enough trust in myself that I will get everything I want.

That’s how it’s worked for me so far.

So {{ subscriber.first_name }}, I encourage you to approach life through this the same lens.

You are a perpetual problem solver.

You can adapt to varying circumstances and environments.

The right opportunities will find you as long as you start progressing.

You have everything you need

You are everything you need.

And any time you’re stressed and feel the walls caving in…

That's just another opportunity to show yourself that you can climb out of any deficit.

​Trust yourself.​

Ben

​
​

subject: Instant transformation is the only way to change
content:
Transformations are a result of micro-adjustments.

Change is perceived as difficult because we get caught up in old habits, routines, and thoughts.

But taking the action to enable change is rarely difficult.

Right now in this instant, you can start a full life transformation.

If you want money, it can be as simple as picking up the phone and pitching someone.

If you want a better social life, you can start a conversation in line at the coffee shop.

You can send a DM on Instagram or make a 30 second video that leads to a friendship, customer, or client.

You can decide to stop asking other people for advice and follow your own instincts.

Over time, that single decision will equip you with the internal conviction necessary to take on more personal responsibility.

And with that, you’ll finally be in the drivers seat of your own life.

Micro-adjustments, macro-results.

You’re just a series of small changes away.

You know this, but you overcomplicate it.

These small changes feel like you’re carrying a whale on your shoulders while walking up a downward moving escalator.

And this is because you’re comfortable with your current struggle and level of responsibility.

You don’t actually want to solve your problem because it’ll force you to evolve.

Your current conflict will be replaced with a new one. And this conflict, you’re not accustomed to.

If you solve your money problem, you have to figure out what you want to do with your life.

It’s temporarily easier to just keep grappling with the same issues.

And that’s why the micro-adjustments you know you need to make in order to change are stopping you.

You’re letting small roadblocks turn into sinkholes.

But if you just start with one small decision. And one small action, you’ll realize it’s not that scary.

Along the way, you’ll be equipped with everything you need to handle a new level of responsibility.

The upgraded, confident version of you is not that far away.

He (or she) just started right now.

​And 6 months later, you’re unrecognizable.​

Get moving,

Ben

​

​

subject: You are meant to build
content:
Your energy alone will take you to where you’re supposed to be.

This isn’t some mystical spiritual concept, but rather an observation I’ve made throughout my journey.

I’ve always felt like I was special.

Perhaps it’s a feeling everyone has, but most suppress.

People tell you that everyone is equal.

They tell you that your ego is a bad thing.

And that your selfish inclination to believe that you’re ordained for greatness is narcissistic.

Perhaps they’re right.

Is this belief likely based on delusion and ego?

Yes.

But will it serve you in ways that I don’t have enough time to articulate on this page?

Also yes.

You are who you believe you are.

If you walk through life with an exuberant confidence in your eye, others will perceive you as someone who’s got it figured out.

If you believe you are that guy and that you weren’t meant to be another dull, lifeless NPC going through the motions in someone else’s movie, that energy will carry you.

I’m not telling you to be an asshole and entirely lose sight of reality.

Yes, you have to put in work.

You have to prove your competence.

And you have to earn the respect of others.

But that’ll be impossible to do without a level of internal conviction that most would deem delusional.

That feeling in your gut is there for a reason.

It’s a version of you that’s possible to attain.

And it’s up to you to bring it to reality.

Most won’t.

But they aren’t reading this email.

​So take this as your head start.​

Ben

​
​

​

subject: How to make $100k/month
content:

Ben

​
​

​

subject: Momentum > Discipline
content:
Trump winning the election has me thinking about how I need a second term with you.

Copy that line and send it to your ex.

You’re welcome.

Anyway, I’m sitting out on my balcony on a cloudy day here in Miami.

I’ve been in a bit of a rut.

As you may have noticed, I haven’t been very consistent with these emails recently.

Every time I think about writing, it’s like my brain shuts off.

Typically I can come up with an idea, open my laptop and 20 minutes later I’ll have a legible email.

But as of late, that’s been a struggle.

The advice I’d give to someone in my position when you just can’t get yourself to do something that you know you need to do is simple:

Make it easy.

If something feels like a herculean task, you won’t do it.

But what if you take the pressure off?

Instead of trying to write the perfect email, make the best content, or craft an amazing outreach message, you just do what you can.

It might not be your best work ever, but it builds momentum.

When you’re in a rut, that’s what you need.

And the next time you sit down to complete whatever task you’re avoiding, it gets a bit easier.

So that’s what this email is about.

I have a friend who recently started making content on Tik Tok.

He’s only made a few videos and keeps asking me for critiques.

I told him to stop asking for help until he posts consistently for a month.

Because right now, the quality doesn’t matter.

He needs reps and data, and over time he’ll naturally work out the kinks.

So {{ subscriber.first_name }}, for any new habit you’re trying to build, I’ll offer you the same advice.

Start small, enjoy the process, and don’t chase perfection.

If you show up for yourself consistently, it will work out.

The tasks that once felt difficult will get easier.

You’ll get into a rhythm and start swimming with the tide.

​Just start building.​

Ben

​
​

subject: The money game is too easy
content:
Sometimes I feel like it’s all been too easy.

I reminisce on the times where I was hopeful and naive.

There was a spark in my eye that was ignited by blind ambition.

The process of making money and building the life I now have felt like a mythical endeavor.

Everything was so new and I was exuberant to be in the arena, playing the game.

I was a typical college dropout with big dreams and little idea how I’d pull it off.

Every time I moved a step closer to my goals, it was electric.

With each new client I signed, it meant I was that much further away from ever having to work a 9-5.

My first full year in business I made around $80k.

“Holy shit! That’s way more than I would’ve made in my first year out of college,” I thought to myself.

That feeling of hopefulness remained as a buzz in the back of my mind for a while.

It’s like I was the chubby, socially off kid on the basketball team who finally gets to play during senior night.

I was just happy to be here.

But at some point, that wore off.

Unfortunately, it all worked and I got most of the things I wanted… Maybe a little too easily.

Perhaps my vision for what I’d want after accomplishing my current status didn’t evolve fast enough.

I guess that’s an easy thing to overlook when you begin to embark on any journey – What do I do if it works?

In the past, my goals would naturally evolve.

There was a point where I just wanted to make $5k per month.

Once I got there, I wanted $10k per month and so on, all the way up to six figures a month.

It was easy to keep going. That was until money stopped impacting my lifestyle.

I already don’t have to think about expenses, I go on trips when I want, and I have my dream car.

I could triple my income and it would have a minimal impact on my day to day life.

But that’s where the goals have to evolve.

More money now means more security.

It means I can invest more and set up my future self and my perfect 10 wife, so we can have beautiful babies that go to the league.

It means I can take care of and employ more people.

That was never in the vision.

I just wanted the flashy shit and fun lifestyle.

But that part was surprisingly easy.

This might read like I’m spoiled and ungrateful, but I’m sharing this because you will likely reach a point in your journey where you complete your vision.

You’ll get everything that you believed was possible for you and find yourself in a position where life feels a bit dull, even though it might look exciting externally.

That’s when you have to move the goal post back again.

Find a new north star and begin working towards it.

See you at the top,

Ben

PS - Go here to get 1 on 1 help from me and scale your info-product agency​

PPS - Lmk if you made it all the way down here and liked this one :)
​

​

​

subject: Stop thinking, you idiot
content:
I woke up on the 28th floor of a hotel in Soho.

I threw on some sweats and a hoodie, and now I’m sitting at a red metal table in a crowded coffee shop.

The woman(?) who took my order was wearing a covid mask and there’s a girl behind me with a slight lisp talking loudly on the phone about her problems at work.

I’m contemplating throwing my sugary iced latte at her.

You now have a clear picture of my exact situation as I sit here typing to you on my phone.

Now onto the more important stuff:

Think less.

When you’re making a business decision.

When you’re sending a text.

When you’re talking to the perfect model 10.

When you’re deciding between rigatoni or penne.

Just please stop thinking so much.

Your initial instinctive response is the best one 99 times out of 100.

And you’re fucking up the natural, authentic flow of life by hyper-analyzing every aspect of it.

YOU DON’T GET ANY EXTRA POINTS FOR CONSTANT CONTEMPLATION.

All you’re doing is stressing yourself out and diminishing that natural carefree spirit in your soul.

“What should I say to pretty gorl to get her to like me??? Oh no, should I send this emoji or is that too aggressive? I shouldn’t have put that period at the end of my sentence, now I sound too serious.”

YOU’RE COOKED.

Seriously, this is ruining your life.

The intention is pure but it has an inverse effect.

You have instincts for a reason. STOP DOUBTING THEM.

But I get it — This habit of analysis is a double edged sword.

Being someone who is aware and thinks critically can help you.

Without this, you’ll just blindly follow other people.

But you have to toe the line between overthinking and ignorance.

Too much thought makes you a spiritually cucked pussy.

Too little thought makes you a sheep who stands in the middle of crowded doorways.

Don’t be either.

Learn when to shut off that part of your brain who revises every decision before you make it.

And learn when to question whether or not a belief or operating system aligns with what you want.

But when in doubt — stop thinking and let it fly.​

That’s life in the flow state.

Ben

​
​

subject: Life is fair
content:
Happy Monday {{ subscriber.first_name }},

The other day I wrote a tweet I want to expand on.

I said:

“Life is actually incredibly fair. You get what you truly believe you are capable of receiving. But you can’t deceive the universe the way you can your own mind. There is no hiding or contorting the truth. If you don’t get what you want, you’re not unlucky, you’re undeserving.”

Any time I’ve found myself disappointed in an outcome, it’s because I failed to remember the truth above.

There’s been periods in business where I felt like I deserved more than what I received.

That could go on for a while until eventually I’d make some sort of adjustment and my income would grow exponentially.

Only after that could I see the picture clearly.

Beforehand, I wasn’t ready.

There was a skill gap, mental hurdle, or some other form of maturing I needed.

The delay was a result of that fact and it was equipping me with whatever I was missing.

When I was disappointed, it was a result of not seeing reality clearly.

This is what I learned:

If you think you deserve a different outcome than you received, it’s because you’re fooling yourself or being impatient.

There’s an inkling in your gut that knows exactly that.

If you’re too closely attached to your income, your bank account won’t grow.

If you’re heavily reliant on validation from others, you’ll feel empty even when you get it.

If you refuse to make the necessary adjustment to reach a goal, and you fool yourself into thinking that you can get around it…

The universe will remind you that you cannot outsmart it.

You reap what you sow and there is no cheating.

You know what you truly deserve and you know if there are things you’ve been running from.

Continue to run, continue to lie to yourself, continue to be disappointed.

Or accept that you will not get what you want out of life until you slay the necessary dragons.

And remember…

​You can’t outperform your own self-image.​

Ben

​
​

subject: You're thinking too much
content:
Most of your problems are not real.

They're illusions you've created in your own head as a result of habitual over-thinking.

Stop contemplating, you're making it worse.

The issue can be solved in an instant.

Make the decision. It's not daunting as you've made it out to be in your mind.

Stop dwelling.

Nobody remembers the "embarrassing" thing you said.

Stop fixating.

Your date doesn't notice that your shirt isn't perfectly ironed.

Stop analyzing.

The perfect route to financial success doesn't exist, start now.

You can override your conscious mind through action.

Post the content you want to post.

Carry yourself with confidence.

Act as the person you want to become.

You will become that person.

The voice that tells you to flinch loses it's power as you separate from it.

It does not dictate your actions, you do. Only in the present moment.

And that's all you'll ever have.

Stop creating an internal hell because your external world is void of real problems.

​You're thinking too much.​

Ben

​

subject: Secret for {{ subscriber.first_name }}
content:
I have a secret to share with you today.

It’s a law of success that once you understand, you can’t go back.

Making money becomes easy.

You no longer lack clarity or feel like you don’t know where to start.

And all of the bullshit roadblocks and hurdles you previously dealt with start to vanish.

This secret is simple…

Making money is easy when you actually do the work.

Mind-blowing, right?

We tend to have this habit of overcomplicating simple tasks instead of taking the obvious action.

If you want to get clients for your agency, do outreach (duh).

Don’t listen to that voice in your head that’s telling you that you don’t know how to find clients or what to say in your outreach messages.

That’s your ego, fooling you into a state of inaction.

You’re scared to take on the additional responsibility that comes with success.

Everyone has that.

But those who build a successful business learn to stop listening to it.

They act, despite the fact that it’s uncomfortable.

A new student of mine inside of Artisan Lab is quickly realizing this truth.

He this message in the group the other day:

After sending just 3 outbound messages using the process I teach, he’s already gotten a potential client.

If he continues on this trajectory, it’s reasonable to assume he’ll start stacking clients and making money within the next 30 days.

You can do the same if you stop lying to yourself.

You have everything you need right now.

You are capable of handling future problems as they come up.

If you let those imaginary future problems stop you from acting in the present, you’ll never reach them.

Which means you’ll never make money.

And you’ll never live the life you know you’re capable of living.

That sounds horrible.

Don’t let that be you.

​Start winning here.​

Ben

subject: Beginner gets first client in 17 days
content:
Someone really smart (me) once said, “Nothing is saturated because everyone is retarded.”

This whole info-product agency space has blown up over the last year or so.

Everyone wants to work with people who sell coaching.

This obviously means that coaches are getting an abundance of pitches on a daily basis.

You might hear that and think it’s too saturated for you to find success.

I’m here to tell you that’s not the case.

If you do outreach the right way, you can get a client within the next 30 days.

Here’s how I know this…

Yesterday I told you that success comes easy when you actually do the work.

And today I have further proof to back up this statement.

Modjaji, a new member inside of Artisan closed his first client just 17 days after joining:

The steps he followed are simple.

He joined the program and went through the content.

Once he felt like he had a grasp of copywriting and could deliver results for clients, he started outreach using the loom system I showed him.

Less than a week after starting outreach, he closed his first client (as a beginner).

$1,500 in his pocket plus a 25% rev share.

It’s that easy.

You just have to get out of your own way and do what you’re supposed to.

Scott, who’s also a new member in my program, is doing exactly that.

He joined just 11 days ago and is already booking sales calls with great prospects.

This is easy if you have the right system.

​Here’s your cheat code to success.​

Happy Friday,

Ben

​

subject: This is a necessary evil
content:
I’m back.

It’s a frigid morning here in Miami.

I got a hot vanilla latte today because of this.

The weather app says it’s 61 degrees out but I swear it feels like it’s in the 20’s.

Anyway, I have to apologize to the nerds today.

You know the guys you see on Instagram who constantly talk about the importance of routine?

They’re the steak, eggs, standing desk, blue light blocker, and supplement stack types.

For some reason they post 178 Instagram stories per day, showing you the same thing…

Every. Fucking. Day.

Wake up 5am, meditate to David Goggins poster, kettlebell workout, sales call, rant about positivity, involuntarily celibate disguised as ‘no fap.’

(Sorry that last one was mean)

It’s corny as fuck.

But it works.

And recently, I forgot that.

The most productive era’s of my life have typically come when my habits are in check.

I’m getting up early, taking walks, journaling, writing emails, making content…

Everything is consistent.

And this consistency builds momentum.

Getting work done feels easier. Each day is a productive step in the right direction.

The chatter in my mind begins to quiet.

And once again, I’m able to find that intuitive feeling in my gut that just knows the way.

Even though I don’t know exactly where I’m going.

When I’m moving, things unfold in my favor.

Movement is the solution -- And it’s easily created through these corny ass habits that won’t directly make you rich.

Obviously – Sitting in the sauna isn’t gonna put millions in your bank account.

5 minutes in the cold plunge won’t put a Patek on your wrist.

Meditating won’t buy you a Porsche 911 Turbo.

But if you don’t take the time to be with yourself and prove to your little monkey brain that you can exercise discipline…

Then how do you expect to scale and maintain a business?

Sure you don’t always have to be “locked in” but if you neglect things for too long, they die.

If you don’t workout, your muscles begin to atrophy.

And that goes for every “muscle” including discipline, mental aptitude, creativity, etc.

Use it or lose it.

Habits are a cheat code to continual growth. Just don’t be weird about it and start posting your whole day on Instagram.

No one really cares. I promise.

But thank you, Nerds for the reminder.

Feels great to be back :)

Ben

PS Hope you had a great Thanksgiving and Black Friday. Mine was good but the turkey was kinda dry.

Although I didn’t run a BF sale, I added a special bonus inside of Artisan Lab and have made it nearly impossible to fail.

My members are getting rich. I’ve got 21 year old kids making $100k+ per month.

Others are closing famous people as clients.

And others got their first two (PAYING) clients in their first week.

​Join me here now and you will get richer, happier, and better looking.​

Legally I can’t guarantee that, but illegally, I pinky promise.

​

​

subject: 10 principles that helped me scale to $100k/mo
content:
Here are 10 things you need to understand if you want to build a successful info-product agency.

Whether you're just starting out, or you already have some clients, these lessons will help you scale rapidly.

Let's go:

  1. The singular “best” outreach system doesn’t exist. Anything can work, if you take the time to be creative and stand out in your pitches.
  2. Take initiative in solving issues that are in the best interest of the business, even if you are not directly responsible for them.
  3. Think for yourself before asking questions. In most cases the answer is obvious and you just need to take the obvious action.
  4. Your conscious brain is typically not your friend. When you find yourself thinking that you need more information before you can act, you are fooling yourself.
  5. If you don’t feel like you’re in over your head, you’re not saying “yes” enough. The best way to learn is on the fly.
  6. Do not obsess over systems and processes. Make money first, worry about efficiency later.
  7. Non-scalable actions differentiate you from your “competition.” Everyone can send dozens of mediocre pitches daily. Not everyone will take the time to correctly assess a situation and personalize a pitch to solve a specific problem.
  8. Not every client is going to be a homerun. There are two sides to the equation and if your client isn’t holding up their end of the bargain, there’s only so much you can do.
  9. Find a way to get your foot in the door. It can make sense to offer one service, perform well, and take over other parts of their business once you earn their trust and have a better understanding of the gaps in their business.
  10. The best opportunities are found when a client is making good money, despite the fact that their systems are being overlooked. Fixing those problems is like pouring gas on the flame.

There we have it.

Remember these 10 things and you'll be driving an SVJ in no time.

​And if you want my personal help in growing your info-product agency or coaching business, click here.​

See you at the top,

Ben

​

subject: If you don't know where to start, do this
content:
“I don’t know where to start.”

Sound familiar?

I was combing through Artisan Lab applications this morning and found a theme.

There’s a question that asks applicants to share any roadblocks they’re facing.

Around 90% of the answers are long-winded variations of “I don’t know where to start.”

Whether it’s picking a business model, starting outreach, or creating content…

Everyone finds a scapegoat as to why they aren’t taking action.

Perhaps a better way of putting this dilemma is “I want to be told where to start.”

You feel stuck because you have an abundance of options and you're not doing anything about it.

Any business model can work.

Any style of content can garner attention.

Any outreach method can get you a client.

But instead of trying something and seeing if it works, you convince yourself that you need more information.

You’re left in a perpetual cycle of looking for more information rather than actively creating data that steers you in the right direction.

One thing I know for sure is that everything that’s ever been created was done so from scratch.

Someone, like you, didn’t know where to start.

They tried something and it probably didn’t work the first time.

So they tried a different method, now with more data.

They do this over and over until they’ve crossed off many of the “wrong” answers.

In doing so, they came closer to the answer…

And then it clicks.

Action creates clarity.

The route to success is found after knifing through tens, hundreds, or even thousands of routes that don’t directly lead you to where you want to go.

But they continuously reroute you until you arrive at your destination.

And the once “directionless” version of you ceases to exist.

I can’t tell you with full certainty what will work for you. Neither can anyone else.

We’re all different people with various natural advantages and inclinations.

That’s life.

The ones who are rewarded are those who act despite the fact that there is no universal rulebook.

You just gotta start moving and trust that you’ll find the answers while you’re running the race.

There’s no way around this truth.

​Trust yourself, and you’ll be rewarded.​

Ben

​

​

subject: This is a privilege
content:
About 3 years ago, I got recognized from social media in person for the first time.

I was walking on 5th avenue in Playa Del Carmen, Mexico.

This is the main strip in the city, filled with restaurants, clubs, and a lot of people discreetly trying to offer you drugs.

If you made eye contact with one of these vendors they’d go directly into their pitch.

“Amigo! cocaine, ecstasy, molly, women…. tengo todo. What you want?”

Solid offer, but I refrained from ever taking them up on it.

As I walked through the chaos, I could feel someone staring at me.

I looked over and saw this guy who appeared to be around my same age.

He came running up to me and asked, “is your name Ben??”

I answered “yes” and he told me knew me from Twitter.

We chatted for a bit and got a picture together.

That was a surreal feeling.

You mean to tell me that by simply making content through the little device I’m typing this on right now, people from all over the world could see it?

And it could have enough of an impact on their life that they feel impelled to come up to me and say something?

In Mexico of all places?

That’s pretty cool.

Now, as I sit here writing this from a Starbucks in Brickell, two people have come up to me saying they’ve seen my content.

This typically happens multiple times a day now.

But like anything, over time that surrealistic feeling from the beginning starts to wear off.

It feels normal. I find myself taking it for granted.

This isn’t an attempt to brag, sound like an asshole and tell you how famous I am. Although it may read that way.

Rather it’s a reminder to myself and to you reading this — don’t take special for granted.

It’s a privilege to wake up in the morning.

It’s a privilege to work on something you care about.

It’s a privilege to make your own schedule, travel, and take care of those around you.

And it’s a privilege to be born in an era where you can use the device you’re reading this on as an all-powerful tool.

You can make money. You can meet your best friends. You can create content that inspires, entertains, and helps others. Whether it’s one person, or thousands.

That’s really fucking cool. And we’re lucky to be a part of it.

No matter how big you get, how much money you have, or how many people want your time and attention…

You’re never too important to appreciate the little things.

​Don’t take special for granted,​

Ben

​

​

subject: This is really, REALLY bad
content:
I’m going to fear monger you today.

Last night I listened to a podcast about the economic and social state of young men in America.

Long story short, the average guy between 18-30 is down horrendous.

I used to hear guru’s talk about this and I’d write it off as a marketing angle.

But when you look at the data, it’s entirely true (and absolutely fucked).

Here’s some stats for you:

  • Over 41% of men ages 25 to 34 make less than $30k per year, compared to just 25% in 1975 (adjusted for inflation).
  • Young men are 4x more likely to commit suicide compared to women and 3x more likely to overdose on drugs.
  • 20% of men (24-35) still live with their parents compared to just 12% of women.
  • 1 out of every 3 men (18-24) hasn’t had sex in the last year.
  • Marriage rates have gone down from 70% in 1970 to just 30% today.
  • The average man doesn’t buy their first home until age 38, up from age 29 in 1981.
  • The median income of young men has dropped from $73k in 1975 to just $40k today (adjusted for inflation).

I’m not much of a numbers guy but this is completely insane.

Young guys are poorer and more isolated than ever.

The days where you could follow the beaten path and live comfortably are gone.

If you don’t have high value skills that you can use to either build your own business of get a high paying job, you’re fucked.

Unless you have an ivy league degree, you’re gonna be a doctor, or you have a clear path to making 6 figures in a 9-5, you’re left with two options…

  1. Be poor, unattractive to women, and live a miserable exist where you’re more likely to kill yourself or overdose on drugs than you are to become a millionaire.
  2. Bet on yourself. Start learning skills. Start a business and fail. Fail again and again. Want to quit. Push through the turmoil. Find success. Become a millionaire. Buy your dream car(s). Build an amazing circle of friends. Be desirable to women. And live the life you’ve always wanted to live.

Which of the two options sounds better to you?

The answer is obvious.

But you gotta get through the hard part in the beginning where you want to flinch.

And when you consider the alternative, that should make it a bit easier.

I believe in you.

​Go here to adopt the mindset that saved me from a life of mediocrity.​

Let me know if you liked this one,

Ben

​
​

subject: Why, {{ subscriber.first_name }}?
content:
The other day, a member in Artisan Lab told me that he was having trouble staying motivated.

He asked me, “What's your why?” (meaning the deeper motivating purpose that drives me to succeed).

Here’s my answer:

When I first started in online business, I just wanted to make money.

Not having to work a 9-5 sounded cool.

Traveling sounded cool.

Having the freedom to create my own schedule sounded cool.

My “why” was mostly made up of self-serving factors.

I didn’t have to rescue my family from poverty and I didn’t have a grand vision to save endangered turtles.

I wanted money because it looked fucking sick.

And the idea of clocking in and out for the better half of my life sounded wayyyy less sick.

Sickening, if you will.

Furthermore, I had this feeling in my gut that you’re likely familiar with.

It’s the feeling that told me that I couldn’t live a dull life.

I’d try to suppress it sometimes, but it never worked.

I simply knew that if I didn’t take a chance and at least attempt to gain full agency over my life, I’d be absolutely miserable.

I’d rather end up homeless.

So when I looked at it that way, there was one glaringly obvious option…

Build the life that I actually wanted to live.

Not for anyone else. Not for a greater purpose. But for me.

I wanted to escape the inevitable future pain of mediocrity.

Is that selfish? Sure.

But had I deluded myself into believing that I needed a stronger “why,” perhaps I never would’ve started.

I could’ve rationalized, “I’m not motivated and I can’t work because my life is decent as it is.”

Don’t let Simon Sinek (author of It Starts With Why) fool you.

Your “why” can be ripping an SVJ through the Hollywood hills.

Your “why” can be having the autonomy to wake up at noon every day.

Your “why” can be club-hopping in Ibiza with a bunch of ungrateful models.

My point is stop worrying about your fucking “why” and make money.

Do you want to be miserable?

Do you want to be poor?

Do you want to be an incel?

No?

Okay! Then what the fuck else are you gonna do with your time? Lol.

Eventually, your motivating factors will naturally evolve.

Once you check off the superficial desires, perhaps your focus will shift to retiring your parents, setting up future generations, or saving the Goddamn turtles.

But right now, you probably don’t care much about any of that.

If you’re honest with yourself, you just don’t want to worry about spending money.

And that’s completely fine.

You don’t need to find some moral justification to stay motivated.

It’s okay to want something, simply because you want to prove to yourself that you can get it.

​Ready to get rich now?​

See you at the top,

Ben

​
​

subject: Indecision will kill you
content:
If there’s one core message from my recent content, it’s this…

Indecision will kill you.

You’ll pass up the open shot and throw the ball to the other team.

Your foot will hover between both pedals as you slam into the car that merged in front of you.

The girl who could’ve been your wife will get up and walk away while you sit there contemplating the perfect line.

Indecision will kill you.

You’ll stand there, idle on the sidelines, watching what could be pass you by.

Frame by frame, day by day. Missed opportunities stack up. You’re just waiting for the next one though…right?

At least that’s the story you’re telling yourself.

But even you don’t truly believe that anymore.

You can live your entire life half in, half out, as most do.

Indecision will kill you.

It’s a slow, painful death.

You’ll learn to numb the pain, but with it will go your spark.

Your exuberance, your hopefulness, your natural childlike spirit will be beaten down to a flicker.

Fake laughs. Forced smiles. An artificial version of you, stripped of any charm or charisma.

Floating from one day to the next.

Not living, but existing.

Indecision will kill you.

​Decide, commit, attack.​

Happy Friday,

Ben

​

​

subject: Why you're not motivated
content:
Good morning {{ subscriber.first_name }},

I started this beautiful Monday with a 30 minute walk and now I’m back at my desk.

Important topic today – motivation.

A subscriber left a comment on my recent video saying he doesn’t feel like he has enough drive to be successful.

He wants the things that come with success but just can’t get himself to do the work.

This makes me think of a quote from a super rich guy you may have heard of named Jim Rohn.

He said, “We generally change ourselves for one of two reasons: inspiration or desperation.”

This theory generally holds up when you listen to the stories of successful people.

They were either in a horrible situation and had no choice but to claw their way out.

Or they created the internal willpower required to take consistent action.

I’m in boat number two.

I was lucky enough to grow up in an affluent environment in a first world country with access to abundant resources including the internet.

To end up in a position of desperation, I would’ve had to make some seriously poor choices.

And if you’re reading this right now from your phone or laptop in 2024, odds are you’re in a fairly similar spot.

Even if you don’t come from any money, there are guardrails in place that will likely keep you from ending up as a homeless man under a bridge.

Because of this, you have the “luxury” of choice.

You can follow the rules and live a semi-decent life.

It won’t be extraordinary and you won’t exceed expectations, but you’ll survive.

To me, the idea of simply getting by and forgoing my natural desire to create an extraordinary life sounded like misery.

I knew that if I allowed myself to choose comfort and familiarity over the slight possibility that everything in my dreams could come true, I’d hate myself.

That’s where my inspiration came from.

Although I wasn’t truly desperate, it felt like I had no other choice but to go after everything I wanted.

If it didn’t work out, the guardrails I referenced earlier would still be there.

So why not attack life with ferocity?

Why not try to build myself into someone I am proud to be?

Why not trade a dull life for one with ups, downs, and everything in between?

Where I’m entirely in control of my own destiny and I have the power to make my reality as beautiful as I’d always dreamed.

That was my inspiration and desperation in one.

Inspired because I knew it could all be possible.

Desperate because I knew I wasn’t put on this earth to be another brick in the wall.

You’re capable of becoming everything you want to be.

If you feel like you’re too comfortable to change, it’s because you’re not genuinely considering just how uncomfortable life would be if you let others make your decisions for you.

That’s enough motivation for me.

Reply and let me know if you liked this one.

Happy Monday :)

Ben

​

​

subject: This makes growth effortless
content:
I walked home from the coffee shop with my left shoe untied.

And when I say untied, I mean it.

Laces dragging on the ground. Everyone looking at me like I’m some sort of neanderthal with no regard for safety.

Did I trip? Of course not.

Imagine tripping due to a little string wrapped around your foot. Are you 12?

Couldn’t be me.

Although, my formerly white laces are now black from stepping on them into the pavement.

Anyway, isn't it crazy that 2024 is almost over?

The end of the year is always a good time to reflect.

Odds are, you set some goals about 12 months ago.

Let’s check in on them.

Where are you settling?

What are the things you told yourself that you’d do that you’re not doing?

What areas of your life require more focus and attention?

Personally, 2024 was a solid year but I feel like I didn’t squeeze as much juice out of it as I could have.

I’m ready to step into a new reality.

I feel like I have a real opportunity to grow my personal brand and I’ve been settling a bit too much.

If you’re in a similar spot when it comes to your business or any other area of life, here’s my advice to you:

You must be the agent of change in your own life.

Nothing happens unless you make it happen.

If you don’t create order, it will be created for you.

With new habits comes an increased level of pressure and responsibility.

This will make you want to flinch.

That voice in your head will attempt to pull you back down to where you were previously.

The actualization of your goals and the new version of yourself that you’re aiming to become relies on your ability to shut out that voice.

So make it easier on yourself.

Implement small habits that allow you to stay on track with your goals.

That could be jotting down some action items each night before bed or making a list of prospects you’re going to reach out to.

It’s small changes like this that create a ripple effect over time.

Momentum will start to carry you once you get the ball rolling.

But you have to commit.

Set a new standard for yourself and abide by it.

Come this time next year, you’ll be a completely different person. Likely with a much bigger number in your bank account.

And you’ll be incredibly grateful that you didn’t let your previous self stop you.

You’re just a few small changes away from a completely different life.

Get after it,

Ben

PS Use this to kickstart your journey and make 2025 the best year of your life.​

​

​

subject: It's simple, but it makes you magnetic
content:
It’s impossible to be unhappy when you’re loved by everyone around you.

A few months ago, I started working out with a personal trainer named Earl

From the very first session I could tell we’d get along.

You know when you meet someone and instantly click?

That was Earl (no diddy).

But it’s not just me.

Everyone loves this guy.

At the gym people constantly stop to greet him with warm smiles and choreographed handshakes.

Last weekend, he had a birthday party with over 100 people in attendance.

There’s just something magnetic about him.

It sounds like I’m writing a love letter, but there’s an important lesson here.

Everyone craves connection.

Yet most of the interactions that people have in their day to day lives are dull.

They’re just going through the motions – no smiles, no small talk, no genuine compliments.

It creates this energetic lull where life just doesn’t have any spark to it.

But here’s the good news – one small interaction can break this cycle.

A simple smile.

A quick compliment.

A lighthearted conversation with a stranger.

When you choose to be a bright spot in someone's day, your life gets brighter too.

Why?

Because your actions influence your emotions.

When you act like someone who radiates joy and confidence, your brain begins to believe it – and you become that person.

If you’re low energy, angry, or sad remember:

You have the power to snap out of it right now.

Stop spending too much time alone.

Stop being afraid of real human connection.

Stop replaying negative thoughts.

Instead, focus on making others smile, and that energy will find its way back to you.

You’ll become the kind of person who’s magnetic, confident, and happy – like Earl.

And when that happens, life gets a lot brighter.

Be the light,

Ben

P.S. I made a banger Youtube video with my friend Phillip who turned $1 into millions of dollars. You can check it out here.​

​

subject: Here's your answer
content:
Happy Friday,

I just put up a Q&A on my second Instagram and will be answering some questions in this email.

Here we go:

“What's the piece of advice for the college kid grinding building a biz while others coast?”

You will look back at this time period in a few years and be grateful that you made the decision to start now.

A wake up call is coming on graduation day.

Most of your peers will get slapped in the face with the harsh reality that their actions over the last 4 years have put them in a tough spot.

A degree (in most cases) no longer equals security – Building a valuable skillset and network does.

If you can block out the noise and the FOMO, your life can be everything you want it to be plus more in the near future.

“How do you know when you should change things up?”

Simple.

Ask yourself “Do my actions align with the reality I want to create?”

If not, adjust accordingly.

You likely have this pit in your stomach that knows the truth.

As every waking hour goes by it reminds you that you’re wasting your life.

If you don’t change, that pit won’t go away on its own.

It’ll drain you every single day until you become a dull, lifeless version of the infinite being with limitless potential that you once were.

That sounds fucking horrible.

Don’t let that be you.

“How did you network at the beginning of your journey?”

The first element of building an amazing circle of friends who are all winners, is being on the path to become a winner yourself.

You need to be building – create better habits, start the business, audit and remove the broken pieces of your mindset that are holding you down.

Begin documenting your journey on the internet.

Naturally people who align with you will find you and vice versa.

Hop on calls with those who you want to connect with. Plan a trip together. Become homies.

Easy as.

“How can I get like you?”

By not trying to be like me or anyone else.

By listening to your internal compass that knows the way.

By following your natural curiosity with a childlike spirit.

By creating your own standards and upholding them.

This is how you become the fullest version, most authentic version of yourself.

It takes life from black and white to color.

It allows you to figure out who you really are and bring your uniqueness to the surface.

Hope you enjoyed this one :)

If you're not following my business Instagram account, you can do so here.​

Will be much more active on there in the near future.

Have a good weekend,

Ben

​

subject: Do this NOW (Or 2025 will suck)
content:
I’m 40,000 feet in the air, writing this from seat 4A.

Heading home to Cincinnati over the Holidays.

It’ll be my first time back since last Christmas.

This year has absolutely flown by, hasn’t it?

I’m using this last week and a half of the year to prepare for 2025 and go into the new year with momentum.

This is something I didn’t do a great job of going into 2024.

I had a rough idea of what I wanted to accomplish and some goals written down, but I wasn’t very precise on the key levers that would make success inevitable.

Because of this, it felt like I was playing catch up for the first few months of the year.

This reminds me of something one of my high school basketball coaches used to always say…

“If you’re not 15 minutes early, you’re late.”

It takes time to stretch out, tie your shoes, and get some shots up before practice.

If you show up “on time” you’ll miss your chance to get ready and be underprepared.

This is how I’m thinking of this period until January 1st.

It’s the 15 minutes before “game-time” that will dictate whether or not I go into the new year ready to make it the best one yet.

I’m ready to make more money than ever, explode on social media, build a bigger team, and simply turn up the dial in all facets of my life.

So if you want to go into 2025 like a rocket shot out of a cannon while others kick their feet up till the new year…

Here are some things you should get clear on:

What's the one thing that would make 2025 a success?

This can be an income goal, fitness goal, social media growth, etc.

Set your standards high and arrow it down to one thing that will make you feel accomplished.

Be as specific as possible.

How will you measure your progress towards that goal?

If you don’t track it, you don’t improve it.

Create a system where you can continually measure your progress and make sure you’re staying on par.

This can be as simple as using a google doc or notion sheet.

Again, be specific and write down exactly how you’ll keep track of growth.

What processes can you put in place that will make the achievement of your goal inevitable?

These are the big levers.

If you set an income goal, this could look like “send 10 quality outbound pitches per day.”

You can write down a few things here that have a direct impact on the achievement of your main goal.

There we have it…

I highly encourage you to not overlook these three questions.

I know it might look corny or basic – I tend to have an aversion to doing things like this too.

But this simple exercise can be the difference between a reality-changing 2025, versus yet another year where you feel like you didn’t make the strides you could’ve.

Be different. Put both feet on the gas. And lap all the dorks sipping eggnog in pajamas for the next 10 days.

And if you REALLY want to get ahead – go here now (only if you’re a psycho who’s ready to run through a fucking wall in order to make this your best year ever).

Cheers,

Ben

P.S. If you noticed a new font in this email, congrats on being observant. I was re-reading some of my old emails and found the last font a bit hard to read. Do you like this one better?
​

​

subject: Is goal setting corny?
content:
In yesterday’s email I implored you to set clear goals going into 2025.

There was a time where I thought doing this was a rather silly act.

This was because when I started my business journey, I was sort of autistic about goal setting.

Every few months I’d map out new 3, 6, and 12 month goals.

I had clear targets to hit and planned exactly how I’d do so.

After following this protocol for a while, I noticed that things almost never happened the way I planned.

Although I’d make progress and typically come close to hitting my goals, I’d get rerouted a dozen times in the process and felt like an idiot for ever trying to map out the “perfect” route.

So I came to the conclusion that goal setting was corny.

It’s for the Instagram coaches who’ve never built a real business.

The room temperature IQ neanderthals who get an erection when talking about their morning routine.

I’m not naive enough to think that things will happen the exact way I plan them, so I don’t need to set goals.

Or at least that’s what I thought…

Looking back, when I set clear targets I progressed quicker.

Sure the path comes with twists, turns, and hurdles that I could’ve never anticipated, but that’s not important.

What IS important is the fact that goal setting gives you a starting point.

You have a target you want to hit.

A method to track your progress.

And daily actions to make it happen.

That’s all that matters.

Obviously unexpected events will occur – you might find an alternative vehicle that proves to be a better fit.

You’re not a genie with a crystal ball.

But don’t let that stop you from giving yourself that clear mission and starting point.

Objectively, you will operate better when doing so.

Don’t fool yourself into thinking you’re smarter than other people because you don’t “need” to set goals.

Accept that your plans will likely change and adapt to future circumstances.

That’s okay.

Alright?

This might’ve been more of a message to myself than it was for you, but it’s an important thing to note nonetheless.

Let me know if you liked this one {{ subscriber.first_name }} :)

- Ben

​
​

subject: is the American dream dead?
content:
I remember being around the age of 12 or 13 when I first started to conceptualize money.

Many of the houses in the area I grew up in were $1m plus.

At the time I was told that $100k per year is a really good salary.

After doing some math in my head, it didn’t make sense.

If a nice house costs one million dollars…

And a good salary was $100k…

I’m supposed to work for 10 years and somehow miraculously save every penny before I can buy a house?

Obviously I was oversimplifying it but this broke my adolescent brain at the time.

It just didn’t make sense.

Not long after I realized that if I want to live a good life, I have to get rich.

Not a couple million dollars net worth by 65, rich – But real rich. Fast.

Millions in my 20’s, tens of millions in my 30’s and so on.

After coming to this realization about the world, my life changed forever.

I began to see reality through a new lens.

And in this one, I was in control.

​Is the American dream dead?​

Ben

​
​

subject: How to use "loss aversion" in your favor
content:
Merry Christmas {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Hope you’re enjoying the day with your fam.

I bought myself a fancy new camera today.

I was long overdue for an upgrade so I got the Canon R5 with the 15-35mm lens.

All in, it cost me a little over $5k.

But I didn’t buy it because of the quality upgrade (that’s a bonus).

Personally, I think equipment is somewhat overrated.

If your content is good enough, it will perform if you film on a potato.

The main reason I upgraded is because it’s a commitment to myself.

Since I spent the money on a new camera I’ll have more pressure to put it to good use.

I’m using this concept in psychology called loss aversion to motivate myself.

Basically it means that people value keeping what they have even more than they value acquiring things they don’t have.

I spent enough money to where it stings a bit and I don’t want to feel like I wasted it.

So with this additional motivation, I have a lot of content coming for you in the new year.

I feel like I left some gas in the tank in this area in 2024.

Sure my audience grew, but I didn’t put in nearly as much effort as I could’ve.

There was one 3 month streak where I was consistent on Youtube, posting 3x per week.

Over that time, I went from basically zero to 10k subscribers.

Even then, there was minimal planning or strategy behind my videos.

I can’t help but wonder what I could do with more intentionality and consistency.

Time will tell.

Since we’re on this topic – that’s a good way to find new opportunities that can offer you asymmetric returns.

Audit your efforts right now and see if there’s anything where you’re getting more out than what you’re putting in.

Maybe there’s a part of your business that comes easy to you and whenever you focus on it, you make more money.

And maybe it would be wise to double down on that thing.

However I must add a disclaimer – this advice is dangerous in the wrong hands.

If you’re in the beginning stages of your journey, odds are nothing is easy right now.

You’re fighting an uphill battle.

Don’t look for the easy way out because there isn’t one.

You have to keep climbing until you break through a lot of the natural barriers that come with change.

Only once you do that, can you position yourself to go “downhill” where you have gravity working in your favor.

I know this email has been a bit jumpy, so thanks for sticking with me here.

I encourage you to do something in these next few days that will force you to commit.

Risk something that you have to get something you don’t.

You’ll likely end up with more than you could’ve imagined.

Merry Christmas,

Ben

P.S. Go watch this if you haven't already​

​
​

subject: Business is like hot wheels
content:
Business success is like a battery powered toy car.

Imagine you’re an 8 year old with snot on your face.

For Christmas, you got a miniature brown Bugatti with a bald action figure sitting in the passenger seat.

You rip it out of the box and put it on the ground.

Excitedly, you click the “on” button and…

Nothing happens.

You turn it off and on again…

Nothing.

And then it clicks inside your little pea brain.

Batteries!

Your Bugatti needs 2 double A batteries.

You run upstairs and say “Mom! Get me some fucking double A batteries ASAP no rocky!”

To your disappointment, your Mom is hammered.

She caught your Dad cheating on her with your Uncle so she’s numbing the pain with two bottles of Rosé.

“Dammit! She won’t be able to drive to the store,” you think to yourself.

Time to take matters into your own hands.

You scour the house for batteries, opening the back of every TV remote.

None of them fit into your toy car.

You’d ask your Dad for help but he’s upstairs with Uncle Timmy.

So you decide to hop in his Ford F-150.

You can barely see over the steering wheel so you grab a pipe from the garage as an extension to your foot.

Next thing you know you’re pulling out of the driveway.

Luckily you’ve played a lot of GTA.

By some miracle, you make it to the store, find the batteries, check out, and make it back home.

Finally you put the batteries in the bottom of the car and you’re off to the races.

Congrats kid.

Now {{ subscriber.first_name }} you’re probably thinking...

“Are you going anywhere with this or are you just telling me a fabricated, alarming story about an unsupervised child with an alcoholic mother and gay father?”

Here’s how this relates to you and your business success:

Right now, you’re that toy Bugatti.

If you’re a complete beginner, you have to get batteries before you can start moving.

That means you go down Youtube rabbit holes, read books, watch courses, and start practicing your skills.

The car won’t start moving yet (you won’t make any money).

But you’re installing the necessary batteries that will allow you to go fast.

Welcome to the trenches :)

It’s impossible to say how much time you’ll spend here, but I can promise you that on the other side is everything you’ve ever wanted.

Once you get through, you’ll hit the gas.

And if you're someone who's already been through the trenches...

Maybe you've been trying to build an agency for a while or you've been grinding in a sales gig.

All you need now, are the right batteries -- A higher leveraged opportunity.

Finally, you’ll be rewarded for all of your previously unrewarded effort.

Just don’t quit before you even get the right batteries installed.

Let me know if you liked this one,

Ben

​
​

subject: The world is yours
content:
It’s a beautiful 75 degree, sunny day in Miami.

And it also happens to be January 1st.

4 years ago, this month was a pivotal one in my online business career.

I drained my bank account and bought a $5,000 coaching program.

I began journaling every day, describing the new version of myself that I was becoming in vivid detail.

I got my first few free trial clients for my agency.

Here’s an excerpt from my journal entry on January 15, 2021:

“I am building my business that generates $10,000 per month with little of my time. I am able to go where I want, buy what I want, and meet who I want. Reality bends itself to my desires. I am in the driver’s seat, steering the ship on how my life goes. I am in full control. Money loves me. I attract more and more of it daily. I find new ways to make money with ease. I live a life that has no bounds. My friends look up to me. My parents are proud of me. I am able to help my brothers. I am the person I have always wanted to be.”

None of this was true at the time.

But 2 months later I closed my first 3 paying clients at $1k per month each.

By August, I hit $10k months and dropped out of college.

I moved to Mexico and reached $15k months.

Now as I sit here writing to you 4 years later, my life looks even better than the way I used to dream of it.

I’ve built a 7 figure agency, grown my personal brand, and started helping others replicate my success.​

I’m telling you all to show you that I’m not special.

I was once lost, undisciplined, and unfocused.

But a series of decisions led me here.

I began taking life seriously and I understood that nothing would change unless I made it change.

New year's resolutions are corny and perhaps this is just some arbitrary date on the calendar…

But your words are powerful.

Today, you can decide that you’ll no longer accept mediocrity for yourself.

You can begin keeping the promises you’ve made internally.

You can take full control of your life and commit to your goals.

And I promise you…

In a few months you’ll start to see your dreams come to fruition.

In a year you won’t recognize the old you.

In a few years, your life will be better than you ever imagined.

And you’ll be glad you started today.

The world is yours… if you’re ready for it.​

Happy New Year,

Ben

​
​

subject: The 3 phases to reach $100k/month
content:
Okay, I have a less philosophical email for you today…

You could be the most profound thinker of the 21st century.

But no one will listen if you’re poor.

Everything you say will have an asterisk next to it.

*Take any advice or opinion with a grain of salt. This person lacks the basic competence necessary to provide for themself and their family.*

“OMG Ben, that's so insensitive”– shut up.

Let’s talk about how to get fucking rich… Specifically working with people who sell info.

I’m gonna break this down into phases for you (if you already have a client or two you can skip to phase 3):

Phase 1: Exit the clueless monkey

You’re lost.

You hear about all these people making money online and the different ways of doing so.

You don’t know what’s legit and what isn’t.

You feel like a monkey who was taken out of the wild and placed at a dinner party.

Here’s how to change this – Immerse yourself into the online business space.

Tailor your social media feed to show you less baddies and more money.

Build a swipe file of funnels, email copy, VSLs, etc.

Phase 2: Enter the arena

Once you understand the basics, you need to start getting real practice.

Write samples. Ask Chat GPT or Claude AI to grade them.

Keep improving and start doing outreach.

Don’t listen to the voice that tells you that you’re not ready.

Send as many high quality outreach messages as you can daily (I will teach you how to do this).​

Don’t stop until you get a client.

Phase 3: Squeeze the lemon

Congrats. You got a client or two.

What you do now, can change your life.

Imagine a billionaire hires you as a personal assistant.

He tasks you with getting his coffee in the morning and that’s it.

So, you spend the rest of your day finding ways to make his life easier.

He sees your hard work and makes you his next of kin.

This is *basically* what can happen if you maximize the opportunity with one solid client.

Go above and beyond to improve any area of their business, even if you’re not directly responsible for it.

This can snowball into a 5 figure rev share from that client. Plus a case study you can use to get more clients.

There’s your 0-$100k/month blueprint.

I know it sounds simple.

The only part that’s more complicated is the identification of bottlenecks.

Once you get a client, you have to be able to correctly assess the levers which need to be pulled to scale them.

And before that, you have to determine if they’re even in a position that will allow them to scale.

In Artisan Lab, you’ll learn how to do all of this.

You’ll know who to reach out to, what a high quality pitch looks like, what to offer, how to close the deal, and how to make your clients a boatload of money.

​Go here now and apply to join the winning team :)​

Talk soon,

Ben

subject: A new way to view risk
content:
Before I get into it, I just made a new video that’ll show you how to make $20k/mo partnering with online coaches.

​You can watch it here.​

It’s an incredible day here in Miami.

Did you know I live on the 80-somethingth floor?

I can basically see the end of the Earth from up here. It’s definitely flat.

I’m on my balcony watching the boats go by.

The water is this beautiful blueish-greenish color and the sun is beaming, so it looks even more vibrant than usual.

Switching gears to a much more somber note – I truly think some people are just NGMI (not gonna make it).

It’s not that they can’t “make it” but rather that they won’t allow themselves.

They’re too comfortable in their current self-image.

Things aren’t bad enough because their perception of risk to reward is flawed.

Going after what they want seems like this big leap of faith where if they fail their life is over.

Obviously that’s almost never the case. If you put your all into anything, you will naturally unlock an abundance of additional opportunities.

But they don’t understand this.

So even though they may be unhappy, the desire to change doesn’t outweigh the perceived pain of it.

From the outside looking in it’s easy to see that the “pain” really isn’t that bad.

Sure, upgrading any area of your life comes with challenges – whether it’s financial pursuit or a different quest.

And sure, there may be some level of risk involved but when you truly weigh your options, you see reality clearly.

You can stay the same forever, merely flirting with the idea of success.

Or you can think, “Why not? I’ll put my all into this endeavor and worst case scenario I end up back where I was beforehand.”

Does that sound incredibly risky?

To me, it doesn’t.

And that’s why I think I was able to muster up the courage to attack my dream life despite the fact that I never had it that bad.

As Socrates once said, “fuck it, we ball.”

So as I sit here, writing this from my castle in the sky, I’m grateful that I’ve been able to view risk through this lens.

It will work out for you too.

But you actually have to allow yourself to try.

I’ll leave you with a tweet I wrote over two years ago – “You're hesitant to hit the gas because you know it raises the bar. The further you get from the bottom the harder it’ll be to go back. You know what you're capable of but you're afraid to hold yourself to that standard. Then it's no longer an option to show up every day.”

Go after everything you desire.

​It will be worth it,​

Ben

​
​

subject: AI is going to take your job
content:
{{ subscriber.first_name }}. This is important.

There’s a popular meme amongst NBA fans.

When a player can’t compete in the league, they often go play in China or another country.

“Get ready to learn Chinese buddy” has become a popular phrase because of this.

When a player is struggling, you’ll find that sentence in the comment section.

There is a similar phenomenon going on in the copywriting world…

AI is going to take your job.

I’m 100% serious. This is not a drill.

If you’ve been neglecting it, I’d highly advise you to stop.

You will be demoted to putting fries in the bag for a living quite soon.

Get ready to learn minimum wage buddy.

Up until recently, this was me.

Although I’ve been using AI for some time, I felt like I was just scratching the surface.

I’d have it write or critique email copy, VSL’s, content ideas and more.

It was a useful tool, but I wasn’t amazed.

And when I’d try to have it write copy for me, it’d do so a 4 or 5 out of 10.

It wasn’t horrible, but it read like a non-native english speaker who just discovered a dictionary.

Bland and robotic. When I’d try to get it to spice things up it’d sound too try-hardy.

Nonetheless, it was somewhat useful.

That was until I got better at prompting and training it.

This took it from a 4/10 to an 8/10.

And I STILL think I’m just scratching the surface.

When you input enough data with the right prompt(s) it’s capable of writing a sufficient email that’s indistinguishable from human copy.

I’d be willing to bet it’s better than 99% of beginner to intermediate level writers.

Here’s what this means for you:

It’s a tool that you NEED to utilize.

Go down the rabbit hole and become familiar with popular AI softwares (not just Chat GPT).

Once you do so, it will make you better, more efficient, and nearly do your job for you.

It’s not something to fear, IF you learn it.

If you don’t… well Nǐ hǎo, my friend.

Extra large fries please.

If you want to see how I’m using it inside of my business…

​I’ll be sharing everything I learn about AI in the coming months here.​

Don’t get left behind,

Ben

subject: One DM changed my entire business model
content:
Let me take you back to November, 2021.

I’m living in Merida, Mexico after spending the last couple months in Playa Del Carmen and Tulum.

My days are simple.

Wake up at 8am, bike 15 minutes to the gym, and try to get agency clients.

It’s working… sort of.

I hit a new high score, of $16,037 profit for the month.

The only issue?

It took SIXTEEN clients to get here.

Most of them are local basketball trainers paying me $1k/month for lead gen and automation.

Many of which have broken sales processes, so getting results is difficult.

They’re constantly churning, I’m constantly replacing, and it's leaving me constantly stressed.

Then, one small pivot changed everything.

I’m scrolling through Instagram and decide to pitch a slightly different type of prospect.

Instead of selling in person training, he’s selling online training.

He has a big personal brand and I actually used to watch his content.

His business partner replied the next day.

3 months later, he became a paying client.

5 months after that, I’m still making $16k/month.

But this time, only with 6 clients.

All of which are selling online coaching, not just basketball anymore.

A Youtube coach, Amazon FBA offer, and sales trainer.

Your typical make money online gurus.

Fast forward one year…

I hit my first $100k month with just 7 clients.

The difference maker?

I applied my existing skill set to higher leverage opportunities.

While I was running the basketball trainer agency, I got really good at one thing:

Copywriting.

I used it to write emails, VSLs, and build funnels.

Because I handled all of their marketing, they were happy to pay me a rev share.

That’s how I went from charging just $1k/month to up to $45k/month.

And now, AI has made this easier than ever.

Feed it the right data, master the prompts, and it'll write 80% of your copy.

Inside Artisan Lab, I’ll teach you this exact system.

With the right skills and opportunity, one client can pay you more than a neurosurgeon.

Which is exactly what many of my students are doing.

​Join us here.​

Ben

subject: RE: your resolutions
content:
This is the breaking point.

Remember the goals you set 8 days ago?

It’s this time of the year where most people revert back to old habits.

The motivation and excitement fades.

And the excuses are creeping back in.

This is the emotional cycle of change at work.

Stage 1: Pure excitement "This is it. I’m finally committed."

Stage 2: Reality check "Damn, this is actually a lot of work..."

Stage 3: The dip "Maybe I'm not ready for this..."

Stage 4: The breakthrough "Wait... I think I'm figuring this out..."

Stage 5: Momentum "Can't believe I almost quit."

Right now, you're probably somewhere between stages 2 and 3.

The initial excitement has worn off.

The path feels harder than expected.

Your old comfort zone is looking enticing.

This is exactly where most people quit.

They think because it got hard, something's wrong.

But difficulty isn't a sign to stop.

It's a sign you're finally playing the game.

Welcome, my friend.

What you do right now will make or break the rest of your year.

You can decide to step into the 2.0 version of yourself and actualize the goals you’ve set…

Or you can let the natural desire to resist change, win.

Just remember this:

Goals aren't achieved through motivation.

They're achieved through showing up when motivation dies.

Through pushing forward when everyone else quits.

Through accepting that it's supposed to feel hard.

Show up for yourself today.

Lambos, champagne, and models feeding you grapes on a Yacht in the South France await.

But you have to push through this part.

By the end of the year, you’ll be unrecognizable.

​Ready to make this the best year of your life? I’ll help you here.​

To overcoming resistance,

Ben

P.S. AI wrote 80% of this email. In the future I’ll keep it 100% real me, but I just wanted to show you what AI is capable of when you feed it the correct prompts. More on this in here :)​

​
​

subject: Stop resisting your dream life
content:
The secret is that you already know the secret.

You’re looking for solutions to problems that you have the key to unlock.

The anxiety ridden cloud in the back of your mind can be gone in an instant.

But you keep searching.

“Maybe if I move across the country.”

“Maybe if I watch another Youtube video.”

“Maybe if I try a different business model.”

You’ll do anything to avoid taking the obvious action.

In Steven Pressfield’s book, The War Of Art, he calls this “resistance.”

It’s the internal force stopping you from pursuing creative endeavors and personal growth.

Most succumb to it and live dull lives void of any self expression.

Every day, you have the option to overcome this.

Only once you start acting despite this resistance, will it lose power over you.

Although it’ll never disappear entirely, you’ll learn that it’s okay to not know exactly how things will work out.

You never will.

This morning, someone commented on my recent Youtube video asking, “Can I do this as a complete beginner?”

Here’s my answer:

No… at least, not with that mindset.

No one will ever grant you permission to begin going after what you want in life.

You will never feel ready, especially if you think that some external opinion or event will make you ready.

I am not the guard at the gate of your desires holding a magic wand.

Neither is anyone else.

You hold the wand.

You are making the conscious decision to either let your fear control you or accept that it’ll never go away.

You decide when you are going to overcome resistance.

Win that battle. Your dream life awaits.

Ben

P.S. I just created what’s likely the most informative Youtube video I’ve ever posted.

It’ll show you step by step how to land a great client that you can actually get results for.

Then how to scale with them and leverage that case study to get more clients and scale past $20k/month.

And in the process, you’ll beat the resistance that’s holding you back.

​Go here to watch the video now.​

​
​
