subject: The plague that no one is talking about
content:
There’s a plague happening right now.

It’s incredibly common but people rarely talk about it online.

I’ve gotten it, as well as my friends, and nearly every successful entrepreneur I know.

And you’re bound to get it too, if you haven’t already.

But when you scroll through social media, you’d think everyones immune…

It’s Monday morning.

Your favorite guru is up before the sun.

He just went through his 7 step morning routine.

Now he’s sitting at his desk making moves that’ll result in generational wealth.

Or at least, that’s what he wants you to think.

Unseen is the plague – the constant battle against complacency.

It affects some more than others, but anyone who tells you they’ve never experienced it is smoking crack.

And it’s not exclusive to those who are already successful.

Before I made any money online, there was a period where I just couldn’t get myself to do the work.

I’d sit there at my computer, knowing that all I needed to do was send outbound messages.

My finger would hover over the keyboard for a bit and next thing you know I’m watching Derrick Rose basketball highlights from 2010.

Objectively, I was nowhere near the point where I should be complacent.

But somehow, complacency would win.

Though I eventually beat it, it never went away entirely.

I’d feel the constant battle against this plague at every level of income I reached.

And last year I reached a point where my life was pretty damn good.

I bought my dream car. $100k months were easy. My lifestyle was incredibly fun.

And complacency reared its ugly head again.

For a while, it won.

Until one day I woke up and thought to myself…

“Brother, you’re putting in a fraction of the effort you could be, and things are still working. What would happen if you go all in?”

Perhaps this sounds familiar.

Whether you’re just starting out, or you’ve gotten comfortable at your current level of income.

I’ll offer you some advice a mentor of mine gave me recently…

If life’s already good at this level, imagine how much better it is at levels above this.

We’re playing a never ending game here.

The higher you go, the better life gets.

Not because you can buy another supercar, move to a better place, and take care of those around you (although that’s a nice plus).

But because you’re actualizing the potential you know you have inside of you.

With each level you progress, you unlock an upgraded version of yourself.

And after all, what else is there to do?

​Resist the plague and life will keep getting better.​

To overcoming complacency,

Ben

​
​
​

subject: The Tik Tok Ban
content:
Tik Tok is NOT getting banned.

Although I can’t make a logical argument to support that claim, I’ve been through enough breakups and make-ups to know this is a smokescreen.

You know when your girlfriend says “Ok, this is it I’m actually done this time!”

And then she “forgets” her bag at your place and has to come get it the next day…

What happens?

Exactly.

This is one of those.

At least I think.

If it does get banned, it’ll be interesting to see what happens next.

More traffic to Instagram reels?

YT shorts?

A new platform?

Who knows. But honestly I think the Chinese algorithm is better than all of them.

It just knows me so well.

My fyp consists of Johnny Walker, NBA highlights, and random comedy I didn’t know I was even interested in beforehand.

This whole situation is like the normie super bowl.

“Woohoo course seller! Now you have to go get a real job like the rest of us!!”

Little do they know… If the ban strikes, we will stand here, unfazed.

Ready to pounce on whatever opportunity this creates.

Plus many personal brands have built an email list, Instagram, and Youtube. So one platform getting shut down isn’t the end of the world.

This reminds me of the common skepticism that unaware people have when you tell them you’re starting a business.

They’ll say some shit like, “Well what happens when that gets too saturated! What if AI takes your job? Can’t a business owner just do that on their own?”

Lol.

Yes, unforeseen events can occur.

Yes, there will be times where you are forced to adapt.

Yes, AI is advancing at a rapid rate.

Good thing you’re a business owner who’s built a plethora of skills, a network, and developed a mental fortitude that allows you to thrive in any environment.

Hold that L skeptic.

Fries. Bag. Now. Extra large coke. Keep the change. You filthy animal.

I am an infinite being with limitless potential. My unmatched perspicacity coupled with sheer indefatigability makes me a feared opponent in any realm of human endeavour.

Damn that really is a bar.

Anyway this email has gone off the rails a bit but I assure you:

No matter what happens with Tik Tok, AI, and any other unforeseen events…

If you focus on mastering your craft, innovating, and creating leverage – there will always be endless opportunities at your fingertips.

​Your success is inevitable.​

Ben

P.S. Reply and lmk if you liked this one

​
​

subject: Rules are for ugly people
content:
It’s an early one today.

I’m starting this at 8:17am from my phone, sitting outside of Starbucks.

They’re playing “Nice N Easy” by Frank Sinatra.

It’s 60 degrees and sunny-ish, which is cold for Miami but it feels good.

I took the scenic route here - a 25 minute walk along the water, circle around and walk back towards my apartment to get to the coffee shop.

They didn’t put the lid on all the way but luckily I spotted it before dumping the cup on myself shirt.

You know, most copywriters will tell you that the way I’m writing right now is flawed.

1 topic per email.

Don’t get sidetracked.

Don’t use more than 14 words per sentence.

Blah blah blah.

Rules like that are made for people who aren’t good enough to break them.

This applies to any realm of human endeavor (lol).

If you lean in to your authentic edge — and you’re good, you can do most things “wrong” and still win.

Everyone advises you to follow some content system…

You do the opposite. It works. They copy you.

The Golden State Warriors shoot too many threes. They win four NBA championships. Now everyone’s chucking threes.

See my point?

Lean into your own unique edge.

This is not school. You won’t get expelled for carving your own path.

Walk through life with that spark in your eye that only ignites when you’re authentically you.

Most never get to access it past childhood.

And sure, there are times where the common system is best to follow.

Remain aware of the norm and let it serve as a starting point, not an unbreakable rule book.

Got it?

Good.

When you’re authentically you, you leave an indelible mark on everything around you.

And your success is undeniably, inevitably, certain.

Break more rules,

Ben

P.S. If you're an existing copywriter, agency owner, or closer… this will help you.​

​
​

subject: How I landed a 9 figure client
content:
A client of mine ran his first webinar last night.

He’s a Miami resident, so my partner and I pulled up to his studio to help him get set up.

It was my first time meeting him in person and let me tell you – this guy is a savage.

For the sake of the email let’s call him Tony.

Tony’s made 9 figures in Real Estate and recently hopped on social media, sharing his story.

His audience has grown to the hundreds of thousands fast.

He’s got 4 decades of experience in RE. Billions of dollars in transactions.

When someone is this successful for this long, obviously there’s a lot to be learned.

My first observation was how energetic he is.

Although he's in his 60’s, he’s sharp as a tac.

The guy goes through a pack of Neurogum a day (lol) and is always on the move.

He was telling me about this new office they’re moving into…

Then how he’s shooting content 3 days a week…

Then about the new properties he’s developing.

He just doesn’t stop.

Working like this definitely keeps him young.

I pitched Tony about 6 months ago and we started working together.

He told me “I went with you because I liked your confidence. It was almost arrogance but that’s what you need in a team. I didn’t want someone who was timid.”

Since then we’ve scaled from zero to multiple six figure months with him.

As I’ve met more older, wealthy people over the past couple years, I’m always astounded by how normal they are.

I used to think deca-millionaires and centimillionaires must be so unrelatable and serious.

But as we sat at this burger restaurant after the webby, Tony was cracking jokes and telling stories.

He’s a normal guy – just with decades of hard work and calculated decisions under his belt.

And that's the thing about success...

The people who achieve it aren't superhuman.

They're just normal people who make different decisions consistently.

Tony's not successful because he's special.

He's successful because he shows up with energy every day, takes massive action, and makes calculated moves.

But here's what really struck me...

At 60+ years old, he's still pushing. Still learning. Still adapting.

While most people his age are slowing down, he's speeding up.

This is what separates the elite from everyone else.

Want to see exactly how I landed Tony as a client and scaled him to multiple six figures per month?

​Get access to the full breakdown inside of here.​

To calculated confidence,

Ben

P.S. Using the exact same pitch that landed Tony, my students are now closing their dream clients every week. You can be next.​

​

​

subject: I'm buying a Penthouse
content:
Hello and happy Friday, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Good news…

I got my business Instagram account back.

If you’re not following yet, you should – the movement has commenced and I want you to be a part of it.

Yesterday, I was browsing condos for rent in Miami.

My current place is nice, the view is incredible, and it’s in a great location.

But I want to hear echoes.

High ceilings. Wrap around floor to ceiling windows. And more space than I know what to do with.

During my search, I found this penthouse for $19k/mo.

It’s 2,500 square feet, marble floors, huge living area, big balcony etc.

Basically everything I want.

To move there, I’d pay at least $10k to break my current ($5k/mo) lease.

Then another $30k+ furnishing the new place.

And then obviously my rent would quadruple.

It’s not that I couldn’t do it, but it would sting.

And that pissed me off.

There’s something I want.

And I can’t get it.

Because it’s too… expensive?

My fingers hurt just typing the word expensi– I can’t do it again.

Am I a child?

Should I start asking permission to go to the bathroom too?

This lit a fire under me.

My lease is up in July and by then, I want to be in a position where I can spend $15k+ on rent without batting an eye.

If I can’t, I’ve dishonored my entire bloodline.

People often tell you to find a strong “why” – some altruistic motive that drives you.

And while I’m motivated by actualizing my potential and being able to take care of the people around me, sometimes that’s not enough.

My family isn’t in poverty.

Mom’s already retired and my Dad has more money in cars than most do in savings.

I don’t need to rescue anyone.

So sometimes, I’ll lean on superficial things as a source of motivation.

I’ll picture myself hopping out of a new supercar and walking into my penthouse.

And guess what?

In case no one’s ever told you this, allow me — it’s okay to want what you want.

If you’re not motivated, maybe you’re just not being honest with yourself.

You listened to dorks online tell you that you can’t want the flashy lifestyle.

Now you’re mad at your parents for raising you in a good home because you don’t have a strong enough “why.”

Be real with yourself. If you want to make money so you can hangout with baddies on the beach all day, then work really hard so you can do exactly that.​

Sure, at some point you’ll probably need a deeper reason to keep pushing.

But that’s not a worry right now.

​Get to the bag. You’ll find your purpose along the way.

I’ll see you in the Penthouse,

Ben

​
​

subject: Opportunity is here. Don't miss it
content:
Do you remember where you were when you realized COVID was gonna be a big deal?

I was nearing the end of my freshman year of college.

The rumblings about the virus were becoming more prevalent.

Still, I didn’t think much of it.

Then it all started to happen…

I remember checking my phone and seeing that the NBA postponed the games that night.

Not long after, I got an email from my school saying that we’d have to evacuate.

“Uh oh… this is starting to feel real,” I thought.

Next thing you know, the whole world is on pause and everyones wearing diapers on their faces to avoid the equivalent of a common cold.

Last night, I got a similar feeling when I opened Tik Tok.

“Holy shit… it’s actually banned.”

It seems likely that it’ll be back in the coming days or weeks once Trumps in office and everything will return to normal.

But you can’t ignore the fact that this is a big deal.

In 2023 alone, Tik Tok contributed $24.2 BILLION to the U.S. GDP.

And obviously that number has grown since then.

When an event of this magnitude occurs, opportunity arises.

The money doesn’t vanish, it gets redirected.

Other platforms would benefit from an influx of users.

Instagram reels, Youtube shorts, maybe Snapchat or a completely different app.

The first adopters would be heavily rewarded.

Again, it seems like this will get resolved sooner than later.

But the point about opportunity remains.

Whatever happens in the next couple weeks, you can use this as an excuse to get moving.

When the COVID lockdowns happened, all my friends and I took advantage of it.

We laid the foundation that allowed us to make more money than we ever thought possible and completely change our lives over the next couple years.

Could we have done this without the impact of the pandemic?

Yes.

But did it help spur us into action and get rich while everyone else was pouting?

Also yes.

You don’t want to look back on these crazy times and feel like you watched from the sidelines.

Crypto’s pumping.

The creator economy is booming.

AI is evolving.

Trumps getting inaugurated.

Money is everywhere.

Pick a lane and move as fast as you fucking can.

Because you don’t know when this run will end.

But if you follow the money, build your skillset, and adapt to the shifts in the market…

Nothing can phase you.

Not a ban. Not a fake virus. Not a robot with 1,000x your mental capacity.

​Become undeniable.​

Ben

​
​

subject: I need some advice...
content:
I’m advising you to stop taking advice.

Ironic, but important.

Everyone has their own biased beliefs, ideas, and perceptions.

And they’re not necessarily wrong.

But if you’re not careful, you’ll listen too much.

The habit of asking others for their thoughts will consume your own thoughts.

Any time you reach a crossroad, obstacle, or internal conflict, you'll feel helpless.

Consider what this signals to your subconscious…

{{ subscriber.first_name }} isn't self-reliant.

{{ subscriber.first_name }} doesn’t trust himself (or herself).

{{ subscriber.first_name }} can’t speak with conviction because their beliefs come from others.

You’re an infant. Basically asking for permission to think.

You’ll be the person who asks Google-able questions.

And worst of all, the excess of opinions will stun you.

Different potential solutions to problems get jumbled around in your head.

Any of which could work.

But because you haven’t built up internal conviction by making your own decisions, you can’t decide and commit.​

And even the smallest amount of resistance can pull you back to inaction.

So how do you fix this?

How do you start trusting yourself and feeling like you're in the driver’s seat of your life?

How do you begin to rely on your inner voice?

Here’s the solution…

Stop waiting for me (or anyone else) to give you an answer that you already have.

Ask yourself “How do I start building internal conviction?”

Ponder that question and come up with some simple ideas…

It can be minor changes to your habits.

Starting a hobby you’ve been putting off.

Pursuing a new opportunity in your business.

Whatever it is, it doesn't have to be anything wild or crazy.

But you need to show yourself that you can take actions simply because you want to.

You don’t need permission.

You don’t need advice.

You need you.

And luckily, you’re all you’ll ever have.​

Conviction is the great equalizer. You can’t win without it, you can’t lose with it.

The only way to build it is by listening to yourself.

Start today, right now. Don’t go looking for answers that you already have.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. Obviously there is nuance to this and there are times where guidance from people you trust is 100% helpful. Just don’t make it a habit to ask others before you ask yourself.

​
​

subject: You're overcomplicating this
content:
A little over a year ago, a friend of mine started building his first software company.

It’s now worth multiple 7 figures, soon to be 8.

Software is a difficult space to get into.

It’s especially harder than building an agency or coaching business.

In watching him get this off the ground, I learned a valuable lesson that can be applied to any endeavor…

Do not over complicate the uncomplicated.

There will always be a variety of things you don’t know.

You’ll likely have a tendency to want to feel ready, but it’s impossible to solve tomorrow's problems, today.

If you feel like you’re in over your head, you’re doing something right.

Nearly every successful business owner follows a similar path:

1. They learn the basics.

2. They dive in well before they feel ready.

3. They solve problems on the fly.

4. They adapt, carve their lane, and find success.

There is no way around this.

Most people get caught up in step 1 and 2 because they start overcomplicating it.

Let’s say you’re building an info-product agency.

You need to do two things…

Learn the fundamentals of copywriting for coaching businesses.

Do outreach.

Everything else is a waste of time.

You can spend weeks or months contemplating a niche, offer, what to say in your outreach, etc.

All you’re doing is avoiding action.

When you get a client, you’ll then have a better vantage point to understand what bottlenecks need to be solved.

You just can’t let the unknown stop you from putting one foot in front of the other.

Steve Jobs didn’t know how he’d build Apple.

Zuckerberg didn't have Facebook mapped out.

They just started and figured it out along the way.

The same applies to you.

You don't need to know how you'll get to $100k months.

You just need to know your next step.

For you, that's probably sending your first outreach message.

Or jumping on your first sales call.

Or closing your first client.

Everything after that?

You'll figure it out when you get there.

​Ready to take your first step? Let me show you exactly where to start.​

To keeping it simple,

Ben

​
​
​

subject: Shortcuts DO exist...
content:
When I first got into online business, all I wanted was fast success.

I was one of the idiots in the comment sections saying…

“How long will it take to get a client?”

“How long will it take to get to $10k/month?”

“How long will it take to buy my dream car?”

My perception of time was skewed.

Even hearing that it could take 6 months of hard work before I make financial progress sounded like eternity.

I wanted money and I wanted it now!

Because of my flawed mindset, it ended up taking longer.

I hopped from one business model to the next.

I’d look for someone to give me a defined, step-by-step roadmap with a timeline.

Obviously that didn’t exist.

After spending nearly a year flirting with the idea of success and making half-hearted attempts at a few businesses, I finally accepted it…

This shit is gonna be hard.

It’s gonna take time.

I’m gonna have to learn A LOT.

And even with all my hard work, nothing is guaranteed.

As grim as that may sound, accepting this made it a hell of a lot easier.

Instead of looking for shortcuts I started planting seeds.

My inner dialogue shifted from, “how can I make money this month?” to “how can I set up a solid foundation over the next 3 months?”​

And when I finally did that, guess what?

I found the fast success I was looking for.

Ironic, huh?

The shortcut is understanding that there is no shortcut.

When you stop searching for it, you start focusing on what’s important.

And when you focus on what’s important, you make progress.

(Relatively) Fast.

“The day you plant the seed is not the day you eat the fruit.”

Build skills.

Commit to continuous learning.

Make connections.

Improve your habits.

Fortify your mind.

And accept that anything fast, doesn’t last.

​You’ll be in your dream car in no time.​

Godspeed,

Ben

​
​

subject: What makes a good copywriter?
content:
I’m writing to you from the clouds.

Let me show you:

A parakeet just landed on my balcony.

He said “Ben, what makes a good copywriter?”

Here’s my answer…

A good copywriter accurately articulates a prospect's current situation in detail.

He makes a logical argument overcoming all objections that would prevent them from purchasing the product.

That’s about it.

I’ll show you in action.

My goal is to get you to book a call and join Artisan Lab.​

Right now, there’s a variety of factors that could be stopping you:

1. You think you can learn everything for free on Youtube

2. You don’t fully understand the info-product agency model

3. You’re worried you won’t be able to get clients

4. You’re unclear on what you’d do for clients and how you’d pitch them

5. You think it sounds too complex to start right now

There are more potential objections, but those are the 5 most prevalent I hear.

I’ll show you how I’d overcome a couple of them…

Objection 1:

The truth is, you can learn most of what you'd need to know on Youtube.

But it’ll slow you down immensely.

Instead of having a step-by-step roadmap showing you what to do every day for the next 90 days…

You’ll have to spend hours digging through mud to find gems on social media.

And even then, how will you know what information to trust?

It’s a gamble.

If you have time to waste, by all means figure it out on your own.

But if you want a sure thing?

Coaching is the way to go.

Objection 2:

So you’ve heard people talk about building an info-product agency but you’re unsure where to start.

Let me break it down for you:

Your job is to partner with a content creator who posts educational content.

They focus on getting more attention, you focus on selling their coaching program.

To do this, you’ll start by learning the foundational skill of copywriting.

Next you’ll get up to speed on the info-product space – I’ll teach you about offers, funnels, VSLs, webinars, etc.

After 2-4 weeks of active studying and practice reps, you’ll be ready to start outreach.

Boom.

See what I’m doing here?

If I were writing a VSL or sales page I’d simply continue to address objections 3-5.

Prospects would feel understood and trust me to lead them to the solution.

So there’s your answer Mr. Parakeet.

Want to see me overcome the rest of your objections?

​Go here now and you’ll see a clear example of everything I just told you about.​

To better copy,

Ben

​
​
​

subject: Why AI *won't* take your job
content:
Two days President Trump announced the formation of Stargate.

A few of the largest tech firms came together and will be investing $500 BILLION into AI infrastructure over the next four years.

Big news.

So what does this mean for you?

Will AI replace you and you’ll resort to mopping the floors at your local high school?

Quite the opposite, actually.

Trump says this project will create around 100,000 jobs.

It’s impossible to predict what will be built over the coming years.

But in the short term, here’s my recommendation for you…

Do not neglect the utilization of AI in your business.

It’s a tool that can make you wildly more efficient, improve your copy, and expand your service delivery.

A marketer who uses AI effectively will outperform one who doesn’t.

Simple as that.

Now this brings me to the question…

“If AI can do most of the legwork, why would online coaches still hire copywriters?”

There are two main arguments here:

1. Laziness/unawareness

ChatGPT and Claude have been around for a while now.

Most info-product sellers already know this.

But still, they haven’t taken the time to use them effectively on their own.

They prefer bringing someone on to do the work for them rather than diving into the AI world themselves.

2. A vast skill set makes you irreplaceable

An email copywriter who writes a few half decent emails a week is expendable.

You could be replaced with AI or by any of the other horny copywriters in your clients DMs.

But if you’re offering a multitude of services – funnels, VSLs, offer creation, sales management, automations, etc…

You’re invaluable.

AI can’t do all of that on its own (although it can help you do it more effectively).

We’re entering a golden era.​

There’s a lot of money to be made over the next 4 years.

And it’d be a shame if you don’t capitalize on it.

​Go here and I’ll show you how you can use AI to your advantage.​

Have a good weekend,

Ben

​
​

subject: The fast lane to millions
content:
Good morning.

I’m on my balcony squinting at my computer screen.

If you’re somewhere cold and gloomy right now, I feel bad for you.

It’s 73 and sunny here.

I’m shirtless with a zyn in my upper lip, looking down at the water.

Serenity.

Alright, let’s cut the chit chat.

You want to get rich fast?

Easy.

1. Set an objective

2. Identify potential solutions

3. Implement immediately

4. Get data

5. Make necessary adjustments

The faster you do this, the faster you find success.

I have very few closely held beliefs but this is one I’m sure of.

Have an idea?

Act on it.

The voice telling you that you don’t know where to start is natural.

It’s impossible to know because you don’t have the necessary data.

The only way to get data is through trial and error.

And when you make action your default state, you get data a hell of a lot quicker.

Here’s an example:

Ellis joined Artisan Lab 7 days ago.

Yesterday, he got a new client.

Are there some potential obstacles that he might not know how to solve right now?

Yes.

But he’ll find the solution once he acquires more data.

Same with Phillip, who just signed a client on a 20% rev share.

Winners win because they take action quicker than losers.

They learn on the fly and adapt as they go.

​You can join the winning team and get access to the same system they’re using to close deals by going here.​

Or you can remain on the sidelines and keep making excuses.

It’s all up to you, my friend.

Ben

​
​

subject: Organic vs paid traffic for info-products
content:
Last night, I was hanging out with my rich uncle, Rob (@robthebank).

We mostly chatted about content and selling info.

Most coaching businesses seem to have a relatively short life span.

A personal brand gets hot, capitalizes on (or creates) a trend, and makes a bag.

All they have to do is make organic content.

Their systems typically aren’t great and their product might not be the best…

But they’re swimming with the tide – right place, right time, right offer.

They print with ease.

This can last for as short as a few months and probably as long as a handful of years.

But eventually, the tide shifts…

Views decline.

Reputations get tainted.

The market gets flooded with competition.

The offer isn’t as hot as it used to be.

Any of the above can occur and when this happens, the once simple and easy cash flow business starts to get complex.

Used to 80% margins with organic traffic?

Hope you’re ready for that to decline when you have to pay for every eyeball.

And if you have subpar systems, aren’t tracking your metrics, and your attention to detail isn’t rock solid…

You’re in for a rude awakening.

This is how info-businesses end up collapsing quickly.

Their organic traffic dies down and they don’t build the infrastructure to be successful selling to cold traffic.

Scaling through paid ads is a completely different game.

First, your margins will likely get cut down to around 50% or less as you scale.

A friend of mine made $2m in a month last year, almost all through paid.

He kept around $600k.

Sure it’s great money, but it’s 10x the work and the stress of organic traffic.

And there’s (almost always) no real enterprise value.

The goal is cash flow.

If you have to spend $1m/mo, build a huge team, constantly test new offers, and sell your heart out to keep a couple hundred grand?

It definitely gets draining.

The game is to stay relevant organically (which is hard to do for more than a few years)...

While also building the infrastructure that can work on cold traffic.

If you rely solely on one or the other, you’re running a risky business.

Just my 2 cents,

Ben

P.S. If you want to learn how to build an info-product agency the right way – with systems that work for both organic and paid traffic – I can show you here.​

You’ll learn how I’ve scaled offers all the way up to $700k/month, how I get the best clients in the business, and how you can do the same.

​Go here to apply for a strategy call.​

subject: How to make hard tasks feel easy
content:
One day life will be all peace and joy.

You’ll spend your time only doing things you love.

All of your problems will vanish.

And you’ll never have to do things you don’t want to do.

At least, that’s what I used to think…

But this, my friend, is what we call a delusion.

There will always be things in business (and in life) that feel like a chore.

Sorry to burst your bubble.

Now, this doesn’t have to be a bad thing.

All it takes is a simple reframe…

Think of a task that you typically dread doing.

Maybe it’s outreach, building systems, calls, etc.

Instead of looking at it like this daunting activity that you want to avoid at all costs…

Simply accept that it will suck.

You won’t enjoy the time that it takes to complete said task.

But once you get through it, you’ll feel good.

You’ll move the needle forward and that’s all that matters.

When you do this, the daunting tasks begin to lose their power.

Instead of fighting two battles – one against your mind and one against the thing you’re dreading…

You’re only fighting one.

Just embrace that it won’t be fun.

And get it done.

Eventually that resistance will feel like curling 5lb dumbbells.

It gets easier.

You just have to overcome the voice in your head that’s telling you to run from the pain.

Soon you’ll be enjoying the fruits of your labor.

​If you want me to guide you through the trenches, join me here.​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​
​

subject: Diversifying your income is for the poors
content:
“The average millionaire has 7 different income streams.”

Shut up.

This is some shit your broke uncle puts on his Instagram story with a 💯 emoji.

Fuck off Uncle Tony, you work at Dennys.

Do not let poverty advice like this fool you…

I spent the majority of 2024 haphazardly chasing random projects.

I’d consider scaling my agency, launching a new offer, coaching, crypto, etc.

After considering each thing for a week or two, I’d move on to the next shiny solution.

This was quite idiotic and it halted my progress.

Because I was always half in, half out, I never put enough attention or time into any one thing.

Now, I’m the opposite.

I have one objective every day:

Create content that makes more people know, like and trust me.

My main focus is solidified.

And after being on both sides, I can tell you with full certainty, it’s much better this way.

When I was unfocused, there were days where I’d wake up and not know what to do.

Although there was plenty of work to be done, I couldn’t pick one thing.

It’s impossible to make progress this way.

But when you have one main objective, you wake up every day knowing the levers you need to pull.

It feels amazing because you have clarity.

This allows you to perform effectively without constantly pondering if you’re doing the right thing.

And if you’re stressed right now, it’s likely because you’re not giving yourself that clarity.

You’re listening to Uncle Tony and Instagram theme pages.

To be entirely clear, this doesn’t mean you can never have multiple businesses.

As you progress as an entrepreneur, opportunities fall into your lap.

Oftentimes, those opportunities can complement one another.

But when you try to start too many new things at once without having concrete objectives, you’re just distracting yourself.

Instead, focus on one main thing at a time.

Build it to a point where it doesn’t require your full attention.

And then think about other ways to grow.

Don’t get fooled into thinking you need 7 unprofitable businesses.

You don’t get an award for opening up an LLC.

Money won’t magically start falling into your lap.

​Start with one cash flowing business and put your sole focus into it.​

You'll grow much faster.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​
​

subject: How to be comfortably irresponsible with money
content:
I hit a new high score today.

$8.51.

Eight dollars and fifty one cents on an iced latte. Before tip.

To be fair, I added vanilla.

And yes, the vanilla does in fact cure cancer.

Pretty cool, right?

This got me thinking…

If you were to spend $8.51 on coffee every day, that’s $3,106.15 over the course of a year.

Meaning if you make $60k per year, you’re blowing over 5% of your income on coffee.

“WeLl aCtuAlLy, YoU cOulD JuSt MaKe iT aT hoMe.”

Stop.

Here’s how to make enough money to enjoy your morning stroll in the Miami sun and happily buy whatever coffee you want:

First things first, this will likely take two years.

Hey now, don’t leave just yet.

I know that sounds like a while but stick with me here…

Two years isn’t that long!

Okay, we just lost everyone else reading this so it’s just you me now, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Here are three steps to escape the cubicle…

Step 1. Learn copywriting

I’m not saying this to sell you, I’m saying this because it’s the most versatile skill you can learn.

You can pitch local businesses, eCom brands, agencies, or coaching businesses.

To reach escape velocity, you only need $5-10k/month.

That’s like two or three clients on retainer. Or one solid client on a rev share (tutorial).​

If you’re starting from zero, pitch anyone and everyone.

Take $500 retainers.

Do free work for a testimonial.

Work with your Grandma’s friend's niece who owns a wildly unprofitable bakery (even though she sells $8 coffee).

You just need experience and money.

Do this for six months and you’ll be in a decent spot.

Let’s say you’re making around $5-7k per month…

Step 2. Move somewhere cheap

Get your passport, buddy. I hope you like latinas.

Head over to Tulum, Mexico or somewhere similar.

Bonus points if you make sure you’re not gonna get captured by a local gang.

Now it’s time to lock in.

You’ll save most of your money and spend the time you’re not working on a beach.

Stay here until you start making software engineer money.

For me this phase was four months.

By the end, I was making around $15k per month and had nearly $100k in savings.

Step 3. Bienvenidos a Miami

Time to up the stakes.

You’ve proven to yourself that you can consistently make money on your own.

It doesn’t appear the business will randomly collapse any time soon. And if it does you’ve got some cash in the bank.

Open up your wallet and find a spot in a bigger city.

You’ll likely spend more on rent than you were spending total the previous few months.

That’s okay, you need pressure.

Between the pressure, your now year of experience in the game, and the connections you’ll make in your new city…

It’s inevitable you’ll get to $30k, $50k, and eventually $100k/month plus.

And maybe I’ll run into you in line to get a cancer-curing latte :)

If you made it down here and you’re ready to do this…

​Here’s a good place to start.​

Ben

​
​

subject: You're afraid of success and you know it
content:
Success comes with downsides…

More pressure.

Increased responsibility.

Higher standards.

Added expectations.

And greater consequences.

Sure, these are better problems to have.

But problems are problems, nonetheless.

There’ve been times in my life where I’ve sabotaged my own growth in order to avoid these downsides.

It was almost subconscious.

I didn’t want the pressure of dealing with more clients, so I’d “forget” to follow up with a lead.

Or I’d disqualify someone that I could’ve pitched and closed.

And as my brand has grown on social media, I’ve become more particular with what I share.

A louder microphone means more attention.

More attention means greater consequences – for better or worse.

You can only grow as big as you allow yourself to be.

Yes, there are future repercussions that come with success.

But you want to know the key to getting over your fear?

Accept your unpreparedness.

You probably aren’t equipped to handle an abundance of responsibility, attention, or expectations.

If tomorrow, you were given one million followers on social media, a $500k/mo business, dozens of clients and a big team…

You’d probably crumble.

You’d be too nervous to post any content and continue growing your brand.

Your clients and team members would leave because you don’t know how to lead.

And the business would go to shit…

But that’s exactly why the journey exists.

It’s there to mold you into the person capable of receiving success.

Go through challenges and tribulations. You’ll be forced to grow.

The more you overcome, the more prepared you become.

By the time you reach the top of the mountain, you’ll have won so many battles that you’re bulletproof.

The “downsides” you were once afraid of no longer hold any power over you.

Congrats, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

You’ve stopped running from the pressure.

Soon enough it’ll feel weightless,

Ben.

This is best for existing copywriters, closers, agency owners, and content creators.

subject: Your $25,325 payout is on the way...
content:
The other day I got a $25,325 wire.

It’s one of a few 5 figure payments I’ll get from various clients this month.

Just three years ago, I was struggling to land $1k retainers.

I was gonna make this email a step by step outline on how to land whale clients…

​But I already did that here.​

I’d rather tell you about the mindset shift you must go through to get paid this much.

It’s a 25x increase from what I used to charge, but that doesn’t mean I’m 25x more skilled.

I’d argue that I’m only 2-3x better than I was then.

There are two main difference makers here:

Key difference #1 – The ability to identify opportunity vehicles.

Not all clients are created equally.

Not all markets are created equally.

Not all business models are created equally.

A personal brand with thousands of followers in a specific niche will make more money than a local basketball trainer.

That one's obvious but there’s a plethora of other factors that factor into what makes a good client.

After doing this for a few years I’ve gotten better at identifying them (I’ll show you how here).​

Key difference #2 – Who I believe I am.

I’m incredibly confident in my ability to scale businesses.

When I take someone on as a client, I am doing them a favor.

It is the best possible investment they can make.

Because we’re the best at what we do, that comes with a higher price.

This is the frame you need to take to be successful.

Even before it’s true.

You can be confident in your willingness to figure out problems on the fly.

And you can be confident in your work ethic.

With that, you’ll create data (making clients a bunch of money) that solidifies your beliefs.

And next thing you know, you’ll have a client portfolio like the one I have on here.​

See you at the top,

Ben

​

subject: The antidote to shiny object syndrome
content:
The grass is greener where you water it.

I’ve been in the online business world for about four years now.

Every project I’ve worked on follows a similar timeline:

I start something new – it’s exciting and I’m eager to get the ball moving.

Soon after, the initial excitement wears off.

The work starts to feel less like play and more like work.

But the momentum I’ve built up carries me and I keep progressing.

This is typically where exponential growth occurs.

It feels new enough to keep me engaged and I’ve accepted the reality that it requires intentionality and focus.

Eventually the novelty completely fades.

I start dreading many of the tasks that used to feel easy.

I’m now solely relying on willpower, my enjoyment of the process is gone.

This period continues until one of two things occur…

I find a way to spice things up and the potential for growth reignites my spark.

Or I become completely uninterested with the project at hand and pivot to something fresh.

This is a natural progression I see amongst nearly all of my friends.

It’s not a bad thing, if you’re aware of it.

But if you’re unaware, you can convince yourself that the business “doesn't feel right” it’s time to shift.

You’ll find a shinier objective and pursue it until the luster inevitably wears off.

Again, you’ll search for something new and the cycle repeats.

This won’t lead to any meaningful progress.

On the contrary, you can accept that eventually the work will become dull.

That doesn’t mean you’re going in the wrong direction.

It means you have to keep “watering the grass” even though it’s redundant.

Excitement can only take you so far.

If you’re too reliant on it, your eyes will constantly wander.

But if you stay engaged, keep moving, and accept that the excitement will come and go…

​That’s where the grass is greenest.​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​
​

​

subject: Stop concealing your desires
content:
I began writing to this list in 2021.

There were a little under 200 subscribers, all of which I’d gotten through Twitter.

I started it solely for fun.

Since then, it’s grown by the tens of thousands and I’ve made multiple six figures from it.

I get around 50% open rates.

Countless people have come up to me in real life telling me they love my emails.

In fact, a few months ago I ran into a kind Australian guy who was reading an email of mine as I walked into a coffee shop in Brickell.

That was cool.

Of everything I’ve built online, this list is something I’m most proud of.

I’m not telling you all of this to brag…

My approach here has never been very calculated.

I write these because I enjoy it.

Sure it’s made me money now, but I’d sent hundreds of emails before ever pitching anything.

And I think that’s what makes it special.

Even if you’re not interested in anything I sell, you know that when you open an email of mine you’ll get value from it.

Instead of viewing each email as a mini sales pitch, I write about what I find interesting.

​My coaching is here if you want it but I’m not shoving it down your throat.

This leads me to my main point:

You are rewarded most when your intentions are pure and honest.

In any interaction – business, dating, or socially…

You can feel it when someone wants something from you.

Every word out of their mouth is an attempt to get you to give them what they want.

When they try to conceal that objective, you lose trust in them.

Now I’m not telling you that you can’t sell others on you.

But rather be open about the desired exchange in value.

If you’re trying to close a prospect, you need to show them why they should buy from you.

Give them advice.

Tell them what they could do, even if they don’t work with you.

Prove that you are competent and you know what you’re talking about.

The law of reciprocity is real.

As corny as it sounds, the more you give, the more you get.

Remain transparent with your motive behind giving.

And you will be rewarded with the things you want.

If you liked this one and want to work with me more closely, you can do so here :)​

Happy Monday,

Ben

​

​

subject: The AI prompt that cut my workload in half
content:
The setup is often more difficult to overcome than the implementation.

It’s hard to get in the car and drive to the gym.

It’s easy to workout once you’re there.

Similarly, when I write these emails, the idea is half the battle.

I’ll take a walk, stare at a blinking cursor, or scroll through social media…

Dozens of potential topics come to mind, most of which I discard.

But finally, an idea that seems worthy of an email will emerge.

After that, the assembly of the words you’re reading now is the easy part.

All I need is a rough idea.

Then I start typing, my brain starts cooking, and 20 minutes later we’ve completed the task.

50% of my energy is spent on ideation, the other 50% on implementation.

Here’s how AI can cut this time in half:

To be clear – it could write the entire email for me, but I like writing these.

Instead, I’ll have it source an idea.

First I’ll upload a handful of my previous emails and/or Youtube videos into Claude.

Next, I’ll prompt it with something like:

“Based on my previous content, give me five potential topics I could write an email on in the future that align with my brand.”

Obviously I can get more specific here as well if I want to.

If I like the five ideas it gives me, I’ll ask it to generate another 20.

And just like that, I have a month's worth of email topics ready to go.

If you have a copywriting client or your own list, I encourage you to try this out.

It’s a step you can take to start using AI that will make you wildly more efficient.

Stop being afraid of AI.

It’s here to help you (at least for now).

It won’t replace you, but someone using it will.

​Be the hunter, not the hunted.​

Ben

​
​

​

subject: You're being tricked
content:
You’re under attack.

Every day, hundreds of destructive thoughts enter your mind.

They’re deceptive and deceitful.

Their goal?

Keep you where you are and who you are.

They’ll try to convince you you’re underprepared or going in the wrong direction.

“{{ subscriber.first_name }}, you’re not ready to start yet… but maybe if you watch 12 more Hormozi videos you will be!”

Or “{{ subscriber.first_name }}, this business model is too difficult, you should rent a Corvette C8 (the lambo’s too expensive) and sell dropshipping courses instead.

Sound familiar?

Your success is dependent on your ability to resist these tricks.

This magical utopia you envision where you love every second of the journey doesn’t exist.

At least not on this spiritual plane.

There is no way to get around the fact that at times, work will feel like work.

You’ll often feel underprepared.

Temptations of alternative routes will always be there.

These thoughts are natural.

But you must remember you live in reality – where nothing is ever as good or as bad as it looks in your head.

Change is difficult.

Growth brings higher expectations.

And work gets redundant.

A sexier business model or new Youtube video are not the way around this.

That’s your ego luring you into a trap.

Resist, my friend.

You know what needs to be done.

You don’t need more advice.

You don’t need a better vehicle.

Hit the gas and throw your rearview mirror out the window.

Ben

P.S. If you’re a copywriter, closer, or agency owner who wants to be able to charge clients 5 figures a month, check out Artisan Lab here.​

subject: The strategy behind 6 figure launches
content:
In the past few years I’ve launched countless new offers for my clients.

A few flopped.

A handful did okay.

And almost a dozen made six figures in the first 30 days.

In terms of percentages, we’re talking Barry Bonds PED era numbers.

Our best was a $600k week.

Our worst was a single $997 sale.

But it's safe to say we’ve had a lot more winners than losers.

Here’s how to successfully crush a new info-product launch:

Phase 1: The offer

Half the battle is identifying what the audience wants.

That’ll be contingent on the type of content the client makes and their field of expertise.

If they’ve attracted a mass market B2C audience, perhaps a mid-ticket offer ($500-$2,000) will work better.

If it’s a more mature audience and the bulk of the value is in access to the client, high ticket is the way to go.

99 times out of 100, avoid low ticket like the plague.

Our success has come through selling mid ticket via sales pages and webinars, or high ticket through a VSL call funnel.

As a general rule of thumb, either price it at $3k+ and sell over the phone.

Or price it between $500 to $2k and sell through a sales page/webinar.

Phase 2: Pre-launch

Once you’ve decided on your offer and price point, now it’s time to build hype.

Roughly two weeks before launch, make an announcement on all channels.

Email, Instagram stories, existing communities, etc.

Your goal is to get people excited.

Identify the problem the audience is facing.

Use these channels to exacerbate their pain and explain how you have a solution coming soon.

You can also build up a waitlist or start getting people to sign up for a webinar.

As the launch approaches, increase the frequency of reminders.

Phase 3: Launch

Offer goes live.

Announce it on all channels.

Hammer the scarcity and urgency – why should they buy now?

The first batch can get special bonuses and/or discounted pricing.

Set a date or (real) limit on how many people get access.

You’ll typically have a spike in sales immediately, it’ll sustain for a few days, and then it’s time to remind them what they’ll miss out on if they don’t get in now.

This should create an additional spike towards the end of the launch.

Once all spots are filled, or the window is over, don’t go back on your word.

Just like that, you’ve successfully made a doctor's annual salary in a week or two.

And you didn’t even have to cheat your way through medical school.

Congrats,

Ben

P.S. I share full breakdowns of this kind of stuff inside Artisan Lab.​

If you want to see this entire process in depth, including:

- How to craft a winning offer that the audience will actually want

- Selecting the perfect price point for the offer

- The exact emails/ strategies I’ve used to build hype

- How to write a launch VSL

- The full webinar template we’ve used to make six figures in a single day

And much more…

subject: Why Growth Operating never truly worked
content:
Remember the whole “Growth Operating” trend about a year ago?

It appears to be dead.

Brady and Eddie (the guys who popularized the model) are friends of mine.

They actually paid me for a few consulting calls right before Eddie’s brand started to blow up.

In no way am I intending to throw shade at them, but rather objectively breakdown why the offer fell apart.

The traffic was great.

Eddie’s awesome on camera.

Brady’s a wizard on the backend.

And the online education industry is growing, so teaching people how to capitalize on it makes sense.

The problem?

Positioning.

From the outside looking in, this appears to be the core problem.

The business model was drastically oversimplified.

It was marketed to beginners, with little focus on skill acquisition and service delivery (at least front facing).

When you have a bunch of little idiots running around in a community thinking it’ll be easy to make money online, that creates some problems.

It’s not that what they taught was wrong, but the way they positioned it was.

They clearly had many successful students.

But when you scale as high and as fast as they did, the majority of your students will be complete beginners.

Most beginners fail.

The ones who succeed take longer to do so.

Couple this with the fact that it seemed like there was a new hit piece going out on Eddie every day…

And the negative word of mouth associated with the term “Growth Operating” spreads.

Next thing you know, the decline is steep and fast.

This is why I’ll never tell you that building an Info-Product Agency is easy.

You’ll have to learn a lot.

It might take a while to get a really solid client.

If you’re not resilient, you’ll quit before you succeed.

But if you commit to the process?

A single client can change your life.

And soon enough, you can be one of the successful case studies we have here.​

Ben

P.S. I just made a video going more in depth on everything I talked about here.

​Come check it out.​

​

​

subject: The gap gets wider
content:
“A good marketer can fully articulate why two opposing arguments can both be true.” - Ben Bader

I’ve talked a lot about the benefits of AI.

It’s helped me become more efficient.

It’s given me content ideas.

And it’s helping the members inside Artisan Lab get clients.

Although we’re just scratching the surface of potential use cases, it’s already been an incredibly powerful tool.

But as stated in my quote above, I'd be a bad marketer if I didn’t tell you about the downside of AI.

So without further ado, here’s how artificial intelligence could ruin your life:

AI won’t save you, it’ll dig your grave for you.

Someone smart once said, “winners win and losers lose.”

In this case, AI won’t turn you from a loser to a winner.

It’ll make you a bigger loser.

If you get fooled into thinking you don’t have to work on your craft because a robot will do your entire job for you, you'll wind up replacing yourself.

Natural human creativity will be removed from the equation and your quality of work will decline and become bland.

As implementation becomes easy, the one with the best idea wins.

This is especially true in the copywriting world.

If you think like everyone else, you’ll write like everyone else.

You won’t understand the difference between a good idea and a bad idea.

You’ll sound like a robot.

And eventually, your over-reliance on AI will make you obsolete.

Congrats, you played yourself.

Now, if you use AI the right way…

As a tool to turbocharge your own ability, not as a replacement.

And you keep innovating, testing, and improving your craft.

You’ll be lightyears ahead of everyone else.

The gap gets wider.

Winners win, and losers lose.

If you want to avoid being on the losing team, don’t listen to anyone who says AI can do your entire job for you (nothing is as easy as it sounds).

And if you want to be on the winning team?

​Join me here.​

Ben

​

​

subject: Why some are allergic to success
content:
I figured it out…

There’s a way to guarantee failure.

If you follow this foolproof failure formula, you’ll become helpless and bitter.

And no matter what happens, it’ll never be your fault.

Last night, I was scrolling through Twitter before bed.

I saw a post that gave me nightmares.

It beautifully encapsulated the mindset required to lose.

A grown man said publicly… to thousands of people on the internet… the following…

“I fucked up.

Burned through $18K in 5 months. Got about $20K left.

I should’ve gone to Asia instead of Canada.

If you’re living on savings, DO NOT move to the West. The same money would’ve taken me 10x further.

Made no money while I’ve been here. Just watching my bank balance shrink.

My X account is dead because I barely tweet. Years of growth, gone.

Meanwhile, some people are making millions per month by selling some stupid course on how to get rich.

I hate how unfair life can be.”

As I began reading the tweet I figured he’d turn it around at some point.

You know like, hook you with a sob story and then tell you how he persevered.

But there is no perseverance in sight.

Just pity and blame.

Normally I’m empathetic but this guy lost me when he started hating on course gurus and said how life is unfair.

You can argue with reality, or you can learn the rules and win the game.

Whatever you do, don’t start feeling sorry for yourself.

Don’t blame your inadequacies on external factors.

Don’t harbor resentment for those who find success.

And perhaps most importantly, don’t quit before it’s even close to over.

That guy said he had $20k left and based on his spending that’s another 6 months of expenses.

Even if he blew through that, there’s always another option.

You are as resilient as you allow yourself to be.

Nothing worth having comes easy.

You’ll be tested and tricked. But if you make it through, the other side is beautiful.

And you’ll know that you earned it.

You only lose when you throw in the towel.

Don’t go crying to strangers on the internet,

Ben

P.S. While that guy wastes his last $20k feeling sorry for himself, my students are building 6 and 7 figure agencies. Join them here.​

subject: Most course sellers are lying about this
content:
“If what they taught actually worked, they wouldn’t be selling a course on it.”

This is a common argument you’ve probably heard against course sellers.

It’s a valid concern and true in some cases.

Many reach an iota of success from their business and immediately start selling info on it.

That annoys the hell out of me.

A singular $10k month does not make you an expert.

Personally, I made over $100k/mo with my agency before I ever sold coaching.

Here’s a literal screenshot from my bank statement in September 2023 for proof:

That being said, different business models scale to varying levels.

For example most closers cap out around $20-30k/mo.

Let's say a closer reaches that number for a while.

After a year or two in sales, they begin selling info on it and get to $100k/mo as a coach.

I see no problem with it as long as they’re not claiming you can make 6 figures monthly from sales.

It’s a good beginner business model to make your first $10-30k/mo.

But it’s quite the anomaly to scale past that.

This is the case for many of the other popular business models as well.

However, the Info-Product Agency is different.

Even if you’re just starting out, a few retainers and/or rev shares can get you past $10k/month.

Once you do that, you’ll be much more skilled.

And then you can start getting bigger clients and higher rev shares.

That can take you to $50k or even $100k/month like it did for me.

I made over $2m in about two years from my agency.

I got a high rise in Miami from my agency money.

I bought my dream car from my agency money.

Most people who sell coaching can’t say that the business they teach made them rich.

They made good money from it, but great money from info.

I’m doing both.

So my question for you is this…

Would you rather pick a business model that inevitably caps out at a relatively low income threshold?

Or would you rather pick a model that can scale to 7 figures annually?

(Which is not easy whatsoever but it is possible, as I am living proof).

That’s a choice you’ll have to make.

But if you wanna learn from someone who got rich by doing, not teaching…

​Go here now and get access to my blueprint.​

To ethical info,

Ben

​

subject: I accidentally replaced myself
content:
Each morning as I open a blank Google doc to write to you, I consider using AI.

It could write the whole thing for me.

I’d skim the copy, making sure it didn’t say anything super cringey.

And after a few edits, we’d be done.

You’d probably never know it’s robot Ben and not real Ben.

It’s tempting, but I’ll never do it.

Or maybe I’m doing it right now and tricking you?

Either way, here’s what I would do if I were a lazy piece of shit who didn’t want to write these emails manually:

Step 1. Open a new project in Claude.

I’d upload my last 25+ emails as PDFs.

Then prompt Claude to build a full breakdown of my style and tone.

Perhaps I’d have it create a list of frequent topics I write about as well.

This would likely be the most time consuming part, but once it’s done, we’re smooth sailing.

Step 2. Transcribe my Youtube videos

Let’s say I make a Youtube video about why eating seed oils gives you superpowers.

I could take that transcript and upload it to Claude.

Then I’d say, “Hey Mr. Claude. Please write a complete email to my list in my tone and style using a topic from the seed oil superpower video. P.S. You look really handsome today.”

My glorious robot would then give me a complete email.

And after a few tweaks, you’d be sitting here reading it with no idea it’s AI copy.

The only downside here is transcribing the videos could take a bit.

I share a way where you can drastically speed up that process here.​

Step 3. Get creative

Once I have this AI version of me (which I could actually make even better by fine tuning it, but that’s a bit harder), the sky’s the limit.

I could give it an idea and analogy to use and have it spit out an email.

I could tell it to reference a book I’m reading or use a lesson from a certain movie.

I could have it write a complete email based on one of my Tweets.

As long as I’m creative with my prompts, the emails would never get redundant or feel like AI.

Now I enjoy writing these so I’ll never do that.

But if I wanted to, I could.

Which is pretty cool.

However I must add a big caveat here:

If you’re not already a decent copywriter, this won’t work for you.

I’ve written hundreds of emails. I easily come up with creative analogies and metaphors.

The process is second nature at this point.

Because of these reasons, AI can be useful.

But without them, it’s like giving nuclear launch codes to a squirrel on meth.

No bueno.

Still typing my own damn emails,

Ben

P.S. There’s a way to make the process I outlined here take minutes instead of hours. I’ve built a system that cuts the time down by 80%. Soon I’ll be able to share it publicly, but for now you can get exclusive access by going here.​

​
​

​

subject: Value is overrated
content:
I really could care less about you today.

No offense.

I’m not gonna pretend to give you value here.

It’s a rather low status action.

“I need to give my audience VALUE, so they will like me and buy from me.”

Grow up.

I’d rather you buy from me because I made you laugh.

Anyway, I’m getting a haircut in two hours.

I considered canceling because my barber is being a dick.

I texted to confirm.

He liked the message.

No “awesome, see you then!” or even a simple “bet, locked you in.”

Just a thumbs up 👍🏼.

That’s a man who really doesn’t care about giving value.

But I won’t leave him -- finding a solid barber who speaks English in Miami is like finding a virgin in a brothel.

Impossible.

The thing about “value” is it’s finite.

Every creator eventually runs out of new things to say.

Once they’ve said it all, they just repeat themselves -- like actors reciting lines they know will resonate.

People feel indebted to them, so they keep buying their stuff.

But let's be real – people don't stay subscribed to my emails because I'm constantly dropping value bombs.

They stay because they like how I communicate.

Because I'm not afraid to say what everyone else is thinking.

Because sometimes, reading an honest email is more refreshing than another "7 tips to crush your goals" bullshit.

So apologies, I gave you zero value today.

But if we’re being honest, you don’t need more value.

Do outreach. Make content. Get clients or customers.

Stop looking for value bombs.

​Start doing the actual work.​

You're welcome.

Thumbs up only,

Ben

​
​

​

subject: The Kobe and Shaq of webinars
content:
Good morning, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

It’s a sunny one today.

I’m out on the balcony squinting at my screen.

I was talking to Chat GPT before bed last night and he told me something crazy.

Did you know the average 24 year old in America makes $40,768 a year?

This made me realize how the info-product world has warped my perception of money.

My biggest client wins in this space have come through live webinars.

You get as many people as possible on a stream, go through a calculated, 45 min presentation, and pitch.

They’ve been money printers.

Imagine you’re watching the stripe dashboard as your client pitches.

Sales start rolling in…

Refresh and you’re at $20k…

Three minutes later you’re at $35k…

Then $53k…

And 20 minutes later you just made six figures in about an hour.

It’s insane.

Throughout the majority of 2023, I had one client who was the Shaq to my Kobe.

For nearly a 10 month span, we were printing $50k+ on each weekly webinar.

My client would drive a bunch of sign ups through short form content.

I had the backend dialed in with email, SMS, and a bunch of automations.

And like clockwork, we'd clear our age group’s yearly salary every Thursday night."

But it didn’t stop there…

After selling a mid-ticket offer on the webby, my next job was to get purchasers on calls for the high ticket offer.

That made up the other half of our revenue and we scaled this model past $500k/month.

It was electric.

This worked so well for a few reasons:

First, my client was a wizard at content and pulling in consistent views.

That said, most people struggle to convert viewers from short form content.

That’s why the webinar played such a crucial role.

No one's gonna spend a meaningful amount of money after watching a single minute long video.

But they will sign up for a “free live class” if you get them curious.

Every piece of content was like an ad (that we didn’t have to pay for).

The goal was simply to get them to give me their contact info on the registration page.

I’ll get them to actually show up.

Then we indoctrinate them as they sit through our presentation…

“Kobe sees an opening, drives right… lobs it up to Shaq… SLAM!

They buy.

This model prints money when done right.

If you want to execute it yourself, I’ll hand you the entire playbook.​

Mamba out,

Ben

P.S. If you want to learn the entire system that we’ve built for live webinars…

Which is responsible for generating too many millions to count…

​I’m giving away the entire system—but only for those who move fast.

The funnel, the slides, the emails, the texts, the pitch, the upsells.

Everything.

​

subject: Underwhelming advice from a $500M man
content:
I’ve been reading How To Get Rich by Felix Dennis.

He was a goofy looking British guy who made multiple 9 figures through his publishing company in the 90s.

There are plenty of great quotes in the book but here’s one that’s stood out to me:

“The key to successful business is self-belief and application.”

It’s underwhelmingly simple.

On the surface, you might pass it off as generic, bland advice.

But as I consider my own success, these two elements are at the core of it.

I believed I could do something cool with my life.

I took the necessary actions required to do so.

And eventually things clicked.

I had no idea how everything would work out, although I naively thought I did.

Countless reroutes, poor decisions, and overly ambitious timelines later, I’m where I wanted to be.

The elements of luck, chance, leverage, and opportunity have played roles as well.

But they’re outputs of the first two elements (self-belief and application).

Without these, you have nothing.

You are basically a Miami wannabe scammer who swipes up on Instagram stories saying “put me on fam 💯.”

Felix Dennis rolls in his grave.

If you’re not making the progress you’d like right now, consider this:

Do you actually believe you can be successful?

If no, fix that first.

If yes, what are the most obvious daily actions you need to take to move the needle?

Even if these actions aren’t particularly clear, that’s okay.

You just need to use your best judgment and move.

The path is only illuminated once you begin walking.

​This can be your flashlight.​

Ben

​

​

subject: The art of figuring it out
content:
You learn the most while flying the plane.

I’ve always been fairly confident in my figure-it-out-ability.

When I was growing up, I’d hold ‘A’ to skip through the directions when playing a new video game.

After a brief period of being completely lost, I’d get the hang of it.

This attitude carried into school as well.

I regularly wouldn’t study for tests, breeze through instructions, and complete homework assignments while walking in the door.

Surprisingly, it’d work out more often than not.

I’d end up sitting next to the smart kid who wrote big enough for me to see his answers or I’d find another creative way to cheat.

This is how I began to learn the art of figuring it out.

There’s one arena where this figure-it-out-ability has been rewarded tremendously.

It’s almost like the less you try to contemplate and prepare, the more you win.

Not in a chaotic, irresponsible way, but rather in a way that relies on internal trust.

It’s an approach that sounds like this:

“I”m gonna try this…

I’ll prepare enough to put myself in a position for success.

But I understand that most of my learning will be done on the fly.

And I trust my ability to overcome future obstacles.”

This is the world of entrepreneurship.

Where critical thought is your double edged sword.

Too little, and you’ll scramble like an ant on a bathroom sink—

Aimless, frantic, and one wrong move from getting washed away.

Too much, and you’ll hesitate, overanalyzing until opportunity slips through your fingers.

Success is found in the middle ground between YOLO and over preparedness.

But when in doubt, err on the side of YOLO.

Seriously – when I got into the online business world, I studied a lot.

I was constantly reading books, watching YouTube videos, taking notes, etc.

That helped, but NOTHING compares to getting real, in game reps.

At first you stare at your computer screen like a dyslexic monkey trying to read Chinese backwards.

But after some trial and error…

Next thing you know, nǐ zhèngzài zuò (you’re doing it).

To learning on the fly,

Ben

P.S. If you're ready to start flying instead of reading manuals, I’ll give you the exact blueprint to build and scale an Info-Product Agency.

You'll still learn on the fly, but with me as your co-pilot.

​Go here to apply now.​

​

​

subject: This copywriting 'guru' stole my email
content:

subject: I sent $1,000 to a stranger (again)
content:
I’m back in Miami, writing to you from my balcony.

I’ve spent the last few days in Dorado, Puerto Rico and I’m heading to LA tomorrow.

Four years ago when I started a business, this is pretty much all I wanted.

A nice apartment with a Porsche 911 in the garage, time and location freedom, plus a cool friend group to share experiences with.

Done.

My motivation has been mostly selfish and superficial.

I don’t have an impoverished family to rescue and I don’t care about saving the turtles or whatever other driving forces people come up with.

I wanted to get rich because it sounded way cooler than the alternative – sitting in a cubicle and listening to some blue haired woman they/them or skinny-fat balding man tell me when to use the bathroom.

No thank you ma'am… or sir I mean.

Although my initial motivation wasn't altruistic, this selfish pursuit has seemed to end up as the most selfless thing I can do…

Sunday night, we’re heading home from dinner in Puerto Rico.

I’m on the back of the golf cart as my friend Jimmy drives as if we’re in a stolen hellcat.

I check my phone and see a DM from a server at my local lunch spot in Miami.

He doesn’t speak much English, but we’ve become friends purely through vibes and Google translate.

Let’s call him Juan for the sake of the story (sorry if that’s racist but I can’t call him John, because why would someone named John not know English lol).

Juan tells me he had a family emergency and asks if I could loan him $1,000.

I get his number, go to Zelle, and send it before we get home.

I’m not telling you this to brag about how virtuous I am.

But rather to tell you not to be ashamed of your “why.”

Many people say you need a strong, unselfish reason to pursue wealth.

And for those that have one, that’s great.

I didn’t.

But along the way, nothing has compared to the feeling I get when I can impact the lives of others.

Seeing people win inside Artisan Lab feels incredible.

A server thanking me after I tip 100% on a $200 bill feels incredible.

Being able to send money to people I care about without expecting anything in return feels incredible.

Just start with whatever motivation gets you moving.

Even if it's a Lambo with a baddie in the passenger seat.

Your deeper purpose will often reveal itself later.

And when it does, it'll fuel you to go further than you imagined.

Whether you're trying to help your family, escape the cubicle, or just want nice things - you need money to make it happen.

If you want to learn how to build an info-product agency that could give you the income and freedom to live life on your terms, go here.​

I'm not promising you a Porsche or balcony views.

But I am showing you a path that worked for me and many of my students.

Where it takes you is up to you.

To finding your why along the way,

Ben

​

subject: It's irresponsible not to try to get rich
content:
I’m writing to you from 1B.

I flew private to LA a few months ago, but times are tough now.

Or maybe my brain is just closer to being fully developed.

I’ve got two more years of using an underdeveloped brain as an excuse.

“Sorry I ran over your Grandma, I’m only 24!”

Lol.

On to more important matters…

It’s quite honestly irresponsible for any young semi-competent man to not at least *try* to get rich.

I grew up in a very affluent area in Ohio.

Ranked 17th nationally with an average household income of $318,319.

Many kids from my high school go on to Ivy Leagues.

Some end up at their parents' companies.

Others bounce from real estate to random finance jobs.

It’s reasonable to assume growing up in an area like this offers great advantages and breeds excellence.

But many of my high school peers are just not… doing much.

It’s not like they’re entirely miserable or crash outs.

They’re just idle.

Basically watching the clock until they get whatever’s in their trust or inheritance.

They’ll go their entire lives never truly feeling risk.

They’ll never be in sole control of their path.

I know these are privileged problems and this may sound like an ideal scenario but I can promise you it typically doesn’t lead to a full life.

Even with all their advantages, these people often end up with less fulfillment than someone who built something from nothing.

Privilege without purpose is just comfortable emptiness.

It’s like watching an 80 year long movie where you already know the ending.

And in search of meaning, you grow bitter, finding silly problems to stress about.

Yes, it’s an incredible privilege to never have to worry about money.

But it doesn’t guarantee you live a life you enjoy.

And to me - that’s what winning is.

So no matter your situation…

Whether you’re born in the 17th wealthiest place in America or the 17,000th.

Why wouldn’t you go after what you want?

You either get it all, or end up somewhere in between.

But at least you have a much better story to tell.

If you’re ready to take the risk and bet on yourself…

​I can help you here.​

Ben

​

subject: Being a great copywriter is overrated
content:
Being a great copywriter is overrated.

I know this might sound like backwards advice coming from me, but allow me to explain.

The info-product space has changed a lot.

Organic content is more of a necessity now than ever.

You used to be able to spin up an offer, build a landing page, run ads, and print.

This has become increasingly difficult as consumers have gotten more skeptical.

Why would they buy from a stranger in an ad when they’ve consumed hours of free content from someone else?

They’ll go with the person they trust more.

And unless you’re a world-class copywriter, you don't have much of a shot.

So wouldn’t that mean that being incredibly skilled at copywriting isn’t overrated?

Yes and no.

For organic audiences you need to be good enough, not great.

An okay copywriter on a great offer with the right funnel and sales process will outperform a great copywriter without the above.

The organic content does the heavy lifting.

As long as you know who you’re talking to and what their pain points are, simple copy is just fine.

Additionally your clients don't care about literary brilliance.

They care about ROI.

A "good enough" copywriter who understands marketing fundamentals beats the wordsmith who obsesses over minuscule details.

The gap between "good" to "amazing" rarely justifies the time investment.

And honestly, with AI tools today, achieving "good enough" copy has never been easier.

The real skill is knowing which questions to ask and what problems to solve.

My most successful students aren't the grammar perfectionists or the ones who can recite Breakthrough Advertising by heart.

They're the ones who:

  • Understand their audience deeply
  • Build systems that convert reliably
  • Move quickly and iterate often
  • Prioritize relationships over word choice

Don't get me wrong – you still need a baseline of competence.

But if you're obsessing over becoming the next Gary Halbert instead of building connections and refining your offer, you're optimizing the wrong variables.

​Inside Artisan Lab, we focus on the complete picture – the copywriting fundamentals that actually matter, plus the systems and relationships that truly scale an info product agency.

If you want to learn the full blueprint instead of just one skill with decreasing value -- go here.​

Ben
