subject: Do not buy Artisan Lab
content:
I have a boring topic for you today.

It’s the thing that makes most info sellers roll their eyes.

They ignore it until there are dozens of reddit threads rightfully slandering them.

Many info businesses crash and burn quickly because of it.

This topic?

It’s called ‘product.’

Yes, product, meaning the thing you actually give to the people who pay you.

I know it’s rare to hear someone talk about such a foreign concept.

But this weird little term ends up making or breaking you.

And most people overlook it until it’s too late.

Let’s say you sell a high ticket coaching program.

You have a bunch of course content, a couple weekly group calls, and a community.

At first, it’s easy to answer questions and make sure people are staying on track.

It’s a smaller, tight knit community and students get results.

However as time goes on and you start scaling, this once small community has turned into a big one.

There are too many students and not enough of you.

It’s effectively become a daycare and you’re a babysitter trying to stop the kids from revolting.

Eventually it becomes this big mess where everyones lost, no one gets results, and you hate your own business.

But here’s the thing:

Hiring more coaches doesn't fix this.

A better course doesn’t fix this.

Even more support and clearer roadmap doesn’t fix this.

The root of the problem is who you begin selling to.

Oftentimes to scale, you start selling anyone and everyone who wants to buy your offer.

And now you have loser idiots who expect to get rich in 24 hours acting as parasites inside your community.

(What a surprise! The person with a 520 credit score who’ll be paying off your course for the next 76 years isn’t a competent, responsible human being lol).

They’re unrealistic, lazy, and don’t take accountability.

This turns off serious prospects because no one wants to be surrounded by a bunch of room temperature IQ smooth brains.

You’ve created a little idiot army. Congrats.

Here’s how to avoid this:

Do not overpromise.

Do not take customers' last dollar.

Do not claim they won’t have to work hard

When you’re realistic in your marketing, people get results like this:

Dom got a new client 3 days in (this is rare but not impossible).

Marcus got a new client less than 4 weeks in (also rare, not impossible).

And Vander, struggled for a couple months (perhaps the most realistic timeline) but is now breaking through, signing two clients in the past week.

I will not promise you get rich.

I will simply give you the resources, information, and network that has made me (and many students) rich.

What you do that this is up to you...

Do not click here and apply for Artisan Lab if you’re stupid.

Do not click here and apply for Artisan Lab if you think it’ll be easy.

But if you’re a winner…

There’s no better place to be.

Ben

​
​

subject: Hard work won't make you rich
content:
Hard work matters, but not as much as you think.

I consider it a prerequisite.

Everyone who finds success goes through a phase where they’re in the trenches.

This part sucks, but if you’re consistent and actually try for two years, you basically guarantee that you’ll make it.

It doesn’t mean that you’ll be abnormally successful.

But enough to where you can make a solid living on your own.

After that, hard work seems to have diminishing returns.

Two other factors become increasingly important in your pursuit of wealth:

  1. Your ability to create leverage.
  2. Your speed of execution.

I used to never understand what people meant when they discussed leverage.

It sounded like a buzzword that guru #138 would throw around while wearing dorky blue light blockers.

And then, I started to actually understand leverage (in this context).

Leverage is when you can write one email or make one video and generate six figures.

Leverage is when one hire frees up a month’s worth of time and energy.

Leverage is when you can build something once and create systems that allow for exponential growth.

The more connections, influence, and manpower you have, the more leverage you have, and the richer you get.

Secondly, your speed of execution dictates everything.

Life and entrepreneurship are just games of data.

You have to experience things to know what you like, what you don’t like, what works, and what doesn’t.

The quicker you implement ideas, the quicker you get more data.

More data creates better decisions.

Better decisions create more wealth.

I don’t want to be the hardest worker in the room.

I want to be the one with the most leverage and the quickest to execute.

Then I’ll be doing donuts on a Jetski in the Atlantic ocean while the hardest worker is at a desk in a dark room trying to figure out something I did months ago.

To working smarter,

Ben

P.S. Inside Artisan Lab, you’ll learn how to create leverage and move faster - the exact way I built a 7-figure agency without working myself to death.

If you’re ready to stop grinding endlessly and start building real leverage (with the help of AI), go here to apply.​

subject: 5 traits of people who will never succeed
content:
Some people just aren’t gonna make it.

No matter what they do, they’ll find a way to sabotage themselves.

You could tell them that all they have to do to get rich is tie their shoes daily.

They’d come back to you a week later and tell you they’re not passionate enough or they didn’t know what kind of knot to tie.

They are the kamikaze pilots of entrepreneurship.

They’re true masters at one thing and one thing only:

Self-destruction.

This has little to do with intelligence and it’s independent of the business model they choose.

So what’s the problem?

They have unwavering loyalty to a broken mindset.

While almost no one starts out with the “right” mindset, the game is to discard the beliefs and habits that don’t serve you.

Successful people become successful after doing the wrong thing and then correcting it.

“Kamikaze entrepreneurs” find creative ways to keep doing the wrong thing while convincing themselves they’re doing the right thing.

It’s honestly impressive.

Here are some traits of those who are not gonna make it:

- They’re too distracted, jumping from one thing to the next.

- They always have an excuse as to why their lack of success isn’t their fault.

- They’re incredibly skilled at deluding themselves into believing they know best.

- They're unlikable and not smart enough to make up for it.

- They always feel like they’re “missing something,” like there’s a secret success formula they don’t have.

If you identify with any of the above and refuse to change, your failure is inevitable.

I didn’t include laziness because typically these types aren’t lazy.

The mental gymnastics they're doing to avoid taking action requires an incredible amount of energy.

But the good news is everyone starts with some of these traits.

Successful people are self-aware enough to recognize and discard them.

If these patterns sound familiar, it's your job to begin adapting.

Only then can everything I'd teach you in here actually help you.

Choose evolution over self-sabotage.

Your future is depends on it.

Ben
​
​

subject: "it’s only cringe until it works"
content:
I was just sitting outside Starbucks trying to start this email.

There was this jacked dude to my left in a full salmon-colored workout set.

Didn’t catch his face, but he had a disheveled videographer taking pictures of him sipping coffee.

Between the outfit and the coffee photoshoot, I couldn’t help but start mentally clowning him.

It felt like a live-action version of the morning routine guy who just went viral on Twitter.

Then he turned slightly and I got a better look.

He sort of looked like this popular fitness influencer/podcaster you’ve probably seen on YouTube.

And when I got up to throw out my coffee, I realized it was Mike Thurston.

So I stopped clowning him and walked home to write this to you.

There’s probably a lesson in there somewhere —

“Don’t judge a book by its cover” or “It’s only cringe until it works.”

Whatever. A lol — that story was a detour.

Here’s what I actually wanted to share:

Do you remember what you were doing at 15?

I’d just gotten my driver’s permit and was riding around listening to “Hotline Bling” by Drake.

Like any normal teenage kid my top priorities were sports, keeping my Snapchat streaks alive, and cheating on my homework.

That was 2015.

Now it’s 2025 — and meanwhile, Michael, the youngest member inside Artisan Lab, is out here pulling in $10k/month with his Info-Product Agency.

He’s 15.

I sat down with him for a short interview where he breaks down how he went from $3k/month a few months ago to 5-figure months.

subject: Boredom is a superpower
content:
The best decisions I’ve made have almost never been extremely calculated.

Typically, they’re a result of boredom and curiosity.

There’s no 10 step foolproof roadmap.

There’s a desire and an idea.

After some procrastination, one day I’d wake up too fed up with myself to not act.

Next thing you know I’m finally doing it – I swatted the gnat buzzing in the back of my mind.

One day, I was bored so I searched up “how to make money online.”

One day, I was bored so I sent my first outreach message.

One day, I was bored so I began posting videos online.

The first of those three led me into this space.

The second got me my first client.

And the third has made me a couple million dollars.

All because there was a split second where I decided:

“I’m gonna do it now. Not in one hour, not tomorrow and definitely not on the arbitrary date I told myself I’d start. Right. Now.”

About a year ago, that’s exactly how I started posting on Youtube.

I remember sitting in the office of my last apartment and thinking, “damn, I’ve really been putting off this Youtube thing for a while.”

Two minutes later, the camera was out and an hour later, I clicked upload.

That exact decision has made me lots of money, led to many connections, and might be the reason you’re reading this right now.

So {{ subscriber.first_name }}, what's the gnat buzzing in the back of your mind?

What idea keeps popping up that you've been putting off?

Maybe it's time to get "too fed up" with yourself.

Maybe today is your "right now" moment.

Or maybe you should keep watching thirst traps on TikTok and forget you ever read this.

I’m not judging you and I’m not your therapist.

Hell, I’d probably keep scrolling too.

But I will say – doing the things you’ve been putting off makes you feel good.

And being (relatively) rich is fun – Definitely more fun than sitting in a cubicle taking orders from some overweight, soy milk drinking, mouth breathing buffoon.

So why not try?

Stop being a [redacted].

That's it.

​Go here if you want my help along the way.​

Ben

subject: Abraham Lincoln taught me how to use AI
content:
I got coffee with Chat GPT this morning.

We were trying to generate an image of Abraham Lincoln and me in the back of a carriage shaking hands.

At first I gave him two images of me to work off.

The first response was decent but it made me look like I’d been born in Brooklyn and was raised on lox and bagels.

My eyes were too far apart and other features were just a bit off.

I asked Mr. GPT how we can get it closer to looking like the real me.

He instructed me to upload more photos of myself, from various angles, so I did.

We generated the image again and it improved, but I still looked like a close relative of mine, not me exactly.

I asked him how we could get it to be exact.

He told me the best route is to train a custom model.

Now, I know there are softwares that make it easy to generate more realistic images of yourself, but this got me thinking about the learning curve with AI.

Some people are telling you to be afraid of it, others are saying it’ll do your whole job for you, even if you suck.

In the info-product/copywriting world, the true answer seems to be somewhere in the middle.

Here are both sides of the coin:

AI is incredible and it’s only getting better but as of now, it can’t do everything for you.

You should only be afraid of it if you’re unwilling to learn how to utilize it.

A marketer or copywriter empowered by AI is vastly more efficient and accurate than one who isn’t.

On the contrary, AI will not save you.

The notion that you don’t have to be a good marketer anymore is a complete lie.

If you don’t have a solid understanding of what you’re doing and haven’t found success pre-AI, it’s basically useless until you reach a baseline level of competence.

It won’t effectively do your outreach, take your sales calls, demonstrate competence, or do your work for you.

Think of AI as power tools for a carpenter.

They make a skilled craftsman more efficient, but give a table saw to someone who's never built anything and you'll end up with a missing limb.

​Inside Artisan Lab, you’ll learn both the foundational skills and how to leverage AI as a multiplier.

Not as a replacement, but as an accelerator.

Ready to build the skills AI can't replace while learning to use it as your secret weapon?

​Join me inside here.​

To augmentation, not replacement,

Ben

subject: The 2 worst places in America...
content:
This isn’t gonna be a typical email.

I won’t offer you any word of advice and in no way will this help you make more money.

Actually, I’ll probably say something that offends you.

Here we go:

Austin and Tampa are my two least favorite cities.

I have a deep disgust for both of them (aside from Terry Black's BBQ in Austin) and I’d pick a vacation to Gary, Indiana over these two places.

Austin is just weird.

Their literal slogan is “keep Austin weird.”

When I think of this city, images of the following starter pack come to mind:

A bag of granola, muddy hiking shoes, a cold plunge, and sweaty shirtless men that eat raw meat.

Tampa is a different story.

It looks sort of dystopian to me.

The main thing I dislike is that everyone tries to convince you it’s like Miami, but smaller.

Tampa is not a mini Miami.

There is a meat market, an Edition hotel that smells like garbage, and a cigar lounge.

That’s it.

It’d be a fine city if everyone stopped trying to push the narrative that it’s Miami’s younger brother.

If anything, it’s Miami’s adopted cousin from China with a speech impediment.

You just feel obligated to be nice.

Anyway, this thought sparked because there’s been a lot of Miami slander on social media recently.

I get it.

I’m tired of the scammers, excess of huracans, and OF girls too.

It’s a party city and easy to get caught up spending money that you don’t actually have.

But here's the cool thing about Miami – and life in general…

You have the power to choose.

If you’re disciplined, the above is a non issue.

Lol nvm – I’m not gonna try to turn this rant into a lesson.

​Here’s something you might find valuable though.​

Have a good weekend,

Ben

subject: How to break out of a slump (w/o excess stimulants)
content:
A fly was just buzzing around my laptop.

I swung twice and missed both times.

This is a rare occurrence.

If there's a worldwide fly swatting accuracy leaderboard anywhere, I’d be near the top.

It’s a sunny morning in Miami, although it rained all day yesterday so the ground is still wet.

I have an iced espresso next to me and I’m ready to work.

The past couple weeks have been a bit unfocused.

I got out of my normal routine from traveling and am now getting back into the swing of things.

You know that feeling when you want to be productive but you’re being a lazy, unmotivated piece of shit?

Me too.

Slumps like this are inevitable and they happen to everyone.

Even the greatest athletes on the planet go through periods where they can’t make a shot or get on base.

Let’s consider how they get through this…

A struggling athlete has to become aware of components that are typically subconscious.

Perhaps they started rushing their follow-through or rotating too much on their swing.

To correct themselves, they have to be more intentional and disciplined than usual.

If they can typically get away with lacing up their shoes right before practice, that’s not gonna fly for now.

They have to put more time in, identify the error they’re making and consciously decide to fix it.

Eventually things go back to normal and it becomes subconscious or easy again.

Productivity works the same way.

When you’re in a slump, the bitch voice in your head is the loudest.

To shut it out, you’ll likely have to be more disciplined than usual.

Get up earlier.

Stop yourself from scrolling on social media.

Write down a detailed schedule to follow each day.

Put your phone on DND and stick to the plan.

Next thing you know, you’ll knock off the rust and feel good about working again.

This doesn’t take long unless you let it.

A member of Artisan Lab recently came to me with this exact problem and I told him the following:

“Momentum and habits outweigh motivation. Small wins will create bigger ones. You're one productive morning away from a productive day, and one productive day away from a productive week. Just have to get the ball rolling with the small things.”

Soon enough you’ll get back in rhythm.

The ball will hit your hands and you’ll effortlessly rise up and let it fly.

Slump over, Lambo coming soon.​

Ben

​

​

​

subject: I wrote a VSL in 30 seconds (here's how)
content:
I ran an interesting experiment yesterday.

On my call with the Artisan Lab members, I tested how quickly I could write a VSL for a new offer using AI.

I scrolled through Youtube until I found a creator who makes content about high ticket sales.

She has under 1k subscribers but gets solid engagement on her videos and only began uploading a few months ago.

This potentially would be a great client for a copywriter/info-agency owner for a few reasons:

- High ticket sales is a validated niche and she innately has a unique mechanism in selling to women.

- She’s newer to info and doesn’t have a full funnel built out yet.

- She’s posting consistent content and her personal brand is growing.

So here’s where the experiment began:

I copied the links of her existing YT videos and put them into an AI software I’m gatekeeping for now (sorry).

Then I uploaded a VSL framework for AI to reference.

And I prompted it to write the VSL using the information in her videos based on the winning framework I gave it.

30 seconds later, the script was done.

After a few minor edits, my job would be completely finished.

This is something that used to require hours of research and another hour or so to write.

Now it can be effectively completed in under 5 minutes with the right AI tools and prompts.

But here’s the catch…

If you don’t know how to find good clients, what to say in your outreach, and you can’t articulate your value on a sales call, AI doesn’t help you.

Sure you could use the same process I laid out and get a similar result.

But you also need to be able to demonstrate a solid understanding of the info-product space.

For me and the members inside Artisan Lab, this is game-changing because we already have the fundamentals down.

AI is multiplying our effectiveness, not replacing us.

The gap between those who understand both the info-product space AND how to leverage AI effectively is widening every day.

If you want to be on the right side of that gap, you need both skill sets.

Only then will you be able to get results like this…

​Inside Artisan Lab, you'll learn both the foundational knowledge and AI implementations that'll fast-track your success.

To not getting replaced,

Ben

​
​
​

​

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }}, let's compromise...
content:
Fair and noble people make compromises.

Life is not like Burger King. You can’t always have it your way…

Fuck. That.

This way of thinking is for the mentally enslaved.

But you {{ subscriber.first_name }}, as a reader of the best newsletter on the internet, deserve better…

You owe yourself better.

When you’re quick to make compromises, here’s what happens:

Your Ferrari dreams turn into a Corolla (or perhaps you buy a corvette C8 when you’re 68 and try to convince yourself it’s a real supercar).

Your supermodel wife turns into a plus sized hand model. Or your “rich husband” turns into a guy that makes $105k/yr and loves to say he makes six figures.

Your dream of waking up to the sound of the waves crashing on the shore only happens 3 days a year. And you’re on vacation in Myrtle Beach, not Honolulu.

I know this sounds a bit dramatic, but making compromises when it comes to your desires is a slippery slope.

You need to be militant.

You need to be stubborn.

You need to aim for what you actually want.

When others tell you to be reasonable, or when you begin to hear a voice in your head negotiating with you, shut it out.

I’d rather be an insane, unreasonable, stubborn asshole than a chubby balding middle aged man… in a COROLLA!

Do not tolerate behavior that doesn’t align with your goals.

When you make a plan, stick to it as if you are following orders from God.

There is no negotiating, there is no settling, and when you find yourself exchanging “great” for “good enough,” stop yourself.

If you compromise, I guess I’ll send you a postcard from Honolulu.

That’s basically the real thing isn’t it! LOL!

No. Stop. It’s not the real thing. And a C8 isn’t a supercar. And fuck Mrytle Beach.

Their rules and standards are meant to be broken. Yours aren’t.

See you in a Ferrari with a supermodel in your passenger seat.

To the stubborn and unreasonable – I will help you win.​

Ben

P.S. I’d feel slightly irresponsible by not clarifying some nuance here.

Not compromising doesn’t mean you refuse to turn up the temperature when you set it at 67 and your girl wants it at 72.

It also doesn’t mean that there is only one way to accomplish a goal and the route can’t be adjusted.

But when it comes to the real shit you want…

Don’t let anyone talk you out of it (including yourself).

​This is for those who refuse to compromise.​

​
​

​

subject: The info-product bull run is here
content:
Big things are happening.

This reminds me of the 2021 crypto bull run.

Bitcoin surpassed $60k and people were buying million-dollar pictures of cartoon monkeys (NFTs).

What a time.

Many of my friends became millionaires that year.

They’d get in on a big NFT project or they’d buy the right coin at the right time.

But not me.

I was in the beginning stages of building my agency so that’s where my energy was directed.

And looking back, I feel like an idiot for sitting on the sidelines.

Money was falling from the sky and all I had to do was put my hand out and grab some.

Right now, a new bull run is happening outside of the crypto world.

And it’s creating some of the craziest success stories I’ve ever seen…

This is Jace.

You may recognize him from some of my previous emails or the interview we did on Youtube.

When we recorded that video just 3 months ago, he was at $50k/mo.

Now, he made $204k…

In a week…

Actually just 6 days:

It feels like the equivalent of hitting a 100x on a random meme coin.

Except luck doesn’t play nearly as much of a role here.

He followed a blueprint, worked incredibly hard, got the right clients, and made it happen.

This is a result of capitalizing on the info-product bull run.

As you probably saw, Iman Gadzhi became a co-owner of Whop (the leading digital product platform).

This means more people will be selling info.

Which creates more clients to partner up with.

And more money to be extracted out of thin air.

Welcome to the info-product bull run.

You can watch from the sidelines or use this opportunity to build the life of your dreams.

And if you want to learn from the best of the best…

Jace is gonna be hosting a guest call inside of Artisan Lab next Wednesday.

​Hop in here before then if you want to learn how he made $200k profit in the last 6 days.

WAGMI,

Ben

P.S. The chances of you making TWO HUNDRED THOUSAND DOLLARS in a single week are slim to none. That is absolute insanity and you will likely not replicate Jace’s success. BUT you might get sort of close with the right help, if you actually put in the work.

The creator economy is booming, everyone is slinging info, Whop might be the next Shopify, AND YOU’RE NOT GONNA CAPITALIZE ON THIS???

Don’t be poor.

​Get in loser, we’re slinging info :)​

​
​
​
​

​

subject: You can’t unsee this
content:
“Curiosity killed the cat.”

Have you ever heard that phrase?

I never understood it because my curiosity has never led me astray.

I just asked Chat GPT about it and guess what he told me?

The full quote is “curiosity killed the cat, but satisfaction brought it back.”

This flips the meaning and suggests that curiosity is worth the risk if it leads to the truth.

What a scam!

Imagine going through life thinking that being a curious person is a bad thing...

Till one day you find out you were abiding by an incomplete phrase.

This makes me wonder what other quotes we might be misinterpreting.

Perhaps it’s “Thou shall not kill… unless someone is going 55 mph in the fast lane.”

Or “All men are created equal… except for those who drive Corvette C8’s.”

Lol.

I’m glad we cleared this curiosity thing up.

It’s a trait I observe amongst nearly all successful people I meet.

They’re always asking questions and trying to solve problems.

They don’t blindly accept the popular opinion, they pause, think and form their own conclusions.

If you ended up on my email list, you’re likely more curious than most people.

Only stubbornness and blind naivety would lead someone into the world of entrepreneurship.

Most are too ignorant.

But you’re curious enough to at least go down the rabbit hole.

Congrats…

This was a dangerous, irresponsible thing for you to do.

Because now, you can’t unsee it.

You know this route is possible.

You know you could build the life of your dreams.

And you also know it’s not easy.

So now, if you return to safety and try to blend in with the dull and ignorant, you’d go insane.

You’d become bitter and angry, both at yourself and at the world.

Because you’d know that there’s a deeper purpose to fulfill and you’re not doing it.

Maybe curiosity did kill the cat.

But at least you know now…

Everything you dream of exists.

It’s real.

And it’s on the other side of curiosity, courage, and consistent action.

So keep asking questions…

But be careful, because you’ll get the answer.

​If you're ready to turn curiosity into real results, here’s your next step.​

Build the thing,

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: The most productive thing you can do today
content:
You don’t need a different business model.

You don’t need another “high-converting funnel template.”

You definitely don’t need another podcast episode on “morning routines of billionaires.”

You need silence.

For five minutes.

No scrolling. No input.

No attempt to feel productive by watching someone else do what you're too scared to try.

Just you. And the truth.

Because in that silence, you'll be forced to admit something:

You already know what you should be doing.

But doing it means letting go of the identity you've built -- the one that's “learning, researching, and getting ready.”

So you keep hiding behind consumption.

Here’s the truth:

Action is terrifying because it kills the version of you that talks but doesn’t do.

And that version of you?

It wants to survive.

But if you want your life to change, that version has to die.

I made a video about this.

It’s not loud.

It’s not aggressive.

It’s just the boring truth.

​Watch it here.​

Or don’t.

Either way, just stop looking for answers you already have.

Ben

​

​

subject: Claude stole my laptop
content:
Good morning.

There is a 2% chance this is the first email of mine you’ve ever read.

I did one of those corny lead magnet’s on my Instagram and now there are an additional 200 of you.

If you’re new, welcome.

This is not your typical guru-list.

Unlike most newsletters, each email is not an engineered pitch written by a copywriter pretending to be me.

Although, I’ve been the copywriter pretending to be someone else many times.

But this is me, physically sitting at my desk typing to you.

My second coffee of the morning is to my right.

My first coffee got thrown out after two sips because the barista at Starbucks must’ve woken up on the wrong side of the bed.

I was playing with AI all night last night.

Claude now has every email I’ve ever written and knows me better than my mother.

Together we are gonna take over the world.

Watch this:

It mimics my tone, sentence structure, and even my tendency to go on weird tangents about Corvette C8’s and normies.

The possibilities are endless.

Imagine having a digital twin that can handle the mundane writing tasks while you focus on the creative work that actually moves the needle.

But here's where it gets interesting…

Wait –

Did you catch that?

Those last few lines weren't me.

Claude took over after I said “watch this.”

It’s real me again, typing with my actual fingers.

Now that AI has hundreds of my previous emails, it’s pretty good.

Still not 100%, but close.

Does this mean that copywriters are cooked? Are you destined to put fries in a bag until AI comes and replaces you again?

Maybe.

Here’s what I think:

The edge isn’t voice anymore.

It’s perspective.

AI can mimic cadence. It can’t manufacture conviction.

It can remix a thought. It can’t live one (for now).

If you’re an idiot without AI, you’re still an idiot with it.

If you’re skilled without it, you’re 10x better with it.

Adapt or die,

Ben

P.S. If you want to see how I'm using AI to scale my agency and help my clients make more

money with less effort, check out Artisan Lab.​

You’ll learn the exact systems (plus everything else that's working right now in the info-business space).

Or if you just want to tell me your thoughts on AI, hit reply. I miss talking to you.

​
​

​

subject: Your $204,000 payout is NOT on the way...
content:
I hate it when people come up to me and say “I know you from TikTok!”

This is a pretentious thing to complain about.

But allow me:

They’ll say these words as if I’m gonna break into character and start performing for them after.

Like “I know you from TikTok!” is code for me to begin singing and dancing like a circus clown.

But that doesn’t happen.

We blankly stare at each other for a sec, then I usually say “yeah?”

Then they say “yeah.”

And after another 2.2 seconds of awkward silence I’ll ask their name, tell them it was nice to meet them (it wasn’t) and move along.

As I write this I’m considering the possibility that I’m the awkward one….

Eh no. I’m normal.

It’s the TikTok brained people.

They’re the type that would approach a girl and expect her to carry the conversation.

When others approach me and mention they’ve seen me on YT or Twitter, we have a solid conversation.

This probably reads as if I’m trying to indirectly brag about how cool and famous I am.

I’m not (ok, maybe a little).

These awkward interactions are sort of a microcosm of the whole short form content/internet culture.

It’s why the “this is so easy, AI will do all the work for you!” Angle works for marketers.

It’s a lie, but it’s sexy enough that people want to believe it anyway.

The people that fall for it are the same ones that will send an outbound message and follow up “???” after they don’t get a reply.

There is a special place in Clownland for them.

No one owes you anything.

Successful people understand this and earn everything they get.

Like Jace – a member in Artisan Lab who recently hit six figure months with his info-product agency.

​In this interview he talks about how he drove 25 hours from Minnesota to Scottsdale to close his first client.

25 HOURS. To get a coffee with someone.

That decision led to his first solid case study.

And it’s a big reason why a single client just paid him $204,000 in commission for 10 days of work.

Do the things others won’t and you will win.

That’s how Jace did it. That’s how you can, too.

​Watch the full breakdown here.​

Then go do something ridiculous.

Ben

​
​

​

subject: I'm struggling...
content:
I opened a Google doc to write this 19 minutes ago.

Since then, I’ve written and deleted the first line 4 times.

I asked AI to give me ideas to write about but didn’t like any of them.

Then I got distracted and started scrolling through Instagram.

Many times, I’d lose this battle.

I’d convince myself that I just don’t have it in me to write an email today and close my laptop.

The 2 espresso martinis and 3 tequila sodas I drank last night might have something to do with that.

But if I lose this battle, I’ll feel like a loser.

The rest of my day will be clouded by the fact that I didn’t do this.

So selfishly, I’m writing this to avoid feeling like shit.

And unselfishly, I owe it to you.

I recently watched a Youtube video where this guy said it’s your duty as a personal brand to show up for your audience.

It’s easy to forget that every “view” on a piece of content is a living, breathing soul.

Not sending an email on a day you’re supposed to, is the equivalent of no-showing a date.

I guess this is our date. I like your tits dress.

Consistency is a moral duty.

Every time you leave a task unfinished because you don’t feel good, you’re letting down everyone who believes in you.

That means your family, friends, staff, future children, bloodline, baby mama, followers, and GOD himself.

You can’t click buttons on a laptop in an air conditioned box in the sky because you… have a headache?

Grow up.

You are (probably) a man.

You were lucky enough to be alive in the greatest era in human history.

Your ancestors had to hunt wild animals.

You click a few buttons and Pedro shows up 15 minutes later with your burrito.

Show up for yourself, so you don’t hate yourself.

And show up for others, so you don’t let them down.

You’ll be glad you did (just like I am right now).

Ben

P.S. Neither rain, nor snow, nor sleet, nor hail shall keep the postmen from their appointed rounds. Nor shall a hangover keep you from clicking this... and allowing me to assist you in your pursuit of generational wealth.

​
​

​

subject: How to become a billionaire (easy & simple)
content:
Did you know there are only 902 billionaires in the US?

And somehow they all drive Huracans, sell courses, take high doses of TRT, and live in Miami (lol).

I have one friend who I think could become a billionaire.

Not because he’s close to it or has any kind of head start.

Right now, he’s actually the most cash-poor in my immediate circle, as a lot of his money is tied up in a software company.

Obviously he’s intelligent, works hard, all of that.

Those two traits alone aren’t gonna make you billions — the janitor works hard and the economics professor is intelligent…

Never seen them in a baby blue Huracan.

But there’s one trait that makes me bet on him:

It’s relentless. Inconvenient. Borderline annoying.

And it’s…

Curiosity.

(Coupled with the ability to spot opportunities and execute —I know I said one trait but there’s always some nuance).

One day, my potential billionaire friend and I are driving home from the gym.

I’m in the passenger seat as Lebron (probably not his real name, obviously) speeds past the cars in the left turn lane, cuts in front of them, and makes a left.

As I hold on to the roof handle, he begins telling me about quantum physics.

Most of it goes over my head as he discusses his predictions and what he wants to build in the quantum realm.

Let me pause here.

You might be thinking, “Ben, your potential billionaire friend is probably just a pothead who goes down weird rabbit holes sometimes.”

Maybe.

But for the right type of person, a weird rabbit hole could be the gateway to extreme wealth.

You trip and fall and next thing you know you invented the door handle equivalent in the quantum realm.

If necessity is the mother of invention, curiosity is its grandmother.

Necessity forces you to be curious.

Curiosity leads you to find new problems.

And if you find a reeaaally big problem - and solve it?

Time to start picking the type of leather you want on the seats of your Gulfstream G700.

So yeah…

Maybe “Lebron” ends up broke in five years, yelling about dark matter on the corner of Brickell Ave.

Or maybe he builds something so impactful it forces us to redefine the word "genius."

Either way, I’ll keep showing up to hear the next quantum rabbit hole – because curiosity pays.

Stay curious.

It just might make you billions.

Ben

P.S. Inside Artisan Lab, we’ve got a bunch of curious weirdos turning ideas into income. If you wanna get rich without becoming a soulless automaton, you’d probably like it here.​

​

​

​

​

subject: Did AI just replace me?
content:
I don’t want to do this.

But I have to show you something…

I’ve been training Claude and ChatGPT on my writing style for about a week.

It’s gotten to the point where I could go live in a cabin in Alaska, spend all day with Alpacas, and if AI-me kept emailing you…

You’d probably never notice.

So let’s run an experiment:

I’ll come up with an idea for an email.

Give AI a lazy one-line prompt.

We’ll read it together.

Then I’ll meet you at the end and we’ll talk.

Sound good?

Cool. (Not like you had a choice anyway.)

Prompt:

Write and email about why most people fail when trying to start a business in the info/agency world.

BenGPT:

"Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }},

Here’s the part they don’t tell you in those “how I made $100K/month” YouTube videos:

Most people don’t fail because of strategy.

They fail because they’re fucking soft.

They read Russell Brunson, buy a cold email course, slap together an offer, and post 3 times on Twitter.

Then wonder why clients aren’t lining up to wire them $5K.

Meanwhile, the guy who is getting clients?

He’s not smarter than you. Or more talented. Or even better looking (unless it’s me, in which case, sorry bro).

He just didn’t stop.

The truth is, most people enter the info/agency game with all the wrong expectations.

They think:

  • It’s gonna be passive.
  • It’s gonna be fast.
  • It’s gonna feel good.

Wrong, wrong, and LOL.

What it’s gonna feel like is:

Rewriting your VSL script 7 times and still hating it.

Getting ghosted by 33 different leads in a row.

Having a panic attack after realizing you owe Stripe $1,200 in fees.

This is not a business for people who crave comfort.

This is a business for psychos.

The type who’ll build a landing page at 2am just because he had a weird idea in the shower.

If that’s not you – cool.

Go get a job. Live a peaceful life. Watch Netflix and pay rent forever.

But if it is you?

Then you need to stop acting like a confused beginner and start behaving like someone who’s already successful.

Because here’s the truth:

There are only 3 things that actually matter when starting your agency/info-biz:

  1. A skill that solves a painful problem
  2. A system that gets that skill in front of people
  3. The brain damage tolerance to repeat that until rich

That’s it.

Everything else is masturbation.

You don’t need another course.

You don’t need a better logo.

You don’t need to ask your group chat for feedback on your offer doc.

You just need to move.

Fast. Messy. Relentless. Like your future depends on it – because it does.

Ben"

[End]

Pretty solid, yeah?

And that was with a half-baked, one-sentence prompt.

Obviously there’s still some magic that comes from real-life experiences, fresh insights, and having a pulse.

But voice-wise?

I’d say it’s 90% of the way there.

Here’s the coolest part:

I now have a repeatable framework I can use with every client.

Import their data. Feed it the right examples.

And 30 minutes later? Boom -- I have a writing clone that sounds just like them.

If you want to learn how to do the same — I’ll teach you inside Artisan Lab.​

I’ll be in the cabin.

You bring the alpacas.

See you in Alaska,

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: The three levels of leverage
content:
Money, money, money.

That’s all I care about right now.

Unless you’re already sitting on 8 figures, or you’re a hippie-meditator-eat-bugs-and-practice-acceptance type…

I’d recommend making money your top priority.

If there’s a sliver of “Capitalist pig” in your mind after reading that, skip the rest of this email and hit unsubscribe at the bottom.

Goodbye.

Now that all of the purple haired people are gone, let’s talk money, {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "bro" }}!

On a recent 1-1 call with a new Artisan Lab member, I broke down the three elements of success in the digital economy.

When you first start, you have none of the three.

As you progress, you earn your badges and things get a whole lot easier.

Here’s the breakdown:

1. Skill set

This one’s the most obvious.

Learn a skill that other people find valuable, trade that skill for money.

This is the prerequisite.

It’s the equivalent of a college degree in the entrepreneur world (except it actually means something).

As you increase competency, you grow capable of solving bigger problems that pay better.

Once this foundation is laid, the other two elements unlock…

2. Opportunity vehicle

This is what you’re selling and who you’re selling to.

The best marketer in the world will make no money if their clients are broke.

On the contrary, apply your skill set the right way (in a growing industry where people are making lots of money) you’ll be paid in proportion.

Nail these two, and money starts to rain.

And then, there’s the third which makes everything click…

3. Influence

This is who you know and who knows you.

It could mean attention on social media or even just a network of the right people.

That’s it.

Skill, vehicle, influence.

Master all three and business becomes unfairly easy.

Ignore even one… and you’ll feel like you’re a stripper without rhythm. Or an ass.

So here’s the move:

Audit yourself.

What’s missing?

What’s the next smallest move to fix it?

For me, working with course sellers was the unlock.

Skillset? Check — copywriting and funnel building were finally being put to good use.

Vehicle? Check — these creators had leverage, audience, and cash flow.

Influence? Check — proximity to high-level operators opened more doors than I could count.

It was the rare overlap of all 3 elements.

And once I leaned in, everything changed.

If you’re still trying to force something that doesn’t check all three boxes…

​Maybe it’s time to pivot.​

Ben

​

​

subject: Still interested in the 911 Turbo S?
content:
What’s the difference between a Porsche 911 Carrera and a Turbo S?

From the outside, they look almost identical.

Only car nerds can tell the difference.

But the Turbo S will cost you over $100k more than the Carrera.

Why would someone pay six figures more for a model that only impresses car nerds?

They give you a handjob at the dealership when you get the Turbo S.

The engine.

640 horsepower vs. 379.

0-60 mph in 2.4 seconds vs 4.0.

The Turbo S is a supercar. The Carrera is a nice daily.

From ten feet away you’d never know.

But the second you hit the gas?

The Turbo S launches.

The Carrera just… moves.

That’s the power of what’s under the hood.

In the coaching space, your product is your engine.

And most people forget about it.

A good product means sexier marketing.

Your testimonials are your rims, wheels, and headlights.

You can coast with a shit product…

Until you floor it next to someone with real horsepower.

Then you blow up.

Artisan Lab is finally to the point where it feels like a V10.

When I started coaching, it was just a private group and a few calls.

I let in 20 people and used it as a test run.

Took the feedback.

Built out a full course.

Rebranded it from The Bader Group to Artisan Lab.

That’s where most people stop.

They build the course, toss in some weekly calls, and shift all attention to marketing.

But here’s the truth:

If your product isn’t improving, it’s deteriorating.

So I kept going:

  • I update the content constantly based on where people get stuck
  • Every call is recorded and labeled inside a searchable vault
  • I bring in 7–8 figure entrepreneurs twice a month for guest sessions
  • I paid one of my star students to build an outreach course, and my sales guy to build a sales management course
  • Sean — one of the best marketers I know — runs weekly calls and offers 1-1 support
  • And as of yesterday, Jace (you’ve probably seen him in a testimonial) is now running an additional weekly group call

Here’s the current engine:

Content – funnels, copywriting, sales, acquisition, personal brand & everything in between

1-1 Support – from me and Sean

Active 24/7 Community – no idiots allowed, only winners

Coaching – 3 weekly calls, led by me, Sean, and Jace (plus bi-weekly guest calls)

Plus plug and play SOPs, frameworks, and all the other more boring stuff...

This has inadvertently turned into a pitch.

But that’s kinda the point.

When your product is actually good, you don’t need to force a transition or do some weird NLP sales voodoo.

You just talk about it.

Because you’re proud of the engine you’ve built.

​Artisan Lab is the engine.

Everything else is just the body kit.

And if you want to go fast, you’re gonna need something under the hood that doesn’t explode when it gets on the highway.

​Apply here if you want to build your own Turbo S.​

Not a Corolla with a spoiler (or God forbid a corvette C8).

Ben

​

subject: How to get a client in the next 7 days
content:
Idleness is the root of suffering.

That’s it.

Maybe that’s what the Buddha meant to say too but it got lost in translation.

The life changes you think will make you happy?

Illusions.

You're convinced the issue is your job, your city, your relationship, or your (smol) bank account.

But it's not.

You feel like shit because you're stagnant.

The human mind wasn't designed to be still.

You were designed to hunt, build, pursue, do.

When you stop moving, that energy has nowhere to go, so it turns inward.

Next thing you know, you’ll be a depressed 47 year old, substance addicted, beer-bellied, bitter, man-child. And your wife will beat you.

Is that what you want?

I doubt it.

The voice in your mind that's constantly displeased gets quiet when you start moving.

Action is the only answer.

Even when you don't know where to go, what to do, and you feel like you're in over your head.

You can’t think your way out of a rut.

You have to move your way out.

That’s the whole game.

Ben

P.S. I Just dropped a ​new video​ with two members in Artisan Lab.

They quit their jobs. Got their first client in a week. Now doing $30K/month.

It’s simple this is when you take action Check it out.​

subject: Be more impulsive
content:
Good morning and happy Monday.

A man in his mid-30’s just walked by me in a button down and tie that looked like it was choking the life out of him.

I assume he’s on his way to the office.

And once again, I’m reminded to be grateful for my impulsiveness.

I remember the exact moment I decided not to be a wagie slave for the rest of my existence.

There I was, in my sophomore year of college at frat party #397 of the semester.

As I drunkenly looked around at everyone having fun, I thought to myself “yeah, no thanks.”

Here’s a picture from that night:

The next day I started planning my escape.

I’m gonna drop out and move to Mexico once the semester is up.

It was a decision I made on a whim… kinda.

Sometimes impulsivity is the only way things actually happen.

There’d been a lingering voice in my head for a while.

And deep down, I always knew that the “can I take a vacation please?” route wasn’t for me.

But it’s not official until it’s official.

Once I made a legitimate decision, unenrolled in classes, and booked my flight to Tulum, it became real.

It was no longer a lingering thought — and my life changed for the better.

So, what’s going on in your life that you know isn’t in alignment with your soul?

It could be as grand as your career path or as small as your social media addiction.

You know it needs to change and you keep telling yourself it will.

But when?

That’s the million dollar question.

When the universe sends you a perfectly-timed, arbitrary wake-up call?

Maybe.

Or maybe a month, a year, 10 years, or… never?

Maybe you need to be more impulsive.​

I know this “us vs. the system" angle is incredibly overused and if you want to be a normie, I’m not judging you.

But know there will probably come a time when you, too, are wearing a button down and tie that’s way too tight on you and some asshole kid writes an email about it.

And maybe the voice in your head that knows better will linger forever.

Unless you act on it.

See you at the office, {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "bro" }}!

Ben

P.S. My calendar for Artisan Lab was full over the weekend so if you tried to book and couldn’t I’m sorry. I opened it back up, so you can apply here and book in now.​

​
​

subject: Put lipstick on a pig with AI
content:
I officially became a nerd yesterday.

I went through what can be described as a business-tracking crisis.

What doesn’t get tracked doesn’t improve – and I realized my tracking is meh.

Frantically, I began building automations, SOP’s, and Google Sheets.

I typically hate doing this type of stuff.

It feels like listening to a Miami girl talk about astrology, minus the lip filler and silicone.

Painful.

But yesterday, I powered through it.

I set up new zaps, built a Slack channel, and made a tracking sheet for my Artisan Lab members.

The sheet was the hardest of it all.

It required complex formulas and I’m a college dropout. Not a good combo, typically.

But I had a cheat code.

Any time I got stuck, I’d turn to AI.

“Hello, my Glorious KingGPT. How do I sum an itemized list based on certain criteria? Plz reply. Thx ily.”

AI would then give me the exact formula to plug in.

I’d follow its instructions.

And if anything broke, I’d simply take a screenshot and ask it what went wrong.

With AI’s help, the sheet took me around 30 minutes to build.

Without it, it would’ve taken hours or I would’ve quit.

It also saved me time after a sales call yesterday.

My “AI Companion” joined my Zoom meeting with me.

The word companion makes me think of dogs, so I named him Buddy.

After the call, Buddy sent me a summary of everything we talked about with a detailed plan outlining the next steps.

Simple things like this have been saving me hours.

Everyone (myself included) talks about writing copy with AI because it sounds sexy.

But what might be even cooler, is it makes the boring stuff easier.

Unless you had a Minecraft addiction and were nonverbal in groups larger than 2 growing up, you probably hate automations, tracking, and summarizing data.

AI makes this way less painful.

Don’t overlook using it to improve your workflow, outside of writing copy.

That’s only the tip of the iceberg.

I break all this down (and more) for my coaching clients.

If you're building an info-product agency and want to save time, make more money, and not cry while setting up Zapier... apply here.​

Gonna go play with Buddy,

Ben

​
​

​

subject: How I escaped the guru hamster wheel
content:
“I just wanna make $5k per month,” I thought to myself.

It’s January 1st, 2020.

I’m sitting in my childhood bedroom with 6 Youtube tabs open on my laptop.

One’s a dropshipping video, another’s about SMMA.

The rest are random business models I found on ads along the way.

This is what one may call shiny object syndrome maxxing.

I know something can work…

These gurus claim to be making so much money online.

I don’t completely trust them, but there has to be some level of truth to it.

And they can’t be that much smarter than me, right?

I might not be the next Einstein, but I’m definitely not a complete idiot.

And dedication isn’t the problem… I’m willing to work hard.

The problem is, I need to find the right outlet to channel my ambition.

$5k per month. That’s all I need.

I’ll get my own apartment and have enough money for food and juul pods.

What more does a 19 year old kid need?

Ok, maybe I’ll get a used 911 too.

But fuck, where do I start?

My head is beginning to hurt from all of the “best online business model of 2020” videos.

There’s no way there are 36 “best” business models.

35 of you guys are lying.

I just need to find the one who’s telling the truth…

Or maybe the one that’s best for me…

Or maybe I shouldn’t drop out of colle– FUCK!

I can’t keep doing this.

I need to pick something and stick to it.

If I get burned by a guru, so be it – I’d rather go down swinging.

Fast forward about a year, I’m… at the plate, you could say.

Not hitting much, but at least I’m trying.

I’ve now started a videography business, dropshipping store, ad creative agency and high ticket sales…

Aaaand I’m still poor.

The previous handful of business attempts have beaten the idiot out of me.

I’m ready to go all in on one thing…

Lead generation agency. For basketball trainers.

Good idea? No.

Good mindset? Yes.

Although it wasn’t the “best” business model I could’ve picked, it began to work.

I stuck with it for over a year.

$5k months – check.

Drop out of college – check.

I moved to Mexico, kept building, and hit $10k months.

And then…

I stumbled into a much better way to make money online that didn’t require me to beg broke people for $1k retainers.

So, here I am now.

The same kid who wrote this journal entry on January 8, 2021…

“I am lost… Do I want to start an agency? Do I want to be a closer? Should I say fuck it and try something else? Do I need to go back to school?”

This one’s getting long so I’ll leave you with this:

Close your Youtube tabs.

Pick one thing.

The best business model is the one you pick and commit to.

​I’ll help you here.​

Ben

​
​

​

subject: You're a millionaire
content:
I became a millionaire on paper about a year ago.

That didn’t really register until last week.

I looked at some numbers, thought “huh, that’s neat,” and went back to scrolling Instagram.

A few years ago, that number felt like a pipe dream.

It was my endgame.

Now everyone and their grandma is a “millionaire” (at least in YouTube thumbnails).

The pedestal disappears once you’re standing on it.

~A millionaire~

Such a broad term.

Someone making $100k/yr with a Saas can convince themselves they’re a millionaire based on a hypothetical valuation of their company.

That’s very different from someone with $5m liquid.

Most people are “millionaires” the same way someone’s a “business owner” because they open an LLC.

Definitions get blurry when everyone starts flexing.

But really, the goal is to forget along the way.

Be so locked in on your vision, stacking cash and then one day you realize you “made it.”

But by then, your idea of making it will have evolved a dozen times and you’ll feel poor.

That’s where I’m at.

I know this reads like a humble brag, but I’m 24 – it’s really not that impressive.

However, the 20 year old version of me who was just getting started in online business would think it’s pretty cool.

Back then I didn’t fully believe any of this was possible.

Millionaire? Maybe one day.

But I just wanted to make enough money so that I didn’t have to ask some dickhead for a day off.

“S..sss…Sir… I’m not feeling too well, can I—”

I’d rather sell my body on OF.

Anyway, it works.

This vision that plays in the back of your mind is real.

Not every guru is trying to fuck you over.

There are people just like you (and probably much dumber) who’ve actualized their goals.

Stop listening to the sliver of doubt that creeps into your mind whenever you’re about to take a leap.

​Just jump.​

You’ll grow your wings on the way down…

And one day, you’ll look up and realize you did it.

But by then, it’ll feel normal – and you’ll know you’ve got so much further to go.

Or you can ignore everything I said and just keep watching other people win:

(that one's crazy ⬆)

​Up to you.​

Ben

​

​

​
​

subject: Just move
content:
It’s 9:39am on a sunny Monday in Miami.

I just opened a Google doc to write to you.

Actually, that was a lie.

I’ve had this page open for about 20 minutes but I kept distracting myself.

So now, my other tabs are closed and my phone is on DND.

Good morning, {{ first_name | default: "friend" }}.

Today is one of those days where I just don’t want to do this.

But I know that if I succumb to that emotion, the rest of my day will be even worse.

That is how losers are created – and I’m too blessed to be a loser today.

If there’s one word that defines the lesser type, it’d be idle.

I’ve been there.

Waiting for inspiration to take action.

Thinking someone or something is gonna come to save me.

My foot would hover over the gas pedal, teasing the idea of pressing down.

Some nights I’d even find a burst of inspiration after stumbling down a YouTube rabbithole.

I’d swear that tomorrow would be the day everything changed.

But when morning came, I’d freeze again.

Scared of what might happen if I actually picked up speed.

Every time I got close to jumping, I bitched out.

And even when I did jump, I'd revert back to my old self the second the excitement wore off.

This type of idleness is a surefire way to guarantee misery.

I’d rather be ignorant and oblivious than aware and idle.

Awareness without action is self-inflicted torture.

Desire sits in your soul for a reason.

When you want it badly enough to begin moving toward it, that means you were destined to have it.

But you sit there…

Overthinking, waiting, and making excuses.

You let fear and doubt scramble your brain while life passes you by.

The truth is – smart people don’t contemplate every move.

They’re smart enough to know what thoughts they shouldn’t listen to.

At some point, as the great philosopher Socrates once said, “Fuck it, we ball.”

Feel the fear.

​Hit the gas.​

And trust that you'll figure it out before you crash into a tree.

Idleness is death,

Ben

P.S. Join the winning team here.​

​

​

subject: "yOuR nEtwoRk iS yoUr NetWorTh"
content:
My least favorite word in the English dictionary is “networking.”

No brother, I do not want to connect for a virtual coffee.

That said, building a tribe of like-minded friends has been a big reason I’ve succeeded.

When I first started taking online business seriously, I was living in a frat house.

Most of my friends were supportive but they didn’t necessarily get it.

I distinctly remember a conversation I had with a childhood friend when I was home for the summer.

He was as skeptical as they come.

We went back and forth as he tried to poke holes in my plan and deter me.

By the end of the conversation, he was angry.

The idea of me following a different path made him bitter.

Eventually, I just stopped trying to explain it to him.

Most of my closest friends now are people I met in coaching programs or social media.

We’re all on the same path.

We push each other.

We’re not “networking,” we’re building together.

And occasionally that means we spend five figures on bottles at LIV like it’s a tax write-off (it is).

So as corny as the “your network is your net worth” saying is…

It’s fairly accurate.

If you have no one to turn to when shit gets tough, you’re more likely to talk yourself out of action.

Your standards come from proximity.

Surrounding yourself with people who make you feel like you’re behind brings the best out of you.

Because deep down…

You know your idiot friend who fell in love with a stripper isn’t smarter than you.

He’s just moving faster.

That’s why I built Artisan Lab.​

It’s not just about learning how to land a client or scale an offer.

It’s about being in the right room where the standard is getting results like this:

If you want to "level up your network" without chanting affirmations in a forest -- come apply to Artisan Lab.​

We’re just getting warmed up.

Ben

​
​

subject: Boooringg
content:
I’ve been enjoying the boring stuff more recently.

Automations, SOP’s, and Google sheets have always been a fear of mine.

The people who talk about these things online are always so nerdy.

This made me think that building proper systems would turn me into a virgin with blue light blockers glued to my face.

Luckily, that didn’t happen.

My systems have always been “good enough” but not great.

I relied heavily on the more fun side of the equation – content, angles, offers, etc.

But what I’m realizing now more than ever, is that the boring stuff makes the fun stuff funner.

Scaling feels better when you’re building on a solid foundation.

When your foundation is solid and your numbers are clear, your bottlenecks become creative puzzles, not existential threats.

This stuff feels so miniscule but if you neglect it for too long, it can burn down your business.

Most info-sellers build a course, set up a community, hire coaches and call it a day.

It’s fine to start, but it must evolve.

Your product is a living, breathing organism.

If you’re not building systems that make it easier for members to succeed.

And you don’t use tools to speed up their learning curve…

You’re simply being negligent.

Access will always be the core of the product, but why not use tools to make everything else more efficient?

This is what I’m doing with Artisan Lab.​

I began to think about what AI will do to online education and realized…

We are not far away from a time where a non-AI powered product is obsolete.

It’ll be like using a blackberry in 2025.

You’re a dinosaur.

Yes, the product is “boring.”

Yes, the systems are tedious.

But they’re part of the foundation.

And a solid foundation frees up your brain to go all-in on the fun shit.

Content. Offers. Funnels. Vision.

Your program becomes something that doesn’t just look good… but runs good.

And that’s why I put on my nerd hat and started building.

Because AI will make all this shit a necessity.

​Adapt or die.​

Ben

​
​
​
​

subject: Why SMMA sucks
content:
I hate people.

Let me rephrase that:

I hate annoying people.

I hate managing people.

I hate babysitting people.

Despite these factors, I began my entrepreneurial career in the SMMA space charging $1k monthly retainers.

This meant I had to get lots of clients and deal with lots of people to make money.

But I was hungry enough to make it work.

After about a year, I was making around $15k/mo… with 15 clients.

In total, I worked with over 50 clients during that run.

That’s a lot of people for someone who hates people!

And every day, I’d wake up to fires…

Clients complaining, breaching our three month agreement, or trying to add on services that were completely out of scope.

(Maybe the reason you’re not getting results is because you haven’t replied to the 136 leads I’ve gotten you. And no, I will not throw in email marketing for your baby mama’s nail salon).

I knew there had to be a better model.

Fewer clients, less churn, and more predictability.

And I’d finally discard the exhausting, ever present thought of “this could burn down at any moment.”

My goal -- make $15k/mo with no more than 5 clients.

That’s when I started shifting to info-product businesses.

My first client was an online basketball trainer.

I sent him a voice memo offering to help with his funnel.

A few days later, I was on a call with his business partner.

I didn’t have a fancy pitch, I just told them I’d help however I could.

Funnels, ads, email copy… I just wanted out of SMMA.

They brought me on to run ads.

I charged $1k/mo (I knew no better) and 10% of return on ad spend.

That first month, they paid me $2,351 just from the rev share.

That was 2.35x more than I was used to.

This was the lightbulb moment.

Why was I still begging for $1k retainers when I could just get… better clients?

I imagine this is how the man who invented sliced bread felt.

I’m a genius!

Five months later, I’d dropped nearly all of my SMMA clients.

Now I had five instead of 15, and made $16,290 that month.

I hit $25k two months later.

And $100k/mo a year after that, with just seven clients.

No chaos.

No babysitting.

The problem was never my skill set.

It was the vehicle.

And this is the one that finally worked.

Ben

​
​
​
​

​

subject: Why you CAN trust strangers on the internet
content:
Is internet money actually real?

This question sat in the back of my mind for a while.

I wanted to believe it was real, but I had no first-hand data.

The guys I watched on Youtube sounded legit, but they’re still strangers on the internet.

When I was little, I talked to “Megan Fox” on Facebook.

That’s how I learned to not trust strangers on the internet.

But sometimes, it’s not all bad.

Sometimes, talking to a stranger on the internet might make you rich.

One of my first Artisan Lab members was this 18 year old kid named Tomy.

Unlike most members, he had basically zero experience online.

I actually got a little annoyed with my closer when he joined because I thought this might be too overwhelming for him.

Artisan Lab was brand new and not yet “beginner-proof.”

This was Tomy’s intro message when he joined:

I hopped on a 1-1 with him and gave him a roadmap.

To my surprise, he began following it to a T.

He showed up to every call, asked questions, kept me updated, and even started posting on Twitter.

“This mf has that DAWG in him,” I thought to myself.

Despite this, he still struggled for a bit.

He dealt with a few crappy clients but finally found a solid one.

That client scaled to $50k/mo in just a few months.

And Tomy actually paid off Artisan Lab with the money he made from that.

(I wouldn’t recommend doing this but like I said – Tomy is a DAWG).

Yesterday, he posted a win inside the community that made me smile like a serial killer.

It took him about 9 months.

From complete beginner, to his first $10k month.

That might not sound super sexy in a world where everyone promises you “$10k/mo in 3 months or you don’t pay.”

That’s all bulshit.

When you’re completely new, you have to accept that it’s gonna be a long, bumpy road in the beginning.

But when you get over that hump, things get fun.

And I’m excited to see how quickly Tomy is able to scale from here.

Typically, the business that gets you to your first $10k/month can’t take you much farther beyond that.

That’s not the case here.

The hardest part is over, and now he just has to double down.

Tomy, I’m proud of you bro.

And if you’re like him and you have that DAWG in you…

​Here, I’ll give you the same roadmap I gave him.​

Ben

subject: I <3 Whales
content:
Good morning.

It’s a sunny Monday in Miami.

To put it bluntly — Trying to get clients absolutely blows dick at first.

I spent my first two years in business on a client hamster wheel.

Get on a few sales calls.

Close a couple clients.

And then most would leave after a few months.

The cycle then continued…

Until I found the Info-Agency model.

Instead I could just make them more money.

Pretty cool.

After all, you don’t want to be DMing strangers, begging for a crum of money forever.

You’d rather have them come to you.

The only way to do that, is to be someone others talk about.

And the only way to do that, is to get clients insane results.

(Which you’re incentivized to do when you have a rev share).

Here’s how this plays out:

The other day, I was at lunch with my friends Phillip and Jace (both are members in Artisan Lab).

They told me how they had too many prospects wanting to work with them and not enough bandwidth.

Both are working with whale clients only right now.

Jace has a single client paying him 6 figures in a month.

And Phillip’s smallest client paid him $30k last month.

Because they’re getting such good results, word spreads and they have prospects lining up to work with them.

They don’t have to slide in DMs.

They don’t have to send hundreds of cold emails.

And they don’t have to deal with clients churning every month.

This is the difference between chasing clients… and *attracting them.*

When you finally make that shift, business gets fun again.

The money's better.

The stress is lower.

And you’re perceived as a partner rather than a service provider.

If that’s what you want, Artisan Lab was built for you.​

I’ll help you land your first whale and keep ‘em forever.

Ben
