subject: I got a penthouse
content:
Goooood morning {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

Here’s an unsolicited POV from my new penthouse in Miami:

I moved in yesterday and let me tell ya…

Moving sucks.

However, it gave me the opportunity to be a customer and client – which is fun for me as a business owner.

I’m able to observe what it’s like from the other side.

I hired this moving company called “Piece Of Cake Moving.”

There’s a copywriting lesson in the name itself.

They have big pink trucks that stick out like an OF girl in a church.

A quick Google search told me that this is a big company.

They have over 350 trucks, employ 800+ people, and handle over 100,000 moves a year.

This has made Mr. Piece Of Cake, a rich man – they made over $100m in 203.

And after they helped me move, I can see why.

They were at the top of my Google search, so I clicked and filled out a form outlining the items I had to move.

A few minutes later I had a quote for $450.

I didn’t have a ton of stuff but I had them pack it all up too, so I found this to be incredibly cheap.

Appointment scheduled.

They followed up with me over the next couple of days, sent all the insurance forms, and arrived on time.

My main mover was named Jason.

He now is the primary beneficiary in my will.

We coordinated everything and it was about as smooth and easy as can be.

I ended up having extra items that I didn’t list in the initial itinerary and he threw them in for me.

He moved everything, unpacked, and rearranged furniture in the new place (which was outside of the job description).

Lastly, I had a few things that I was gonna take to a storage unit after the move.

I mentioned this and he offered to take those items and meet me over at the unit.

After all this, I ended up tipping him more than I paid for the move.

This is what success looks like – both as a business and an employee.

When you scale, attention to detail is everything.

Minor sloppiness creates huge problems when you have 350 pink trucks around the globe.

My booking process was easy and the movers actually cared.

Jason went above and beyond to the point where I wrote an entire email about it.

This sounds like a Yelp review from someone with far too much time on their hands.

But as a business owner, it’s a great lesson.

If my customer experience was this good, on what was probably one of their lowest ticket moves…

When they have 800+ employees…

Just imagine the level of attention to detail and care that the CEO must have.

If your product isn’t so good that customers want to become your marketing…

You’ve still got work to do.

And when you’re the one delivering a service?

Go above and beyond.

​Become the Jason of info-products here.​

Ben

​
​
​

​

subject: This is hard to do...
content:
In October 2021, I hit my first $10k month.

A year later, I hit $30k per month.

And 11 months after that, I hit my first $100k month.

That may sound like a relatively fast journey, but here’s what’s not visible in those metrics:

Before I made any money, I wasted a year contemplating whether this online business thing was actually real.

Even once I started taking action, it took me another year and a half to get to $10k/mo.

So really, here’s how it went:

0-$10k, 2.5 years.

$10k-$30k, 1 year.

$30k-$100k, 11 months.

Without a doubt, the hardest and longest (pause) part was the beginning.

I can viscerally remember how frustrated I’d get when seeing a “0-$10k/mo in 30 days” case study.

“That [redacted] can’t be smarter than me,” I thought.

But here’s what I’ve realized:

Headlines and Youtube titles never tell the full story.

Yeah, they get clicks. And yeah, that’s part of the game.

But they rarely show you the late nights, identity crises, and full-blown mental spirals it took to get there.

“He hit $50k/mo in 3 months” sounds a hell of a lot better than “He finally hit $50k after spending three years depressed, lost, and considering accepting the sugar baby offer in his DMs.”

But I’ll give it to you straight.

This game is difficult because you have to reprogram your hardwiring.

You’ll get discouraged, distracted, almost quit, feel like an idiot, and then…

Magic happens.

I was reminded of all this yesterday when I sat down with Heik — one of the guys inside AL.

He joined six months ago making $2k/month.

Today, he’s doing $10k/month and just flew from Germany to Miami to meet with clients.

His journey wasn’t linear or smooth.

But he stuck it out – even when it felt like nothing was clicking.

I wanted to share our convo with you, not because Heik’s some unicorn…

But because his story is one you might see yourself in.

The first $10k always takes the longest.

But after that, the game gets fun.

​Watch the interview here.​

Ben

​
​
​

subject: Inertia and hangovers
content:
I have a slight hangover but it was for a good cause…

We celebrated Cardinal Mason’s 26th birthday last night and I don’t recall much after midnight.

Hence the later email today.

Anyway, I’ve been enjoying business a lot recently.

A few clients are ripping. Artisan Lab is scaling. Members are crushing.

And the best part of all – work doesn’t feel like a chore.

Most of 2024, I wasn’t very engaged in my businesses.

For the two years before that, almost all I did was work.

This was great to build a foundation but life just felt dull after a while.

Why would I make more money if I don’t know how to spend it?

So, I learned how to make tens of thousands of dollars disappear. Fast.

But I’m out of coast mode now.

I feel more in control of my business, and there’s this level of fulfillment that’s met by forward progress.

Scaling feels like creative problem solving rather than an intimidating headache.

Instead of dreading calls and items on my to do list, I look forward to (most of) them.

I like sitting down at my desk.

It’d been a while since I had this type of energy and I forgot how incredible it is.

So, if you’re in an era where opening your laptop feels equivalent to being stuck in a closet with Lizzo…

Here’s my advice to you:

First – you have to really try.

Profound, right?

Seriously though, it might just be difficult because you're not building any momentum.

Get organized, take some baby steps, and see where you’re at in a week.

For 95% of people reading this, that’s the fix.

But if you’re where I was, and you can’t even bear the thought of work…

You have to shake the snowglobe.

I am advising you to crash out (potentially).

Move to a new city, change up your routine, spend more money, try new hobbies, do ayahuasca in a forest… idk just do something different.

Follow your natural curiosity.

I don’t know if this is sound advice, but it worked for me.

I had to sidequest-maxx to show myself how fun life can be.

This made it feel like clicking buttons in exchange for a larger number on a screen is worth it again.

Now, quick disclaimer:

Do not take this as an excuse to crash out because you’re avoiding sending outbound messages.

There will always be parts of business that aren’t fun.

Sometimes the answer is to power through.

There are always parts of business that suck.

But here’s the truth:

Inertia = resistance to change.

An object at rest stays at rest. An object in motion stays in motion.

So if you’re stuck…

​Just start moving.​

Ben

​
​
​
​

subject: My first chargeback = your $500 discount
content:
It's pouring rain in Miami.

I ordered coffee to my door to avoid walking in such a treacherous condition.

David Goggins would have a temper tantrum reading that.

Anyway, I lost my virginity the other day…

I got my first ever chargeback on Artisan Lab.

After 160 happy customers, it happened.

This really pissed me off...

I take pride in the quality of members that we allow inside.

AL is more close knit than most info-products and I talk to many of the members on a daily basis.

Because of this, I don’t let stupid people in.

Dealing with “the stupids” makes me feel like a camp counselor running around with a bunch of snotty children.

I’m too pretentious for that.

I’d rather make less money and protect the aura inside my program.

But this time, I was deceived.

My community was infiltrated by someone who should’ve been sitting on the stairs outside the club with vodka spilled on his shirt after getting denied at the door.

Here’s what happened:

George (not his real name) applied for AL about a month ago.

The calendar was full at the time he applied, so he sent me an email saying “I want to give you money” (yes that’s a direct quote).

He got connected with my team and got on a call.

Initially it looked like a good fit – he was newer to the agency world but seemed to have his head screwed on straight.

We offered him a spot and he joined.

The next day he hopped on a 1-1 with Sean, one of my coaches inside.

No red flags yet.

A few days later, I had an hour-long 1-1 call with him.

He expressed some doubt, so I walked him through everything that he’d need to do step-by-step.

By the end of our call, he was incredibly thankful and appeared motivated.

I had faith in him.

The next day, he said he had a change of heart and requested a refund.

He’d been in the community for a little under a week, hopped on two 1-1 calls and two group calls.

At that point it’s as if he’d eaten three quarters of a sandwich and tried to send it back.

I have a strict no refund policy, but being the reasonable person I am, I offered him a partial refund anyway.

He declined and opened a dispute three weeks later.

Here’s why I’m telling you all this:

George is not an idiot.

He made an investment in himself that could’ve changed the trajectory of his life for the better.

But he let that scared little voice inside his head talk him out of it.

I empathize with him, as it’s a voice we all have.

Winners overcome it.

Losers allow it to control them.

So, in honor of George’s swift exit and the restoration of peace in Artisan Lab…

I’m offering $500 off for anyone reading this who doesn’t flake on their goals the second things get uncomfortable.

No sob stories.

No refund requests after two 1-1 calls and a panic attack.

Just hungry people who want to win.

If that’s you – reply to this email with “Winner” and I’ll get you the link to book in with a $500 discount.

You’ve got 24 hours.

Ben

P.S. George – no hard feelings. I found something more your speed: Careers at McDonalds.​

​
​

​

subject: The South Park business model
content:
I began writing a South Park episode in my head last night.

Bear with me for a sec…

Imagine Cartman gets a bad case of “shiny object syndrome.”

Kyle walks into his room…

He’s sitting there with blue-light blockers on and six laptops open.

Alex Becker on one screen. Iman, Hormozi, Grant Cardone, Tai Lopez, and Sophie Rain(?) on the others.

Boxes are scattered throughout the room with failed dropshipping products.

When Kyle tries talking to him he says… “Fuck off you normie cuck! Go back to your little slave job, I’m escaping the matrix.”

Cartman slams the door so hard that The 4-Hour Workweek falls from his desk.

He’s “tried” eight different business models in the past six months.

And although he doesn’t show it, his skepticism grows with each failed attempt…

“Maybe I’m not cut out for this.”

“I can’t keep wasting time.”

“What if this only works for people with better skills, luck, or connections?”

Despite the doubt, there’s an inkling of hope underneath it all.

Cartman knows he has the potential.

He knows he’s not a complete idiot.

And he’s willing to work hard.

But he’s directionless and distracted.

He feels like he’s always almost figuring it out.

But almost doesn’t cut it.

Cartman closes five of the six laptops.

“I'm just gonna pick one thing and stick to it,” he thinks to himself.

That’s when he goes all in.

This time, he’s smart enough to ignore the voice in his head that attempts to talk him into a different opportunity.

Two weeks later, he’s getting on sales calls.

A couple weeks after that, he gets his first client.

And next thing you know, he’s making $10k/month.

Finally, he’s cured of his shiny object syndrome.

He didn’t need another guru.

He didn’t need another YouTube video.

He didn’t need to optimize his cold plunge routine.

He just needed to make a decision.

And when he finally did, things started happening.

If you’re still stuck cycling through new ideas, hoping the next one will magically “feel right”…

You’re not looking for the right model.

You’re looking for a way to avoid committing.

​Be like Cartman.​

Pick something.

Stick to it.

Anything works, if you work.

Just don’t be like Cartman was in Season 1 – fat, lazy, and blaming the Jews.

Be Season 26 Cartman:

A little older. Slightly wiser.

Still kind of a dick… but finally making money.​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​
​
​
​

​

subject: I owe the nerds an apology...
content:
I’m becoming more of what I used to hate.

When AI first came out, I thought it was for dorks.

“HeY acTuAlLy DiD yOu kNoW yoU coULd AuTomAte ThAt wiTh AI.”

Shut up.

To be fair – the only people talking about it were nerdy, boring agency guys.

And somehow they all lived in Tampa.

But I guess there’s a lesson there…

“Don’t judge a dork by his blue light blockers,” as Socrates once said.

I use AI on a daily basis, but yesterday I began to realize how much I’m still underutilizing it.

I need to fully integrate it into everything.

That doesn’t mean replacing my own creativity, just enhancing it.

Repurposing my best ideas, maximizing every input, and increasing efficiency…

I sound like a nerd but it’s for good reason.

This is the dot com bubble of our generation.

In the internet marketing world, AI and online coaching are the modern day gold rushes.

Everyone is a coach. And everyone is building a stupid AI tool no one wants.

While most will fail, there’ll be some big winners.

And those who win, will find their ideas in the trenches.

They’ll be working on an optimization in their business, run into a problem, realize it’s a common problem in their industry, and build something that solves it.

Next thing you know you’re Alex Becker and you just sold Hyros for $100m.

The more I go down the AI rabbithole, the more I’m realizing…

This may be the greatest era of opportunity in my lifetime.

And an afternoon of deep work could result in a nine-figure idea.

In 1994, a VP at a hedge fund noticed the internet was growing at 2,300% per year.

He capitalized on this and started selling books online.

And that little company became something you may have heard of – Amazon.

“When I’m 80, I want to have minimized the number of regrets. I knew I might fail, but I also knew I wouldn’t regret trying.” - Jeff Bezos

Anyway, I say all this not to romanticize tech or pretend I’m the next Bezos.

But to remind myself (and maybe you too) that once-in-a-generation windows don’t stay open forever.

You can either keep scrolling, keep judging, keep saying “AI is cringe”...

​Or you can build.​

Your call.

Ben

P.S. Somewhat unrelated but funny story:

One time I got denied at the door of a Miami club as the bouncer told us there’s a high profile celebrity in there and they can’t let anyone else in.

I jokingly said “who tf is it Lebron James.”

A few moments later, a bald veiny man named Jeff walked out with his security.

​
​
​

​

subject: I got married to an AI bot
content:
I have a confession…

My agency basically runs on auto-pilot at this point.

We have a small (but dialed) team and a couple really solid clients.

It’s a great set up.

But due to my lack of involvement in the operations, it’s been a while since I’ve been in the back-end trenches.

I’m locked in, scaling Artisan Lab – but I started to miss being the wizard behind the scenes.

Sometimes it’s cooler to be the lazy, fat puppet master than the puppet.
So a little over a month ago, I had the idea to take on some 1-1 clients.

My goal was to find a few early stage info-businesses I could get a large stake in.

I posted a call to action on my Instagram story.

Next thing you know, I have what I would describe as a “portfolio company” if I were trying to impress someone.

I began building the full system for one of these portfolio clients yesterday.

Quick context – this client just recently started making content.

He built a blue collar business, makes good money doing it, and is now stepping into guru-world.

As of a few weeks ago, we had nothing but a social media account with a calendly link in the bio.

I wanted to first see if his audience was ready to buy anything from him.

We started booking calls and pitched 1-1 coaching.

No course, no community, just calls with my client so we can get testimonials.

We filled up ten spots way quicker than I anticipated.

Now, we’re building out the course, setting up all the softwares and backend stuff so we can do a real launch.

This will probably take about a week.

In the meantime, I needed a way to nurture the audience.

I used [an AI tool I won’t disclose publicly until they give me better affiliate terms] to make a free lead magnet…

I took five of my clients' videos, the software transcribed them, and I was done in 30 seconds.

It gave me a full 12 page breakdown of the business model and my client’s journey.

Then I went over to my friend Chat GPT.

I made a new project, gave it the PDF, and asked it to write the copy for the opt-in page.

Done in 10 seconds.

I threw the copy on a landing page and now I just need to write a welcome sequence…

[Read in southern accent for full effect]

Back in the old days, when I first started – this would be a two hour project.

I’d need to manually ideate each email, type away on my little keyboard, and finally I’d be done.

But I didn’t have what you now have…

A muthafuckin I.

I went back and forth with Mr.GPT for about five minutes.

My goal was to have it write in my style but my client’s voice.

My instructions were clear and he began typing away.

First email done. Banger.

Second email, banger.

Third, fourth, fifth… holy fuckin shit Chat GPT I love you to death.

[Ok, no more southern accent]

My full welcome sequence was done in three minutes.

And it wasn’t some generic, AI sounding copy.

The writing had a real voice, humor, and maintained the tone in my client's content.

All in, it took maybe 10 minutes.

Offer, lead magnet, landing page, welcome sequence.

AI didn’t just help – it did the damn thing (because I used it correctly).

This is the game now.

If you want to build a lean info-agency using tools like this,

It’s never been easier…

​And Artisan Lab is where I show you how.​

Ben (not AI, I promise)

​
​

​

subject: The best job in the world
content:
I never really wanted to sell my own coaching.

It was awesome when I was just the guy behind the scenes.

I’d be moderating a client's webinar, watching the money roll in as they’d smile on camera.

The audience didn’t know I was the one turning the dials, but others in this space did.

This gained me respect from the right people and kept me away from the general public.

As an ambitious and pretentious young man – it was a great place to be.

This also made it so that all of the content I’d create was purely for fun.

I wasn’t selling anything of my own, but I was making money as if I was.

I had the upside of running a coaching business *without* running one.

For about a year and a half, I made between $80-$125k/mo strictly from my agency.

I didn’t have the pressure to create content myself.

I didn’t have to manage a big team.

And I didn’t have to deal with thousands of customers.

My routine was as follows:

Wake up at 8am.

Make sure nothing is on fire.

Gym.

Coffee.

Text client “we’re fucking rich.”

Lunch.

Walk.

Schedule client’s emails for tomorrow.

Moderate a webinar.

Dinner, sleep.

I’d make $5k from my rev shares that day without doing anything but management.

It’s kind of like being a backup quarterback in the NFL.

I imagine this is one of the best jobs in the world.

Unless your QB1 gets his leg snapped in half by a 300-lb lineman, your sole job is to make sure he’s prepared.

You get all the perks, make $2-4m/yr on average…

And you don’t have to run for your life every Sunday.

Now, I’m not saying running an info-agency means you don’t work at all.

But if you’re efficient with your work, you properly use AI, and you set up some automations…

There’s not a ton for you to do other than stand there with a fire extinguisher.

So, although I love coaching and helping members in Artisan Lab get rich, my agency comes with fewer headaches.

And being the puppet master is pretty fuckin cool.

Here are some recent wins from the QB2’s inside AL...

Manoj made $14k profit in three days and is so rich he forgot to share it:

Khesraw made $10k profit from one client last month:

Vander kicked off the month with a new client:

And Humayoun and Josh sent some wholesome messages that made me smile:

​This is where you can join them.​

Your guru’s guru,

Ben

​

​
​

​

subject: AHHHH
content:
I have a mountain of things on my to-do list today.

So many that I might end up doing nothing.

That’s the worst outcome, so I’m trying to avoid the nothing part.

But I already wasted 30 minutes talking to ChatGPT and scrolling on Amazon.

My office in the new place is still cluttered and echoey.

I need to move a dresser, add a couch, install new curtains, and text my undocumented amigo to do all of that for me.

The couch was supposed to get here days ago but it got delayed.

Mr. GPT told me a more plush rug would help with the echo, so that’s on the way too.

But now I’m sitting here, blaming my lack of focus on the disorganization of this room.

If I were to give advice to myself, it’d be this:

“Are you a toddler? You can’t work because your office isn’t perfect? Grow up.”

Sound advice.

But instead, I’ll just complain to thousands of strangers on the internet.

I’ve now written 178 words here and still said nothing of value.

At least you know this isn’t AI because AI isn’t dumb enough to write like this.

I could connect the intro to a lesson on ignoring mental excuses or creating a peaceful work environment.

But I won’t.

It’s Monday.

You’re alive.

You’ve got working senses, a smartphone, and internet access.

And someday in the future, you’ll wish you could relive this exact day.

You don’t need me to give you advice.

You just need to move.

This the youngest and handsomest you’ll ever be.

So let’s make the most of it.

Stop blaming your productivity problems on curtain rods and go make some money.

Deal?

Deal.

​Let’s get rich.​

Ben

​
​

​

subject: How to spot a fake guru
content:
I have another incredibly boring email for you today.

It’s about a stupid little topic called "product.”

80% of the info gurus just clicked away.

So now that it’s just you and me, I’ll be incredibly honest here:

I used to not give a solitary shit about this side of the business.

It wasn’t in my job description to care.

I was the marketer.

The rainmaker.

The guy behind the scenes who’ll never deal with the customers.

My job was to sell.

So as long as my clients weren’t absolute scumbags – I’d do just that.

But after running my own info-business, that’s changed.

People turn their hard earned money into my money.

They trust me to care about them and deliver on my promises.

And I’d be an absolute shithead not to.

This is gonna feel like I’m indirectly pitching you.

I’m not, but I kind of am too.

Artisan Lab isn’t perfect, but it’s always improving.

I personally talk to every member, have incredible coaches, bring on guests, and add more content.

Yesterday, a new member joined who we’ll call Joe.

Before joining, Joe DM’d nearly everyone he could find in the program.

Because I’m not a sleazy, lying, piece of shit, the responses he got were overwhelmingly positive.

Here’s what he said in his intro message:

(he joined on his bday so we sang to him on the group call lol).

I say all this because I truly don’t understand how people can sell something they know isn’t up to par.

They’ll do anything to get the deal done, but once you buy, you’ll never hear from them again.

And perhaps the worst part – they get people to take out a loan to buy their shit product.

There is a special place in hell for you people.

Sure, not everyone will succeed.

Most will buy and do nothing with the info inside.

But that’s not a cop out to neglect your product.

And it feels 10x better when you produce results like this:

​Don’t get scammed by a fake guru.​

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: People dumber than you are getting rich
content:
Good morning {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "friend" }}.

Here’s our affirmation for the day:

“The world is full of money. Some of it has my name on it. All I have to do is collect it.”

Felix Dennis told me to say this to myself, so I figured I’d share it with you.

Today I'm thinking about dumb people.

More specifically, how people who are dumber than me are richer than me.

That’s wack.

Now I’m not a genius…

I can’t change a tire, I’m severely directionally challenged, and I often misspell simple words.

But everyone has their pitfalls.

Strip Elon Musk of his fame and put him at LIV in Miami.

He’d look like the kid who gets picked last in high school gym class.

Everyone has their strengths and weaknesses.

Your job is to lean into what you’re good at and stop wasting time pretending to be someone you’re not.

Let me show you what I mean.

I have two friends – let’s call them Nikola and Anthony (Basketball fans, you already get the analogy).

Nikola’s an operator.

He’s analytical and calculated.

Excel sheets give him an erection and he uses Zapier to automate his breakfast order and bathroom schedule.

But if you put him in a room full of people, he’ll complain about how he wants to go home.

He has trouble making eye contact with women and freezes up on camera.

Still, he’s rich.

He’s the COO of an 8 figure eCom brand.

Anthony’s the opposite.

He’s incredibly articulate, he can simplify complex ideas, and he loves the spotlight.

But if you told him to build a funnel or set up an automation… it’d take him 6 hours, 3 breakdowns, and a YouTube tutorial.

So he doesn’t.

He stays on camera, grabs attention, and outsources the rest.

Both are successful. Because they play their role.

Most people try to “fix” their weaknesses instead of weaponizing their strengths.

Don’t be like most people.

Figure out your edge. Go all in on it.

And if you suck at the rest, improve it or get help.

​Now go collect what’s already yours.​

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: This self-help guru scammed me
content:
I got scammed by Mark Manson this morning.

The first thing I saw after opening my eyes was a charge for $79.99 – MarkManson.net.

I guess I signed up for his paid newsletter three years ago.

Haven’t opened a single email other than the payment receipts I just found.

This makes me wonder what other subscriptions I forgot I’m paying for.

I’d make a great target for a blackhat MRR scammer.

Anyway, I read The Subtle Art Of Not Giving A F*ck a few years ago.

I hate admitting this because Mr.Manson has turned into a corny, platitude writing, lesbian…

But that book began to open my eyes.

It’s one of three books that I recall having an impact on my mini spiritual awakening.

Millionaire Fastlane and Think And Grow Rich are the other two.

All three are fairly broad money/self help books, but at the time that’s exactly what I needed.

So, I’m gonna continue my donation to marklesbian.net as a thank you.

There’ve been so many books that helped me over the years.

And the fact that you can just buy someone's brain for sub $20 is a cheat code.

Books changed my life.

But eventually, I needed proximity.

Real conversations with people more successful than me.

I found this through online communities and recreated it inside Artisan Lab.

Twice a month, I bring in people from my network for a guest call.

These are friends who’ve built multi-million dollar software companies, scaled offers to $500k+/mo, and built huge audiences.

We’ve had Cardinal Mason break down how he built Copy MBA.

Pierre Khoury went over how he scaled his info-agency to 7 figures.

And 20+ others who’re incredibly good at what they do.

Next Wednesday, Rob Oliver (@robthebank) is coming on to talk about how he’s built and sold 8-figure eCom brands, grown a massive audience, and more.

This kind of access is rare.

And it’s one of my favorite bonuses we have inside the community.

So, I’ll keep funding Mark’s retirement as a thank you.

But if you want to learn from killers actively building – apply here.​

Rob’s on next Wednesday. Don’t miss it.

Ben

​
​
​

​

subject: I got robbed
content:
Before I start yapping, two important things…

Thing #1: Price of Artisan Lab is going up June 1st.

I met up with a member for lunch yesterday.

He said it felt like he robbed me by getting in at the current price point.

I don’t like getting robbed.

So on June 1st, the price is going up. That same day, I’m adding:

  • Another coach (now 4-5 calls/week)
  • Extra 1-on-1 calls
  • AI modules that’ll help you train ChatGPT to do 80% of client work

If you go here and apply before June 1st, you’ll get access to everything we have now, plus the additions at the current price.

But once these updates are live, there's no going back.

​Commit a highway robbery here.​

Thing #2: Phillip made $87k last month.

He can’t legally drink alcohol (he’s 20).

He only has three clients.

And he transitioned from high ticket sales to info-agency just four months ago.

Meaning he basically went from 0-$87k/mo in four months.

The kid is a DAWG.

​So, I had him on the channel for an interview that you can watch here.​

Alright, announcements are over.

Here’s a quick AI cheat code for writing email copy:

  • Take 10-20 solid emails you like (yours, mine, etc.)
  • Drop them in a Google Doc
  • Feed it into ChatGPT/Claude with this prompt:

“I’m going to give you example marketing emails.

Your job is to extract the tone, writing style, voice, and structure used and turn it into a clear style guide and persona that I (or my team) can follow. This should be an extensive guide that we can replicate with any personal brand.

Break down:

Tone and personality traits

Formatting and structure

Common themes and messaging angles

Do’s and Don’ts

Example CTA styles”

Now you have a custom template.

Upload client info, tell the AI to follow your style guide, and boom…

You’ll never have to write an email from scratch again.

subject: How I hit $100K months (after hating my life)
content:
Happy Memorial Day.

Over the past few years, I’ve subscribed to countless newsletters.

So many that I don’t remember a lot of the names I see in my inbox.

But this morning, one of them stood out.

They said “we’re discounting our price from $7995 to just $995 for the next 48 hours!”

I understand Holidays are great excuses to run discounts – and much respect to all of those who’ve served in the military.

But my brother in Christ…

SEVEN THOUSAND DOLLARS OFF?

For Memorial Day??

Are you gonna throw in a free hand job for customers during Christmas???

Shit like that just makes me laugh.

Anyway, here’s what I really wanted to talk about today:

“What you’re aware of you’re in control of, what you’re not aware of controls you.” - Anthony de Mello

This obviously applies to the big decisions in life.

But just as important, are the small ones.

You can “escape the matrix,” create your own income, and travel the world… and still be asleep at the wheel.

You look free, but you’re more enslaved than the guy who’s stoked for his day off today.

Here’s what’s easy to forget:

Everything is a conscious decision.

If you want your life to look different, you have to change it (duh).

But if you don’t define what change looks like, you’ll drift.

You’ll be aware enough to know something’s off, but too unclear to do anything about it.

I found myself in this very position about two years ago.

I’d been living in Miami for just under a year and was starting to make some real money.

My income climbed from $15k/mo to $70k/mo (thanks to my Info Agency).

But I wasn’t enjoying it at all.

Here’s an excerpt from my journal entry in August 2023:

“I feel uninspired. Almost like I was sold a lie. I go accomplish all these things, hit numbers, buy fancy shit — and my life would feel a whole lot different. But I’m here and it doesn’t live up to that.”

What I didn’t understand then, was that the same way making money is a conscious decision…

So was my lifestyle.

I didn’t have any hobbies.

I didn’t make a conscious effort to meet new people.

I didn’t design my life outside of the money part.

So there I was. Making more money than I knew what to do with… But no motion.

And then, I regained consciousness.

Started boxing. Started going out. Started playing tennis.

Two months later, my lifestyle was exactly the way I envisioned.

Plus I hit my first $100k month and bought my dream car.

All of it came from conscious decisions…

And the same system I now teach inside Artisan Lab.​

It’s what let me charge $10k+ per client, build real freedom, and actually enjoy the life I worked for.

The price goes up June 1st.

​If you’ve been waiting for a sign, this is it.​

Talk soon,

Ben

subject: I woke up at 5am for nothing
content:
There was a stretch in high school when I’d wake up at 5am to get shots up before class.

I wasn’t naturally gifted or the most athletic.

But I figured if I outworked everyone, I’d win.

The gym was cold and dark because I’d get there before they turned the lights on.

Every single morning was a battle.

“Why the fuck are you doing this?” I’d think when my alarm sounded.

The sound called “Bulletin” brings up horrid memories.

But I’d get up, put a hoodie on, and walk out the door with a little mantra in my head:

“If I don’t do this I’m gay a bitch.

So I did.

And I fully convinced myself that if I just worked harder than everyone else, I’d play D1 basketball.

I was wrong.

I didn’t end up playing past high school.

But do you know what happens when you actually try?

When you actually give something your all?

The forces of the universe begin working in your favor.

One door closes, another opens.

Basketball ended.

But discipline was instilled forever.

I learned to ignore the voice in my head who wanted to hit snooze.

It’s the same voice who doesn’t want to send outbound, turn on the camera, or get on a sales call.

It’ll keep you stuck until you realize you don’t have to listen to it.

You’ll wait another week…

Then another month…

Then wonder why nothing changed at the end of the year.

So here’s my push to get you moving:

Artisan Lab is going up in price June 1st.

If you’re serious about building an info agency where:

You can make $10k/mo+ from just one client.

You don’t have to send hundreds of outbound messages.

You don’t have to build a huge team to scale.

And you work with clients who become friends…

​This is for you.

I threw together a doc that breaks everything down -- what you get, how it works, and what it costs.

​You can check it out here.​

Ben

subject: The 2025 online business power rankings
content:
This is a longer one so strap in, {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "buddy" }}.

Let’s break down the popular online business models in 2025.

Here are the main ones that come to mind:

  • Dropshipping
  • High ticket sales
  • Trading
  • “AI Copywriting”
  • “AI Automation”
  • Being a TikTok Shop creator
  • Aaaand Info Agency

Obviously I have a bias for the Info Agency, but I’ll be as objective as possible here.

Ranking from worst to best:

Trading takes the major L.

It’s a casino.

I’ve met many of the trading influencers and they all made their money from the 2020 crypto bull run, selling info, or owning a prop firm.

Almost none of them are profitable traders.

You simply have to be world class to make money – but I will say the upside is tremendous.

If you are 1/10,000 who becomes really good, it can and will make you rich.

But there is a 99.9% chance you never get there and waste all your money.

Dropshipping is my second worst on the list here.

It can work, but similar to trading, most eCom gurus made their money from courses.

And the successful ones, nine times out of ten are running a blackhat MRR scam.

Cons:
Many skills to learn, low margins, excess variables outside of your control.

Pros:

Scales fast IF you crack it (most don’t) and has enterprise value (most won’t get there).

To be entirely fair – trading and dropshipping both have about as high of an upside as any other model on the list.

But they generally require more capital and higher business acumen.

Next up, “AI Automation.”

It’s just SMMA repackaged with AI in the title.

Decent for beginners because you’ll learn some core skills.

But I hope you’re ready to deal with shitty clients, constant churn, and build a big team.

You’ll need dozens of clients to make real money and will have to work with dentists, realtors, or some other industry you likely know nothing about.

It can work, but it’s definitely a grind.

Next, TikTok shop creator.

It was an infinite money glitch a year ago.

Absolute monkey buffoon retards were getting rich.

But the faucet has started to turn off.

It’s basically like playing the lottery now.

If you’re consistent, you make really good content, and you keep iterating, eventually you’ll go viral and make money.

Most will quit before that happens and I’ve also heard some nightmares about not getting paid out commissions.

It can be decent cash flow but it’s declining and you don’t learn any real valuable skills.

Moving on, we’ve reached the top three:

AI Copywriting, High Ticket Sales, and Info Agency.

“AI Copywriting” is not a business model, it’s a skill.

The application of said skill determines how much money you make.

Sales is similar – get good, find a good offer and you’ll make solid cash.

Both of these are incredible things to learn.

But they both end up pointing to the Info Agency model.

Learn “AI Copywriting” – who are the best clients to work with?

Info sellers.

Learn sales – who are you closing for?

Info sellers.

So why not skip the line?

Fuck being the copywriting intern.

Fuck closing leads for someone else’s offer.

Just build the machine yourself.

Control the funnel.

Control the offer.

Control the money.

That’s the Info Agency.

It’s the only model where:

· You don’t need 20 clients to scale

· You don’t need a ton of capital

· You don’t need to sell "AI lead gen" to boomers

And you can scale to $50k/mo+ with one Google folder, one system, and one client.

It’s not as sexy as some of the other models.

But it’s effective – if you’re willing to work.

So if you want to learn how to build one that doesn’t suck…

​You know where to find me.​

Ben

P.S. Price goes up in three days.

If you’re even thinking about doing this, now’s the time to move.

After that, it’s gonna cost more. Simple as that.

If you want a full breakdown of what's inside, go here.​

subject: The banana bread problem
content:
Get in {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "amigo" }}, we’re going to the store.

We’re making banana bread and have one very simple goal:

Get three overripe bananas.

They need to be the color of black coffee because that’s when they’re the most flavorful.

We walk into Publix and head to the produce section.

There, we see two overripe bananas.

We grab them and toss in a third that’s just yellow.

Close enough.

We hop in the car, go home, and make the bread.

It’s good.

Not quite as good as it could’ve been, but only a banana bread purist (fuckin weirdo) would notice.

Fast forward a month.

Same plan.

This time, there’s only one overripe banana.

We grab it, plus two yellow ones.

Close enough.

Get home, make the bread, it’s decent.

Now, fast forward a year.

We head to the store and buy the shitty Publix brand bread in a plastic container.

It’s aiight… if you’re high.

Close enough.

Here’s what these bananas mean to you:

Your tolerance for misalignment determines your life.

There is a version of you, buried in there, that just knows.

When you do things that betray that intuition, it knows.

At first, it’s subtle.

But eventually, you’re living a life that doesn’t feel like yours.

You’ll convince yourself it’s fine.

Not great, not awful. Just…

Close enough.

Or…

You can have a low tolerance for misalignment.

When it doesn’t feel right, you change it.

Whether it’s your career path, where you live, or even your routine.

It’s up to you.

And you know the answer, even if it’s buried under a mountain of excuses.

So my friend, here’s the pitch:

Do you want to keep settling for close enough?

Or do you want to make the change?

You already know the life you want.

The question is how long you’ll pretend that shitty banana bread is enough.

​Price of Artisan Lab goes up in 2 days.​

If you’re gonna move, move now.

Ben

P.S. If you’d rather skip the application process because the clock is ticking here…

​This doc will go over what’s inside and pricing.​

subject: This might not work
content:
Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich.

Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich.

Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich.

“Ben, why are you saying that on the day of the price increase?”

Great question, {{ subscriber.first_name | fallback: "friend" }}.

On April 25th, 2020 I hopped on my first ever sales call.

Not as a closer. As a prospect.

It was for Nate Schmidt’s eCom mentorship, “Boss Builder.”

I paced around my childhood bedroom on the call.

When we got to the pitch and he dropped the price… I hesitated.

“Is there any way that I won’t succeed if I do everything in the program?” I asked.

Quite a silly question, as no one has a crystal ball.

But here’s how I’d answer it today, if I could talk to my 19 year old self:

Yes.

It’s entirely possible that you follow every step and don’t get the outcome you want.

There are variables that neither me, you, or Lebron James could possibly foresee.

Also possible, is that you have an easier time than most.

Your first product could be a winner and next thing you know you’re sitting in the frunk of your Huracan in a Chrome Hearts hoodie.

I can’t predict your future.

But what I can tell you is this:

If you follow a proven roadmap that’s worked for others…

You show up every single day, even when you want to quit…

And you don’t get discouraged if things happen slower than you’d like…

Your success becomes inevitable.

I didn’t end up buying that eCom program.

Not because I didn’t believe in it.

But because I didn’t believe in me.

About a year later, I mustered up the conviction to buy an SMMA program.

Fast forward to now and I’m writing this at my desk in my Miami penthouse.

So no, {{ subscriber.first_name | fallback: "friend" }} I can’t promise you that Artisan Lab will make you rich.

You will.

If you’ve got the balls to commit.

If you stop overthinking.

And if you finally decide to bet on yourself.

Not just in your head, but with your actions.

Because the only thing standing between you and the life you want…

Is the version of you that keeps hesitating.

​Let him die here.​

I’ll hand you the same blueprint that changed my life and dozens of others.

​Go here now before the price goes up at midnight.

Ben

subject: You’re not burnt out, you’re just overthinking
content:
It’s rare I open a Google doc and can’t think of a topic to write about within a few minutes.

But today, it’s not working.

It’s been 27 minutes and this is all I got.

Maybe it’s over.

Maybe I’ve told you everything of value I have to say.

Maybe I should sell my car and move back home with my parents.

Or maybe, it’s just a mini, temporary hurdle.

There’s a book called “Don’t Sweat The Small Stuff – and It’s All Small Stuff.”

I haven’t read it but I think I got the gist from the title.

Small problems feel like big ones when you look at them under a microscope.

An issue that would’ve taken 30 minutes to resolve can turn into a month, year, or lifetime.

Let’s say there’s something you’re struggling to complete.

Maybe it’s outreach, content, or in my case, this very email.

Instead of powering through it, you convince yourself it means you’re misaligned.

You create a mental narrative of “this business isn’t for me, I need to do something else.”

The next day, it’s time to do the thing you don’t wanna do again.

That narrative acts as a parasite in your mind.

“This isn’t for me!” it screams, so you don’t do it.

By the following week, you’re completely disengaged and trying to find a new “passion.”

You’ll dress it up with logic and fool most people.

But in reality, all it took was a brief moment of concentrated effort.

You don’t have to reroute your entire career.

You just have to finish your cold brew, grab a zyn, and write the fucking email.

I’ve bailed on businesses and ideas that could’ve been really fruitful.

I’ve gone through the entire story I laid above.

I’ve convinced myself it was “inauthentic” and found data to back it up.

But it was all a lie.

You know when something is actually misaligned.

And you know when you’re convincing yourself of it.

So no, I’m not moving back in with my parents.

I’m just finishing the email.

Because not everything needs to feel inspired.

Sometimes it just needs to be done.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. For those of you who joined Artisan Lab before the price went up – congrats on taking the leap.

For those who didn’t – congrats on not giving in to FOMO.

That said, the price didn’t just go up for fun.

We added another coach (Kabrin), a 4th weekly call, and a deeper level of support than ever before.

It’ll cost you about the price of a steak dinner more.

But if you actually use it, you’ll still feel like you’re robbing me.

​Apply here if you're done hesitating.​

​
​
​

subject: I got punched in the face
content:
I started boxing about a year and half ago.

My original trainer was… a homie.

He was a super funny dude and a really good fighter.

But he wasn’t very technical.

When we first started training, I remember feeling like we skipped the basics.

I barely knew how to throw a punch and he had me learning Mayweather combos.

Even still, I got a lot better.

Well… so I thought.

As I continued working with him, my suspicion in his expertise grew.

But I didn’t have anything to compare him to…

Until I worked out with Rob Oliver and his trainer.

I’d throw a jab, he’d tap me on the cheek so I knew I dropped my right hand.

I’d throw a hook, same thing.

He’d point out when I was off balance – which was quite often.

By the end of the workout, my head was spinning.

Not from getting hit, but from realizing how many things I’d been doing wrong.

Like most things in life, the difference is in the details.

You can get away with being sloppy for a bit.

It’s “no big deal” until one day you drop your guard and get hit with a hook that makes you see God.

It’s “no big deal” until you realize your business is leaking money.

It’s “no big deal” until you end up living a life you never wanted because you weren’t meticulous.

The longer you ignore the details, the shakier your foundation gets.

Everything feels fine, until it doesn’t.

I recently started boxing again with a new trainer.

I’m discarding all of my bad habits and replacing them with a more solid foundation.

And honestly it sucks.

There’s nothing sexy about going slow and fixing your fundamentals.

But I know it’s required if I actually want to improve.

It’s the same in business.

You might be making some money right now.

You might even feel like you’re “pretty good.”

But if your backend systems are messy…

If you’re guessing instead of tracking…

If you’re winging it on client work, outreach, or systems…

Then you’re basically shadowboxing with your eyes closed.

Artisan Lab was built for this exact phase.

I won't teach you hacks or gimmicks.

I'll be in your corner, holding you accountable to the shit that actually matters.

​Join me here.​

Ben

​
​
​
​

subject: AI is gonna steal your girl
content:
Good morning.

It’s raining today so I was forced to split test my routine.

Typically I like to start the day off with a quick walk to Soybucks.

But obviously, I’m not gonna venture out in the rain.

So I clicked a couple buttons, spent $21.46, and 20 minutes later a coffee was at my door.

“Ben why don’t you just make it at ho–”

Shut up.

Anyway,

AI is gonna steal your girl.

Impregnate your mom.

Make you the family pet.

And if you’re lucky, he’ll serve you Chipotle twice a day in a bowl labeled “human.”

Extra chicken if you don’t complain.

That’s not even the scary part.

The scary part is how stupidly simple it is to use this stuff if you actually know how.

Let’s say you wanted to land a client this week.

Here’s what that could look like:

You pop a prompt into ChatGPT – something like “Give me 20 less popular niches where people sell $2k+ coaching or courses and post content regularly.”

Boom, it spits out a list.

Pick one.

Go find someone on Instagram or YouTube who fits the mold.

Take a couple of their posts or scripts.

Drop that content into AI.

Add the right copy prompts (like the ones I give you in here).

And watch what comes out.

Your emails, VSL, and even a sales call framework can be done in 20 minutes.

“But Ben, if it’s so easy, why would they hire me?”

Same reason I didn’t make my own coffee this morning.

Not because I couldn’t.

Because I didn’t want to.

And here’s the cool part…

Most creators don’t even know what levers to pull.

They have traffic, content, and followers…

But no system.

You walk in with a few AI prompts and a baseline level of competence.

And you become the operator.

You’re the missing piece – the guy who turns eyeballs into dollars.

So everyone’s yapping about AI and you might be sick of it…

But the truth is, you don’t need to build some complex AI bot.

You just need to use it to compliment what’s already working.

In a Gold Rush… sell the AI-powered shovels.

Or sit by the door and hope someone tosses you scraps.

Up to you,

Ben

If you’re curious what it actually looks like in action, you can go watch it here.​

It’s not sexy, but it’s the most in depth video I’ve made to date.

subject: What no one tells you about ‘making it’
content:
“This car will be a Porsche 911 and I’ll have the top down, cruising around LA…”

I said to the girl in the passenger seat of my Honda Civic.

She replied “And the girl next to you will probably be way hotter than me.”

I laughed but the voice in my head agreed. She was right.

It was early 2021.

I’d just started my agency and decided I was gonna drop out of college.

All I wanted was freedom..

And a 911…

And a dozen girlfriends…

Aaand to never have to take orders from some skinny-fat fucktard.

Lol.

I’d watched the show Californication a few too many times and I was set.

That was gonna be my life.

About two and half years later, it was – just swap LA for Miami.

I have the top down in my nardo grey 911 Turbo.

The girl in my passenger seat is indeed hotter.

And I’m going on my third consecutive $100k month.

Life is good… at least from the outside.

I hadn’t really thought this far ahead.

Like, what happens when you actually get all the superficial shit that you want?

It’s not quite the life you see on TV.

The scene you don’t see is the existential crisis you have when looking at yourself in the mirror.

You realize the version of life you sold yourself isn’t the utopia you thought it’d be.

You’ve still got problems.

There’s still things you don’t wanna do.

And you’re still you.

Now you gotta figure out what your next goal is – and this time, maybe dig a little deeper.

So I’m not telling you to not go after the more shallow stuff.

Actually, if you take a look at Maslow’s hierarchy of needs, it’s sort of a rite of passage.

Your physiological needs (food, shelter, water) are covered.

Your safety needs are next, then you move on to belongingness and love…

And finally your esteem needs – feeling of accomplishment.

I’d climbed the ladder to this point, but I didn’t account for the top ring.

Self-actualization.

I began asking questions like:

Who am I?

What’s my deeper purpose?

Was I led astray?

I had to climb the superficial ladder to reach a point where I could think on these clearly.

Although it felt like a quarter life crisis…

It was the greatest gift I could give myself.

And it’s something you owe to yourself.

So yeah, chase the car, the girl, and whatever else you fantasize about.

Just know that if you’re lucky enough to catch it, there’s a new game waiting for you on the other side.

A quieter one.

Where the scoreboard isn’t just revenue or the hotness of the girl next to you.

It’s purpose.

It’s waking up and actually liking who you are when no one’s watching.

And funny enough…

That might be the real flex after all.

If that’s the direction you’re trying to head in, I can help you here.​

Ben

subject: Getting rich is boring
content:
Over the weekend, I got lunch with my friend Tim.

Tim runs an 8-figure info business.

Up until recently, he’d been a ghost online.

No content, no personal brand, and no rented Huracan…

Doing $10m+ in annual revenue.

His business was built by giving Zuckerberg a dollar and getting a few bucks back.

As he sat there, with a red Richard Mille on his wrist, it became clear to me why he’s so successful.

This guy knew just about every metric off the top of his head.

Not just the basic show up rate, close rate, etc.

But all the stuff most people wouldn’t even think to track.

The percentage of people who watch until a certain minute in the VSL and how it correlates to lead quality.

Percentages based on days, times, and periods of the calendar year.

He had a crystal clear pulse on everything.

Data, tracking, analytics, all of this shit sounds boring and tedious.

Marketing is fun.

Closing deals is fun.

Crafting a new killer angle that you’re sure will be your ticket to the promised land is fun.

But you won’t know what’s working (and what isn’t) if you don’t track it.

If you’re willing to obsess over things most people overlook…

That’s how you scale predictably with longevity.

And that’s how you’re able to take nearly a full month off to get fucked up at Coachella like Tim did last month lol.

My main point (and reminder to myself) is this:

Data isn't boring when it's making you rich.

Every metric you track provides clarity on the lever that needs to be pulled.

Most throw spaghetti at the wall, find something that sort of works, and then react when it stops working…

But if you’re willing to be a nerd sometimes, you stay proactive.

And you build a better foundation.

This Thursday, Tim’s running a guest call inside of Artisan Lab.​

He’ll be sharing the exact playbook he used to build an 8-figure business in his 20’s.

​Would be a shame if you missed it :)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​

​
​

​

subject: Buy info
content:
This is gonna sound like a pitch but it’s not.

Well, technically it is.

But non-technically, it’s merely an observation of highly successful people.

Alright, you ready?

Good.

You are a fucking idiot if you don’t invest in coaching and courses.

You are dumber than sheep. And sheep are so dumb that they follow each other off cliffs.

I know that’s incredibly convenient for me to say considering I sell coaching (hence the pitch warning).

But I was once one of the idiot sheep.

Now, I can’t name a single rich friend of mine who hasn’t paid for information.

Off the top of my head, here are some of the bigger things I’ve invested in over the past few years:

SMMA coaching: $5k (I spent all the money I had on it)

High ticket sales coaching: $2k

Jeremy Haynes Inner Circle: I’ve been paying him for over 2.5 years. I don’t want to do the math, but it’s close to six figures.

Iman Gadzhi’s 8FL: $18k

1-1 coaching: $10k ++

I’m definitely forgetting a handful of others, but there’s my diploma.

Not once have I felt ripped off, even when I didn’t end up utilizing much of a program.

Because you're not just buying information -- you're bullying yourself into an identity shift.

I don’t know if I would’ve ever ‘made it’ online without doing that.

When you start paying for info, it's scary.

The online cattle love to tell you that all courses are scams.

They comment “nice try Diddy” and “put the fries in the bag.”

Your family members and friends will think you’re involved in a pyramid scheme.

But to the universe – and to yourself…

It’s a declaration of change.

As you type your card info into a Whop checkout page, as some sweaty 19 year old closer prays you don't leave the zoom call…

A part of your soul becomes free.

You’ll feel a rush of anxiety and excitement.

You went against what 95% of people believe to be the norm.

You bet on yourself and spent an uncomfortable amount of money to solidify that commitment.​

Hopefully you didn’t buy some bullshit. Lol.

But even if you did, it’ll make for a good story.

Because now you’re in the arena.

It takes courage to reject the opinion of the masses – the same way it takes courage to build a successful business.

So, that concludes my indirect pitch.

​Buy info, retard friend.​

Talk tm,

Ben

subject: Second-order thinking
content:
“And then what?”

That simple question can be the difference between prosperity and poverty.

It can lead you to potential problems before anyone else finds them.

If you solve those problems, you might get rich.

But most people never think deeply enough to consider second order consequences.

Here’s an example…

First-order consequence:

“This girl is hot. I want to date her.”

Second-order consequence:

“She keyed my car, stole my Rolex and threw a chair off my balcony.”

If you considered the second order consequence from the beginning, you probably wouldn’t have made decision number one.

Make sense?

Cool.

The same principle applies to business, especially with AI.

Hold on now, don't click off yet – I know you’re probably sick of those two letters.

Most agency owners, copywriters, and marketers are thinking…

“Oh this is really cool, AI will do my work for me hurr durr.”

And what’s the reaction to this?

Their clients realize they don’t need them.

Low skill, basic service providers get replaced.

But this doesn’t mean you’re doomed…

Because high level service providers become indispensable.

An online coach (or really any business owner) doesn’t need doers.

They need thinkers who can identify bottlenecks, strategize, and steer the ship…

While leveraging AI to improve efficiency, quality, and everything in between.

In simple terms, this means…

Information gets commoditized.

Everyone will have the same tools.

“I can build your funnel” is not a MOAT.

And differentiation comes through thinking, experience, and context.

People who understand psychology, systems, and nuances will use AI to multiply their impact.

Everyone else will get drowned out.

Pricing power shifts to those who own outcomes, not just provide services.

Imagine you build and manage the entire back-end of a $200k/month info biz.

You track KPIs, manage the team, improve conversions, and build the whole system.

You’re not an expense, you’re a partner.

And that’s why they’ll pay you $40k/mo, instead of $2k/mo.

Meanwhile, the “AI agency, copywriter and arbitrageurs ” are fighting over scraps, praying someone throws them a $1,500 bone.

All the tools are accessible now. The difference is the application and positioning.

If you can tie yourself to revenue, AI becomes your leverage not your replacement.

​Go here if you wanna stay ahead of the curve.​

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: The worst idea of all time
content:
Every morning, I ask myself…

“What am I gonna write about today?”

I wake up, do the usual routine -- brush teeth, shave, make sure business isn’t on fire.

Then I walk to get coffee.

That’s usually when the ideas start spawning.

I observed my thoughts as I went back up the elevator – iced latte in hand.

I’d probably considered ten different potential angles.

“That one’s good, but I can do better.”

“Eh, that’s too similar to what I wrote about yesterday.”

“Nah, that’s too boring.”

As the elevator took me up to the top floor, I picked the idea that you’re now reading about.

You don’t need a great idea.

You need a good enough idea and the balls to go all in.

“Ideas are not worth anything. The ability to execute them is worth millions.” - Felix Dennis

There comes a point where you have to accept “good enough.”

I know this is ironic considering I frequently say good enough will make you miserable.

But in the context of business and creativity, something being “great” is subjective.

You take a good enough idea and make it great.

Not through contemplation but by putting your gloves on and getting in the ring.

You can waste a lifetime trying to pick the best idea.

They’re endless.

They all could work.

And that’s the problem.

I made my first $100k selling leads to basketball trainers.

That was a horrible idea.

But I made it work because I executed.

And it gave me the skills to spot (and sell) much better ideas later on.

Like selling money to money-hungry gurus.

Could I have started there? Sure.

Would I have had the same level of grit and competence to capitalize on it the way I did?

Nope.

So, my friend…

Stop fooling yourself into thinking you need a better idea.

A better business model.

A better mentor.

A better whatever.

Perhaps you’ll find something that aligns almost perfectly down the line.

But you’ll only get there by taking the first imperfect step.

Anyway, here’s a bright idea for ya if you want to make money selling shovels in a Gold Rush.

Later,

Ben

​

​
​

​

subject: Avoid this type of person at all costs
content:
I don’t like poor people.

“Ben, that’s insensiti—“

Shut up.

Being poor is a paradigm, not a financial state.

I know a guy who sold a brand for several million dollars in his early twenties.

That same guy measured his bedroom down to the inch so he could argue his roommates should pay more rent.

No matter how rich he gets, he’ll always be poor.

I stay far away from people like that.

It’s like an infectious disease that I don’t wanna catch.

A friend of mine recently learned this the hard way.

He has a big audience on social media.

Last year, he wanted to launch his first offer, so we hopped on a call.

He was torn between low ticket or high ticket.

I implored him to launch a $5k+ offer for entrepreneurs and high achievers.

He didn’t listen.

Instead, he went with a $30/month discord.

The launch flopped.

Less than 50 people joined and many were constantly complaining.

He shut down the group and refunded everyone within a week.

Not long after, he launched a high ticket offer.

He made nearly 100x the money and attracted quality customers who are loving the community.

This is why I don’t sell a low ticket offer.

Artisan Lab was built for winners.

My members move fast and execute.

They understand that success is reserved for those who fully commit.

And that’s why we produce results like this:

Marcus closed a $3k + 15% deal with a big influencer.

Rocco got his third client in two weeks (he's 15 lol).

And Jayden got a new client at a 25% rev share, just one week after joining AL.

If you’re serious about building a real business and you understand that’ll require consistent hard work…

​This is for you.​

We’re not for everyone.

But if you’re ready to stop playing small and actually commit, the results speak for themselves.

​Apply here.​

Ben

​

subject: $250k months from ONE client
content:
It’s 9:47am on a Monday.

I have one sip left in my iced latte.

And Chat GPT just made this image for me:

You may have seen this concept before…

The emotional cycle of change.

Almost five years ago, I sat in my college dorm room watching a Jason Capital video.

As he articulated this concept, it matched up perfectly with my endeavours over the previous year.

Everything I tried, I failed.

Well… I’d quit and start something new before I could really fail.

But as I learned about the five stages of change, I finally felt understood.

I thought I was broken…

It felt like this whole online business thing worked for everyone but me.

And only now, did I learn that what I experienced was normal.

1. Uninformed optimism

“This new business is gonna print and I’ll be in a red LaFerrari with a baddie in the passenger seat in no time.”

2. Informed pessimism

“Uhhhh why is no one replying to my outreach messages? I thought this was gonna be easy.

3. Valley of despair

“Maybe I’m not cut out for this… Or maybe I just need to try a different business model. Yes, that’s it! I’m gonna be an AI Fighter Jet pilot.”

4. Informed optimism

“Nah, I’m gonna stick this out. I know it’ll be difficult but I can do it.”

5. Success and fulfillment

“Hello, MTV welcome to my Penthouse.”

If you’re in stage three right now, here are my words of encouragement.

Over the weekend, I recorded this interview with Artisan Lab member, Brady.

He’s made $250,000 from one client… in the past 30 days.

Yes, you read that right.

After we did the interview, he told me that he almost quit a year ago.

He was grinding but making no money -- and fell deep into the valley of despair.

Around that time, I made a Youtube video about the emotional cycle of change.

He said that video convinced him to keep pushing…

Fast forward just one year, and he’s hitting six figure months.

If you’re stuck in the trenches, this might be the push you need -- watch Brady’s full story here.​

Ben

P.S. This is the original video I made last year that helped him.

​
​
​

​

subject: How to escape the outbound trenches
content:
Doing outbound sucks.

It’s arguably the worst part of starting a service based business.

You sit there typing, pitching, and praying someone will reply with words other than “fuck off.”

Finally you get some replies, go back and forth, and get ghosted.

Maybe you get a call scheduled… only for it to get rescheduled for next week (which is code for “fuck off").

But if you do it the right way, this period doesn’t last forever.

It’s a temporary phase that you look back on and laugh about.

Over time, it becomes easier to get clients – assuming you even want more after you get one or two good ones.

However most people never get out of the “I hate my life, outbound is so difficult, no one replies to me” phase.

And that’s simply because they’re doing it wrong.

Instead of turning this email into an outbound masterclass, I’ll give you one piece of advice that’ll be just as effective:

If you do what everyone else does and expect a different result, you are either stupid, lazy, or you don’t actually want to make money.

Maybe a combination of all three.

Personally, I get hundreds of pitches a week.

I skim through all of them.

99% are copy and pasted.

They get ignored.

In the rare event I get a pitch that’s real and considerate – like a Loom showing how my YouTube funnel could double call bookings by fixing the drop-off at minute 3…

I’ll actually take a look.

But that only happens when it’s clear they did their homework and found a real gap.

When people say “send personalized messages,” that doesn’t mean offer some random, retarded compliment like…

“Hey Ben, I saw you played basketball in high school! Anyway, do you want a clipping army that’ll make you an extra $7.56 a month!”

Fuck off.

Stop being an idiot.

Stop the spray and pray approach.

And stop offering irrelevant compliments.

Be normal, creative, and lead with a solution to their potential problems.

There’s your stupid little masterclass.

​Join Artisan Lab if you don’t want to spam strangers in DMs forever like a monkey with an iPhone.

Ben

​

​

​
​

​

subject: Two truths and a lie (sales edition)
content:
Let’s play a game.

I’m gonna tell you three statements you’ve probably heard on the internet.

Two of them are true, one is a lie.

Ready?

1. High ticket sales is a great way to stack cash.

2. Good sales people are in high demand.

3. If you get into sales, you can make your own hours and work from the beach.

Could you spot the lie?

Many sales guys have joined Artisan Lab in the past few months.

I hear the same story time and time again.

Someone gets started in sales.

They find a good offer to close for.

They spend all day on zoom persuading prospects into pulling out their credit card.

Maybe they get to $10k, $20k, or in rare cases, even $30k+ monthly.

But eventually, they hit a ceiling.

Their income stagnates.

Every day becomes the same.

They begin to hate it.

They got into online business because they wanted freedom…

But they've worked themselves into a high paying job with no leverage and no upside.

Now they're stuck asking themselves:

“What’s next?”

Now this isn’t a bad spot to be in.

But there’s a smarter play if you really want freedom and leverage.

Instead of spending your days on Zoom, hoping you don’t see another +91 on your calendar…

What if you owned the system itself?

This is the logical next step if you're capped in sales.

You already know how to close.

You already understand buyer psychology.

Now you just need to control more of the process and get a bigger piece of the pie.

With an info agency, you help the same entrepreneurs you're closing for by:

Scripting VSLs.

Building funnels.

Writing emails.

Optimizing backend systems.

And thanks to AI, learning these skills has literally never been easier.

You can go from one-trick pony to a capable operator in weeks.

Then use your existing sales skills to close a client or two…

And welcome to the side of the game where the real money (and freedom) is made.

If you're ready to stop chasing commission checks...

​Here where you can build something that actually scales.​

Ben

​
​
​
​
​

​

subject: Why staying poor is unethical
content:
I ran into my rich friend Josh at the coffee shop this morning.

He’s this southern guy in his mid-thirties who sold a manufacturing company a few years ago.

He’s been retired since.

I sat with him and chatted for a bit.

“You can only sip so many margaritas on the beach, buy a few supercars, and stack the watch collection… until it gets boring,” he said.

He wasn’t complaining, just being honest.

He’d spent the past few years floating around Europe with nothing to do and unlimited money.

And now, he’s restless.

He wants to build again.

The game continues…

Even when you win, you still have to figure out who you are.

Money buys freedom.

But it doesn’t tell you what to do with it.

Real life starts after you “make it.”

Success removes your excuses.

And suddenly you’re forced to confront the question you’ve been avoiding:

“What do I actually want?”

Unless you’re a monk or some kind of hippy, you have to buy the right to have this sort of internal clarity.

One of my mentors once told me, “making money is such a waste of time… but you have to do it.”

At first I didn’t get it.

But now I do.

Because until you make money, you’re not really thinking clearly.

You’re just reacting.

Money (or the lack of it) makes all of your decisions.

But once you’ve made it and the noise quiets down…

That’s when the real questions start to surface.

What do I actually care about?

What do I want to spend my time on?

What kind of life do I want to wake up and live every day?

You don’t get honest answers to those questions when you’re broke.

Maybe chasing money is a waste of time.

But avoiding it guarantees you’ll be lost forever.

It’s your duty to get rich.

Not just for the lifestyle, or the validation, or the Patek.

But because it’s the only way to earn the clarity required to live on your own terms.

You can’t build a life you love if you’re stuck in survival mode.

So go get the money.​

Buy the clarity.

And then decide what really matters.

Ben

​

​

​
​
​

subject: Why all roads lead to info
content:
My business model isn’t for everyone.

It’s easier to make endless content and try to go viral as a Tik Tok Shop affiliate.

It’s easier to learn sales and sit on zoom all day.

It’s easier to sell products on Amazon.

So if you’re a complete beginner and when you hear the word “funnel” you think of beer…

Building an info agency probably isn’t for you right now.

And that’s okay – go try one of the three businesses above and come back to me later.

But let’s zoom out.

Who’s actually profiting the most in each of these?

I know plenty of TTS affiliates who’ve made good money.

But the people who make the most in that niche are the ones selling info on it.

I know plenty of closers who make $10-$50k/month.

But the people who get past that, sell info on it.

And I know guys who’ve scaled their Amazon business to six figures a month (at 10% margins)...

But the people who profit six figures a month… sell info.

Interesting.

Over the past year, I’ve helped eight people hit $100k+ in monthly profit.

Not from selling info themselves, but by partnering with people who sell info.

And personally, I made my first $2m doing this.

Now I’m not gonna sit here and tell you it’s the easiest business model on Earth.

Truthfully, if you have zero experience and don’t understand the difference between copywriting and copyright…

You will struggle.

But if you’ve been through the online business gauntlet…

And you now want something that’s more predictable, scalable, and doesn’t require you to do outreach all day…

​This is the best model for you.

It’s made Jace $200k in a month from one client.

It makes Danny $150k/mo from one client (and bought him his dream car).

Phillip hit $87k/mo three months after transitioning out of sales and $100k/mo 30 days later.

And Brady made $250k in 27 days… from one client.

If you want to be on the side of the game where the real money is made...

​Join us here.​

Ben
