subject: The bag is right in front of you, {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "bro" }}
content:
Getting rich is easy, actually.

Find a problem, create a solution, and sell.

Sounds braindead simple to me.

The hard part is deprogramming old habits and standards to replace them with new ones.

For some, this seems to happen fast.

For others, it can be a few months or a couple years.

And for most, it never really happens, and they stay miserable.

Don’t do that.

One of the most prevalent paradigm shifts you have to make is the ability to identify and seize opportunities.

Most people don’t think critically enough to do this.

They think,”hurr durr dis not working right now, maybe i do something else.”

A few years ago, my inner dialogue sounded something like the above.

I ran a marketing agency for basketball trainers and just couldn’t seem to scale.

No matter what I tried, nothing worked.

But then I spotted a better lane.

I applied my skill set to digital products instead of local businesses…

I got a couple big clients…

And even though I felt like I was in way over my head, I worked like a dog.

I took every chance to prove myself.

I did more than what was asked.

And said yes to things I didn’t know how to do.

That season of being overworked and underpaid is what set me up for everything I have now.

A few months ago, my top sales guy on one of my offers was in the same spot.

It was a newer offer and he wasn’t making a ton of money at first.

Despite this, he went above and beyond to help the business grow.

Not only did he do his job well, but he also spent hours building systems, creating tracking sheets, and making course content.

No one asked him to do any of this, but his income grew as a result.

Now, he’s working for one of the most famous marketers in the world.

And unsurprisingly, he's now their top sales guy.

Had he not maximized a lesser opportunity, he wouldn't have been competent enough to get that role.

But he did. And now, he will quite literally be set up for life.

Ask yourself what you would’ve done in that position.

You’re underpaid.

Your income doesn’t reflect your skill set.

And no one is asking you to take any initiative.

Would you go above and beyond?

Or would you get complacent?

The answer to that question determines the rest of your life.

There’s no secret.

​Just a moment where you decide to act like the person you want to become.

No pressure,

Ben

P.S. “Opportunities are all around you, you’re just too fucking retarded to spot them.” - Socrates

​
​

​

​

​

subject: Get off the rollercoaster
content:
“My confidence isn’t a rollercoaster,” my high school basketball teammate said.

I’d asked him how he stays consistent when shots aren’t falling.

That simple answer is a big reason why he became the all time leading scorer at our school.

He was the type of athlete that would just win.

No matter what was going on, how big the moment was, or even how he was playing up until that point…

There was this ever-present stillness in his demeanor.

Every game he’d show up, do what’s needed, and go home.

Completely emotionless.

And although he wasn’t exceptionally athletic or way more skilled than everyone else…

He did the basics a whole lot better.

Almost a decade after that conversation, I’ve watched this same principle make a lot of people rich.

Those who win in business aren’t the ones constantly jumping from one thing to the next.

They’re the quiet, consistent killers who execute the basics day after day.

And their confidence isn’t tied to immediate results.

If you can wake up each morning, do what’s needed, and move forward…

Maintain consistency, even when you hit setbacks or your outreach is met with silence.

You will win.

Because business, like sports – is often a war of attrition.

Consistency wins.

Show up and do the simple things repeatedly.

Even when it’s boring, difficult, and when no one is watching.

And the next time your confidence feels like it’s on a rollercoaster, remember this:

You are being tested by the universe.

Will {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "you" }} execute relentlessly, despite that fact that you’re not getting the result you want?

Or will you be like the masses and quit or jump to a different shiny object?

The answer to that question will determine everything about your future.

Someone has to put the fries in the bag.

​Don’t let that person be you.​

Ben

​
​
​

​
​

subject: The difference between $10k & $100k/month
content:
I have good news and bad news.

The bad news:

If you want to get rich, you have to get lucky.

The good news:

You can rig luck in your favor.

Consistent hard work plus a decent skill set will ensure some success.

Even if you have a room temperature IQ, you can brute force your way to low six-figs a year.

But beyond that?

You need leverage.

I’ve had calls with two new Artisan Lab members recently where this stood out to me.

One of them is a sales guy.

He’s closing on one of the best offers you can be on in the info space.

Making good money, but spending 8+ hours a day on zoom.

The other guy is running a content agency.

He’s got almost 10 clients on monthly retainers and is crushing it for them.

His systems are incredibly detailed and he has a decent sized team.

Both are hard-working, smart, and have the talent they need to get to six-figure months.

But they don’t have much leverage.

They’re making commissions or flat fees and getting paid for effort, instead of outcomes.

That’s the cap.

Those who break through to $100k/month aren’t necessarily better.

They’re just riding a better vehicle -- a business model that multiplies their output.

That’s what changed everything for me.

I went from $15k/month with my SMMA to $120k/month within a year.

Not because I learned new skills.

Not because I worked harder.

Because I switched vehicles.

If you want to be “lucky,” this is how you do it.​

Ben

P.S. I just made a new video about how you can use AI to write banger VSLs and emails in seconds. Watch it here.​

​
​
​
​
​

​

subject: Tell better stories
content:
“What story or analogy can I use to articulate this idea?”

That’s the question I ask myself at the beginning of every piece of copy I write.

Coming up with the idea is the easy part.

Wrapping It up into a 400 word hero's-journey is the trickier part.

The best marketers on the planet are just really good storytellers.

I was first exposed to this subconsciously.

Right before I dropped out of college, I was watching Jason Capital videos religiously.

I’d sit at the desk in my bedroom of the frat house.

I had this white and black gaming chair and notebook in front of me.

I’d take pages of notes and even started using flashcards to memorize marketing and psychology principles.

Off the top of my head, I can’t remember a single concept I wrote down.

But what I can remember is the story…

He quits college basketball, gets into online marketing, pays Craig Ballantyne who writes down a business plan on a napkin…

Then starts making $20k/mo in his dorm room…

Leaves college, lives at the Ritz Carlton, blah blah, blah.

Similarly, I’ve watched a good amount of Hormozi content and can’t recite many of his lessons.

But I vividly remember the beginning of $100M Offers.

Four years ago, I opened that big ass purple book.

It was the second month after I dropped out of college, as I sat in this knit chair on the balcony of my villa in Tulum, Mexico.

He starts by telling the story of how a business partner stole all his money.

At his girlfriend's parents' house, he told her what happened and said he wouldn’t blame her if she left him.

She replied, “I’d sleep under a bridge with you.”

I remember all of that off the dome.

And I promise I’m not a weirdo, that's just how our brains are wired.

We remember stories.

The better stories you tell, the better marketer you will be.

If you’ve been reading my newsletter or watching my content for a while, what do you remember?

Probably not much.

But hopefully a few stories if I did my job well.

So next time you’re at an impasse, thinking about taking a leap…

Maybe just do it for the plot.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben
​
​
​

​
​

subject: You’re early
content:
Have you ever watched someone do something so well that it sort of made you want to quit?

They perform at a level that seems inconceivable to reach.

It makes you feel like you’re lightyears behind…

And you should pack it up and do something else with your life.

Sometimes that signal is accurate.

The game is rigged in their favor and they have a natural ability that you don’t.

The first time I ever watched an NBA player workout, I realized I wasn’t going to the NBA.

But most of the time -- especially in a business setting…

The people who seem to be on another level are normal.

They’re absent of advantages… other than hundreds or thousands of reps and split tests.

Data is the difference.

And life is basically an ad campaign.

When you set up a campaign on Meta, its AI has a general understanding of who you’re targeting based on what you say in the ad.

As you start spending money, it gets more data.

That data indicates “yes, this is the type of prospect we are looking for…”

Or “no, this person is homeless and addicted to fent, he probably can’t invest $25k into a DFY AI Arbitrage Agency.”

Meta’s machine learning adapts and stops looking for unqualified drug addicts.

The more money you spend, the more data it gets, and the faster it knows exactly who to target.

Think of yourself like an AI machine.

You can master anything if you input enough data.

Speaking, dating, business, copy, sales, boxing… the list goes on.

Your rate of improvement is dependent on the amount of reps you get in the allotted time.

If you send 100 outbound messages in a week…

You test different styles and approaches…

You listen to the data and adapt…

You will basically be a different person than you were 7 days prior.

Extrapolate this to anything in life -- and work towards mastery.

And when you feel behind…

Don’t quit the game.

Just double the spend -- figuratively or literally.

More reps, more data, more progress.

Because most of the time, the people ahead of you aren’t superhuman, they’re just further into the campaign.

With enough inputs, your results will catch up.

Just don’t close your laptop before you learn how to deter homeless people from booking a call on your sales team's calendar.

​Start your campaign here.​

Ben

​
​

​

subject: How Chrome Hearts ruined online coaching
content:
Good morning, happy Monday.

Let’s talk about the “trust recession.”

You’ve probably heard marketers throw this term around recently.

Consumers are more skeptical than ever and there’s data to back it up.

In hindsight, it seems obvious as to why.

Remember the “automation” phase a few years ago?

People started slinging “DFY passive income streams” for multi-five figures a pop.

Imagine you’re a depressed middle aged man named Jerry.

You live paycheck to paycheck in Gary, Indiana with your 248lb wife.

On a random Tuesday night, you’re scrolling through Instagram.

You see a 30-second ad from a tattooed man, draped in Chrome Hearts standing in front of a Huracan.

He says “we’ll build you an Amazon store and guarantee $15k/mo in 90 days!”

You’re hooked.

You get on a sales call with some 19-year-old kid who convinces you to take out a loan.

After spending $40k that you don’t have, 90 days later you’ve made nothing and can’t get a hold of the automation company.

No shit there’s a trust recession!

Thousands of people, like our friend Jerry, are now in generational debt.

Rightfully so, events like this have given online coaching a bad rap.

But I still believe it’s one of the most ethical and impactful businesses…

*If you do it the right way* (most don’t).

When there’s something you want to master, having a coach makes it infinitely easier.

Someone taught you how to drive.

Someone taught you how to play an instrument.

Someone taught you how to shoot a jump shot.

You could’ve figured all of these things out on your own, but that’d be illogical.

It would take you exponentially longer, and you know that.

So, you take a shortcut – you get help from someone who’s done what you’re trying to do.

Making money is no different.

Over the past year I’ve invested close to six figures to learn from people like Jeremy Haynes, William Brown, Taylor Allan and Iman Gadzhi.

Could I learn everything they’ve taught me through Youtube plus trial and error?

Maybe.

But why would I take the longer road, when an express lane is available?

That’s what idiots do. And I don’t consider myself an idiot.

So {{ subscriber.first_name }}, I’m imploring you to get coaching.

Whether it’s from me or someone else, I’m pitching you for your sake.

​Go here and buy this.​

Or go somewhere else and buy something else (preferably not from someone wearing Chrome).

Just don’t end up like Jerry.

And don’t buy anything with automation in the title.

Alright bye,

Ben

​
​
​
​

subject: The most pretentious email you'll read today
content:
I have a flight to New York in a few hours and I still need to pack.

This is unfortunate, because I hate packing.

Even more unfortunate, is that I’m flying commercial!

It’s Phillips' birthday tomorrow so we’re celebrating in NYC and then heading to the Hamptons for the 4th of July.

Danny, who you may recognize from my Youtube, is coming along as well.

At first I was fine with flying commercial.

It’s not thaaaat bad…

But I texted my jet guy last minute for the hell of it.

He found a solid deal that would get us from Opa Locka to Teterboro airport for under $20k.

I’m not one to pass up a half decent deal.

So I texted Phillip and Danny to see if they’d be down to split it…

And they said no.

Phillip spent his last dollar on another pair of Chrome jeans and Danny just bought a Patek.

You’d think when you rescue people from poverty and help them make $100k/mo+ they’d be a bit more eager to split a jet right?

I guess not.

But it’s crazy to me that all three of us run info agencies.

Danny has one great client who he’s helped scale to multi-seven figures and personally nets six-figures a month from his rev share.

Phillip got off sales calls five months ago, and hit his first $100k month last month, with just three clients.

This is a business model I randomly stumbled into three years ago.

It worked for me, but I thought I was the anomaly.

I had a decent network and a vast skill set.

Because of this, I never imagined this model would work for others the way it has for me.

So even though Phillip and Danny are being frugal today, it’s cool to see.

But maybe they’re anomalies too…

Maybe we all just got lucky and the stars aligned for us.

Just like they did for Elijah, who made $25k+ from one rev share client last month:

Or Alo, who made $34k from one client...

Or Khesraw who had record months with two clients and will make over $15k from his rev share.

We all got lucky.

We're all anomalies.

Or maybe we just stopped overcomplicating things and picked the right vehicle.​

Alright, I gotta go pack.

See you on Delta,

Ben

​

​

​

subject: I lied again!
content:
I lied to you.

In yesterday’s email I told you I was about to fly to New York with my friends Phillip and Danny.

30 minutes later, our flight got delayed from 3pm to 8pm.

Delays always scare me because there never seems to be just one.

First it’s 8pm, then 10pm, and then somehow you’re leaving at 1am and going to Kazakhstan instead of JFK.

I did not want to end up in Kazakhstan.

So after a dozen phone calls, a lot of convincing, and a five figure wire…

Our new flight now takes off in an hour and 45 minutes.

And instead of Delta, well…

It’s a jet.

“Wow bro you’re so cool! Stupid ass guru.”

Thank you.

Anyway, I gotta finish packing and don’t have any lessons for you today…

(Other than don’t stay in school and say maybe to drugs.)

But I don’t want to leave you empty handed so here’s a video I made recently about how business gets easier over time.

If you’re in the trenches right now…

And you’re reading this email from some pretentious asshole bragging about flying private…

Just know, it gets easier.

You’re in the part that sucks.

It's a training camp that everyone has to go through.

You’re earning stripes every day that you show up and blindly throw spaghetti at the wall.

Even though you might have nothing to show for it and feel like you’re spinning in circles…

There will come a time where things click.

I can’t tell you when, how, or why.

But if you just stick it out for long enough, eventually the universe will decide:

{{ subscriber.first_name | default: "You’re" }}'s ready now.

You won’t be flying commercial forever.

See you at Opa-Locka Airport,

Ben

P.S. If you read this one and want to chat about anything, hit reply. I’ve got three hours to kill on this flight.

​

​

​

subject: Spent all my money & now I'm sad :(
content:
I had a quarter-life crisis yesterday.

As I sat in 2A on my flight home from the Hamptons, I got this pit in my stomach.

Not because I was on a commercial flight.

And not because my friends and I spent an accountant's annual salary over the past four days.

Let me rewind a bit…

We flew to New York on a jet (I know, I know – I’ve rinsed this story. Last time I mention it lol).

We stayed at the St. Regis – one of the nicest hotels in the city.

We celebrated my friend Phillip’s birthday at a restaurant you typically have to reserve a year in advance.

The next day, we were driven to Montauk, where we stayed in a beautiful AirBNB right on the beach.

Over the following two nights, we spent five figures at the club.

And on our last night, we went to the biggest, most exclusive party in the Hamptons.

Phillip was on stage next to Livvy Dunne and Bobby Shmurda (lol) and I said cancelable things on Sneako’s stream.

If you told me this was my life four years ago, I’d be over the moon.

But on the flight home, I felt numb.

“What the fuck is wrong with me?” I thought.

I just went on this amazing trip.

And everything in my life is objectively great right now.

I’ve hit a new record in my business each of the past three months.

I’ve helped people make their first dollar online – and others hit their first six figure month.

I have my dream car, an incredible circle of friends, and a close relationship with my family.

But it all just feels… normal.

What the fuck.

I thought every day would be blissful.

I thought everything would feel perfect.

I thought my only problem would be choosing between the blonde or brunette.

But I was wrong.

That’s not how life works.

As you reach new levels, your standards rise.

The jet is just a flight.

The supercar is just a car.

The penthouse is just an apartment.

And you…

Are still you.

It feels incredible to earn a lifestyle you dreamt of.

But probably not as incredible as the Utopia you created in your head.

This is not a “sell your things and live like a monk” email.

Nor is it a cry for help.

Just a reminder that even as you start to get the things you want…

The best part of your day will likely be something simple.

A peaceful walk.

A conversation with a friend.

Or a morning coffee and email to your list.

Life is amazing, don’t forget to appreciate it.

​And keep getting richer just so you can know for sure that it won’t fix everything :)

Alright, glad to be back.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. If you liked this one, reply and let me know <3

​
​

​

​

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "Yo" }}, you got cheated on
content:
“What’s the best business model to start that’ll get me to $10k/mo in 90 days?”

I spent six months Googling that question every day.

Because of that, it took me about two years longer than it should’ve.

Instead of locking in to build one thing, my eyes always wandered to the badder bitch.

Social media is like the playboy mansion for business models, so there were plenty.

This is a common mishap.

Nearly everyone goes through a phase where they’re in a situationship with eight different businesses.

Somehow you convince yourself that they’re all mid or not “wifey material.”

So you refuse to commit to any one of them and proclaim every business is a whore!

The other day, I met an uber driver with possibly the worst case of shiny object syndrome I’d ever seen.

First he told me about his dropshipping business where he sold Donald Trump t-shirts.

Then his “tinder for injury lawyers.”

Then his contracting business.

Then his AI only fans agency.

Then he showed me a demo account where he allegedly turned $1k into $10m.

Oh, and then he asked me for $100k so he could do it with real money.

I politely declined.

The thing is, this guy actually seemed pretty intelligent.

He showed me the websites he built for each business and they were clean.

His ideas were thorough and it’s clear he was doing his research…

Too much research.

You can convince yourself any business is better than what you’re doing.

They all look sexy from afar.

But one day, you’ll wake up next to it and see it without makeup.

And only then will you realize it’s been using Facetune and AI filters.

You’ll find the shortcut once you stop looking for it.

You commit.

You ignore the temptation.

And you build with speed and enough patience.

Just don’t wife a hoe, pick the right model.​

Ben

​

​

subject: The only "manifestation strategy" that works
content:
“I manifested this shit!”

Says the black-hat MRR scammer turned grifter who’s financing a Huracan on a balloon loan.

He'll default on his payment and make a story post saying…

“God gives his toughest battles to his strongest soldiers.”

No retard, you just have a 27% chargeback rate because you sell air for $8k.

Not long ago, I began to hate “manifestation” because I associated it with those guys.

And then I remembered how I got here.

During my last year in college (before I dropped out) I entered my “spiritual entrepreneur” phase.

I had sticky notes with affirmations scattered around my room.

“Money flows to me easily.”

“I am not chopped.”

“I make $10k/month effortlessly.”

There were incense sticks next to my bed and a vision board on my Notion homepage.

Although, there was still a little voice in my head saying:

“This is gay.”

But I kept doing it.

Because everyone I followed said that’s how success happens.

I was confused why selling leads to basketball trainers required me to become one with the Universe.

Years later when the goals actually started coming true, I realized manifestation is just a rebranded version of planning.

It only looks magical from the outside.

Because when you set a specific target, train your brain to see it constantly, and take relentless action toward it…

Things start to work out.

It’s not some mythical awakening but rather the compound interest of commitment.

So here’s the “law of attraction” in simple terms:

1. Set precise goals.

“Land one client on a 20% rev share, get them to $100k/mo.”

2. Reverse engineer it.

How many outbound messages do I need to send daily to get a client?

3. Execute.

Actually do it.

There’s your spiritual alignment manifestation guru guide – no crystals required.

Just set a goal, make a plan, and do the work.

If you want to manifest $20k/month without becoming a hippy, join me here.​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. I just dropped a new YouTube video on how AI is doing 90% of my client work. Check it out here.​

subject: I got scammed for $5k and filed a dispute
content:
I filed my first ever dispute yesterday.

After 24 years on this beautiful Earth, I finally had to do it.

Here’s what happened:

On our way to the Hamptons, we had a driver take us from NYC to Montauk.

He showed up on time and his car was clean…

But the second I got in his black suburban, I regretted it.

This fucker smelled like he’d just eaten a bowl of curry and ran a marathon to 7/11, where he then bought a bag of beef jerky.

My shirt was over my nose and I had the window open for the majority of the ride.

It was still torture – I wouldn’t even wish such a thing on George (my enemy from previous emails if you remember that dork).

That said, at least he got us there safely.

I didn’t chargeback on the guy just because he smelled like a math convention.

But that ride left a bad smell in my nose.

So on the way back, I decided we’d take a helicopter to NYC and then catch our flight at JFK.

It was about 10x the price but 1/5th of the time and had a lower likelihood of a smelly driver.

Worth every penny in my humble opinion.

On the morning of our flight, I got an email from the helicopter company.

It said if we had any luggage over 25 lbs, we’d have to schedule a car service.

The only way to do so was to call them.

First of all, why was I not prompted to do this until 3 hours before we’re scheduled to leave?

Whatever.

I give them a call, the guy tells me the bags might not arrive on time, so he’d have to check and call me back.

We go back and forth for the next hour as he gives me a dozen different answers.

Basically it’d be $500 to send the luggage to the airport for us and he was unsure if it would arrive on time for our flight.

Finally, I’m fed up so I told him to cancel it and I booked a driver.

“I’m sorry sir, your flight is non-refundable.”

I end up talking to his supervisor, go back and forth, they won’t budge, and basically tell me to get fucked.

So we didn’t take the $5,000 helicopter and now it’s in Amex’s hands.

It felt kind of cool clicking the dispute charge button.

Now I understand what it’s like to be poor.

If I win, it’s a free $5k, if I lose, I’ll have forgotten about it by the time they make a decision.

I guess there’s no lesson in here for you today, I just wanted to tell you that I’m now a proud member of the dispute club.

Later,

Ben

P.S. Artisan Lab’s 1 year anniversary is coming up in 2 days.

I asked our members to leave a quick review and wanted to share this one from Jack:

“48 hours into Artisan Lab hands down one of if not the best purchases in my life. I know I’m glazing rn but honestly wtf it’s gone to a point of over delivering. It’s not just info, it’s every single skill it takes to make money online in one package.”

If only the helicopter company over delivered half as much as we do inside Artisan Lab…

​Join us here.​

​

subject: Do you actually want to make more money?
content:
“You’re making a measly $100k/month and you’re comfortable!” he told me.

Over the weekend, I went to Jeremy Haynes’ Mastermind.

You may have seen him on YouTube yelling about hitting million dollar months.

For two and a half years now, I’ve been in his Inner Circle program.

I’ve been to countless of his quarterly in-person events and he never disappoints.

Jeremy is a very intense person.

He gets hypnotized every year to “get richer.”

I thought that was bullshit until I saw how disgusted he is with stagnation.

My friend Mason told me Jeremy almost made him cry on a 1-1 call recently.

Mason is a 26 year old making $5m+ per year.

If you’re settling, Jeremy will call you out on it.

Three months ago at the last Mastermind, he did just that.

I’m walking around, making small talk and enjoying the food.

Jeremy comes up and a few of us start talking.

Then he looks me dead in the eyes and says…

“Are you still doing pussy numbers?”

Uh oh.

He’s known to do this thing where he’ll just berate you if he thinks you need it.

And in this moment, I realize I might be today's target. Gulp.

“Uhh ye… yeah I’m working man” I respond.

Wrong answer.

You can’t do that with him.

If you try to virtue signal, he sees that as a personal attack in his “get richer" culture.

For the next 5-10 minutes, this guy just goes in on me (pause).

“You’ve been making the same amount of money for two fucking years!”

I honestly don’t remember much else of what he said because I think my brain categorized this as a traumatic event.

But I know it was all out of love.

Or maybe disgust.

Afterwards, he messaged me and said:

“Send me the reasons you’d want the revenue to grow. You’re sold on current reasons to stay where you’re at for perspective to reflect on.”

I started thinking.

“What would I actually do with 3x the money?” I considered.

I made a list.

The first things on there were superficial lifestyle upgrades.

Second were long term investing goals.

And third were more personal desires.

I sent them to Jeremy and he replied, “If you don’t see a lift in productivity and revenue, you’ll know you don’t care about these things listed.”

Over the following three months, I’ve kept this list top of mind.

My income has grown, I’ve seized new opportunities, and have felt more in control.

So {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "friend" }}, I encourage you to ask yourself the same question…

Why do you want to make more money?

Get crystal clear on this and write down a list.

These reasons should provoke emotion when you think about them.

And next time you don’t feel like doing something you know you should, take a look at that list.

There’s the advice I had to get yelled at for.

If you want more lessons from me that I learned the hard way…

​Join me here.​

Happy Money Monday,

Ben

subject: The 3 phase path to six-figure months
content:
One of my first clients texted me the other day.

It reminded me just how far things have come…

He said: “Hey brother, hope you are great. Just sending a message your way to say how cool it is seeing you grow. You’re crushing it.”

This was from Mike, a basketball shooting coach who I worked with a few years ago.

He was one of my first few info clients.

I built a low ticket ascension funnel for him in March, 2022 and ran ads for a handful of months after that.

That was a pivotal era in my journey.

I’d begun dropping my local business clients and replacing them with info guys.

At the start of that year, I had 14 local clients and somehow only made $10k in January.

By June, I had five info clients and made $16k.

Three of my clients were the top personal brands in online basketball training.

Another was a YouTuber with over 500k subs who I used to be a fan of.

And the last was one of my best friends at the time, selling a high ticket sales coaching offer.

This was phase one of my info business.

I’ll refer to it as the “freelancer model.”

I hadn't really tapped into rev shares yet, but I was charging higher prices.

I’d offer anything copy related – emails, ads, funnels, and VSL’s.

By October 2022, I got to $28k/mo this way.

But two months later, I found an even better model and entered phase two…

The “partner model.”

This is where I went all in on rev shares.

Because of that, my biggest client in December 2022 paid me $12,900.

In total, I made $31k that month with just six clients.

Check out what happened next:

This new partner model got me as high as $124k profit in one month by the end of 2023.

I’d have 5-8 clients at a time, who I’d typically become friends with.

Using this model, I’d make between $80k-$120k/mo for the following 12 months.

Since then, I’ve entered phase 3 which I’ll call the “owner model.”

Although I still have a few partner clients – I’ve built my own offer in Artisan Lab and have majority share in a couple other offers.

This seems to be a common progression.

You start off by offering anything you can – prove that you can be trusted to not run away after someone gives you money.

Once you do that, you gain confidence in your skillset and start getting a piece of the pie.

You now have a handful of clients on 10-30% rev shares.

This alone can get you to $100k/mo+ as it has for me and many members in AL.

I’m not saying this is the only path.

But if you’re trying to escape the client hamster wheel and build something meaningful…

This is the one I’d bet on.

  • Start by doing great work for cheap
  • Build real skill and trust
  • Shift into higher-paying, higher-leverage partnerships
  • Eventually own the assets yourself

Three years ago, I was charging as low as $1k/mo to write emails for clients.

Now I’ve had clients happily send $50k wires.

If you don’t wanna wait three years to figure this out the hard way…

​Join me here.​

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: Play fast, but not in a hurry
content:
Money flows to those who deserve it.

If you’re not making as much as you want, it’s NOT because you’re missing a strategy.

A better business model isn’t the solution.

A new outreach script won’t save you.

And whatever excuse you’re coming up with is pure cope.

I shouldn’t be telling you this.

Instead I should tell you that if you’re not making the money you want, it’s not your fault…

You just need a better system.

You’ve been lied to by the gurus, school system, society, blah blah blah.

To be fair – maybe 10% of the people reading this are actually in a bad vehicle and need to switch.

But for the other 90%, I’ll hold your hand when I say this…

You. Are. The. Problem.

I’m sorry to burst your bubble, but the reason your life sucks is not because of the people who run Hollywood.

It’s because you have a skill deficiency.

No replies to outreach? Skill issue.

No views on your content? Skill issue.

Women run away from you? Skill issue.

I know I’m being harsh here and I empathize with you if you’re in the trenches right now.

But when you take full ownership and fix your skill gap…

You’ll notice something strange start to happen – because skill isn’t the only variable.

There’s an invisible element that amplifies or blocks your results.

It’s your energy and your intention.

People can just feel it.

Let’s use outreach as an example.

I’ve seen people come into Artisan Lab and get clients in their first week.

Others seem to struggle for months.

The interesting part is they’re using the same outreach strategies.

Why does Person A send 10 outbound messages and get 3 clients when Person B sends 30 and gets 0 replies?

Intention.

People can tell whether you’re moving from confidence or desperation.

When you’re desperate, they can smell it through the screen.

You try to rush the process…

You get angry when people don’t reply.

You get bitter when you see others win.

I had a basketball coach who’d always say “play fast, but not in a hurry.”

When you hurry, you get sloppy.

You forget about the details.

You try to run too fast and trip over your feet.

Business is no different.

Desperation makes the Universe say… “nah, you’re not ready yet.”

Move with speed. But don’t rush.

Your time is coming, you just have to stop scaring the money Gods.

If you're ready, I can help you here.​

Ben

​
​
​

subject: Exclusive invitation for {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "you" }}
content:
On October 16th, 2022 I got a $5,000 payment that changed my life.

Not because of the money, but what happened after.

I had this client who was paying me $2k-$3k/mo for emails and funnel copy.

After working together for a few months, I started to consider how else I could help the business grow.

That’s when I stumbled upon this book called One To Many.

It’s written by a guy named Jason Fladlien – many refer to him as the “Webinar Goat” (like Bonnie Blue but for virtual events).

Here’s what I learned:

Why sell to only one person at a time, when you can run a live event and sell to many people?

Good point, Jason.

So I followed his framework, added in my own sauce and sold my client on running a webinar.

I spent a few days putting everything together.

We promoted it through organic content for a week.

And we ended up with around 2,000 registrants by the time of the webby.

It's Thursday night, 7pm EST.

Close to a thousand people show up.

The training goes well.

But then, we get to the end.

This is the part where we say…

“Hey, hope you enjoyed all the free game we just gave you. If you want more coaching, here’s an offer.”

We pitch… and nobody buys.

I’m thinking, “did Jason Fladlien lie to me? Does this shit not actually work?”

And then I see a few messages in the chat.

“It won’t let me buy.”

“It says purchase invalid.”

I test a payment myself. It doesn’t work.

After sending a threat to Russel Brunson and his family, I replace our Clickfunnels link with a direct checkout Stripe link.

The money starts coming in.

$5k…$10k…$20k…$40k.

It just spawned out of thin air.

That’s when I knew I stumbled into something special.

We started running weekly webinars.

I pulled the strings on the backend, and my client put on a show each week.

Although I only had a 10% rev share, I made $12,900 from that one client in December 2022.

That’s when it clicked.

Why would I try to get a bunch of clients, when I can focus on scaling with a few?

Since then, I’ve built webinar funnels that generated up to $600k in a week and got me paid handsomely from my rev share.

Not because I’m special…

But because I found a system that works.

This Wednesday (July 23) at 7pm EST, I’ll be showing you that system…

On a free live webinar :)

​How To Make $20,000+/Month From ONE Client Using AI Operating.​

If you want to escape retainers and start earning rev share by printing money for personal brands…

Sign up here: https://go.benbader.com/register​

Ben

subject: Dr. GPT diagnosed me with a serious condition...
content:
Today is one of those days.

I’ve been looking at this screen for 20 minutes.

I typed a few words five minutes ago, but deleted them.

Since I don’t have anything to talk about yet, I’ll remind you to sign up for my free live webinar if you haven’t already.

Now back to our regularly scheduled programming…

I’m four days Zyn free.

I kept seeing people online talk about how much better their life has gotten since they quit.

So I considered it a sign from the Universe…

Or maybe it’s just the Chinese social media algorithm fooling me into being less powerful.

But I figured what the hell, I’ll try it out.

I’ve been a semi-regular user of these little nicotine pouches for about two years.

I’d typically take 3-5 a day, which is light compared to most Zyners.

So I assumed quitting would be easy.

I was wrong.

Over the last few days, I’ve been irritable, sluggish, and weirdly indifferent to everything.

At first, I thought it was just a temporary lull.

But then I asked my doctor (Chat GPT) about common nicotine withdrawal symptoms.

And Dr. GPT told me I’m experiencing them.

So here I am, struggling through this email, zynless.

I’ve got no punchline for you today.

The only reason I’m continuing this little experiment is because of data.

Allegedly, symptoms peak in the first 3-5 days.

Then, after a month or so, your dopamine starts to recalibrate and you return to “normal” – but better.

I wanna see if that’s true.

I also want to see if I can still write a decent email when I’m brain-fogged and mildly homicidal.

Anyway, I’ll leave you with this:

Most people quit hard things right before it starts to get easier.

Sometimes you just need a little faith in the data.

See you on the webinar.​

Zynlessly yours,

Ben

​

​
​

​

​

subject: Stop picturing your dream life
content:
Happy Monday, let’s make some money this week.

We’re only 2 days away from this (and it should help you do the above).

See you there.

Anyway, we’re gonna try an exercise today.

Yes, you and I are gonna exercise in this email.

Let’s begin:

Everyone tells you to picture your dream life.

Imagine…

You wake up in Bali.

You’re surrounded by nature.

The random chick you brought home last night didn’t steal your Rolex.

And you’re working a few hours a day from your laptop.

What a life.

This type of visualization is sexy.

And it works – to an extent.

But sometimes, you need the opposite motivation.

Instead of chasing pleasure, let's run away from pain.

Imagine it doesn’t work out.

You never actually put your all into it.

You blame the gurus, your Mom, and big pharma.

You try to convince yourself that the “normal” life isn’t that bad.

And to be fair, it’s not.

A Corolla will still get you from point A to point B.

You’ll pretend to be in love with the girl you felt pressured to marry because you were getting older.

And every day will be predictable.

Clock in, clock out. Get a beer after work.

Roll your eyes when you see young people on social media driving supercars.

Tell yourself, “They aren’t happy! They’re victims of materialism and capitalism.”

Maybe you’re right, maybe you’re coping. Doesn’t really matter.

At the end of the day, this isn’t a bad life.

But if you’re wired like me, you know it would drive you insane.

The question “what if” would always linger.

You’ll avoid looking at yourself in the mirror because you don’t want to face it.

You knew you wanted more, but you got really good at pretending you didn’t.

And even if on the outside it doesn’t look that bad…

You’ll be miserable knowing you settled.

Is that the life you want?

I doubt it.

I know that wasn’t as fun as visualizing a supercar and supermodel.

But sometimes you need a harder push.

If you want to give yourself a shot at the other life (the one you actually want)...

I’ll see you Wednesday at 7pm EST.​

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: I work at McDonalds.
content:
Quick one for you today.

I'm looking out the window at a McDonald's down the street from me.

Chat GPT told me that the average franchise owner makes between $150k-$460k in annual profit per location.

Maybe putting fries in the bag actually does work?

I recently hit the 1 year mark with a client.

Over the past 13 months, he's paid me $245k.

And today I realized I'm basically a McDonald's franchise owner.

Here's how the franchise model works...

McDonald's (obviously) has the brand, systems, and shitty burgers.

The franchise owner comes in with capital and ops skills.

He leverages the McDonald's brand and executes their proven system locally.

And based on his cut, he keeps 6-15% of gross sales at the end of each year.

The franchise owner didn't have to build anything from zero.

He just used a proven system and ran it properly.

Which is exactly what I do with my clients…

They have the audience, I install the systems.

​Tomorrow at 7pm EST, I’ll show you how to put the fires in the bag (basically).

This is the exact model I’ve used to make hundreds of thousands from a single client - without using my own audience, running a big team, or becoming a virgin agency owner.

​Sign up here if you’re not already.

And I’ll see you tomorrow.

Extra fries please,

Ben

So if you’re not already registered, I’ll leave the link here one more time for ya:

Ben
